title: Restrictions on transfer of funds
description:
The circular (N° 31/MF/DGD/SP/D01/10 of 5 January 2010) by Algerian customs effectively delays and/or blocks a total amount exceeding 206 million euro due to shipowners.
In short the problems relates to:
- A shipping line is a commercial entity expecting due payment for the services rendered, as well as compensation for use of its equipment (containers).
- While much of the cargo shipments will be paid at the port of loading, some Algerian importers demand freight payable upon receipt at destination, for commercial or regulatory reasons. Normally one should expect importers, having ordered goods from abroad under letters of credit, to take delivery of the goods soon after arrival, i.e. in a matter of few days or weeks.
- In practice, however, we observe that many importers delay taking receipt of their cargoes, quite some even many months after arrival. This means that the shipping line has to wait for payment and containers remain blocked for other use in shipping.
- It sets restrictions in the repatriation of freights by the shipping lines. Any income from freight due to the shipping lines and received by the line’s agent from importers later than 90 days after arrival of the vessel may not be transferred outside Algeria.
- Algeria does not allow operators which share vessels in order to ensure more frequent calls and higher quality to open disbursement accounts (system of slot chartering).
- very cumbersome and time consuming control system of customs for the final disbursement account are in place, thus costly for all concerned and delaying legitimate transfers.

At the end of 2015, as a result of pressure from the EU, rules were changed for the future (notably by allowing operators to open supplementary disbrusement accounts for payments received beyond the 90 day-deadline). The Algerian authorities, however, modified the logistical rules charging the costs related to the management of empty containers on shipowners: in the past, as can be seen from the bill of lading conditions, the cost of empty container operations, including reloading, was paid by Algerian receivers.

title: Restrictive measures introduced in the automotive sector
description:
The Budget Law 2014 as well as subsequent regulations introduced the following restrictive measures applicable to the automotive industry:

- a tax exoneration only for locally produced new vehicles;

- an obligation for the car dealers to start an industrial, semi-industrial or "any other activity related to the automotive sector" by 1st January 2017;

- an obligation for car dealers to import a specific quota of vehicles equipped for using LPG (liquefied petroleum gas) and LNG (liquefied natural gas).

- Measures on car dealership and mandatory safety standards for imported vehicles were introduced between February and July 2015 (Executive decree n° 15-54 of 7 February 2015, ministerial decision of 23 March 2015, ministerial decision of 12 May 2015, and ministerial decision of 23 July 2015). These regulations also confirm the requirement already contained in the Budget Law 2014, that car dealers carry out an activity of industrial or semi-industrial nature on top of the dealership (subject to a period of grace of three years, expired on 1.1.2017). The measures also required additional, mandatory safety equipment for all imported cars (it remains unclear whether similar requirements are applied to domestically manufactured vehicles). 

Algeria implemented a new legislation on car imports in 2023. The new legislation allows car imports, but which certain conditions.

title: Requirements on foreign direct investment and difficulties related to financial transfers
description:
Restrictions to foreign direct investment were firstly introduced under the 2009 complementary Budget Law  ("LFC 2009") on 26 July 2009 and subsequently extended in scope under the 2014 Budget Law. 

These measures, which had the effect of deterring foreign direct investment, included the following provisions:

- generalised limitations on foreign ownership: minimum Algerian shareholding of 51 % for all sectors;

- any foreign investment exceeding 5 billion DZD must be approved by the National Investment Council;

- foreign investors must maintain a positive foreign-currency account for the whole duration of the investment and must secure the finance to cover project costs from local sources;

In the discussions leading to the Budget Law for 2019/2020, some declarations of the Governement suggest that the rule may be amended so that its scope would be limited to strategic sectors (as the EU has been advocating in its discussions with Algeria).

Algeira adopted new Investment Law No 22-18 on 24 July 2022 replacing the prior 2016 investment law. The implementing regulations have been published in the Official Journal of 18 September 2022. 

The amendments eliminated the 51/49 rule for all investments except those on certain strategic sectors namely: defence industries, pharmaceuticals (with the exception of FDI in innovative products), all means of transports, mining, extraction and transport via pipeline of oil and gas, as well as imports and resale of goods.

title: VAT Regulation
description:
The ‘Communication au grand public relative aux principals mesures fiscales de la loi de finance pour 2018’ imposed as of 1st January 2018 revoked the exoneration from Value Added Taxation (VAT) for services provided by shipping vessels and relating to their cargo. These services are now subject to a VAT rate of 19 percent.


European shipping companies are heavily affected by this VAT obligation. In contrast to Algerian companies, they, not being Algerian residents, are not in the possibility to recover the VAT. As a consequence this VAT obligation makes operations in Algeria almost one fifth more expensive for non Algerian companies, including European ones. The imposition of VAT on services rendered to vessels and cargo goes against international practice in the shipping sector. Moreover, Algerian shipping companies are – as any shipping company - subject to a zero VAT rate in the Member States of the European Union, according to European law and national legislation implementing the European legal rules (Directive 2006/112/EC). By consequence and following the adoption of the above mentioned Communication, the principle of reciprocity is not respected anymore today.

title: Re-registration of companies
description:
This barrier is related to two measures by the Algerian government:

First measure: in March 2021 Algeria published a decree (No. 21-94 https://www.commerce.gov.dz/reglementation/decret-executif-n-deg-21-94-du-9-mars-2021-jo-n-deg-20-du-17-mars-2021) obliging companies importing and selling consumer and other goods to re-register in the companies’ registry on the basis of a new nomenclature that divides the importing activities in several narrow subcategories. The new rules require that the company should register in only one of the sub-categories of the new nomenclature.
The deadline was fixed to 31/12/2021. However, by a note from the Ministry of Finance to the Association of Algerian banks in August 2021, operators were invited to accelerate the re-registration process and make all necessary changes by 31/10/2021, or otherwise they would not be allowed to obtain bank authorisations to pay for the imported goods. In addition, by a note from the Ministry of Trade of 01/09/2021, companies importing cosmetics and like goods are obliged to immediately renew their import authorisations and re-register their activities as above, or otherwise they will not be authorised to import such goods.

Second measure: the rules in the 2021 Budget Law imposed a 49%-cap on foreign ownership on newly established corporations engaged in the importation of goods. All importing companies need to renew their registrations but the foreign-owned importing companies would be subject to greater burden and obligations than the local national ones, as the former would become subject to the 49-51% ownership rule. This rule stipulates that, for companies active in the importation sector, foreigners may only hold a maximum of 49% the company’s equity.

title: Ban on imports of finished and semi-finished marble products
description:
A presidential directive has been adopted in Algeria introducing a ban on the importation of marble and ceramic products, in their final form . The ban entered into force on 15 January 2024 and the Secretary General of the Ministry of Trade and Export Promotion has instructed bank directors to no longer to accept domiciliation requests related to imports of these products.

The ban has the biggest impact on exports of HS 6907 (ceramic flags and paving, hearth or wall tiles) exported to Algeria mainly by Spain and to a lesser extend, Italy.

title: Restrictions to maritime auxiliary services providers (Exec. Decree 20-348)
description:
On 3 December 2020, Algeria published an executive decree (20-348) revising the conditions to practice auxiliary activities supporting maritime transport, such as brokerage, freight forwarding or ship agency services. One of the conditions to provide such services is to have Algerian nationality. In the case of legal entities (i.e. companies), the manager and partners (or associates and shareholders) have to be of Algerian nationality.

According to the decree, the measures apply to any company willing to enter the Algerian market. For companies already established, they only have to comply with these new rules iftheir shareholders or partners’ composition is altered.

The Decree was published on 3 December 2020.

title: Restrictions to foreign bidders in public tenders
description:
Article 23 of the Presidential Decree 10-236, 7th October 2010 establishes a 25% preference margin in all public contracts for Algerian products and companies completely owned by Algerians (100% Algerian capital).

For those companies with less than 100% of Algerian capital, that 25% preference margin is prorated according to the percentage of Algerian capital in the country. Before that, the preference margin was 15%. Furthermore, there was no requirement for a majority of Algerian capital for Algerian companies, and it only applied to international tenders.

The article penalizes foreign companies that already existed in Algeria, even for national tenders. The same decree, modified on February 2013, establishes that the foreign bidder must invest in the same activity sector via the creation of a company mainly owned by Algerian partners.  The Regulation does not establish amounts or percentages in the contract, as it only refers to an up to 20% penalty if this requirement is breached, and it does not specify any period of time to materialize the investment.

The obligation to invest refers to any public contract, even goods supply, and does not exempt foreign companies that had previously invested in the country. Meanwhile, no investment is required for local bidders.

title: Restrictions on dry ports in the port of Algiers
description:
• Date and reference of the domestic legal act imposing the contested measure:

New circular, amending Note n°1818/DGD/SP/D012/2017 of 7 November 2017 and imposed as of 20th May 2018.

  •  Factual description of the measure:

Algerian Custom authorities will choose, on a random basis, the dryports where ships are directed to discharge goods in the port of Algiers.

European shipping companies are heavily affected by this new provision. The circular is causing them serious operational, legal and financial issues.

Operational issues:

The criterion being used to allocate goods in dry ports (the availability of storage space) appears inadequate. In the absence of an efficient common system linking Algerian customs to Off-Dock Container Yards (ODCYs), it seems technically challenging to obtain reliable real-time information. Besides, the truck capacity deployed to handle the cargo from the port centre to the imposed ODCY is unknown.

Moreover, the imposed ODCY may not be equipped to receive certain cargo (hazardous, reefer, LCL containers). Under these conditions, shipping companies may be forced to delay the delivery of such goods.

Additionally, the tracking of cargo between the port of unloading and the imposed ODCY will be made difficult. To-date, it remains unclear how recipients will be informed of the final location of their cargo. This last minute-allocation induces delays, additional and unnecessary costs.

These measures are hampering operations and worsening the congestion in the port of Algiers where the circular applies, besides being detrimental to the Algerian customers and European exporters. Some of them have already refused to load until the situation is back to normal.

Legal issues:

The absence of a legal and contractual framework between the shipping companies and ODCYs is problematic. For instance, the circular does not specify who is legally responsible for transporting cargo from the port of unloading to the dry port, nor does it address the issue of liability in case of an accident during the journey.

In addition, the existing agreements between receiver customers and the dry port managers (regarding for example “free time” that has to do with storage in dry port) will no longer apply. This will cause legal uncertainty and confusion.

Furthermore, the circular is posing concerns in terms of competition law, by unduly favouring national dry ports, to the detriment of privately foreign-owned facilities. European shipping companies feel that this discriminatory treatment is unjustified.

title: Non-acceptance of preferential origin statement
description:
Algerian customs authorities are not accepting preferential origin declarations on the delivery notes and insist on the EUR.1 certificate despite the fact that, for authorised exporters, the requirement to stamp and sign the origin declarations is not be necessary, according to the provisions of the EU-Algeria Association Agreement. Furthermore, EUR.1 certificates are not required from any exporter provided that the total value of originating products in the consignment does not exceed € 6 000.

The fact that Algerian Customs offices do not respect their legal obligations and continue insisting on the use of EUR.1 creates an additional cost and time delay for the EU exporters. 

The Commission raised the issue with the Algerian government authorities via the EU-delegation in Algiers in March 2023 but received no formal answer to its query .

title: New importing  authorisation requirements
description:
By two notes dated 24/4/2022 and 17/5/2022, the Algerian Association Professionnelle des Banques et Etablissements Financiers (ABEF1 ) instructed commercial banks to require additional documentation as part of the file authorising payment for imported goods. The main requirement is to obtain and present a certificate to be issued by ALGEX (the Algerian Agency for Export Promotion) attesting that the product intended to be imported is not produced locally. This constitutes a sine qua non condition for any Algerian bank (that are solely authorised to finance imports) to accept the application for and conduct such payment transactions. The issuance of certificates by ALGEX relies on a database (https://www.commerce.gov.dz/cartographie) listing 418.000 products. Those produced locally will be normally excluded from importation.

Moreover, by an Executive Decree dated 25 May 2022, the Prime Minister introduced new regulatory provisions concerning the validity duration of import licenses for each import operation (1 year), which were until now automatically issued. To be noted that the import license is also part of the required documentation for Algerian banks to authorise payments for imported goods. The ministerial divisions concerned – depending on the specific trade activity –, are required to seek the prior approval of the Minister of Trade before issuing the licence. The Minister of Trade is required to give its opinion within a maximum of ten days, but there is no information on the process or timelines followed afterwards by the ministerial divisions.

The scheme is similar to a non-automatic import license.

title: Pharmaceuticals and medical devices: import restrictions, intellectual property rights protection
description:
Algeria imposes since 1 January 2009 a ban on imports of drugs and medical devices which are also produced locally. As a result, import is prohibited for a list of around 300 drugs and medical devices. Besides, the possibility to transfer production and invest locally is hampered by lengthy administrative delays and pervasive red tape. Since 2009, foreign investors are obliged to enter into partnership with a majority Algerian shareholder(49/51), with the exception of investments in the production of innovative medicines for which the 49/51 rule does not apply (change introduced with the financial law of 2020). Regarding IPR, while Algeria is a Party to the Patent Cooperation Treaty (but not to the Patent Law Treaty), it appears that patents originating abroad are not properly protected against local copies and data submitted for a market authorisation are not properly protected.

As of September 2019, the situation is unchanged.

title: Impose of an Andean risk analysis to animal and animal products imported to PE, CO and EC
description:
Peru (PE) has introduced an additional administrative layer for evaluating the risk of animals and animal products from IT. This involves performing a risk assessment by the Andean Community Risk assessor. Peru decided to request this Community risk assetment to evaluate the EU regionlisation for African Swine Fever in Italy. 

The Free Trade Agreement (FTA) is between the European Union (EU) and each of the three Andean countries: Colombia (COL), Ecuador (ECU), and Peru (PER). The FTA does not involve the Andean Community (CAN) as an intermediary.

Italian products can still be exported to Colombia (CO) and Ecuador (EC), but not to Peru (PE).The risk analysis process could set a precedent in the region and If the outcome is negative, it may lead to market closures in Ecuador (EC) and Colombia (CO).

title: Non-automatic licensing regime
description:
Angola has been pursuing since 2018 the Programme to Support Production, Export Diversification and Import Substitution (Programa de Apoio à Produção, à Diversificação das Exportações e Substituição de Importações – PRODESI). Initial Presidential Decree 169/18 establishing the Programme was then complemented by a Presidential Decree 23/19, which established quantitative import restrictions for a number of products from 2022 onwards (contingent upon compliance with WTO rules), and introduced import licensing requirements.

On 14 January 2019, Angola published Presidential Decree 23/19 in its official journal. One core element of the Decree was a set of quantitative restrictions and import licensing requirements on a list of 54 products, mainly agricultural products for day-to-day consumption, such as rice, beans, potatoes or pork. The objective was to ensure food security, develop the domestic industry and diversify the economy.

The Angolan legislative decree 23/19 on “national production, export diversification and import substitution” establishes a requirement for companies established in Angola to obtain an import license if they wish to import into Angola any of 54 products listed in the decree. The decree stipulates that the granting of an import license is in particular conditioned on previous efforts to procure the concerned products locally or on other efforts to support domestic production. In addition, the Decree foresees quantitative restrictions for certain products.

You can find the original decree here.

Presidential Decree 23/19 was revoked by Presidential Decree 213/23 in order to address concerns expressed by Angola’s trading partners. However, the new Decree proposes measures which introduce non-automatic licences based on domestic purchase requirements. Decree 213/23 is still under consultations - not entered into force yet.

Article 4 of the new Presidential Decree 213/23 contains a quantitative restriction in the sense of Article XI:1 GATT which apparently does not qualify for any exceptions and is therefore arguably at odds with the GATT/WTO rules.

On the assumption that the non-automatic licensing regime instituted by Article 7 is conditional upon the fulfilment of the requirement set out in Article 4 (i.e. no availability of like domestic products), this licensing regime is arguably as well in breach of Article XI:1 GATT, in addition to an apparent infringement of Article 1.2 of the WTO Import Licensing Agreement.

title: Lengthy processing of market access applications - Plants and products of plant origin
description:
EU Member States have submitted many market access applications to export to Argentina plants and plant products. Despite the ongoing approval of such applications, there are still many pending applications several years after the submition of teh applications.    

The import requirements of Argentina can be found at https://www.gistnet.com/cidb-sample/ar.importproduct.html.

title: Import certification scheme of ceramic tiles
description:
Under Regulation 910/2021 of the Secretary of Internal Trade, a quality certification of ceramic tiles is required from January 2024 onwards for both the manufacture and the import into the country of ceramic tiles classified under HS codes 6907.21.00, 6907.22.00 and 6907.23.00.

According to the said Regulation, ceramic tiles introduced into the Argentinian market must comply with the technical and labelling requirements established its Annex I, which in turn are based on the technical standard Norma IRAM-ISO 13006:2021 adopted by the Argentinian Institute for Standardisation and Certification (IRAM). This requirement obliges both domestic manufacturers and importers to conduct a third-party conformity assessment on their ceramic tiles, including a laboratory test, before placing the products on the market.

This measure constitutes an unnecessary obstacle to trade because European manufacturers are already producing their products under a globally accepted and self-certification international standard (ISO 13006/UNE 14411) which does not require a third-party conformity assessment. Moreover, for the time being, this conformity assessment can only be done by recognised Argentinian Certification Bodies (INTI and IRAM), which places a significant economic and administrative burden on foreign companies that wish to enter the Argentinian market.

Update 15/03/2024: the entry into force of the measure has been postponed. The Secretary of Commerce published on 15/03/2024 an amendment to the technical regulation in the official journal which postpones the entry into force of the requirements on certification until 28 July 2024 https://www.boletinoficial.gob.ar/detalleAviso/primera/304860/20240318

title: Import ban of pork meat and products on African swine fever grounds
description:
On 11 September 2020, the competent authority of ​Argentina (SENASA) announced – following the 10.09.2020 notification from Germany to the OIE of an outbreak of ASF – the closure of the Argentina market to imports of pork meat and sub-products from Germany due to ASF; no legislation was mentioned (https://www.argentina.gob.ar/noticias/argentina-cierra-la-importacion-de-carne-de-cerdo-de-alemania-por-foco-de-peste-porcina).   

Worryingly, in the same communication SENASA also informed that, similarly, "it is considering whether it will close its market to the rest of the European countries until they inform Argentina of the risk mitigating measures established regarding this n​otification, and the reinforcement and adaptation of surveillance actions, in accordance with the international recommendations of the OIE". In the past, Argentina had questioned the European system based on passive surveillance of dead or slaughtered animals, but did not ban imports from any of the Member States that are free from ASF (after receiving answers to questions proivide but those Member States).

According to Argentina, it applies the regionalization principle of the WTO and World Organization for Animal Health. However, as Argentina insistes that the EU legislation does not entirely conform with the OIE Code, in practice Argentina does not allow imports of pork and pork products from Member States where ASF has been found but regionalization.

After the many technical exchanges between the European Commission and Argentina to try to understand at which extent the information provided by the EU legislation and regionalisation decisions address Argentina’s needs and which information Argentina requires from the Commission and Member States, Argentina's position remians unchanged (which prevents imports of pork from CSF and ASF free zones from countries where these diseases have been reported).

title: Export duties
description:
Until 2015 export duties were horizontally applied on exports of all goods. Between December 2015 and 2016, the previous government eliminated them for most products. However, export duties remained in place for soy, biodiesel, raw hides and skins, cork, paper for recycling, ferrous waste and scrap, some mineral fuels and oils and works of art.

In September 2018, in the midst of a financial crisis and due to increased fiscal needs, a horizontal export duty of 12% was reinstated until end 2020 (Decree 793/2018). This rate was applied in addition to the already applicable export duties, but was subject to different kind of caps to the overall export duty to be paid (expressed in AR$ per exported US dollar).

With Degree 39/2019 of 14 December 2019, the new government introduced important amendments to Decree 793/2018. It maintained the previously established additional horizontal export duty of 12%, but eliminated in general the cap to the overall export duty to be paid. This had the consequence that for certain products export duties reached 17 to 22% (certain hides and skins, cork), 27% (biodiesel), or even 30% (soy). Certain caps however remained, and a reduced export tax of 9% applied for specifically listed products.

The law on social solidarity of 23 December 2019 (Law No. 27,541) authorized the President of Argentina to increase further those export duties, for soy to up to 33%.

With Decree 230/2020 of 4 March 2020, the President made use of this authority, hereby however applying as regards soy a staggered approach that imposes an export duty between 20% and 33%, depending on the exported amount per year. The full 33% export duty, for example, only applies to big producers exporting more than 1000 tons of soy per year. As regards other products, export duties were in some cases increased and in other 25 cases decreased, with the apparent intention to protect smaller producers and to consider regional needs at provincial level. Also export duties on services were reduced from 12% to 5%.

Decree 549/2020 of 24 June 2020 suspended export duties on raw hides and skins for 60 days, in an attempt to rescue the sector in view of collapsing exports and prices in the wake of the coronavirus crisis.

To alleviate the effects of the Coronavirus crisis for SMEs, Resolution 4728/2020 of 01 June 2020 allowed SMEs to extend due payments for export duties for 60 days until end of July. Resolution 4787/2020 of 05 August 2020 extended this period for further 60 days until end of September 2020. Beneficiaries of this exceptional measure were more than 25.000 Argentine SMEs.

Decree 785/2020 of 2 October 2020 reduced by 4 percentage points (to 8%) the export duties applicable to certain minerals including cobblestone, marble, and granite, among others, until 31 December 2021.

Decree 789/2020 of 5 October 2020 reduced the export duties applicable to certain final industrial goods and inputs. The decree (i) fixed a 0% export duty on final industrial goods included in Annex I; (ii) fixed an average export duty of 3% on industrial inputs included in Annex I; (iii) reduced to 0% the duties charged on exports of automobiles (including tractors, buses, trucks and cars) insofar as those operations are destined to non-Mercosur countries and they exceed the total exported between October 2019 and October 2020; and (iv) increased the rates of the export refunds applicable on inputs and final industrial goods to 5% or 7%, depending on the product.

Decree 793/2020 of 5 October 2020 reduced the export duties applicable to biodiesel and different soy products, including soybeans, soy oil, pellets, and soy flour, among others, in a staged process, starting with a reduction by 5 percentage points, which is over the following months cut down. As of 1 of January 2021, the export duties applicable to these goods will be 2 percentage points lower than those in force prior to the issuance of Decree No. 790/2020, except for soybeans (which will be subject to the same export duty as before the issuance of the Decree) and biodiesel (with a reduction of only 1 percentage point).

Decree 1060/2020 of 30 December 2020 modified the export duties for nearly 4400 products, representing 43% of the covered products, in an effort to stimulate industrial production and protect agricultural producers in the provinces. As regards industrial goods, it continues the policy launched by decree 789/2020 of 5 October 2020 and applies a scheme of 0 % export duties for another 362 finalized industrial goods, 3% export duties for another 1092 advanced industrial inputs, and 4.5% export duties for around 4000 primary or basic industrial inputs. Additionally, it eliminates export duties for a wide range of agricultural goods from the provinces.   

Decree 150/2021 of 8 March 2021 modified Decree 789/2020 of 5 October 2020 insofar that it maintained the level of export duties for cars at 4.5% but introduced for 2021 an export duty exemption for incremental exports, meaning car exports that surpass the export levels of 2020. The measure aims at providing vital support for the important, but ailing local automotive sector. The measure, originally in force until the end of 2021, was extended until the end of 2022.

Decree 410/2021 of 25 June 2021 exempted from export duties around 70 agroindustrial products, which are produced in provincial areas; The government explained that it had identified the potential of regional economies for growth in investments, production and exportation.

Decree 852/2021 of 14 December 2021 established that the export duty rate is set at zero for products that have the status of ecological, biological or organic, duly certified and authorized by the competent body. At the same time, it reduced the export duty rate for wheat, soybeans and corn that have organic certification by five percent.

Decree 131/2022 of 18 March 2022 increased export duties by 2 percentage points to 33% on a temporary basis for soybean oil and soybean meal until 31 December 2022. The decree also increased export duties on biodiesel (by one percentage point to 30%) and other feedstuff preparations made of soybean meal. The measure reinstated the export duty levels that had been in force between March and October 2020 (decree 230/2020).

title: Preference for national goods in public procurement
description:
All government levels in Argentina (nation, provinces and municipalities) have the power to establish preferences to the public procurement of goods and services of national, provincial or municipal origin. In addition, public companies or decentralized entities may have their own public procurement regimes.

At national level, Law 27,437 of 2018 established a new “Buy Argentina” ("Compre Argentino") regime. The Law adopted by the Congress in April 2018 and published in May 2018 contains various discriminatory provisions in favor of national companies, goods or services.

Main provisions:

  • The law establishes that public entities shall grant a preference for companies offering local goods in their purchases, when the difference with imported goods is equal to or less than of 15% for Micro, Small and Medium Enterprises (MSMEs) and 8% for other companies. Such preference is mandatory above a relatively low threshold (in May 2018, equivalent to approximately €63,000).
  • The above-described preferences of 15% and 8% can be reduced to 5% for the acquisition of goods of high technological scientific content (except for SMEs during the three first years from the enforcement of the Law).
  • The law foresees a mechanism to provide incentives, in case of competition among goods that do not have a national origin, to those goods that contain the highest percentage of local content: offers without national origin have a preference margin of 1% every 5 percentage points of national content in the gross production value of the goods, up to a maximum preference of 8%.
  • In addition to the above, the Law also includes specific preferences for national MSMEs. MSMEs offering goods of national origin in binding processes will have the possibility of improving their offers when their price has not exceeded more than 20% the best price in the process. In case of contracts of up to ARS 1.3 million in goods or ARS 100 million in works in housing and public buildings, the national administration shall award their contracts to local MSMEs that offer goods or works of national origin.
  • The Law applies at central level but also contains a mechanism aimed at encouraging Provinces to adhere to the Law: there is an additional preference of 1% for goods produced in Provinces adhering to the Law, within three years of its entry into force.

Most Provinces and some Municipalities have also established preference regimes that favour local bidders. The thresholds depend on each jurisdiction, although have been normally set around 5% (however, they may start revising them in line with the new national “Buy Argentina” Law). Bidders are considered local if they offer goods produced in the concerned jurisdiction’s territory or if they have legal domicile in that jurisdiction for a determined time. Local bids are favoured in the sense that they will succeed even though they are higher than competing non-local bids.

National content requirement for renewable energies: In December 2006 the government enacted Law 26190, modified by Law 27191 in September 2015, which established the so-called “National Promotion Regime for the Use of Renewable Energy Sources”. It is applied by the Secretariat of Energy. The Law establishes different benefits, including some fiscal incentives and financial support mechanisms. Among these tools, a preference in the selection of offers in public procurement and a discount in the maintenance cost of the World Bank guarantee.

Background

The barrier has been in place in different forms for a long time, except in the period between 1991 and 2001.

A first "Buy Argentine" legislation was applicable until its suspension in 1991. In 2001, the Economic Emergency Law No. 23697 reintroduced a preference in favour of domestic industry for the procurement and contracting of goods, works and services by public entities, with a maximum of 10% domestic preference in the case of goods. This provision was subsequently repealed by Law No. 25551 “Buy Argentine Labour” (“Compre Trabajo Argentino”), which established preferences for goods of domestic origin of 7% (for SMEs) or 5% (for other enterprises).

In addition, since 2012 all companies with exporting activities, irrespective of their SME status, were also given a preference margin of 7%. Different preferences for local suppliers were introduced in the tenders for renewable energy launched by the Ministry of Energy (current Secretariat of Energy) since 2016.

The new, above described Law Nº 27,437 on “Buy Argentina and Development of Suppliers” was published in May 2018 and entered into effect three months later. Its implementing Decree Nº 800/2018 was adopted in September 2018.

title: National Content Requirements for Car Parts and Cars
description:
Law 27,263 of 2016 established the “Regime of Development and Strengthening of Argentine Autopartism” (RDFAA) which includes different local content requirements (LCRs).

Under this regime, car and auto-part manufacturers in Argentina obtain a tax benefit as a result of using a specific percentage of Minimum National Content (MNC) in the production of specific types of cars and auto-parts. The MNC varies between 10% and 30%, depending on the vehicle or auto-part produced.

The tax benefits consist of a digital tax credit bond that can be used for the payment of national taxes. The value of the tax bonus ranges from 4% to 15% of the ex–factory value of the parts of national origin used in the production of the vehicles and auto parts listed in the Law. If both the development of local providers and the expert of the concerned products of national origin in significant volumes can be proven, it is possible to request an increase of up to 5 percentage points on the national content in order to reach the MCN.

Beneficiaries may request in advance up to 15% of the total benefit foreseen during the first five years of the approved production program for the development of local providers.

title: Delays in granting patents and lack of IP protection
description:
The level of IPR protection and enforcement continues to be weak, which discourages investment in innovation and creativity.

Argentina has not yet ratified the Madrid Agreement Concerning the International Registration of Marks, the Madrid Protocol, the Geneva Act of the Hague Agreement Concerning the International Registration of Industrial Designs and the Patent Cooperation Treaty.

IPR protection:

Several constraints on patent protection remain detrimental to EU companies, and research and innovation more broadly. Restrictive patentability criteria combined with difficulties to enforce patents granted, as well as the patent examination backlog make effective patent protection in Argentina very difficult, notably for pharmaceuticals, agro-chemicals and biotechnological innovations. As a result, Argentina is the only G20 member where the number of patent applications has decreased over the last years. Measures to address the patent examination backlog have not borne fruit and it still takes up to 10 years to examine a patent in the pharmaceutical, agro-chemical and biotechnology fields. This backlog is reportedly due in part to the fact that INPI does not have enough specialised staff in these areas and limited financial autonomy.

Another area of continued concern reported by stakeholders is the system for protecting undisclosed test and other data generated to obtain marketing approvals for pharmaceutical and agrochemical products. Stakeholders report that the Confidentiality Law provides some rules on confidentiality concerning data submitted for the market authorisation of pharma products, while allowing Argentinian authorities to rely on that data to approve requests by competitors to market similar products.  The uncertain protection of regulatory test data deters innovators from bringing modern medicines to the Argentinian market.

As regards copyright and related rights, Argentina does not provide adequate legal protection against the circumvention of technological protection measures for performers and phonogram producers as required in Article 18 of the WIPO Performances and Phonograms Treaty (WPPT).

IPR enforcement:

IPR enforcement remains a source of serious concern. IPR infringements are still widespread in Argentina due to the lack of enforcement capacities, appropriate training, dissuasive sanctions and the low number of seizures by customs authorities, in particular when acting on their own initiative. In terms of judicial action, stakeholders report lengthy and unpredictable proceedings, in particular for foreign plaintiffs, as well as difficulties in obtaining damages. Stakeholders report that addressing IP infringements is not a priority for the government.

As regards copyright piracy, stakeholders report lack of awareness in the Argentinian society. Enforcement against copyright infringements (audio-visual, e-books and music) is almost non-existent –unlicensed music and audio-visual services are widely available. There is no notice and take down procedure, and hence, all notifications need to go via the judicial system. This is ineffective, especially regarding urgent or provisional measures. Stakeholders report that third-party injunctions against intermediaries are not easily available. As to IP enforcement in general, there is a deficit of specialised judges or public prosecutor offices.. Without the necessary expertise, court decisions lack consistency and preliminary injunctions are almost impossible to obtain, in particular with regard to patents. Sanctions and sentences actually imposed appear not to be deterrent enough to prevent further infringement.

title: Geographical Indications, lack of adequate protection
description:
Argentina has in place a legal framework in line with TRIPS including a sui generis protection by means of a national register that in principle is also available to foreign holders of Geographic Indications (GI) and Designations of Origin (DO). There are separate regulations for the registration of wines and spirits, on the one hand, and agricultural and foodstuffs, on the other. However, no EU GI or DO has been registered up to date. Without registration, EU GI holders lack legal means to defend their rights in the country. One of the major difficulties is that GI denominations considered as “generic” names cannot be registered, and many European GIs are considered in Argentina and mentioned as such in the local food codex “Codigo Alimentario”. There are concerns on misappropriation of many European GI names.

GI protection for wines and spirits is in place since January 2004 (when Law No 25163 of 1999 entered into force) and for agricultural and food products since May 2009 (when law No 25380 of 2001 became effective). 

At the same time the existing Mercosur rules (MERCOSUR/GMC/Resolución N°26/03 - transposing TRIPS requirements) and implemented in Argentina by Resolution 146/2004 on labelling of packaged foods, establishes that the geographical appellations of a country, a region or a population, recognised as places, in which are manufactured foods with specific characteristics, cannot be used for labelling or advertisement of foods manufactured in other places when this can mislead the customer. It prohibits the use of the expression "type" to names associated with wines and spirits (TRIPS requirement) but allows it for agricultural products and foodstuffs. This latter increases the risk that those names become "generic".

In addition, there is widespread misappropriation of European GI names notably in the wine and spirit sector (for instance private operators try to obtain registration of European GI names, logos or official mentions as trademarks).

Association Agreement EU-Mercosur:

After implementation of this Agreement, many European geographical indications will receive protection both at administrative and judicial level, and directly based upon that Agreement. The Agreement includes protection against the use of "type" "style" (etc) and misleading flags and symbols.

The list of protected geographical indications of the EU comprises 357 names. As regards some names, transition periods ("phasing-out", which allow re-naming and positioning in the markets) are foreseen, and in some very few exceptions so-called “grand-fathering" (with specific labelling conditions). Argentina published lists with the concerned geographical indications in springtime 2020 with a view of establishing the relevant lists of previously used national names.

The Parties will review this list regularly, with the possibility of agreeing on the addition or elimination of names. If no consensus is reached, owners might make use of the national system to protect their geographical indications in Argentina.

title: Lack of protection of EU Geographical indications (GIs) in wines and spirits
description:
EU Geographical Indications (GIs) were not protected in Armenia. This lack of protection meant that locally produced products bearing the names of EU GIs could be produced and marketed in the country and also exported from Armenia to third countries. This was particularly the case for 'Cognac' and 'Champagne'.

This barrier was successfully addressed in the new EU-Armenia Comprehensive and Enhanced Partnership Agreement (CEPA) negotiated in 2016/2017, signed in November 2017 and provisionally applied as of June 2018. Based on CEPA, all GIs registered in the EU will be protected in Armenia, therefore protecting EU producers from misuse and counterfeit of the relevant names. The protection is immediate for all EU GIs, except 'Cognac' and 'Champagne' for which gradual phasing out is foreseen in Armenia for the use of the terms, both domestically and in export markets. For 'Cognac' the respective transitional periods are 25 years for exports and 14 years for the domestic market. For 'Champagne' the respective periods are  3 years and 2 years.

title: Bovine animals and products - BSE
description:
Australia enforces a cumbursome and slow approval process on imports of bovines and their products relating to Bovine Spongiform Encephalopathy (BSE).

The Department of Agriculture and Water Resources of Australia (DAWR) follows a cumbersome approval process to allow imports from countries that have reported an indigenous case of BSE. Under Australia’s requirements (since 2010), Food Standards Australia New Zealand (FSANZ) conducts an individual country risk assessment. In addition to this review, the Department of Agriculture conducts a separate import risk assessment for each exporting country to address animal quarantine issues.

The risk assessment procedures significantly delay imports of bovine products. To date, the risk assessment has been completed for five EU Member States: Croatia, Latvia, Lithuania, the Netherlands and Sweden that are now eligible for exporting selected beef products. Full report available at this link:  Status of country BSE food safety risk assessments (foodstandards.gov.au)

Import procedures and rules can be found in the Australian Government's online system for biosecurity import conditions and permit applications (BICON), at http://www.agriculture.gov.au/import/bicon.

title: Pork meat import restrictions - PRRS and PMWS
description:
Australia has a strict import regime for pig meat and pig meat products, including specific requirements for the heat treatment and deboning of meat. No imported pigmeat can be consumed as fresh product. Only five Member States are authorised to export uncooked pigmeat to Australia at the condition that the product is cooked at the border under specific conditons. Two Member States can export products cooked at the origin and two Member states are authorised only for certain dry-cured products. Exports opportunities for a wide range of products from different MS are frustrated by strict requirements mentioned above.      

Import procedures and rules can be found in the Australian Government's online system for biosecurity import conditions and permit applications (BICON), at http://www.agriculture.gov.au/import/bicon

title: Government Procurement
description:
On 5 April 2019, Australia submitted its instrument of accession to the WTO Agreement on Government Procurement (GPA). The GPA entered into force for Australia on 5 May 2019, providing an opportunity to address outstanding access issues, particularly at the sub-central level involving the Australian States and Territories.

At the central (Commonwealth) level, the Australian Government Procurement market is largely non-discriminatory and transparent, governed by the Commonwealth Procurement Rules (CPRs). This framework is built around the core principle of achieving value for money through competition (i.e. non-discrimination); efficient, effective and ethical procurement; accountability and transparency; consideration of risk; and conducting a process commensurate with the scale and scope of the procurement.

Additional requirements exist for procurement above certain thresholds, but a number of "sensitive" sectors – including property and accommodation, motor vehicles, research and development services, defence-related procurement, blood plasma products, business servicing the disabled, and indigenously-owned SMEs - are exempted from these additional requirements (these sectors are also generally exempt from coverage of the procurement chapters in Australia’s FTAs).

In the significant amendment to procurement rules by the Australian Finance Minister in 2022, the CPRs now require a minimum of 20% of all procurement by value to be sourced from SMEs. This marks a doubling of the previous target of 10% to ensure broader support for SMEs. Additionally, the changes guarantee that at least 35% of contracts valued up to $A20 million originate from SMEs, defined as Australian or New Zealand firms with fewer than 200 full-time equivalent employees. Australian officials argue this does not imply any discrimination in favour of SMEs, as the CPRs elsewhere make clear that SMEs will win government business only if they are competitive. In practice, SMEs' share of Commonwealth procurement far exceeds the 20% target: 27% of total value for 2020-2021, 30.8% for 2021-2022, and 27.3% for 2022-2023.

At the sub-central level, State and Territory governments each have their own policies and legislation governing procurement. Sub-central governments, such as Victoria, may require suppliers to meet a minimum local content in public procurement for "strategic" projects, or may impose weighting for local content criterion in tender evaluation, as is the case in Victoria and South Australia. Western Australia retains a price preference scheme in which it imposes surcharges on goods with a certain proportion of imported content, which works to the advantage of Australian and NZ suppliers. Through the Western Australian Buy Local Policy, a 20% price increase is applied to the portion of a bid that comprises a good, service or items that have been sourced from overseas, excluding New Zealand. However, countries possessing free trade agreements under which state governments are bound by procurement provisions (currently New Zealand, the United States, Chile, Korea and Japan) are excluded from these schemes and requirements.

title: Import duties on plastic spectacle frames
description: On 7 July 2022, Australia revoked the Tariff Concession Order (TCO) that has eliminated tariffs on all plastic spectacle frames since 2003. In line with the MFN, a 5 % tariff has been introduced, backdated to 12 May 2022.

title: Short data exclusivity protection of biological pharmaceuticals
description: Australia has a short period of data exclusivity protection for biological pharmaceuticals: Australia has 5 years of protection, whereas the US has 12 years, Canada and Japan 8 years and the EU 11 years. Data exclusivity protection refers to the period of protection of the data given by the innovative company to a regulatory body in order to establish that its new pharmaceutical product is effective and safe. During this protected period a competitor is not able to use the innovator's data to seek approval of a generic version of the product at the same regulatory body.

title: Wine equalisation tax rebate
description: Australia operates a 29% value-based Wine Equalisation Tax (WET) on wine consumed in Australia, but provides a rebate capped at $350,000 which effectively exempts the vast majority of SME domestic producers from the WET.

title: Luxury Car Tax
description:
Australia levies a 33% sales tax (25% prior to 01/07/08), known as the Luxury Car Tax (LCT), on all imported and domestically produced passenger cars valued over a specified amount which increases yearly. The threshold is AU$76,950 (approx. 46,252€) in the 2023-24 Financial Year. Fuel-efficient vehicles (those that consume less than 7L/100km) have a more lenient (higher) threshold of AU$89,332 (approx. 53,693€) as at 2023-24. Commercial vehicles (including pickup trucks and goods minivans) are not subject to LCT. Cars are the only item still subject to a luxury tax in Australia, with the higher rates of sales taxes for all other luxury items (such as jewellery, furs, watches, televisions and radios) ceasing in 2000.


This tax is applied in addition to the duty of 5% (passenger cars) and a Goods and Service Tax (GST) of 10% (applicable on all retail sales). It is seen as a remnant of the old luxury goods taxes from the 1980s, but it was introduced at the same time as the GST in Australia in 2000. It was widely considered to be designed to protect Australia's domestic automobile manufacturing industry, however, domestic automobile manufacturing ceased in 2017, removing the main rationale for the tax.

In December 2023, the Australian Government announced that the requirements to access the  fuel efficient threshold from less than 7L per 100km to under 3.5L per 100 km. This will take effect from July 2025.

title: Import restrictions due to lack of recognition of regionalization for African Swine Fever
description:
Australia bans the imports of pork and pork products from entire countries when African swine fever (ASF) is found in domestic pigs or wild boars in limited zones, thus not applying regionalization as set in the WTO SPS Agreement art 6  and by the World Organization for Animal Health (OIE).

Regionalization exists to ensure that safe trade occurs from disease-free regions/zones within the exporting countries and that trade is not the cause of the spread of diseases in the importing countries. In the EU internal market and equally for exports to non-EU countries, the European Commission, EU Member States and business operators apply the principle of regionalisation very seriously as a means to support trade while protecting the livestock from contagious animal diseases like ASF.

The EU acknowledges that exchanging technical information about animal diseases or cooperating shall not prevent any non-EU country or the EU from establishing the level of protection they both deem as appropriate, in accordance with the WTO SPS Agreement. In addition, the EU considers that WTO Members have to select risk management options that are not more trade restrictive than necessary.

Australia informed that imports into Australia of some porcine-derived products will be able to continue under existing arrangements, where country freedom from ASF in all pigs is not required, or where products are able to meet alternative risk mitigation measures for ASF. Details of the products that can be exported to Australia may be found by searching in the following database of the Department of Agriculture of Australia: https://bicon.agriculture.gov.au/BiconWeb4.0/

title: Investment Screening mechanism
description:
The foreign investment framework is set by the Foreign Acquisitions and Takeovers Act 1975. On its basis, foreign investments into Australia must be reviewed and approved by the Foreign Investment Review Board (FIRB) if they reach a monetary threshold.

European investors are under a substantial disadvantage when compared to Australia’s network of preferential trade agreement partners, with the threshold for review of investment from an EU investor in a business set at AUD 330 million, compared to AUD 1.427 million for an investor from one Australia’s preferred trading partners which are listed as Chile, China, Hong Kong, Japan, New Zealand, Peru, Singapore, the Republic of Korea, the United States of America, the United Kingdom and (under CPTPP) Canada, Mexico, Malaysia and Vietnam.

There are different and varying thresholds for triggering the review process for investments in agricultural land, mining and production tenements, sensitive commercial land (including mines and critical infrastructure), national security and media businesses, and sensitive businesses (including media; telecommunications; transport; defence and military related industries and activities; encryption and securities technologies and communications systems; and the extraction of uranium or plutonium; or the operation of nuclear facilities.)

title: Backlog of market access applications
description: Australia performs risk assessments to approve the imports of each and every agriculture product, which takes into account mostly the animal and plant health health concerns of Australia. Australia's cumbersome import procedures are performed under Australia's resource constraints, require prioritization of the necessary work, are based on real import interests expressed by the Australian importers, require official requests to be filed by the competent authorities of the exporting countries, and result in undue delays. The European Commission and Australia are working together to mitigate the above-mentioned undue delays and ensure access for all Member States on equal footing. Priority has been given to existing applications from Member States concerning pig meat products. In 2023, the French applicaton for pig meat was approved while others are progressing. Only for pig meat, applications from ten different Member States are pending.

title: Furniture design protection
description:
Australian furniture supplier Matt Blatt markets and sells replica chairs based on the original design by Finnish architect Alvar Aalto without being associated or affiliated with the original designer or manufacturer.

Under Australian legislation, if a design is registered, the designer has exclusive rights to make and sell the design, or assign or license others the right to exploit the design. However, this is only for a period of up to 10 years.

After this 10-year period, furniture which is based on a design can legally be sold including referencing the name of the designer, as long as it clearly states in all marketing and promotional material that the product is a 'replica'.

Australia has agreed in principle to join the Geneva Act of the Hague Agreement. If Australia joins and ratifies the agreement, they will be obliged to increase the period of design protection from 10 years to 15 years.

title: Counterfeit products
description: High-end European branded product companies, such as Louis Vuitton have complained that counterfeit products are entering Australia, and that Australian authorities could improve their enforcement of trademark infringements.

title: Geographical Indications for food related products
description:
While Australia has set up a system to register and protect Geographical Indications (GI) through certification trade marks (CTM), EU exporters find it is not adequate to protect their rights in the foods and spirits sectors.

One issue is that in Australia rightsholders are expected to enforce breaches of their rights themselves, including bearing costs.

Another issue is that Australia views some GIs as being “generic” terms in Australia and unable to be registered because they are commonly used in contexts not meeting the requirements under the GI. Obviously, from the GI rightsholder’s perspective this represents an even greater reputational risk to their GI and even more reason that the GI should be protected.

title: Australian Design Rules – Heavy quadricycles
description:
In order for automobiles to be approved for the Australian market, they must comply with the Australian Design Rules (ADR). The ADR currently do not include the categories of "heavy quadricycles" (L7e) and light quadricycles (L6e) and therefore these are not able to be registered for use on public roads. This is a barrier to potential European exports in this category.

Products affected: HS 8703, 871160.

title: International Freight Assistance Mechanism (IFAM)
description:
The EU is monitoring all the measures implemented by other countries in the context of the COVID-19 pandemic, with a view to analyse whether they are timely-removed

Australian Government is contributing to the cost of freight flights for exports of agricultural products to compensate the lack of cargo availability due to decrease in international passengers travel:

As part of a package introduced in the context of COVID-19 crisis, Australia has implemented a scheme of government support to exports of high-value agricultural and fisheries products, in particular perishable products to key export markets – the International Freight Assistance Mechanism (IFAM). Products eligible for support include seafood (including lobsters), premium red meat (including beef, lamb and pork), dairy (such as fresh milk and yoghurt) and horticulture (such as premium fruits and packaged salad or vegetables). The programme was primarily intended for Asian markets but the US market has also been included due to the current supply situation there.

The Australian Government has provided a total of AU$1042.7 million on this subsidy in several envelopes since April 2020.  IFAM is expected to last till 31 July 2022. The Delegation in Canberra met the Australian Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade on 28 March 2022 who informed that IFAM is not expected to be carried over in the next policy review scheduled by June 2022. In a letter of 10 April 2022, the Australian Trade Minister, Hon. Dan Tehan, confirmed this information to several Australian industry peak bodies that the Government intended to cease IFAM on 30 June 2022 with an operational tail until 31 July 2022. The Minister added that the Government would continue to closely monitor the situation, including whether there is a need to extend IFAM should circumstances change.

The new Labour Government did not change the decision to end IFAM on 30 June 2022.

title: Maritime services
description: The Rule of 2023 implements an Act of 2019, which reserves 50% of the country's maritime trade for Bangladesh flagged vessels. According to the EU industry, more than 90% of container ships that visit ports in Bangladesh are foreign-flagged vessels, while only 8 container ships are registered under the Bangladesh flag. It is therefore without question that 8 vessels are by themselves not capable of carrying 50% of the volumes in order to meet the growing needs of Bangladeshi importers and exporters.

title: Export restrictions on hides and skins
description:
Since 1990, Bangladesh imposes an export ban on raw hides and wet blue. Only exports of finished leather and leather goods are allowed.

However, a temporary relaxation has been introduced.

title: Mandatory payments when submitting electronic declarations to the Belarusian customs authorities
description:
Following Decree of the President of the Republic of Belarus no. 460 dated December 16, 2019, Informal document WP.30 (2020) no. 4 dated January 16, 2020, Belarusian customs authorities have introduced an obligation to pay for the submission of pre-electronic declarations through the national automated information system (E-services single portal – hereinafter as “OAIS”). 

For the submission of the TIR pre-declarations via TIR-EPD application, the transport operator was obliged to pay in advance for the package of 5, 10 or 20 pre-declarations the amount of 60, 120 or 240 Swiss Francs which is CHF 12 per electronic submission.  In the case of re-submission due to an error, change or addition, the same amount of CHF 12 must have been paid by the carrier. Subsequently, the technical adjustments have been made to connect the IRU application to the Belarusian customs authorities´ information system which reduced the amount per single electronic submission from CHF 12 to CHF 4.5 from May 11, 2020.

title: export ban on hides and skins and timber
description:
Export restrictions on wood: Belarus has introduced an export ban on unprocessed wood by Decree of the President No.211 of 20 May 2015. The ban was officially applied as of 1 January 2016. As of August 2017 the existing export ban on round wood was replaced by an export licencing scheme, which covers raw wood (HS 4403) and wood-based products (HS 4404). Initially imposed for 6 months with consequent prolongations.

Temporary export ban on raw hides and skins (HS4101) has been repeatedly extended; last extention untill 23 May 2019. Export of group HS 4104 is possible based on a licence issued by the Ministry of antimonopoly and trade.

The export licensing requirements on hides and skins expired on 31 December 2019 and the export licensing requirement for wood expired on 1 February 2020. Export bans have also ceased. However, these have been replaced by export duties (which have a similar effect). Namely:

- wood and wood products (ex HS Code 4401, 4403, 4404, 4407) -100€ per 1 m3;

- raw hides (HS Code 4101, 4103) -500€ per 1000kg;
- skins (HS Code 4104, 4106) - 10%, but no less than 90€ per 1000kg.

Waste paper (recyclable paper and cardboard) (HS4707): A previous export licensing requirement for waste paper expired on 3 July 2019. However, it was re-introduced on 3 October 2020.

Scrap metal: The Belarussian scrap metal market is highly regulated. There is an export licensing system and regulated prices, which are significantly lower than international market prices. In a note to the Trade Policy Committee of May 2019, the Polish authorities raised the issue of competition distortions in the EU steel market due to the Belarusian regulated prices of scrap.

in mid 2020 Belarus informed the EU that it is working on "liberalising" the export procedure for scrap metal.

title: Food-Cement-Glass
description:
From 1st June 2014, Belarus will introduce import licensing for certain types of pasta and confectionery products, and raw materials for their production, as well as  cement, float polished glass and glass containers from outside the Customs Union of Russian Federation, Belarus and Kazakhstan.

Such decrees were adopted by the Government of Belarus on 16th May, 2014 – particularly for food sector - Resolutions № 469 and for cement as well as glass and glassware - № 468.

The importation of the goods listed in the Resolutions will be performed using one-time licences. The application for the issuance of a licence for the importation of pasta products must be approved by the Ministry of Agriculture and Food, and for the importation of confectionery products - by the "Belgospischeprom" Concern.

One-time licences for the importation of industrial goods will be issued by the Ministry of Architecture and Construction. An agreement must be concluded between the Ministry and the manufacturer of cement or glass and glass containers, specifying the terms of supplies of the manufactured goods to Belarus. Amounts (quotas) of deliveries and minimum prices must be also set in the agreement. To obtain a licence, foreign trade contracts (agreements) should include the supply of cement, glass and glass containers to the country at prices not lower than the minimum prices established by the agreements on the terms of supply of these materials. It is foreseen that the resolutions will last until 30th November, 2014.

As of January 2021, this issue is largely resolved. The import licensing requirements for foods, glass and plasterboard have all expired. 

The only remaining import restriction is in relation to cement (Regulation of the Council of Ministers of the Republic of Belarus of 3 February 2020 № 67, which requires import licensing for cement imported to Belarus from outside the EAEU). However, BY informed us in July 2020 that this is temporary, will be removed, and does not affect EU exporters.

title: Non-automatic import licences for food, furniture and textile products
description: Bolivia introduced in 2016 non-automatic import licenses with resolution 174/2016 ("Resolución Ministerial 174/2016 - Ministerio de Desarrollo Productivo y Economía Plural"). These non-automatic licenses affect food, textiles and furnitures and, according to the Bolivian government, would be WTO-compatible. The EU considers that the resolution breaches WTO rules (Article XI - General Elimination of Quantitative Restrictions and the Agreement on Import Licensing Procedures).

title: Excise tax on beer
description:
HR, Si and Brewers of Europe complain about the latest Law on excise duties on beer which became applicable on 1 Septembere 2014 and allows reduced excise duties for breweries with a production of less than 400 000 hl. It seems all except one BiH brewers fall into the category for reduced duties.

 No improvements since raised in the last sub-Committee.

title: Tax exemption for domestic cars
description:
Law 8989/1995 as modified by law 13755/2018 (http://www.planalto.gov.br/ccivil_03/leis/l8989.htm) provides for the exemption of IPI (Industrial production tax) for domestically produced cars (maximum 2000cm2 engine, 4 doors, and sustainable fuel) purchased for use as a taxi or purchased by persons with deficiencies (IPI tax rate is 11%). Article 72 of law 8383/91 provides for an exemption of the OIF (financial transaction tax of 3% on loans) for the same categories of beneficiaries for the purchase of domestically produced cars with a maximum of 127 HP.

In 2009, this exemption was extended to vehicles of Mercosur origin with law 12.113/09 that modified article 4 in the original law.

An exemption to the ICMS State tax is also given through Convenio ICMS 38/01 (taxis) and convenio ICMS 38/12 (people with deficiencies). For taxis this applies to new vehicles with an engine of maximum 2000 cc, and for people with deficiencies it concerns vehicles that cost less than 70.000 BRL. The exemption 38/01 for taxis extends the exemption to Mercosur produced cars (Clausula 12), while there is no similar clause in the one 38/12 for people with deficiencies. The ICMS is a state tax and the rate varies between 17% and 18% depending on state. 

In 2023, Brazil's Congress finally adopted a comprehensive tax reform, to be phased in over eight years starting in 2026. The reform will replace five separate consumption taxes with a dual VAT system, at federal and state/municipal level. Such simplification is welcome for all taxpayers – including companies from the EU – even if critics point to the high number of exceptions to the new rules, following lobbying by domestic interest groups.

IPI and ICMS are among the taxes due to be replaced by the new VAT.

title: Restrictions in the telecommunication sector
description:
Frequency coordination requirement: Pursuant to section II of Article 12 of ANATEL's Resolution 220/2000, foreign satellite operators are required to complete a technical coordination with existing and planned (future) domestic Brazilian satellite networks through the local regulator (ANATEL). This requirement is in addition to the coordination required under regulations of the International Telecommunications Union (ITU). Importantly, the Brazilian Government requires foreign satellite systems to coordinate with all Brazilian satellite networks regardless of whether these Brazilian networks have lower ITU priority (including satellite networks that are nothing more than "planned"). ANATEL Resolution 748 of 2021 derogated Resolution 220/2000. It mantains the coordination procedure requirement but now with domestic and foreign filings (before it was only with domestic filings).

 

Law No. 13,879, of October 3, 2019, which modifies the telecommunications concession regime, was sanctioned by the President of the Republic of Brazil, Jair Bolsonaro. The text updates the old regulation of the sector, of Law No. 9,472 of July 16, 1997, and Law No. 9,998 of August 17, 2000, and allows, among other measures, the migration of concessions to the regime of authorization, in exchange for companies' commitment to invest in broadband expansion. The law, however, is not related to the provision of cross-border telecom services (Brazil has certain reservations on cross-border services in its GATTS schedule) but to the preoccupation of the telecoms sector that the concessions would be expiring at the end of the last year.

title: Engineering services
description:
HS code: -
(WTO Services Sectoral Classification List)
Engineering services (1Ae/8672), Integrated engineering services (1Af/8673), Architectural services (1Ad/ 8671), Urban planning and landscape architectural services (1Ag/8674)

The registration process for foreign engineers  is extremely time consuming (over 15 months on average) and the outcome uncertain.

Construction and engineering Services - Federal Law 5194/1966 rules that foreign engineers may establish in Brazil, but they need to be registered in a temporary register. Registration is controlled by the Conselho Federal de Engenharia e Agronomia (CONFEA). The process is time consuming and the outcome uncertain.  Since Law 12.378/2010 architects are regulated separately, falling under the newly created Conselho de Arquitetura e Urbanismo.

According to Law 8.666/93 and Regulation 1.025/2009 technical qualifications of engineers who are part of a proposal for a tender must be certified by the regional branches of CONFEA, the Conselhos Regionais de Engenharia e Agronomia (CREA), who will only consider work done in Brazil, unless prior registration of the professional in the CONFEA/CREA system has been obtained.

title: Problems related to corporate taxation and other discriminatory taxes
description:
Complex domestic taxation systems which include multiple cascading and discriminatory taxes pose challenges to EU companies operating in Brazil. Litigation is endemic to determine whether one tax should be included in the base for calculating another tax. 

 

Background Proposals for tax reform have been under consideration for many years but have faced resistance from vested interests. There is a widely recognised need to simplify the indirect tax system. Modifications so far were limited to replacing corporate social security charge by a lower charge applied to corporate revenues and the introduction of differential tax rates for domestic and nationally produced goods (PIS/COFINS) with the aim of compensating for the difference in taxable base between the two taxes due to a Supreme Court decision. This added to the complexity and ambiguity of the system in particular in relation with imported products. Additional main concerns for EU operators pertain, in particular, the CIDE tax, levied on the transfer of any kind of "technology", the high tax rates applied to imported perfumes, the increase of PIS/COFINS levied on imports. The Reintegra programme for tax reimbursements of exports remains on the books but the credit has been reduced to 0.1%.

In December 2023, in a historic achievement, Congress adopted tax reform to replace five separate consumption taxes with a value-added tax (a federal VAT and a state/municipal VAT). 

The reform, to be phased in over eight years starting in 2026, will replace PIS, Cofins, IPI, ICMS e ISS with a dual VAT system. Such simplification is welcome for all taxpayers – including companies from the EU – even if critics point to the high number of exceptions to the new rules, following lobbying by domestic interest groups. 

The standard VAT rate is yet to be determined. Due to the number of exemptions, it may end up as high as 27.5% but still an improvement over the current opaque, overlapping and regressive taxes. The reform will gradually shift taxation from the point of production to the point of consumption.

Previously, the lack of alignment with OECD standards on transfer pricing was a major problem for EU businesses. This was resolved in June 2023 when Brazil brought its law in line with OECD standards. The new rules entered into force from 1 January 2024.


Other concerns of EU companies remain:

 

  • Problems related to taxation of "technological knowledge" transfer due to the discriminatory nature of the CIDE tax (tax on the contribution for intervention in the economic domain), which was established by Law 10168/2000 and further complemented by Law 10332/2001. CIDE is collected to provide financial support to priority scientific and technological development programs and projects. CIDE is levied on payments made by Brazilian companies to foreign suppliers which provide inter alia some kind of "technological knowledge" such as patent assignments, trademarks or technical assistance services. Since 2006, CIDE no longer applies to software, except when it involves transfer of the corresponding technology (Articles 20 and 21 of Law 11452/2007). CIDE amounts to 10% of the underlying transaction. However, the retroactive effect of the law with regard to software only goes back to 1 January 2006. By contrast, Brazilian companies are not subject to CIDE when they pay for the acquisition or use of domestically produced "technology".

 

  • Taxation of perfumes versus "eau de toilette" – Due to the lack of fiscal or custom legislation that precisely defines perfume and "eau de toilette", Brazilian fiscal administration uses Decree 79094/77, which was complemented by a sanitary regulation, making the distinction between these two products on the basis of their respective concentration of aromas. As a result of this distinction, Brazilian importers (ADIPEC - Associação dos Distribuidores e Importadores de Perfumes e Cosméticos) confirmed that most Brazilian domestic products are classified as ’eau de toilette’ and taxed at an IPI (Tax on Industrial Products) rate of 12%, while most of imports from the EU are considered to be perfumes and taxed at 42%. The issue was also dealt with at EU-Brazil Joint Committee meetings. No progress was reported. However, according to the Ministry of Finance the differentiation was first introduced by decree 3.777 in 2001 and Brazil is in a right stemming from the Constitution to apply a higher tax to products considered a luxury good due to the higher concentration in essence/aromas of perfumes.

 

  • Introduction of an increased rate of PIS/COFINS for imports - PIS and COFINS increases for imported goods were officially introduced by the Provisional Measure (MP) 668/15 adopted and published on 30 January 2015. The combined PIS/COFINS rate for imports was increased generally by 2.5 percent (from 9.25 percent to 11.75 percent) with a higher increase for certain specific categories of products (pharmaceuticals, cosmetics, tyres etc.). The increased contributions applied as of 1 May 2015 (90 days after the publication as per the constitutional requirement). The MP 690/2015 was adopted by the Congress and published as Law 13.137/2015 of 19 June 2015.. Furthermore some imported products are subjected to a supplementary 1% PIS/COFINS tax, without the possibility of earning a tax credit. The tax hikes and credit restrictions affect only imported goods, which thereby are placed at a competitive disadvantage in the Brazilian market. According to the Brazilian Government, the rationale for the tax increase relates to a need to compensate for the difference between the taxable bases for imported products (that following the Supreme Federal Tribunal –STF – Ruling 55937/2013 and in accordance with the Constitution must be the customs value, without adding any other taxes or charges) and for domestic companies (where other domestically paid fiscal burdens are included i.e. ICMS). An STF ruling excluding ICMS from the calculation base of PIS/COFINS domestic was issued on 9 March 2017.
