In 2024, China also introduced export controls on antimony. 

For additional information on synthetic graphite, please refer to fiche 17542.

title: Slow approval procedures for fruits and vegetables
description:
Note: updated information missing to assess current importance of market access issue

Many applications pending from several Member States (ES, FR, GR, NL, PL, PT ..) and for many crops, including apples, citrus, kiwis, wheat, peppers, tomatoes etc.

Applications are treated individually and only one application per Member State is under review. 

Some applications, notably from PT, are pending since 2014.

The GACC department of Plant and Animal Quarantine contacted bilaterally various EU MS end of 2023 about "new import requirements" to be followed for products which are not in the scope of Decree 248 (like Fruits and Vegetables notably). As of February 2024, the trade impact of these "new import requirements" on EU F&V exports is unclear since these new requirements are not yet formally in place and have not been formally notified to trade parrtners and WTO for instance.

title: Customs procedures: double testing for textiles, customs classification and labelling requirements
description:
The following legislation and standards are applicable for textiles and apparel imported to China:

The Law of the People's Republic of China on Import and Export Commodity Inspection

  1. Product Quality Law
  2. Two mandatory safety and labelling standards: G.B. 18401 and G.B. 31701.

G.B.31701 covers labelling requirements for children’s garments (in force since June 2016). There were no changes in the most recent official review of the standard, which took place in September 2021. Other textile products must follow GB 18401 -2010.

Foreign companies’ compliance problems in China are not limited to compliance with compulsory standards (18401 and 31701). These products are produced abroad following the standards of the exporting country, as well as the regulation and compulsory standards of China. However, they do not necessarily comply with all recommended standards. Imported textiles must display a production standard on the product (production standard is not compulsory: usually it is a GB/T - recommended - or industrial standard). If a product fails the random product inspection conducted by Market Supervision authority due to noncompliance with recommended standards, it is regarded ‘unqualified’ and administrative penalties are due.

European companies carry out tests on their exports before shipping in order to check compliance. When their goods are presented to Chinese customs, they may be tested again in Chinese laboratories, at the discretion of Chinese customs. The Chinese customs continues to do double testing on imported textiles; however, foreign companies have to a certain extent gotten used to it, as there are no alternatives to go around it.

In November 2021, GACC released draft Measures regarding Credit-acceptance of third party testing report for public comments. If this is finalized and published later, companies could benefit from single testing done by international labs, accredited by GACC.

On 20th September 2022, the General Administration of Customs of China (GACC) issued the Measures for the Administration of Customs Import-Export Commodity Inspection Acceptance (the Measures), aimed at both optimising customs supervision and facilitating trade through the adoption of results from not only domestic but also foreign inspection institutions for import and export commodity inspections. The Measures came into force on 1st December 2022, when the GACC also announced imported apparel as the first commodity eligible for customs acceptance under the new Measures. As of 18th May 2023, only one of the 66 accepted test institutions is located overseas (Spain). So, this means that companies will still need to send product to China for a test.

title: Longstanding and unjustified import ban on EU Bovine products thereof due to BSE.
description:
Since year 2000, the Competent Authority of China (Ministry of Agriculture and Rural Affairs MARA and General Administration of Customs of China GACC) keeps an import ban in place on EU bovine/ovine products and beef/ovine due to bovine spongiform encephalopathy (BSE)

As of June 2024, only 5 EU Member States are authorised to export beef to China (France, Hungary, Ireland, Italy, Latvia)

Note: NL has lost and not yet regained market access for beef in China due to a Blue Tongue outbreak(not because of BSE)


Various other EU Member States have been requesting market access for beef in China but their applications are still pending, despite a BSE “negligible risk” status confirmed at international level (WOAH – World Organisation for Animal Health) and therefore a similar status to other countries having market access for beef in China.

In July 2023 China announced the lifting of the ban on BSE beef from Poland and Belgium but in practice market access for Polish and Belgian beef is not yet re-opened.

In September 2023 China announced the lifting of the BSE ban on beef from Finland but in practice market access for Finnish beef in China is not yet re-opened.

For Ireland market access was suspended after a case of atypical BSE in an old cow mid 2020. It took more than 2 years and half for IE to get back market access for Irish beef in China in January 2023 but imports of Irish beef to Ireland were suspended again in November 2023 due to another atypical BSE case. Irish beef was re-authorised again in January 2024

In February 2024 China announced the lifting of the BSE ban on beef from Spain but in practice market access for Spanish beef in China is not yet re-opened.

In April 2024 China announced the lifting of the BSE ban on beef from Germany but in practice market access for German beef in China is not yet re-opened.

Despite the recent lifting of BSE-related national bans for the above EU MS, market access is in practice not yet re-opened so this trade barrier is still valid and to be monitored.

title: Non recognition of EU regionalisation measures strictly implemented due to African Swine Fever (ASF)
description:
Since 2014, the Competent Authorities of China (Ministry of Agriculture and Rural Affairs MARA and General Administration of Customs of China GACC) impose country-wide bans on the EU Member State where African swine fever (ASF) was detected. The international standards for animal health (WOAH) clearly define conditions to allow safe trade to continue from non-affected areas (regionalisation measures) and on which products can be safely continued to be traded when an outbreak of African swine fever occurs. Upon detection of the virus on its territory, the EU has immediately implemented stringent control measures in the affected areas and implemented regionalisation measures guaranteeing that trade of pigs and pig products can continue to take place under safe conditions. These measures have proven to be effective and are fully in line with international standards. Trading partners (including China) have been provided with detailed information on the stringent EU measures put in place guaranteeing that safe trade can continue to take place.

As of June 2024, 9 EU Member States were authorised to export pork to China : Austria; Denmark; Finland; France; Ireland;  Netherland, Spain; Portugal and Belgium since January 2024. 

However this opening of market access to Belgian pork does not mean that China starts recognising the EU regionalisation measures in place (and based on international WOAH standards) since BE is ASF-free.

China has not lifted the (unjustified) national bans imposed on various EU Member States facing ASF outbreaks and despite the strict EU regionalisation measures in place in those EU MS (like Germany for instance which cannot export pork to China since October 2020)

The EU considers that the various country-wide bans imposed by China are overly trade restrictive and not in line with international standards, neither with the requirements under the WTO SPS Agreement.

 In practice China's approach to regionalisation is to discuss bilaterally with indvidual selected EU MS, rather than engaging with Commission at EU level. For instance France and China have concluded a bilateral agreement on ASF in December 2021 (this agreement on ASF that was never implemented in practice since there has been (so far) no ASF in France).  To be noted also that in October 2023 China officially announced the recognition of regionalisation to Russia for ASF.

title: Non recognition of EUs regionalisation due to avian influenza
description:
The two relevant Competent Authorities of China GACC (General Administration of China Customs) and MARA (Ministry of Agriculture and Rural Affairs) have banned import of poultry meat from the EU Member States due to highly pathogenic avian influenza (HPAI) outbreaks in the EU. A wide range of products are affected by these restrictions, in general live birds and their products.


China imposes a country-wide ban on the exporting country whenever there is a notification of Highly Pathogenic avian influenza, instead of limiting the ban to the affected area. China is thus not recognising disease free areas (regionalisation) as foreseen under the WTO SPS Agreement (article 6) and the animal health code of the World Organization for Animal Health (WOAH).
In addition, China does require a lengthy, non-transparent and burdensome procedure for the lifting of the country-wide ban. The international standard of the WOAH clearly states that a free status of the country, zone, compartment, can be regained three months after a stamping-out policy has applied.


Over the last years this important issue has been continuously raised on every occasion in bilateral and multilateral context with China, both at technical and political level, however without any engagement from China beyond an exchange of technical information. 


China's preferred approach is to discuss regionalisation bilaterally with individual selected EU MS, as illustrated with the bilateral agreement on regionalisation and Avian Influenza concluded in May 2024. 

Due to non-recognition of regionalisation and HPAI, as of June 2024, zero EU MS have market access open for poultry in China. 

Note: in May 2024 France and China have concluded a bilateral agreement on regionalisation and HPAI. This agreement was also yet implemented since market access is not yet open for French poultry in China (in June 2024 China lifted a ban on French poultry but in practice French poultry export establishments still need to be regsitered in China before market access is actually open).

title: Cybersecurity Law
description:
(In addition to the previous IT security related intiatives detailed in Barrier 11027) China's new Cybersecurity Law has entered into force in 2017. The number of implementing acts reaches over 150, dozens of implementing measures in the form of administrative measures, guidelines and standards are currently being developed to implement and operationalise this law. For businesses, compliance remains intrinsically a fast-moving target, we expect there to be more implementing measures still to come.

While the objective to strengthen its cyber legislation is not in itself fundamentally dissimilar to what is happening ain other jurisdictions, including in the EU, the concept of cybersecurity is primarily seen in China from a national security perspective and has a much wider and comprehensive definition, also including economic security and industrial policy considerations.

The law and the implementing regulations are vaguely worded and thus create ample discretionary margin at the implementation level. This leaves in particular the foreign businesses in insecurity over the intent and scope of the measures put in place.

As a result, considerable concerns have been expressed that these measures could lead to new trade barriers and possible discriminatory practices against foreign invested enterprises.

title: Intellectual Property Rights (IPRs) and Enforcement
description:
China remains the EU’s biggest challenge in the area of intellectual property rights. According to the annual DG TAXUD statistics, roughly 90% of all counterfeit goods seized at European borders come every year from China, including Hong Kong. This phenomenon goes beyond lost revenues of IP stakeholders since a significant part of detained articles are products for daily use that could be potentially dangerous to the health and safety of consumers.

Even though significant legislative progress has been made during recent years, IPR protection and enforcement are in many areas still not sufficiently effective. Lengthy registration proceedings and the burdensome legalisation of foreign documents are on-going problems. Substantial concerns exist in particular as regards the low quality standard required for innovation patent and as regards the IPR protection provided for data protection and trade secrets.

Enforcement remains a very serious concern. Despite noteworthy efforts made by China, the access to the Chinese administrative and judicial enforcement system in China remains problematic for EU companies, notably for SMEs. In particular, notarisation and legalisation requirements make the defence of IPRs difficult and time-consuming for foreign right holders. Moreover, interim injunctions are difficult to obtain in practice, the damages awarded by the Courts remain often too low, and the execution of judicial decisions is burdensome. In some cases, signs of selective IPR enforcement are detected when state-owned enterprises or strategic areas are concerned.

In addition, the EU industry suffers from a long-standing discrepancy between the federal and the provincial protection level in China in terms of enforcement effectiveness and efficiency. The recent central anti-corruption campaigns and the creation of specific IPR Courts in various cities give hope for a more harmonized level of protection in the future.

Online counterfeiting and piracy have aggravated the enforcement situation. Potential clients of such goods are now only a mouse-click away from having direct access to them at a global level. The delivery of goods in small consignments makes effective customs control impossible. Major Chinese players, such as Alibaba, are increasingly concerned about their reputation (particularly after having been named and shamed in US 301 reports) and take pro-active measures, without however being able to get the problem under control.

Somewhat related is the active policy of China to make EU companies not exert or even transfer their IP rights as condition to be allowed of having access to the Chinese market. The objective to take over foreign technology in key industrial areas is documented in many Chinese planning documents, such as "Made in China 2025" and five year plans. The ways to make companies obey to unnecessary disclosure and licensing requirements are manifold, such as procurement, standard setting, joint ventures, business registration procedures.

Since 2020, we have observed that Chinese tribunals introduced anti-suit injunctions in disputes involving telecommunication patents. These extraterritorial measures put European firms at a disadvantage and prevents them from protecting their legitimate interests.

Issues were raised in the IP Working Group in November 2022 (next session in 2023), and in October 2022 the IP Key China project was restarted for 3 years. Comments on various draft legislation have been submitted in 2023.

title: IT Security - Chinese licensing practices and approaches to information deviating from the international standards and global practices
description:
During the last years China has issued a series of legislative initiatives taken on the ostensible grounds of “national security”. Many of them relate to cybersecurity. Generally, these measures include very broad and vague definitions, which create uncertainty and implicitly leaves the Chinese Authorities with the option of undermining foreign market access on the basis of unclear and broad considerations.  These measures have raised a number of additional concerns such as mandatory requirements to use domestic cryptography only and to apply Chinese national standards instead of international standards, disclosure of source code, which would amount to the disclosure of business secrets, data localisation requirements, etc.

The “Cyber Security Review System”, announced in May 2014 is part of this trend. The IT banking guidelines was one of the first initiatives under this approach. They required domestic banks as well as foreign incorporated banks to progressively increase their expenditure on "secure and controllable" IT to reach the level of 75 % by 2019. The banking guidelines were suspended after strong international pressure, but China has issued a similar draft initiative for the insurance sector. Other sectors are also expected to follow.

Other pieces of legislation include the Cyber Security Law, the Counter-terror Law, the Provisions on Administration of Web Publishing Services, the Provisions for the Administration of Internet News Information Services, the Regulation on the Operation Behaviours in the Cloud Service Market and the Cybersecurity Review Measures.  

This market access barrier was discussed at the HED in September 2023. A WG will be launched to clarify the law and address concerns. It was also raised at the WTO TBT Committee in November 2023.

title: Chinese Furniture Standards for furniture products - CHN 1094, CHN 1095, CHN 1096
description:
Concerns over the draft Chinese Volatile Organic Compounds (VOC) standard for furniture “Limit of Harmful Substances of Furniture”, which would replace standards notified to the WTO in 2015 (G/TBT/N/CHN/1094, G/TBT/N/CHN/1095, and G/TBT/N/CHN/1096).

Despite the collaboration between the European furniture industries and Chinese standardisation bodies on a new, improved version of the standard that would take into account international standards applied in the area of VOC measurements, the draft Chinese standard “Limit of Harmful Substances of Furniture” fails to bring relevant improvements and presents similar concerns as the original text notified to the WTO in 2015.

Main concerns:

  • The Chinese draft standard on Individual Volatile Organic Compounds shows an arbitrary choice of thresholds and is not focused on hazardous substances. The draft standard will therefore overestimate the impact of natural substances normally present in wood but underestimate the impact of toxic substances. 
  • The volume-based approach to the testing method used in the draft Chinese standard would make the final emission of the product depend on the design and functions (for example number of drawers) rather than the choice of raw material.

UPDATE March 2023: The mandatory standard for volatile organic compounds limits on furniture has been modified and was submitted to MIIT for final technical review end of 2022. The standard is expected to be released soon. SAC/TC480 (furniture), have called for comments on this standard twice and improved the text based on domestic and overseas comments. No major objection from EU Companies was raised since then.

UPDATE November 2023: At the WTO TBT Committee in November, China confirmed that all comments were analysed and work on the amended standard continues and will finalise soon. However, China could not indicate when the new standard would be ready for publication. It was also not clear whether such new, amended standard would be re-notified to the TBT Committee.

title: Access to ICT standardisation bodies
description:
European companies have concerns regarding the lack of access to Chinese standardisation bodies, in particular, but not limited to, those where standards relevant to ICT, high-technology and digital industry are developed, particularly in relation to encryption.

Even when European companies are able to join in working groups on standardisation, they are frequently not able to vote in them, chair them or take the lead in drafting standards.

These issues have been raised repeatedly with China through bilateral and multilateral channels. In particular, the issue has been raised at every meeting of GAMS and the Technical Barriers to Trade Committee of WTO (November 2023 update).

title: Administrative Regulation on market Access of New-Energy Automobile Manufacturers and Product
description:
The regulation  released by the Ministry of Industry and Information Technology (PRC) in 2017 named “Provisions on the Administration of New Energy Automobile Production Enterprises and Products,”, requires NEV manufactures to master the development and manufacturing technology for the complete NEV. Foreign Original Equipment Manufacturers (OEMs) might be forced to disclose all their key technologies to the Joint Venture (JV).

UPDATE November 2023: The 2017 MIIT NEV Production and Products access Regulation (MIIT Decree 39) was revised in 2020. Requirements that the newly established NEV manufacturer has to have R&D capability and own key technology were deleted: for newly established JV, foreign OEMs’ mother company is not obliged to transfer technology to JV. They can sell or transfer technology if they want. However, MIIT Production and Products Access Regulation for ALL Road Motor Vehicles (MIIT Decree 50), which was issued in 2018. It applies to all kinds of Road Motor Vehicles. Requirement such as the obligation for newly established OEMs to have R&D capability remains. There are some conflicts between MIIT Decree 39 and Decree 50. From 1.1. 2022, theoretically speaking foreign company could establish 100% owned manufacturing facility in China, as shown by the example of Tesla. This implies that with or without the barrier, there is no problem for companies like Tesla to establish 100% foreign owned plant in China. For newly established JV, most international “traditional” manufacturers (European) do not have valuable electrical vehicle technology that could be of interest to China. However, the EUCCC PP 2023/2024 points to lack of transparency and equal treatment in policy implementation.

title: Compulsory Certification System (CCC)
description:
The Chinese Compulsory Certification (CCC) system was first introduced in China in 2003 by the China National Certification and Accreditation Administration (CNCA). 

The CCC touches many sectors such as automobiles, electrical/electronic products, machinery, ceramics and more recently ICT products. The system lacks flexibility and the same very heavy third-party certification procedure applies to very diverse categories of products, without any genuine consideration being given to the actual level of health and safety risk associated with them.

 

Update November 2023: 

Market access barriers are created when certain products have to fulfil multiple and uncoordinated requirements published by different Chinese authorities, while certain testing and certification procedures increase manufacturers’ costs and hinder the import of technology and services without improving product safety. Issues incude: 1) Overlapping between mandatory standards, compulsory certification and administrative licensing; 2) Lack of recognition of international test reports due to various testing and certificaiton schemes at national and local level; 3) Recommended standards becoming de facto mandatory; 4) Insufficient and inconsistent market surveillance and enforcement. Despite some progress, the Chinese Compulsory Certification (CCC) remains a burdensome, expensive and time-consuming conformity assessment system, particularly for SMEs. Current requirements are not always related to the level of risk of the products in sectors such as automobiles, electrical/electronic products, machinery, ceramics and ICT products. The system lacks flexibility and the same very heavy third-party certification procedure applies to very diverse categories of products, without any genuine consideration being given to the actual level of health and safety risk associated with them. Progress could hopefully be expected on reducing the number of products subject to the CCC and simplifying certification procedures for lower risk products.

title: Pharmaceuticals: regulatory requirements
description: There is a need for further alignement of the pharmaceutical regulatory system with international standards and practices. Current main concerns relate to new pharmaceuticals approval process; volume-based procurement (VBP); investment restrictions in the development and plication of certain genetic diagnosis and treatment technologies; pricing and reimbursement policies; cross-border data transfer.

title: Pharmaceuticals: IPR
description: The definition of "new pharmaceuticals" in the Draft Implementing Measures for Protection of Clinical Trial Data (dated May 2018) raises concerns that pharmaceuticals approved or marketed first outside of China will  receive weaker or no protection against the unfair commercial use of safety and efficacy data generated by innovative pharmaceutical companies. Regulatory Data Protection (RDP) is included in the draft May 2022 Drug Administration Implementing Regulations (DALIR) and in prior regulations, though as it stands China provides no period of protection during which a non-originator (or follow-on) applicant is prevented from relying on the data submitted to NMPA or a foreign regulatory agency to secure approval of the originator product. The implementation of the new Patent Law is also to be monitored in this respect.

title: Public procurement
description:
Despite recent developments in the Chinese public procurement regulatory framework, the main problem remains an active Buy Chinese policy where, in principle, only Chinese companies are allowed to bid in public tenders and foreign ones are only allowed under certain conditions. Government agencies and related entities are required to purchase equipment and technology from Chinese state or privately owned manufacturing companies. There is limited access to public tenders and insufficient transparency of all public tenders. This barrier is related to the enforcement of the Government Procurement Law (GPL) and the Bidding Law. Central and local entities tend to implement in a very broad manner those provisions, going far beyond discriminations imposed by the law.In addition, the review mechanism for bids is deficient.

The Buy Chinese principle covers all sectors, with most market access problems reported in the medical device sector. The policies range from pre-market R&D support to local government health authorities encouraging procurement of domestic equipment. In addition, the Made in China 2025 policy sets targets for domestic medical devices market shares. In practical terms, we also observe difficulties in accessing the public procurement market by products manufactured in China by foreign invested companies.

Also, the renewable energy (RE) market in China is dominated by SOEs. Foreign companies face market-access barriers from regulations (e.g. data transfer) as well as non-market practices in the allocation of quotas.

In addition, China has not yet undertaken any substantial multilateral or bilateral commitment concerning government procurement. It submitted its WTO GPA (Government Procurement Agreement) initial offer end of December 2007, and subsequently several revised offers. However, despite some progress made, the most recent offer does not provide sufficient coverage of entities, and has many exceptions.

Another issue with wide repercussions on the public procurement field is the implementation of the accreditation procedure for the indigenous innovative procurement scheme. A joint Circular of MOF, MOST and NDRC was issued in September 2009, detailing accreditation procedures to be followed in order to be eligible to tendering procedures. Among the requirements, IPR had to have Chinese origin (e.g. separate existence of brands and the obligation to have R&D related to the IP included in the products located in China), requirement to disclose information related to innovation and IPR, thus exceeding by far standard demands for eligibility to government schemes. A notice issued by the State Council in November 2011, directing all government entities to remove any mention of linkage between indigenous innovation policy and government procurement incentive measures within regulatory documents and to stop such implementation by 1st December 2011. Despite the efforts made the linkage remain a problem as this policy is still applied at sub central level in some of China’s provinces.

In light of China's work towards accession to the WTO GPA, EU expects China to already now ensure EU companies non-discriminatory access and participation to the Chinese procurement market. Importantly, State Council Document No. 5 (2017) clearly stated that products manufactured by foreign enterprises in China will be treated equally in public procurement bids.  This was confirmed in 2019 by article 16 of  the Foreign Investment Law and also in a more specific manner by the State Council Circular 39 of 12 August 2019, instructing various government bodies and agencies to inspect unreasonable restrictions faced by foreign-invested and private enterprises in bidding process by September 2019 and abolishing regulations and practices in government procurement processes that impede fair competition.

For the specific medical device sector, in a reply letter to DG TRADE on 17 Jan. 2020, MOFCOM states that "domestic brands" means products manufactured within the territory of China, rather than those produced by Chinese companies." and that "The Chinese government has taken constant efforts to optimise the business environment and will treat products made in China by foreign-invested enterprises in a fair and equal manner during the bidding process of government procurement." EU/EU industry to monitor in case there other cases of discrimination in tendering processes against EU FIEs. 

UPDATE November 2023: Still in place. Government procurement law, published July 2022 (https://www.pkulaw.com/en_law/a089c7cf0520342ebdfb.html) stipulates that "Government procurements shall be based on the procurement of domestic goods, projects and services with the exception of the certain circumstances". Both the Government Procurement Law and the Bidding Law are currently under revision (calls for comments have expired, but revised and final laws are still pending). Foreign Investment Law (FIL), forbids discriminatory treatment of foreign companies in procurement. Article 16 of FIL stipulates: “The State guarantees that foreign-invested enterprises participate in government procurement activities through fair competition in accordance with the law. Products produced and services provided by foreign-invested enterprises in China shall be treated equally according to law in government procurement activities.” Issue of access to pubic procurement by foreign companies are regularly raised in the dialogue(s) with China (see also fiche 14587). In the renewable energy sector, EUCCC also reports that due to preferences to domestic producers, foreign players in the wind power industry - for instance - face a bidding gap of up to 40% in public tenders. in addition, public procurement processes tend to favour domestic manufacturers and take exclusively into consideration environmental records in China. 

The issue of access to public procurement by foreign companies is regularly raised in the dialogue(s) with China (more lately at the High-level Economic and Trade Dialogue in September 2023.)

title: Shipbuilding Scrapping and Newbuilding Subsidy Programme
description:
In December 2013, the Chinese Ministry of Industry and Information (MIIT) issued the Chinese Shipbuilding Scrapping & Newbuilding Subsidy Programme. The scheme is endowed with €19,5 billion RMB (according to SEA Europe) and was originally running until 2015. It was later extended until 2017. While it may since have been discontinued, as of January 2019 the Chinese authorities had not provided definitive confirmation of this despite EU requests, while some EU industry participants believe it is still operating. There are no official data available on the exact figures and conditions of the scheme.

The objective indicated by the Chinese authorities is to phase out obsolete vessels and replace them by more energy efficient ships and, thus, protect the environment/climate and enhance their fleet's safety standards.

Beneficiaries receive a subsidy of 1500 RMB/GT – 50% is paid on scrapping the old vessel (1-10 years before their mandatory retirement age), 50% on ordering the new vessel. According to the "Administration of Central Government Subsidies for the Scrapping of Outdated Ships and Single-hulled Oil Tankers and the Rebuilding of New Ships" Cai Jian (2014) no 24 the gross tonnage of the newly-built ships should be at least equivalent to that of the disassembled vessels. However, at the EU-China Shipbuilding Dialogue 2014 in Shanghai, MIIT declared that there is no automatic link between scrapping and newbuilding. The vessels must be registered in China and the newbuilding has to take place on a Chinese shipyard. A list of qualified Chinese shipyards entitled to participate was published. The main beneficiaries of the programme are the four state owned shipowners: COSCO, CSG, SINOTRANS-Chang Jing and China Merchant. Foreign equipment manufacturers are apparently allowed to participate subject to complying with certain conditions.

 Conditions for foreign equipment manufacturers: 

  • the percentage of "local" marine equipment must be at least 70%;
  • "local" supply refers only to manufacturing companies. Sales offices of a foreign marine equipment supplier do not qualify as local suppliers;
  • wholly foreign owned manufacturing companies established in China do not qualify as local suppliers either;
  • in case of Joint Ventures, the Chinese partner has to be the major shareholder. 

These restrictions do not appear to have been written down in any formal document. At the EU-China Shipbuilding Dialogue 2014, MIIT declared to have no influence on sourcing maritime equipment. It would be the shipowner's decision. Accordingly, the local content policy is implemented through an arrangement between the shipowner, the shipyard and China Classification Society (CCS) by means of a list of equipment. This not publicly available list attributes a weighting factor to each major component (i.e. 38,5% is attributed to the engines) for calculation of the 70% local content. As a result, a European engine manufacturer can never sell engines to these subsidized ships, regardless of whether they have factories in China or not.

In spite of investment liberalisation in 2022, with the review of the catalogue of encouraged industries for foreign investment (design and application of clean energy in particular), issues faced by EU maritme manufacturing concern difficulties to accessing China's green maritime demonstration zones and incentives, as well as contributing to standard setting organisations.

title: Medical devices (regulatory requirements and pricing)
description:
In additition to non-market practices in public procurement (see dedicated entry section), the EU medical devices industry is facing the following market access barriers:

A) The approval of new medical devices in China is difficult: Chinese Order 680 requires manufacturers to conduct in-China clinical trials for the registration of certain categories of medical devices, i.e. class II (moderate risk) and class III (higher risk) medical devices.

B) The cancellation of testing fees by the Ministry of Finance on 1st April, 2017 results in lack of resources for test institutes which in turn results in delayed type testing or even in rejection of performing type tests by test institutes. The cancellation of testing fees results in significant costs and delays in the registration process.

C) Since September 2017, manufacturers of a selection of categories of devices (namely drug coronary stent systems, artificial hip prosthesis, implantable cardioverter defibrillators (ICD) and cardiac resynchronization therapy devices (CRT)) must provide clinical, production and pricing data to Chinese authorities in order to participate in a national program to set prices of these devices.

D) Country of Origin certification in pre-market-approvals remains a pre-condition for the registration and filing of imported medical devices

E) Market access for innovative In-vitro diagnostics (IVDs) in particular in medical treatment pricing catalogues and timing of their pre-approval trials

These continuing regulatory issues, but also the Buy China policy, increasingly lead to industry shifting production out of China.

title: Restrictions on foreign direct investment (FDI)
description:
FDI in China is subject to a complex regulatory regime and is mainly regulated by the Foreign Investment Negative List.

Bans, limitations and additional requirements may also stem from other laws and mechanisms. Investment in sectors such as defence, agriculture, energy, culture, critical technologies, internet products and services, and important (the term 'important' is not defined) financial services are subject to a review and might be rejected. Other less tangible barriers consist of cumbersome administrative and licencing procedures, targeted enforcement and local, prefectural level protectionist approaches.

A call for comments of the revised “Administrative Measures for Strategic Investments in Listed Companies by Foreign Investors” was launched in July 2020 by MOFCOM. http://www.mofcom.gov.cn/article/b/g/202007/20200702979804.shtml


In August 2023, during a State Council press conference, it was announced that MOFCOM in the second half of 2023 would have worked on reducing the negative list for foreign investment and expanding market access for foreign investors, as well as revising the “Administrative Measures for Strategic Investments in Listed Companies by Foreign Investors”.
https://www.gov.cn/xinwen/2023zccfh/17/index.htm


UPDATE November 2023: There are no changes in the foreign investment regime. Foreign Investment Law (FIL), which entered into force on 1 January 2020, is currently under review. The review focuses on the following: issues in the implementation of pre-entry national treatment and negative list management for foreign investment; issues in the implementation of the investment promotion mechanism; issues in the implementation of ensuring lawful rights of foreign invested enterprises; and issues in the implementation of the foreign investment management system. Although the review started already in autumn 2022, details so far are scarce.

Revision of existing laws and regulations that are incompatible with FIL continues until 2025, according to the transition period stipulated in the FIL. In 2023, MofCom is to revise the “Administrative Measures for Strategic Investments in Listed Companies by Foreign Investors”, in order to take into account for example, the shift from pre-approval to record-filing system and streamlined administrative measures and roles of approving strategic investments.

title: Medical Devices (Buy China policy)
description:
In order to achieve the Made in China 2025's target of 85 percent domestic market share for Chinese companies producing “core medical device components” , China has notably been utilising market-distorting measures and practices linked to localization and technology transfer, as well as volume-based procurement (VBP), among others.  Market access is still restricted for imported medical equipment, as these measures and practices provide unfair competitive advantages to domestic medical devices companies over foreign medical devices manufacturers. In particular: (a) with the "buy China policy" central ministries issue official guidelines and use informal practices to direct local procurement auhtorities towards favouring domestic equipment manufacturers and discriminate imported products; (b) medical devices procurement often include conditions that require or pressure technology transfer to Chinese entities; (c) China’s expanding application of VBP (Volume Based Procurement) for medical devices also creates an unfair competitive environment.

Public government documents show an awareness of and preference for using VBP to increase the market share of domestic producers of medical devices.  VBP operates without sufficient transparency and is increasingly promoting a low-cost, lower-quality commodity market, thereby concentrating market power in a few Chinese companies that can, with government financial support, meet the unreasonably low price requirements under VBP.  In some cases, foreign companies have offered low enough bids to be selected, but this comes at little to no profit, in order to maintain their presence in China’s market, when they do not end up abandoning the China market altogether.This policy is supported by actions from different ministries and continues to expand.

Finally, the lack of a clear legal definition for “domestic product” allows government procurement authorities to interpret the term in a variety of ways.  As a result, our companies report that they are often excluded from public procurement consideration even when they manufacture in China. Local bids often include explicit exclusion of imported products from the tender. Such measures and practices that significantly lack transparency and discriminate against foreign products appear to run counter to the obligations of transparency and non-discrimination under paragraphs 2(C)1 and 3(a) of Part I of China’s Protocol of Accession to the WTO and paragraph 1 of Article X of the GATT 1994, as well as Article 16 of the Foreign Investment Law, Article 15 of the Regulations for Implementing the Foreign Investment Law (State Council Order No. 723), and other relevant laws and regulations in China, such as Notice 35, which the MOF issued in October 2021, and which reiterates China’s previous commitment in the Foreign Investment Law to treat products produced by foreign-invested companies in China equal to those produced by domestic companies in the public procurement context.  They also appear in tension with Article 4 (national treatment and non-discrimination) of the WTO’s Agreement on Government Procurement (GPA), which China is currently in negotiation to join.  China’s measures and practices raise doubts about China’s readiness to comply with obligations of international agreements, such as the GPA, that China aspires to join.

title: Cosmetics
description:
The European cosmetics industry faces a number of market access issues in China. The revised Cosmetics Supervision and Administration Regulation (‘CSAR’) that entered into force on 1 May 2021 improved the situation of imported cosmetics but there still are a number of concerns. 1) Mandatory registration. 2) Multiple requirements to sustain the efficacy claims of cosmetics. 3) The requirement for a responsible entity for the safety and quality of cosmetics is established on natural persons. 4) Certain Chinese GMP standards deviates from internationally agreed ISO 22716. 5) The possibility of inspections to manufacturing sites in third countries.

These issues were raised with NMPA in 2022 and 2023. The EU Ambassador signed a joint letter to SAMR with likeminded countries about concerns of the cosmetic industry, sent in Febuary 2023. The EU Ambassador met NMPA Chief Deputy Commissioner Huang Guo on 17 April 2023, raising also cosmetics and the Ambassadors' letter. A follow-up meeting at EUDEL working level discussing the points of the Ambassadors' letter in detail took place 29 June 2023. Furthermore, DG GROW Director Slotboom met NMPA Chief Counsel Ding Jianhua 26 September 2023, reminding again about the promised response to the Ambassadors' letter. On 25 September 2023 at the HED it was agreed to relaunch GROW-NMPA cosmetics dialogue.

title: Market access in telecom networks
description: EU industry has bid in all phases of China's structured tendering process ((5G) roll-out) but has only been awarded in total ca. 5% of market for 5G base stations. The EU expects that commitments of fair and open market access are effectively implemented at all stages of the process.

title: Cross-Border Transfer of Personal Information and Administrative Measures on Data Security
description:
The EU is highly concerned about China's Outbound Data Transfer Security Assessment Measures and their implementation. There is uncertainty regarding the triggers for assessment, such that they may potentially be triggered by normal cross-border commercial activity. The assessment process is proving to be lengthy and burdensome, giving rise to considerable uncertainty. The opacity of the assessment process makes it impossible to ascertain that assessments are not conducted in a non-discriminatory manner. Assessments have led to de facto rejections of many essential cross-border data transfers for foreign companies. The ‘necessity’ criterion for data transfers during the assessment process appears to be interpreted in a very narrow manner. The EU is particularly concerned that these measures put foreign operators at a disadvantage compared to domestic ones. In addition, there are considerable concerns regarding the protection of trade secrets during the assessment process. There is also considerable uncertainty over the definition of 'important data'.
The EU notes the draft Regulations on Regulating and Facilitating Cross-border Data Flow and requests China to respond to the comments received on these draft regulations from the EU and European industry. The EU also notes that an agreement was reached between Vice-President Jourová and Vice-Premier Zhang Guoqing to put in place a mechanism to ease cross-border flows of industrial data and requests that this mechanism be established as soon as possible.

title: Regulations on Critical Information Infrastructure (CII) Protection
description: China's Cybersecurity Law entered into force in 2017. Dozens of implementing measures are being developed to implement and operationalise this law. The 2021 Critical Information Infraestructure (CII) Security Protection Regulation  do not resolve the overlap between the preexisting MPS-administered system for equipment security, known as the Multi-Level Protection System and the CII protection regime. It is also not clear what the mutual links regarding the compliance around the procurement of approved equipment and software for networks at designated levels of sensitivity are, many of which would likely also be designated CII.

title: Financial services
description:
The financial services market in mainland China is heavily regulated and suffers from a number of distortions with capital in- and outflows being controlled. The market is very clearly dominated by domestic, mostly state-owned firms. Historically, access to the market was difficult for foreign investors with equity caps and similar measures in place that significantly limited access. Among the small footprint of international banks and similar financial services, US companies are dominating with UK investments in second place and the EU footprint in banking probably limited to only ca. 0.1 – 0.2% of the reported 1.2% overall foreign banking market share. (The reservation applies that methodologies to quantify this market share can vary and will lead to different results.)

Beyond banking, China is an important market for EU insurance and re-insurance companies. Whilst the total assets under management by foreign banks stood at ca. EUR 440 bn in 2019 and hence almost double as high as comparable figures for the insurance industry, the foreign market share is with 7.8% significantly higher than in banking. (Similar reservations apply as for banking.)

Starting with policy announcements back in November 2017, China has gradually introduced nearly 20 or so distinct measures that partly opened up its banking sector to greater access on the part of international investors.

One should also note that whilst accessing China’s financial services sector has become easier for outside investment, this does not amount to an international integration of China’s financial services market or its banking system. Indeed, the Chinese government has maintained controls on capital flows as well as interest and exchange rates.

Despite mentioned policy of opening up the financial services sector there remain a number of market access restrictions in place, some of which are of a de jure nature and whilst falling short of discriminating against FIEs create a disparate impact for them. Other such hurdles are more of a de facto nature as in e.g. slow and to some extent opaque licensing procedures.

Of the various still existing such restrictions some pertinent current market access hurdles are:

  1. Market access for European banks to underwrite foreign government bonds
  2. Future extension of the “Carbon Emissions Reduction Framework Facility” by the central bank to also include European banks
  3. Maintenance of leasing companies’ ability to operate nationwide in light of possibly restrictions due to draft “Regulations on Local Financial Supervision and Administration” circulated by the central bank
  4. Extension of cross-border borrowing to consumer finance companies
  5. Different interpretations of some prudential ratios (liquidity and deposit deviation ratio)
  6. Maintenance of effective access to Shanghai Clearing House for EU banks

Further issues that are industry concerns relate to licensing procedures particularly in insurance service (which are cumbersome, do usually not allow for parallel submissions of applications to open up business in several Chinese Provinces, and are in part opaque in their local implementation) as well as certain aspects of macro-prudential assessment policies.

UPDATE March 2023: Still largely in place. A comparatively heavy approach to regulation and a significant number of market distortions, which can give advantage to domestic firms, are unchanged. Market access restrictions remain de jure in some parts of the market, whilst in others regulation is done with China's own large, state-owned banks in mind leading to de facto barriers to access in some cases.

Market access in financial services has been addressed at the 2022 HED (19 July). In detail, access on the part of EU financial institutions invested in China to the central bank's "Carbon Emissions Reduction Facility" (CERF, a facility offering re-financing at below market rates for loans to green projects) was addressed and since granted to at least two EU banks. Further, the Chinese side committed to modifying a draft regulation that would have severely limited the geographical scope for leasing companies so to preserve the status quo.

title: Revision of Standard on wines GB 15037
description:
Note: no updated/recent information available - active status of the market access issue to be checked

 

At the end 2015 China proposed a draft  revision on GB 15037-2006 standard, which refers to definitions, specifications and control in regard to wine and wine products. A second consultation process was launched in July 2017.

The main concern for the EU is this of diverging parameters in regard to international (OIV)/EU ones, which may entail trade disruption. More particularly:

− methods of analysis and how these are applied. The problems faced with the compatibility of methods of analysis and its implementation regards different results between analysis made locally and those conducted in the country of origin. In such cases AQSIQ usually refuses to go through the counter-analysis process thus definitely blocking the wine products from being exported. In this respect, to be noted that the OIV compendium of methods of analysis has been translated into Chinese, thus paving the way for convergence.

− setting up numerical limits for oenological practices where these do not exist at international (OIV) and EU level, or setting up diverging – more restrictive- ones.

title: Cybersecurity Review Mechanism (January 2022)
description: The Cyberspace Administration of China (the "CAC"), in conjunction with 12 other government departments (collectively, the "Working Mechanism"), issued the New Measures for Cybersecurity Review (the "New Measures") on January 4, 2022. The New Measures amends the Measures for Cybersecurity Review (Draft Revision for Comments) (the "Draft Measures") released on July 10, 2021 and will come into effect on February 15, 2022. By way of background, China's Cybersecurity Law for the first time raised the requirement of cybersecurity review for critical information infrastructure operators' (the "CIIO") activities of purchasing network products and services, which may influence national security. Following the Cybersecurity Law, the CAC issued the Measures for Cybersecurity Review in April 2020 (the "2020 Measures"). On July 10, 2021, the CAC issued the Draft Measures, expanding the application scope of the cybersecurity review to cover data processors, if data processors' activities affect or may affect national security. The New Measures follows the expanded application scope under the Draft Measures, although it refers to network platform operators instead of data processors. Under the New Measures, both CIIOs and network platform operators need to pay attention whether their business activities may be subject to cybersecurity review in China.

title: Draft Cryptography Law
description:
(In addition to  previous ICT Security Meassures covered under Barrier 11027)

On April 13, 2017, China’s State Cryptography Administration (“SCA”) published a draft Encryption Law (“the law”) for public comment. Another round of consultations was organised in August 2019, and the law was passed in October 2019, with a enter into force date on 1 January 2020. Regulations to implement the law have partially been released. 

The law is overly broad in scope, covering areas ranging from research and commercial use, import, export as well as certification. The EU notes that it aims at regulating all these use cases of cryptography, whereas in most other parts of the world most such use cases of cryptography are unregulated and left to the market, which corresponds also to best practices as recomended by the World Semiconductor Council (WSC) and adapted by the Government/Authorities Meeting on Semiconductors (GAMS).

Most of ICT products use some elements of encryption, but most are not dedicated primarily to encryption. The latter products (which, for instance, use cryptography as a feature for digital signatures, authentication or verifying product authenticity) are in general not subject to licensing requirements or any similar regulatory constraints. To strike a balance between security and industry development and ensure that the law is not more trade restrictive than necessary, the EU suggests narrowly defining the kind of cryptography products falling under it, and, in line with SCA's (then OSCCA’s) so-called Year 2000 Clarification, ensuring that only such products fall under it the core function of which is encryption. This provision is missing in the approved law. Related, implementing regulations released so far (Commercial Cryptography Administrative Regulations, in draft) have maintained and reinforced the overly broad application of the law.

title: Draft Cybersecurity Multi-Level Protection Scheme
description:
In 2007, the Chinese Ministry of Public Security (MPS - the lead agency tasked with combating cyber-crime and protecting cybersecurity) promulgated the initial MLPS regulation, entitled Administrative Measures for the Multi-level Protection Scheme of Information Security. Designed to secure critical Chinese infrastructure information systems, the initial MLPS is a framework that classifies information systems physically located in China according to their relative impact on national security, social order, and economic interests if the system is damaged or attacked. The classification levels range from one to five, one being the least critical and five being the most critical. Information systems that are classified (initially self-assessed and proposed by operators and then confirmed by MPS) at level 3 or above are subject to enhanced security requirements, resulting in the de facto exclusion of foreign companies from those levels.

China's Cybersecurity Law has entered into force on 1 June 2017. Dozens of implementing measures in the form of administrative measures, guidelines and standards are being developed to implement and operationalise this law. The draft Regulation on Classified Cybersecurity Protection  issued by MPS for public consultation in June 2018 - which could replace the original MLPS of 2007 mentioned above - is part of this package of measures that are designed for implementing the Cybersecurity Law.The main concerns with regard to the regulation and guidelines concern the further extension in scope of protection level three and above, the nature of the expert review that the Guidelines prescribe, as well as a lack of clarify in some definitions.

The Regulation aims to implement Article 21 of the Cybersecurity Law and further builds on the Administrative Measures for Information Security Multi-level Protection from 2007. The Regulation is complemented by the "Guidelines for grading of classified cybersecurity protection (GB/T 22240 – 20XX)" by Technical Committee 260, submitted for public consultation in March 2018. The EU has submitted comments to both the guidelines, as well as the regulation.

title: Anti-dumping duties on European frozen fries
description:
In November 2018, Colombia imposed definitive anti-dumping (AD) measures on imports of frozen fries from BE, DE and NL. Duties range from ~3% to ~8%, and up to ~ 44% and were imposed for 2 years.  Mydibel S.A. (anti-dumping duty rate 8.01%) from Belgium, Aviko B.V. (3.64%) and other companies (44.52%, with the exception of Farm Frites B.V.) from the Netherlands, and Agrarfrost GmbH & Co. KG (3.21%) from Germany.

 

The total market share affected by the duties in Colombia is 84%. Duties from ~3% to ~8% affect 75% of EU exports and duties of 44% affect around 9% of EU exports.

 

The investigation showed serious shortcomings. The European Commission has intervened and raised its concerns with the Colombian authorities at both technical and political level more than 30 times in relation to the anti-dumping investigation.

 

Following the imposition of the measures, the Commission requested the revocation of the measures through an administrative procedure in Colombia (‘revocatoria directa’) in an attempt to reach a quick settlement of the case. However, Colombia rejected the revocation of the measures on 13 May 2018.

On 15 November, the EU has requested WTO consultations with Colombia over anti-dumping duties imposed on frozen fries from Belgium, the Netherlands and Germany. Consultations took place with Colombia on 15 and 16 January 2020 but failed to resolve the issue.

n 17 February 2020, the EU asked that the request for the establishment of a panel be placed on the agenda for the meeting of the Dispute Settlement Body (DSB) to be held on 28 February 2020. At its meeting on 29 June 2020, the DSB established a panel.

On 13 July 2020, the European Union and Colombia informed the DSB that they had agreed to Procedures for Arbitration under Article 25 of the DSU in this dispute (“Agreed Arbitration Procedures”). These procedures, which were subsequently revised on 20 April 2021, were entered into by the parties “to give effect to communication JOB/DSB/1/Add.12” (that is, the Multi-Party Interim Appeal Arbitration Arrangement Pursuant To Article 25 Of The DSU (MPIA)) and “to decide any appeal from any final panel report as issued to the parties in [this] dispute.”

On 29 August 2022, the panel, issued its final report to the parties. On 6 October 2022, Colombia filed a notice of recourse to Article 25 under the Agreed Arbitration Procedures. The final award was issued to the parties in English on 19 December 2022. On 21 December 2022, in accordance with Article 25.3 of the DSU, the award in three working languages of the WTO was notified to the DSB, the Council for Trade in Goods, and the Committee on Anti-Dumping Practices and circulated to Members.

Arbitrators have in substance ruled in favour of the EU in the first WTO appeal dealt with under the ‘Multi-party interim appeal arbitration arrangement', known as the ‘MPIA'. The final and binding award confirms that the anti-dumping duties imposed by Colombia on frozen fries from Belgium, Germany and the Netherlands breach World Trade Organization (WTO) rules and improperly restrict access to the Colombian market.

On 20 January 2023, Colombia informed the DSB that it intended to implement the arbitrators' award in a manner that respects its WTO obligations and that it would need a reasonable period of time to do so. On 10 March 2023, Colombia and the European Union informed the DSB that they had agreed that the reasonable period of time for Colombia to implement the recommendations of the arbitrators' award would expire on 5 November 2023.

On 7 December 2023 Colombia circulated its Status Report under Article 21.6 of the DSU regarding the implementation of the Award of the Arbitrators in this dispute and claimed that, through Ministerial Resolution 286 issued on 21 November 2023, “it has now fully implemented all of the relevant panel and arbitral findings and has complied with its WTO obligations”. The EU disagreed and, therefore, requested compliance consultations with Colombia pursuant to Article 21.5 DSU on 31 May 2024.

On 31 May 2024, the EU requested compliance consultations to Colombia.

title: Ban on imports of live bovine animals and bovine products.
description:
In the Andean Community Resolution 1587 (which entered into force in May 2013), banned imports on Bovine Spongiform Encephalopathy (BSE) of several products such as: live bovine animals, bovine products and by-products. Concentrated meat containing meat/blood/bone meal, bovine meat, bone meal and mammalian offal meal or food additives that contain ruminant proteins for feed animal use from the countries concerned and with different status of negligible risk, are also banned.

However, this regulation excludes some products such as: milk and dairy products, semen and bovine embryos, sebum without protein, di-calcium phosphate, hides and skins, gelatine and collagen. Also, veterinary products not elaborated with risk products identified in Terrestrial Animal Health Code, as long as these products come from animals of negligible risk, as well the feed for felines and canines which comply with the same requirements, are allowed. Deboned bovine meat of animal less 30 months of age is allowed complying with several conditions.

In addition, for de-bone fresh meat and meat products from cattle, the WOAH code states that not import conditions should be set regardless of the BSE status of the exporting country and therefore it can be exported from BSE affected countries following compliance with certain certifications requirements. In the case of other bovine products, the WOAH code states that Veterinary Administrations should authorise without restriction the imports of: milk and milk products, semen, embryos, hides, skins, gelatine and collagen.

The following EU Member States are listed in Andean Community Resolution 1587 because they have reported cases of BSE, i.e. Austria, Belgium, Check Republic, Denmark, France, Germany, Ireland, Sweden, Poland, Portugal, United Kingdom, Netherlands, Luxembourg, Italy, Finland, Spain, Greece, Slovakia and Slovenia.

Meanwhile the measure has also impact on the negotiation of harmonized certificates for exports from the EU as follows: Negotiation of a harmonized certificated for processed meat products to Colombia (including bovine meat products). Here in December 2019 Colombia indicated that their latest proposal for a certificate would be only valid for Member States with a negligible risk status in the OIE.

The point has been discussed in 2020,21, 22 and 2023 SPS subcommitte meeting

title: African Swine Fever: lack of recognition of EU regionalization policy
description:
According to Article 6 of SPS agrrement,  Members shall, in particular, recognize the concepts of pest — or disease-free areas and areas of low pest or disease prevalence. CO does not fulfil this obligation. 

There is non-compliance either with the SPS chapter of the FTA respect recognition of sanitary status and regionalization (Article 94);

Colombia does not recognize the EU regionalization policy on African Swine Fever. This would be due to sanitary concerns and conflicting regional legislation (from Andean Community) that do not seem aligned neither with the FTA in place nor with OIE standards.

This has an impact on exports from Belgium and Poland. Belgium was banned via letter September 2018 and Polands's export application seems to be blocked.

The COM considers this restriction is not in line with provisions in the FTA and have undertook several actions to seek its lifting:

  • Raised this in the FTA SPS Subcommittees 2018 , 2019, 2020 and 2021
  • Provided updated epidemiological information and raised this point also in writing
  • Met the Colombian veterinary service (ICA) to discuss the case

COL indicates that it would be open to withdraw the restrictions on Belgium once it recovers in WOAH its free status on all suidae species.

From 1 October 2021 Belgium declared that the country was free from ASF in all swine.

On 22/10/21 Colombia lifted the ban for Belgium as Colombia recognised the ASF-free status , therefore COL no longer requires risk analysis and is open to make agreements on the trade in pigs.

This does not mean that COL accept the EU regionalization policy. COL had recognised a country free but there are still problems with free regions in other MS.

For PL,  CO presented at the follow up meeting of the november 21 subcommitte meeting on February 2022 ,a report assesing the situation of ASF in PL with the conclusion that the measures applied by PL are not enough to mitigate the risk of importing pig meat.

IT has shown also concern for the not recognition of its free zones since december 2022

title: Excessive delays in the registration of pharmaceutical products by INVIMA
description:
Pharmaceutical companies have reported very long delays of Colombia’s National Food and Drug Surveillance Institute (INVIMA - Instituto Nacional de Vigilancia de Medicamentos y Alimentos) in the compulsory registration of pharmaceutical products, required for the importation and commercialisation of such products. While INVIMA is responsible for registration and surveillance of a long list of products, long delays seem to mostly affect pharmaceutical products.

Companies are facing delays of more than five years in the registration process and complain about the lack of transparency and communication in the process.

title: Discriminatory alcohol practices and regulatory requirements on alcoholic drinks
description:
Following the EU’s request for WTO consultations, in 2016 Colombia enacted Law 1816/2016, which addressed EU concerns on discriminatory spirits taxation. However, there remain national and departmental measures that can be considered discriminatory and that affect the import of EU wine and beer:

-  Since 2016, beer importers have reported unequal treatment in several departments, which adopted discriminatory provisions against imported beers through local legislation acts (ordenanzas, resolutions and circular notes). These measures include strip stamps, exclusively for imported beers, which result in higher costs and burdensome administrative procedures. Currently 11 departments (Caldas, Quindío, Tolima, Nariño, Norte de Santander, Cauca, Boyacá, Guajira, Caquetá, Casanare and Cesar) request strip stamps on each can of beer, whereas 4 departments (Santander, Risaralda, Meta and Huila) have mixed systems with strip stamps on each six-pack of beer. Following pressure to the Ministry of Trade, the Vice Minister of Trade sent a letter to the Federation of Departments requesting to address the issue in the affected departments. However, only 1 department (Atlántico) has lifted the measure so far.  This matter has been raised during the EU-Colombia Sub-Committee on Market Access (established under the Trade Agrement) since 2016. Colombia has repeatedly indicated that these departmental measures should be reviewed in line with national legislation but no progress has been registered.

- Decree 1366 of 16 October 2020, which sets specific rules for domestic micro-enterprises brewing craft beers, which allows nationals to register several beers in a single sanitary registration whereas international producers/importers must process one product per registration.

- Compliance with Decree 162/2021 on GMP standards, national micro-enterprises producing beers have been given a longer transition period, October 2025 instead February 2025 (Decree 1366/2020). This Decree also poses problems for EU exporters of wine and spirits.

 - Resolution 1440/2021, which is the technical regulation for glass, ceramic and articles in contact with foodstuffs, requests importers to go through a procedure with the SIC including paying a laboratory to certify the CE mark for each imported batch.

Furthermore beer importers, as well as wine importers, have complained about other taxation issues (payment of taxes upon importation), delays on national health registration and delays on the implementation of Decree 2106/2019 on the reduction of red tape (Decreto antitrámites),which is still being implemented by the National Federation of Departments, two years behind the legal deadline.  Regarding health registration, the situation has not improved in recent years and, according to small wine importers, the situation has even worsened.

title: Access to government procurement at sub-central level
description:
Following the provisional application of the Trade Agreement between the EU and Colombia on 1 August 2013, Colombia denied national treatment to EU companies of procurement by economically important public entities at sub-central level due to a different interpretation by the EU and Colombia of Colombia's Government Procurement coverage. After several meetings to discuss the matter, Colombia agreed to modify its market access schedule at sub-central level and extend the coverage to those previously excluded entities, including economically important entities. As a result, on 24 November 2017, the EU and Colombia adopted a Decision the Trade Committee,  which adds a note to Colombia’s schedule for sub-central entities with the following text: “‘procuring entities’ cover all sub-central public procuring entities, not having an industrial or commercial character”

However, despite this Decision, recurring instances whereby EU companies are not granted national treatment have been identified, because of a difference of interpretation of this Decision of the Trade Committee, which harms the interests of European companies in accessing public tenders.

title: lack of progress on export applications of fresh animal products, certificates and on the registration of list of pre-approved establishments ( Pre-listing)
description:
CR has included a new requirement for listing establishments of a certain category which were already approved for import. CR is asking for detail information of each establisment withing the category. MS has to give further details of the establishments belonging to the same category, something that it is technically unfeasible for some MS given the high number of establishments already approved,

This goes agaist the EU-CA agreement on which the establishments are pre-listed, if they belong to the same category of products for a category already approved; therefeore, product categories are laid down in such a way that within each of them, all products have the same risk categorisation.

ANNEX VII
REQUIREMENTS AND PROVISIONS FOR APPROVAL OF ESTABLISHMENTS FOR PRODUCTS OF ANIMAL
ORIGIN

point 1:The Competent Authority of the importing Party shall draw up lists of approved establishments and shall make these lists publicly available

3. The provisions in points 1 and 2 shall initially be limited to the following categories of establishments:
(a) all establishments for fresh meat of domestic species;
(b) all establishments for fresh meat of wild and farmed game;
(c) all establishments for poultry meat;
(d) all establishments for meat products of all species;
(e) all establishments for other products of animal origin for human consumption (for example casings, meat
preparations, minced meat);
(f) all establishments for milk and milk products for human consumption; and
(g) processing establishments and factory/freezer vessels for fishery products for human consumption including
bivalve molluscs and crustaceans

After a year of waiting, CR has attended all the requests of certificates and establishments but only for the fish establishments the listing is solved for ES since 24 May 22

In May 2023, 5 certificates for different commodities have been approved for ES(honey, live bovine, Animal subproducts and petfood ) and 1 for BE for gelatine and collagen.  ES got also its its establishments listed after 3 years and IT has opened the market for porcine meat and dairy products in the same year of application. Despite, these advances on certain commoddities, there are still 11 pending applications from other MS too such as IE, EL, PL and PT on which CR does not resolve the applications since years, some of them from 2015 and 2016. The prelisting is not working nor in quality neither on quantity of establishments. 

On 4-5 June 2024 all th epending SPS issues were discussed with CR.The following certificates have been solved according to CR authorities in 2023: 

For BE on Collagen;

For ES on: Honey; live bovine; coffe capsules with milk powder; Bonemeal; petfood for dogs and cats; blueberries, 

For IT on porcine meat and dairy products

For IE on dairy products ( milk powder) 

For ES there has been also authorised all the establisments from the same category in accordance with the AA

title: Discriminatory VAT on imported ham and cheese
description:
The Dominican Republic applies different tax rate on imported cheese and ham compared to domestically produced cheese and ham. Particularly, imported goods are subject to 18% VAT, whereas domestically produced goods are VAT exempted. In 2021 it was found that the discriminatory practice was also being applied to canned tomatoes and pasta preparations.

In the case of cheese, the different treatment stems from an interpretative guideline by the General Direction of Internal Taxation (DGII), adopted at a request of National Regulatory Council for the Promotion of Dairy Industry in 2006, in conjunction with Article 343 of the Tax Code.

Relevant HS codes affected: 020312, 020319, 020322, 020329, 021011, 021012, 021019, 040610, 040620, 040630, 040640 and 040690, 200210, 190220, 190230.

title: Control and fiscal traceability system for alcoholic beverages and cigarettes (Sistema Trafico)
description:
Since beginning of 2018 the General Directorate of Internal Taxes (DGII) of the Dominican Republic has been developing a traceability system (known as Sistema Trafico) to tackle very high rates of illicit trade and tax evasion in the sector of alcoholic beverages and cigarettes (40% in 2018). The initiative was supported by the Association of Industries of the Dominican Republic, mainly concerned with protection of national rum producers, affected by smuggled/adulterated produce. The system will be applicable to all alcoholic beverages and cigarettes (domestic and imported), establishing control and traceability of each product marketed in the Dominican Republic from their initial production to final consumption. The main feature of the system will be the compulsory labelling of each bottle, containing a unique code and serial number, as well as special authentication marks to prevent fraud. The final consumer will also be able to scan the code with a special application for mobile phones. National producers of alcoholic beverages (mainly rum and beer) with higher volumes of production will be able to integrate the labelling process in their production lines, so that the labelling will be done automatically. Importers will need to place the label manually on each bottle. It is not clear where this process would take place (at origin or at destination).

The system still lacks implementing regulations and is only based on Art. 17 of the recently adopted Law 17-19 on the Eradication of Illicit Trade, which empowers regulatory bodies to establish traceability systems for inputs and finished products to prevent smuggling and tax evasion.

The System has been developed by the United Nations Development Program (UNDP), entrusted with the tendering process. The tender was awarded to the Swiss company SICPA in April 2019 who will be the provider, developer and implementer of the system. It was supposed to be ready by November 2019 for alcoholic beverages, however, to date it has not been integrated in the system of the Customs Administration (Integrated Customs Management System SIGA). 

The national alcoholic beverage production sector has been granted a series of facilities to implement the new system. SICPA, the company that won the contract for the implementation of Trafico, must install the marking equipment directly on the automatic and semi-automatic production lines. Therefore, the equipment and processes vital to comply with the requirements of the System by the local production will be fully covered by the supplier.

For imported products, indirect marking (adhesives) should be used, which may be applied at origin or in the Dominican Republic. The costs associated with the adaptation of the software for the printing system as well as the necessary machinery must be covered by the importer. Therefore, contrasting the conditions under which the importing sector must implement the Trafico System with the facilities granted to the national producer sector, there is a clear disadvantage that will negatively affect the competitiveness of the imported product in the national market.

title: Dealer Protection Law - discrimination
description:
The Dealer Protection Law (Law 173) prevents foreign companies from terminating importation and distribution contracts with DR companies except under very stringent conditions, often requiring payments of large indemnities to the importer/distributor. DR companies appear not to have to pay such indemnities when ending contracts.
This means that a foreign company is tied to an importer/distributor even if the latter company develops conflicting interests and is no longer an effective sales route into the DR market.

This law raises concerns as to its compliance with GATT Article III.4.

title: Intellectual Property Protection (plant varieties)
description: Despite legal protection, insufficient actions of the competent authority to pursue coerceive actions on IP violations of rose breeder rights result in enduring IPR violations.

title: Continued changing of import conditions for imports of seed potatoes
description:
