Every year Egypt published new specifications for the import of seed potatoes, most of which come from the EU.

The publication was done close to the import season, allowing no time for comments or clarification and contained many phytosanitary conditions that EU producers considered unjustified. This causes often unnecessary and unjustified trade disruptions

In 2019 Egypt incorporated the phytosanitary part of the conditions in a new plant health regulation and published the remaining conditions earlier in the year, allowing the EU to comment. Moreover, Egypt has agreed to accept certification according to EU standards for an important part of the phytosanitary requirements. However, Egypt has not given the EU a satisfactory answer on some of the plant health issues, which are still pending.

Furthermore, on 27 January 2021, Egypt submitted a new SPS notification to the WTO concerning a proposal of an import mechanism for seed potatoes based on field inspections conducted by Egyptian inspectors in the country of production.

It entail - pre-shipment field inspections in the country of origin of the seed potatoes by Egyptian inspectors; - submission of import applications from 15 April to 15 May of each year and - declaration of the quantity to be imported, the origin, the varieties, grower numbers, the expected date of arrival of the first and last shipment.

The EU has issued comments on this notification and continues the dialogue with the Egyptian authorities with the aim of ensuring that the EU producers can continue their export without disruptions. The field inspection requirement was suspended during the COVID period and then for 2023 too.

 The Commission continues to raise this issue with Egypt.

title: Bovine meat and meat products, ovine meat, live animals and genetic material
description:
As regards BSE, de-bone meat products must be sourced from cattle under 48 months old, and for boned meat products cattle under 30 months old. The OIE code states that not import conditions should be set regardless of the BSE status of the exporting country and therefore it can be exported from BSE affected countries following compliance with certain certifications requirements

Related to calves for slaughtering/fattening there is a compulsory inspection covering the entire pre-shipment quarantine period in the country of origin. Moreover, no clear rules in Halal requirements have been provided by Egypt, so certificates issued by religious authorities are not accepted. Finally, import requirements have been detailed and modified several times (finally Egypt notified its BSE import rules to the WTO SPS Committee in 2011). All these reasons converge in a long approval procedures and lack of transparency

title: Refusal of imports of timber wood and whey permeate due to their level of radioactivity
description:
In August 2020, an EU company exported beech timber to Egypt. The Egyptian General Organization for Export and Import Control (GOEIC) denied the import of a part of the shipment alleging contamination with Caesium 137 (Cs-137).
The shipment was measured at the customs port for radiation levels, with a Geiger counter. However, the exporter did not receive any supporting document confirming the higher values of radionuclides and radiation of the beech timber, and only subsequently received information that the value of Cs-137 was ca. 5 Bq/kg (Becquerel/kilogram) per sample.

The international Basic Safety Standard for radionuclides concentrations, GSR-3, in Table I.2, recommends activity concentrations per radionuclide in any solid material, above which the material falls under the regulatory control. For Cs-137, the listed figure is 0.1 Bq/g = 100 Bq/kg.

In November 2021, Egypt started blocking importation of other products than timber wood (whey permeate, office furniture) that demonstrated any level of radioactivity.  

In March 2022, EUD was informed of Customs Circular no. 4060 (attached) that requires all food imports from certain origins to be cleared by the Egyptian Food Safety Authority as regards their radiation levels. The list includes 11 MS (all new MS).Issue was raised in MAAC meetings in July 2022 and February 2023.

title: Mandatory use of the letter of credit as prior condition for imports
description:
In February 2022, the Egyptian authorities introduced the mandatory use of the Letter of Credit (L/C) as prior condition for imports. The measure enables the Central Bank of Egypt (CBE) to control demand on currency for imports by delaying the issuance of the L/C. Accordingly, several economic operators across industry sectors are experiencing delays in the issuance of their L/C.

In terms of the measure’s design and operation, the L/C is to be opened before the shipment takes place from the supplier. The usage of the L/C is now a pre-requisite for the issuance by the Customs Authority of the Advance Cargo Information Declaration (ACID) number, as it has become one of the mandatory export documents that must be submitted in the system before the number is issued and the shipments can be authorised.

This new measure leads also to more administrative burden and costs, delaying the import process, and de facto limiting the import volume given the limited cash of importers. This is because the use of L/Cs requires Egyptian banks to guarantee and take over the risk for all transactions. However, in order to maintain their risk rating, Egyptian banks cannot guarantee all transactions and they will prioritise those specific products and transactions designated as more secure, while refusing the issuance of L/Cs for the others.

While several exemptions from the measure exist, they are only valid for specific cases or sectors and their implementation remains uncertain.

The official document implementing this measure has not been published up until this stage, but the measure is being implemented.

The measure is horizontal and all Member states are affected.Issue was discussed  in MAAC meetings in July 2022 and February 2023

title: Mandatory registration of factories exporting to Egypt (Decrees 43/2016 and 44/2019)
description:
Registration: Refer to Ministerial Decrees No. 43/2016 and 44/2019

  • Mandatory registration of companies in order to create a registry of factories exporting certain products (including i.a. agricultural products, cosmetics, toys, textiles and garments) to Egypt. Decree 43/2016 entered into force on 16 March 2016. Among the documents required for the registration, the Decree includes a certificate that the producer and/or the trademark owner maintain "a quality control system." On 15 January 2019, the coverage of Decree 43/2016 was extended to further categories of goods (sacks, bags, shaving and hair care equipment/articles, and telephone sets) by Decree 44/2019 .
  • Issue discussed at the MAAC meeting in July 2022 and February 2023.

title: Valuation of imports for the purposes of customs clearance
description:
As a WTO Member, Egypt is subject to the Customs Valuation Agreement. Thus, under the Articles 11 and 22 of the Customs Law 66/1963, amended by Law 95/2005 it is set that an ad valorem tariff will be paid on the declared value, namely the real value of the goods plus the related costs.

However, the Egyptian customs authorities do not always comply with this principle and customs valuation is being carried out on a discretionary basis. Likewise, the authorities reject the value declared in the commercial invoice whereas there is a discrepancy in the HS code of the imported good, against merchandises usually encoded with a higher tariff. In addition, as it is the case, a fine of the same value of the levied tariff is applied and has to be paid by the operators.

Customs authorities in Egypt refuse recognizing importers´ commercial invoice, even if sealed by the Chamber of Commerce in the country of origin.

There is also s specific side of this practice: the valuation uplifts for spare parts under service contracts. The EU was alerted to the fact that Egypt applies a 50% value uplift to all shipments of spare parts as a result of reference to 'internet pricing'. As this concerns spare parts for service contract support, there is no commercial transaction and the hardware is supplied free of charge (under warranty). Such shipments cannot be declared at a transaction value of zero, therefore they should be declared using an alternative valuation methodology, i.e. the sixth valuation method (“fallback”), in accordance with the regulation of the valuation agreement of the World Trade Organization and article 27 of Decree 10/2006 of the Executive Regulations for the Egyptian Customs Law No. 66 of 1963. The 50% uplift based on unauthorized sources (‘internet pricing’) provides no legitimate basis for comparison with or evaluation of actual declared import values and has no connection to the importer. While the Egyptian law does provide for an opportunity to have the goods released under protest (based on article 31 of Decree 10/2006 mentioned above), this implies an increased cost in tariffs as the result of a non-WTO compliant valuation.

title: Import permits for chilled, frozen and processed meat
description:
Exporters from the EU and their local trade partners dealing with processed meat, including luncheon meat, have reported that as per decree 2080 of 2018 they are required to apply to the standing committee to obtain import permits. Their applications are orally rejected, with no justification. 

Prime Minister’s Decree No. 2080 for the year 2018, signed on 12 October 2018, sets up a permanent Committee for Livestock, Fisheries and Poultry chaired by the Deputy Minister of Agriculture and Land Reclamation. The Committee is responsible for:

  • Constantly updating the livestock database and all needed veterinary vaccines;
  • Setting the number of livestock heads to be imported as well as countries to import them from, based on the epidemic situation specified by the Ministry of Agriculture and Land Reclamation;
  • Quantifying the needs of the local market as regards chilled, frozen and processed meat.

The existence of this import permit scheme has structural difficulties like a quota-like system prohibited by the EU-Egypt FTA, the lack of transparency of committee meetings, and the lack of the possibility of appeal.

title: Temporary restriction of import of certain medicines
description: Gabon decided through an Order, on 11 November 2022, to limit the imports of some 50 pharmaceutical products to Gabon. The affected molecules are as follows: Albendazole, Paracétamol, Azithromycine, Levocetrizine, Metformine, Sulfamethoxazole, Ciprofloxacine, Amlodipine, Ibuprofene, Metronidazole, Doxycycline, Floconazole, Carbocistérine, Fer, Acide Folique, and Erythromycin. The measure to reduce imports of these medicinal products is valid for five years from the date of signature of the Order. The Gabonese authorities have given a waiver to a number of companies for each molecule affected by the ban to continue the import. The criteria under which the waivers have been given to certain companies is not clear.

title: Technical specifications for commercial vehicles
description:
Hong Kong’s dimensional and weight regulations for commercial vehicles (CVs) are substantially more restrictive than equivalent regulation in Europe. As a result, European manufacturers cannot sell their products in the Hong Kong market.

More recently, additional issues were raised by the industry when it comes to bringing CVs to Hong Kong – in relation with in vehicles new technologies and alternative fuel and electric CVs.

title: Spirits - Taxation and storage
description:
EU spirits industry in Hong Kong faces two barriers: taxation and storage requirements.

Taxation: The excise duty applied by Hong Kong China on spirit drinks (defined as liquor with alcohol strength of more than 30% by volume) is 100 percent ad valorem, compared with a zero duty on wine and other alcohol drinks.

Storage: Hong Kong China imposes a dangerous goods licence requirement for the storage of potable spirits containing more than 30% alcohol by volume (Dangerous Goods Ordinance). This is not consistent with international practice, limits the number of bonded warehouses that can operate, and further increases the costs of spirits importers.

title: Selective tendering procurement
description:
Hong Kong's procurement regime is complex and opaque and doesn't seem to comply with the WTO's GPA (Hong Kong is a signatory) due to the use of a "probation period" – during which contractors can only bid for contracts of limited value. There are only two ways for a contractor to exit the probation period and start bidding for the largest contracts: (i) gaining the required level of "local experience" by completing smaller contracts or (ii) forming a joint venture with a contractor who is already out of probation.

Hong Kong procurement system could encourage more innovative and sustainable tenders – including due to the conservative nature of the tenders; too much weight being given to the lowest price criteria (vs technical scores) and HK civil servants being risk averse.

The accreditation and certification for engineers seems to be based on works done in Hong Kong, giving less weight to experience from outside Hong Kong.

title: Quality Control Orders on footwear
description:
On 27 October 2020, India notified three Quality Control Orders (QCOs) to the WTO related to:

  • Personal Protective Equipment Footwear;
  • Footwear made from Leather and Other materials and;
  • Footwear made from all Rubber and all Polymeric material and its Components.

Under these QCOs, no leather products can be produced, sold, traded, imported or stocked unless they bear the Bureau of Indian Standards (BIS) mark. The BIS will be the certifying and enforcement body for these goods. In total 26 products are covered by the three QCOs, which diverge slightly from ISO standards.

In order to obtain a BIS mark, each factory must be audited, a process, which is both time consuming (minimum 6 months) and cost thousands of EUR (from 5,000 to 10,000 EUR per factory).

Entry into force was delayed multiple times: The implementation of the QCOs was postponed originally until 1 July 2021. On 30 June 2021, India delayed further the entry into force to 1 January 2022 (for QCO 1: Personal Protective Equipment Footwear) and 1 July 2022 (QCOs 2 & 3: Footwear made from Leather and Other materials and Footwear made from all Rubber and all Polymeric material and its Components

On 3 June 2022, the Department for Promotion of Industry and Internal Trade (DPIIT) notified fresh Quality Control Orders pertaining to:

  • Footwear Made from all-Rubber and all Polymeric Material and its Components (Quality Control) Order, 2022
  • Footwear Made from Leather and Other Materials (Quality Control) Order, 2022

The entry into force of both the above Orders will be effective from 1 July 2023. These are new Orders and the old ones from 2020 have been rescinded.

While, the substance of the QCOs on footwear still remains the same, there has been a delay with regard to the entry into force, previously scheduled for 1 July 2022, now moved to a year later. A small victory, but we need to continue to fight the battle on substance.

However, through an Order dated 11 August 2022, India amended the QCO on Footwear by adding a para “Provided further that nothing in this Order shall apply to micro and small manufacturing units as defined under section 7 of the Micro, Small and Medium Enterprises Development Act, 2006 (27 of 2006), as amended from time to time.”

Four products (sports footwear, rubber hawai chappal, rubber slipper and PVC sandal) will come under mandatory certification from 1 January 2024. 

Also, India through an Order dated 15 March 2024, has exempted the following footwear components from the QCO on Footwear Made from all Rubber and all Polymeric Material and its Components used in manufacturing of footwear in India for export only.

  • Moulded rubber outsoles
  • Microcellular Rubber sheets for outsoles
  • Moulded PVC outsoles
  • PU outsoles

title: Steel products - mandatory certification requirements
description:
Over a period of time, India has been trying to bring more and more steel products under the mandatory certification scheme operated by the Bureau of Indian Standards (BIS). These products are covered under different Steel and Steel Products (Quality Control) Orders. Initially, BIS brought 20 products under the mandatory certification scheme. Subsequently, 18 products were added through different Orders taking the total number of products to 38. The BIS certification procedure adds to additional burden and costs for EU steel companies for obtaining certification, which implies additional tests for products, which have already been tested.

India on 13 August 2018, came out with the Steel and Steel Products (Quality Control) Order, 2018 wherein it notified 54 products. One standard (IS 7904:1995) cease to exist after 18 November 2018. 5 standards (IS 4454 (Part I) : 2001, IS 4454 (Part II) : 2001, IS 4824 : 2006, IS 11169 (Part I) : 1984 and IS 6603 : 2001) have been kept outside the purview of this Order till 17 February 2019 and IS 7904 : 2017 shall come into effect from 19.2.2019.

All the steel and steel products were consolidated and notified under the Steel and Steel Products (Quality Control) Order 2020. which targets 145 steel and steel products. The QCOs for majority of these products are already in force. However, it remains unclear to the EU which of Quality Control Orders for steel products are already in force. India defers from time-to-time the date of implementation of certain steel products. 

India explained at the WTO TBT Committee that the BIS standards are required in order to take into account local manufacturing practices of India and, therefore, international standards are not sufficient.

Not only does India impose BIS-specific standards, in addition, testing is to be performed locally (BIS recognised labs): India should at least accept that tests can be carried out in foreign accredited laboratories attesting compliance with ISO standards (or BIS Indian standards) thus not requiring local testing in India for all types of steel products, and not to conduct factory inspections in the EU steel mills having in place a quality management system as defined in ISO 9001.

The recently issued list of accredited laboratories (11th October 2017) does not include any laboratories outside of India.

Additionally, the QCOs require physical audit by an auditor of the Bureau of Indian Standards (BIS) in order for products manufactured in third countries to receive the approval for exports to India. The on-going COVID-19 pandemic and international travel restrictions linked thereto have negative impact on certification process in India, especially for foreign companies with production facilities outside India.  The EU would also like to support the introduction of virtual/remote inspection for BIS conformity assessment in the steel sector. Alternative inspection methods are crucial to maintain access to Indian market.

The Technical Division of the Ministry of Steel through an Order dated 6th February 2023, extended the date of enforcement for Ferronickel by 6 months to 23 July 2023. The product falls under the Steel and Steel Products (Quality Control) Order 2020 dated 22 December 2020. This was further extended to 23 January 2024 by an Order dated 25 July 2023.

As per the Monthly Summary for January 2023 released by the Ministry of Steel, there are 144 Indian Standards on steel and steel products that are in force.

From time to time, EU makes supporting Statement on QCO on Steel and Steel Products at the TBT Committee meeting.

On 26 October 2023, the Technical Division of the Ministry of Steel issued a Circular stating that all steel importers importing steel without BIS license need to mandatorily apply and seek clarification from Ministry of Steel through QCO Portal for each and every imported steel consignment.

To streamline the implementation of the QCOs, the Ministry of Steel had constituted a Technical Committee for examination and analysis of the application(s) received for issuance of clarification, whether the product(s) which are being imported without BIS certification are covered under Steel QCO or not.

According to the Circular, the Ministry of Steel issues clarification for each single import consignment. In this regard, it is further clarified that for each and every consignment, the importer needs to submit fresh application through TCQCO Portal, unless stated otherwise in the clarification issued.

Through the Steel and Steel Products (Quality Control) Order 2020, Ministry of Steel has been issuing QCOs to widen the scope of coverage to add more grades of steel and related products.

On 5 February 2024, India notified Steel and Steel Products (Quality Control) Order 2024 in supersession of the Steel and Steel Products (Quality Control) Order, 2020, dated 22 December, 2020. In total 157 products were notified under the new Order.  This Order shall apply to steel and steel products specified in column (3) of Schedule 1 and goods or articles specified in column (2) of Schedule 2 of this Order.

On 29 August 2024, India notified Steel and Steel Products (Quality Control) Order 2024 in supersession of the Steel and Steel Products (Quality Control) Order, 2024, dated 5 February, 2024. In total 152 products were notified, of which, entry into force of 3 products is foreseen for 8 November 2024.

In the recently announced Budget 2024-25, India reduced Basic Customs Duty (BCD) on Ferro-nickel from 2.5% to Nil. Similarly, India extended Nil import duty on Ferrous Scrap and Certain specified raw materials for manufacture of CRGO Steel till 31 March 2026.

title: Slow approval procedures for the import of animals and their products
description: The requirements for the import into India of animals and tier products is distributed by several authorities - the Department of Animal Husbandry of India (DAHD, https://dahd.gov.in/), the Department of Fisheries (DF, https://dof.gov.in/), and the Food Safety and Standards Authority of India (FSSAI, https://fssai.gov.in/). India's requirements include health certificates issued by these authorities in isolation or jointly, and standards by the FSSAI. In certain cases, the India authorities perform audits to the exporting countries. Despite having approved several market access applications of Member States, these authorities follow a slow (and often unclear and unpredictable) approval procedures for the import of animals and their products, such as dairy products (e.g. cheeses), pork meat and pork products, and fishery products (fresh and processed).

title: Slow approval procedures, unpredictable pre-shipments' process, and restrictions on imports of plants and plant products (alternatives to methyl bromide)
description:
In its Plant Quarantine Order 2003 (a consolidated version of which can be pound at http://plantquarantineindia.nic.in/pqispub/html/pqo_amendments.htm), India requires, for most plants and plant products, treatment with methyl bromide (MB) prior or upon arrival in India, and provides already for a number of allows alternative treatments. The use of MB in the European Union is forbidden.


In 2017, India has suggested EU Member States to review the pests and measures included in the Order 2003 for any given commodity, and to provide evidence that the alternatives to mitigate the pests in the territory of the Member States are at least as efficient as MB. Afterwards, India introduced a "10 pre-shipments" based process before approving imports. Several Member States have proposed alternatives to MB and started the pre-shipment process. However, the process remains slow and uncertain - the process takes place without a written procedure and is sometimes interrupted without explanations by India as to the pests found.  


MB is addressed in the Montreal Protocol on Substances that Deplete the Ozone Layer and by the International Plant Protection Organisation IPPC, and should not be used.

On 13 October 2022, the Department of Agricultutre and Farmers Welfare of India (DAFW) issued Gazette Notification vide S.O. 4871(E) about the methyl bromide (MB) phased out country status, which changed the Plant Quarantine (Regulation of Import into India) Order, 2003. 

End 2022, the DAFW sent a letter to the Commission asking about the status of MS in the EU. 

On 12 January 2023, the Commission reieterated what it had included in the letter it had sent to India in 2019 (which remains unchanged): plant protection products containing MB are not authorised to be used in any of the Member States of the European Union (since 2010), namely for quarantine and pre-shipment purposes. informed India again that MB cannot be used in the EU for plant quarantine purposes. A written reponse from India is awaited.

title: Cosmetics (registration and standards)
description:
• The registration process for imported cosmetic products is burdensome ;
  • On 12 December 2018, registration fees for imported cosmetics were set at a much higher level than for local products ;
  • Domestic companies can apply for perpetual licensing which is not the case for imported products who have to re-register their products every 3 years (while local manufacturers only register their manufacturing sites) ; 
  • India is not recognizing the international standards and Indian standards are not aligned with the ISO ones. Moreover, importers cannot become member of the Indian normalization body and therefore cannot participate to the development of the national standard.

Updated in October 2024:

For decades, cosmetics in India were regulated under Drugs and Cosmetics Act 1940 and the Drug and Cosmetics Rules 1945. However, these rules, primarily focused on pharmaceuticals, with limited provisions for cosmetics. To establish a more comprehensive and modernized regulatory framework specifically for cosmetics, India launched a regulatory reform, introducing the Cosmetics Rules 2020 on December 15, 2020, which came into immediate effect.

The new rules have streamlined and clarified the regulatory requirements for the import, manufacture, and distribution of cosmetics in India. They also place greater accountability on importers and manufacturers to ensure the quality of their products. In India, the oversight of cosmetics involves multiple authorities at both the central and state levels. The primary national regulatory body is the Central Drugs Standard Control Organization (CDSCO), which operates under the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare (MoHFW). The Drugs Controller General of India (DCGI) heads the CDSCO and serves as the Central Licensing Authority, responsible for amending the 2020 Rules, granting Import Registration Certificates, and regulating cosmetic imports into India, among other duties. At the state level, State Licensing Authorities (SLAs) are responsible for implementing the 1940 Act and 2020 Rules, issuing manufacturing licenses, conducting inspections, and monitoring regulatory compliance within their respective jurisdictions.

For first-time registrations of imported cosmetics, for a foreign manufacturer, it shall be necessary to appoint an authorized agent in India to acts on his behalf in matters related to approvals, registration, and importation of cosmetics. The Indian agent serves as a liaison between the manufacturer and the CDSCO, assisting with document submission and ensuring compliance with regulatory requirements. The authorization from the foreign manufacturer should be duly authenticated by a first-class Magistrate in India, the Indian Embassy in the country of origin, or an equivalent authority.

title: Labelling requirements for Maximum Retail Price
description:
As per section 18 of the Legal Metrology Act, 2009 (‘LMA’) read with Rule 2(k) of the Legal Metrology (Packaged Commodities) Rules, 2011 (‘LPMC Rules’) sale of packaged commodities, including imported packages, are allowed to be sold, delivered, distributed only if such package contains MRP labelling declarations. Further, as per Condition No. 5 of General Notes regarding Import Policy, ITC (HS), 2017 all packaged products imported into India need to carry declarations prescribed under Legal Metrology (Packaged Commodities) Rules, 2011 (as amended from time to time1).
Pursuant to the above, the Customs Authorities under CBIC had permitted such labelling to be conducted in a Customs Bonded Warehouse to ensure compliance to the LMPC Rules and the FTP provisions. However, for companies having an AEO-T2 certification, there is a relaxation that such companies would be given the facility to do MRP labelling activity post import of goods, in their own premises (not under customs supervision). This has been stated under serial no (x) of para 1.5.2 of Circular No. 33/2016-Customs dated July 22, 2016 issued by the CBIC. While the above stated relaxation to carry out MRP labelling activity by AEO-T2 companies in their own premises has been stated under the Customs Circular (as referred above), it appears that no specific notification to this effect has been issued by the DGFT stating this relaxation.

 

NOTE: the QCO on Toys is affecting also EU single brand retailers

title: Intellectual Property Rights
description:
India’s Intellectual Property Rights environment often lacks stability and predictability. Inventors have reported to face serious impediments in securing patents and protection in India. This increasingly impacts investment decisions and it is a strong deterrent especially for SMEs interested in the Indian market. Specific concerns are notably the following:

 As for the IPR legislation:

  • Restrictive patentability criteria ( i.e application of "Section 3d" - restricting grant of patent for incremental innovation in the pharma sector)
  • Broad criteria for granting compulsory licences ( a few compulsory licence has been granted since 2012);
  • The absence of an effective system for protecting undisclosed test and other data generated to obtain marketing approval for pharmaceutical and agricultural chemical products against unfair commercial use, as well as unauthorized disclosure;
  • Patent working requirement: with the last amendment to the Patents Act in 2005, key changes are urgently required as long-standing issues remain for innovative industries. The potential threat of compulsory licenses and patent revocations, and the narrow patentability criteria under the India Patents Act, burden companies across different sectors. Moreover, patent applicants continue to confront costly and time-consuming pre- and post-grant oppositions, long waiting periods to receive patent approval, and excessive reporting requirements
  • Unclear scope of the Sept 2016 Office Memorandum concerning Section 31D of the Copyright Act: broadcasting vs. streaming.

 As for IPR enforcement:

  • Delays in registration of patents, GIs and trademarks, due to cumbersome procedures and limited manpower by IPR authorities;
  • Widespread piracy in the sectors of video gaming, music and movie industry; custom authority lacking skills and resources to fight infringments
  • Weak IPR enforcement, with insufficient action by relevant authorities to fight IPR infringements;
  • Backlogs in Civil Courts for IPR cases: The Commercial Courts Act, enacted in 2015 and amended in 2018, was established to help reduce delays and increase expertise in judicial IP matters.  However, to date, only a limited number of courts have benefited under the Act.  Rights holders report that jurisdictional challenges have reduced the effectiveness of the commercial courts, and that inadequate resources for staffing and training continue.
  • Large number of locally produced infringing goods especially regarding patents and trademarks in the pharmaceutical : Indian law does not protect against unfair commercial use, nor against the unauthorized disclosure of undisclosed test or other data submitted to the government during the application for market approval of pharmaceutical or agrochemical products.
  • There is no statutory protection of trade secrets in India, which creates uncertainty for businesses needing to secure sensitive information exchanged between parties.  Protection and enforcement of trade secrets is challenging as there are no civil or criminal laws in India that specifically address their protection.  
  • On July 23, 2021, India’s Department Related Parliamentary Standing Committee on Commerce (DRPSCC), presented its 161st Report on “Review of the Intellectual Property Rights Regime in India”.  The Report emphasizes that the IPR regime should be in compliance with international agreements, rules and norms, and be compatible with those of other nations and foreign entities.  While many of the recommendations in the Report are welcomed, some recommendations, such as those relating to compulsory licenses and online broadcasting, raise serious concerns and are regarded as problematic for IP rights holders.

title: DS 380 India-Certain taxes and other measures on imported wines and spirits
description:
On 22 September 2008 the EC requested DSU consultations with India on certain tax measures and other import measures applied at State level on imported wines and spirits.

 

October 2024:  In a positive move, the Andhra Pradesh government has notified its new excise policy for the period from October 12, 2024, to September 30, 2026 withdrawing the retail liquor business from the government and allowing private retailers to sell liquor through 3736 shops.

title: Mandatory veterinary certificates for importing leather
description:
Indian trade authorities ask for the import of finished leather that the goods are accompanied by a veterinary certificate stating the innocuousness of the animal material. INDIA applies to a finished product of HS 4107, technical requirements that apply only to products of HS 4101-4103. A veterinary certificate for leather is absurd, as the material has no longer the attributes of the raw animal product.

By end 2021, India published office memorandum dated 17 December 2021 exempting most leather products from the requirement of veterinary certificate. 

October 2024:  In April 2022 EU asked for the exemption of three additional leather tariff lines that have not yet been exempted. The issue has been raised repeatedly in the 4th and 5th EU India Technical Working Group (TWG) on Animal Health. Indian side replied that the incidence of Lumpy Skin Disease in India; from which the country had freedom in the past, has raised a serious concern in the matter and the relevant notifications may be reviewed in the coming future in a scientific manner, as well as in terms of Ease of Doing Business.

title: Ban on the sale of imported alcoholic beverages products in Canteen Department Stores
description:
On 12 May, Prime Minister Modi called, in his address to the Nation, for a ‘Self-Reliant India’, i.e. to go local and protect and strengthen Indian industries’ competitivity in the context post COVID-19. Following that announcement, it was reported in the press (see here) that the Minister of Defence, responsible for the Canteen Stores Department (CSD), was considering to review its procurement rules to allow the sale of only domestic products in these shops. Following that:

  • A mail was circulated to suppliers of imported alcoholic beverages requiring them to state the origin of products supplies, which wasn’t required previously.
  • All orders of supplies for imported alcoholic beverages were put on hold.

October 2024: Since October 2020, India has stopped selling imported products in military canteen shops. The issue was raised in the EU-India Joint Working Group on SPS-TBT, the EU-India Sub-Commission on Trade, and the EU-India JWG Agriculture. None of these actions resulted in positive developments. In the bilateral meetings, India responded, that this was a decision of the Ministry of Defence, and that it would not have an impact on EU exports since there was no import restriction.

title: Licencing scheme for importing tyres
description:
Through Notification No. 12/2015-2020 dated 12 June 2020, the Indian Government decided to impose curbs on imports of certain new pneumatic tyres used in motor cars, busses, lorries and motorcycles in a move to promote domestic manufacturing, at a time of economic difficulties due to the COVID 19 crisis. The decision changes the import policy of new pneumatic tyres from free to restricted. 

Putting the goods under restricted category means that an importer would now require a license or permission from the DGFT for its imports. This further measure has the immediate effect of temporarily closing the market for European exports to the country, before importers are granted a license.

The procedure to obtain the licence has not been published in its entirety notably the licensing authority requires supplementary information from tyre manufacturers which is additional to the published proceedure. Furthermore, the guidelines for license allocation have also not been published. No transitional period for application of licenses was granted.

According to the General Guidelines Regarding Imports and Exports, when the imports are subject to authorisation, the “actual user alone may import such good(s) unless actual user condition is specifically dispensed with by DGFT” (Art. 2.10). The definition of “Actual user” is given in another document (here, Chapter 9.03). However, in the case of tyres, it appears impossible to comply with such criteria.

On 17 November 2020, a joint letter signed by Ambassadors of EU and MSs ((FR, IT, DE, CZ and PL) was sent to Mr. Piyush Goyal, Minister of Commerce and Industry. So far, we have had no response from Minister Goyal. 

Subsequently, jointly with same group of MSs Commercial Counsellors, the Delegation on 21 January 2021 organised a meeting with Additional Director General of Foreign Trade Hardeep Singh. Issues faced by OEMs and tyre manufacturers were explained to him. After listening to the concerns, Mr. Singh stated that licences are being issued and delays have been significantly reduced. All OEMs are getting the licenses requested. DGFT did not agree to our request for guidelines and conveyed that the published form was sufficient. Additionally, they shared that if any company/MS has a specific concern, they should approach them bilaterally and assured EU its support. The EU and Member States agreed to continue to engage with DGFT in this regard.

The issue of licensing requirement for imports of tyres was raised by EVP Valdis Dombrovskis with Minister Piyush Goyal at the High Level Dialogue (HLD) meeting on 5.2.2021. Unfortunately, India was not willing to find a positive solution to the issue.

A meeting with the Director General of DGFT was held on this issues on 4 May 2022, unfortunately, no concrete result came out from the meeting.  

On 2 August 2023, the Department for Promotion of Industry and Internal Trade (DPIIT) announced the fresh Guidelines for Tyre Manufacturers. The details, however, are not yet known as the attached paper released by the DPIIT says that the specific details are available with the concerned division of DPIIT.  

As per the paper, the proposed fresh guidelines have been proposed considering the overall growth of the Indian tyre industry. However, India has put a condition that manufacturers should commit to invest in India in brownfield or greenfield projects for manufacturing tyres. The condition put by India that companies should invest in brownfield or greenfield projects is clearly in the direction towards Make in India.

The guidelines were never put in public domain.

title: Export duties on raw and semi-finished leather
description:
In October 2000, India lifted its export restrictions (de facto export ban) in the leather sector, but simultaneously, the export duty on raw hides and skins and certain semi-finished leather was raised from 25 % to 60 %, which is the highest rate in the world (Notification No. 132/2000-Customs). Certain leathers are exempted from the 60 % export duty rate, and lower export duties are applied on the following items (Notification No. 133/2000-Customs)

- E.I. tanned leather 15%
- Snake skin 10%
- Raw fur lamb skins 10%
- Luggage leather - case hide or side/suit case/bag luggage/cash bag leather 25%
- Cycle saddle leathers 15%
- Hydraulic/packing/belting/washer leathers 15%
- Industrial harness leather 25%
- Picking band leathers 15%
- Strap/combing leathers 15%
- Transistor case/camera case leathers 25%.

This comes on top of India’s existing export duties on hides and skins (60%).

In the Budget 2019-20 announced on 5 July, India reduced export duty on EI Tanned Leather and Hides, Skins and leathers, tanned and untanned, all sorts. Following are the new rates:

  • Export duty has been reduced from 15% to NIL on EI tanned leather
  • Export duty has been reduced from 60% to 40% on hides, skins and leather, tanned and untanned, all sorts.

In the Budget 2022-23, India reduced export duty on raw hides and skins of buffalo. The new export duty rate will come into effect from 2.2.2022. Export duty has been reduced from 40% to 30% on raw hides and skins of buffalo.

In the Budget 2024-25, India rationalised the export duties on raw hides, skins and leather. The changes were carried out through Notification No. 37/2024-Customs dated 23 July 2024. The details and comparison are given in the Table below:

title: Export duties on raw and semi-finished steel products and iron ore
description:
Through Customs Notification No. 28/2022-Customs dated 21 May 2022, India increased export duty on Iron Ore and Concentrates (non-Agglomerated) and Iron Ore and Concentrates (Agglomerated) other than iron ore pellets to 50%. Export duty was also reinstated on iron ore pellets at 45%. Pig iron and spiegeleisen in pigs, blocks or other primary forms at 15%. 

Through Customs notification (No. 27/2011) of 1 March 2011, the Indian Government has increased the rate of export duty for all types of iron or at a unified level of 20% ad valorem (the previous rates being 5% for iron ore fines and 15% for iron ore lumps). These duties were subsequently raised from 20% to 30% on 30 December 2011.

Export duty on iron ore pellets was removed on 4 January 2016. Similary, export duty of 15% was introduced through Customs Notification 66/2008-Customs dated 10.5.2008 on ferrous waste and scrap, re-melting scrap ingots of iron or steel.

As of 4 March 2022, export duties are on the following items:

Iron Ore pellets (HS 26011210) - Nil, Bauxite (natural) not calcined or calcined  (HS 26060010 & 26060020) - 15%, Other aluminium ores and concentrates (HS 26060090) - 30%, Other aluminium ores including laterite (HS 26060090) - 15%, Ilmenite, unprocessed (HS 26140010) - 10%, Ilmenite, upgraded (beneficiated ilmenite including ilmenite ground) (HS 26140020) - 2.5%.

Through Customs Notification 58/2022-Customs dated 18.11.2022, export duty was brought down from 15% to 'Nil' for the following products:

  • Steel Flat rolled products of iron or non-alloy steel, hot rolled, not clad, plated or coated
  • Flat rolled products of iron or non-alloy steel, cold rolled (cold-reduced), not clad, plated or coated
  • Flat-rolled products of iron or non-alloy steel, of a width of 600 mm or more, clad, plated or coated
  • Bars and rods, hot-rolled, in irregularly wound coils, of iron or non-alloy steel
  • Other bars and rods of iron or non-alloy steel, not further worked than forged, hot-rolled, hot-drawn or hot-extruded, but including those twisted after rolling

title: Draft - Quality Control Order for furniture
description:
The draft Quality Control Order (QCO) for furniture sets product requirements through prescribing mandatory use of (recently developed) Indian standards for specific furniture items (work chairs, general purpose chairs and stools, tables and desks, storage units, beds and bunk beds). The purpose of the QCO is to ensure that products meet certain prescribed quality, safety and performance requirements before they can be manufactured, imported, stored or sold in India.

Currently, compliance with the existing Indian standards is voluntary for the above cited furniture articles, but will become compulsory once the QCO enters into force. The measure is not in force yet. It was notified through the WTO TBT Enquiry Point to WTO members on 27 September 2023 (G/TBT/N/IND/318). The date of adoption was not indicated in the notification. The draft provides that the measure will enter into force 12 months after its adoption and publication.

title: Certification requirements of tyres
description:
By Quality Control Order 2009, India placed pneumatic tyres (including tubes) under mandatory certification, not reflecting UN-ECE standards. Since 13 May 2011, the mandatory certification requirements put an extra administrative and financial burden on importers in the form of marking fees charged per tyre produced, minimum fee amount, lengthy certification procedure, unnecessary factory inspections, bank guarantee, short license validity. Additionally, on 11 December 2014, BIS informed it was changing the on-tyre license number marking system, requiring that currently licensed tyres are also marked under the scheme, which requires modifying the marking moulds, which is costly. In relation to this, IN has not notified the scheme under the TBT. Situation has remained unchanged to date.

India has ensured that Indian tyre industry is protected and bare minimum imports enter India.

title: Standards and labelling programme for tyres
description:
India is establishing minimum requirements (wet grip and rolling resistance) and labelling for tyres. The requirements diverge from international rules and uncertainty remains for the EU industry.

  • On labelling: Schedule-30([1])

Schedule-30: Standards and Labelling (S&L) programme for Tyres by the Bureau of Energy Efficiency (BEE), has been voluntarily in force since 14 December 2021. EUDEL has been informed that Schedule-30 will officially be implemented from 1 January 2024, but this was postponed until end 2024. It applies to passenger car tyres (C1), light truck tyres (C2) and heavy truck tyres (C3) covered under scope of AIS:142, that are manufactured, imported and sold in India.

  • On minimum requirements for wet grip and rolling resistance: Amended Automotive Industry Standards (AIS) 142:2019

The Amended AIS 142:2019 has been applied since October 2021. However, its implementation was deferred by Notification dated 20 June 2023, wherein the date of implementation for standards on Rolling Resistance and Wet Grip has been extended until 1 January 2024 and for Rolling Sound to 1 October 2024, and more recently until end 2024. Minimum requirements introduced by Amended AIS 142:2019 differ from the UNECE Regulation 117, which is widely used, including by the EU.

([1])   https://www.beestarlabel.com/Content/Files/Schedule_30.pdf

Through an Advisory dated 26 October 2023 from the Bureau of Energy Efficiency (BEE), the validity of star rating table of Tyres was extended till 31 December 2024. Accordingly, the revised sample label validity period is 1 January 2022 to 31 December 2024. 

For models already approved by BEE, the manufacturers/permittees have to submit the proforma enclosed with this advisory for their willingness to continue the registered models with BEE beyond 31 December 2023. The Advisory further stated that no continuation of application for models would be accepted beyond 31 December 2023 and models for which such requests are not received timely shall get deactivated automatically after 31 December 2023.

title: Telecommunications - licensing requirements/mandatory testing
description:
India planned to introduce security testing of telecommunication equipment since 2017. Facing the risk of disruption of the supply chain, the government postponed the onset of the measures several times, until announcing to finally launch it on 1 October 2019 (wireline and radio equipment) in Phase-I. Phase-II was brought into force from 1 October 2020 for transmission terminal equipment (SDH Equipment, Multiplexing Equipment), PON family of broadband equipment (PON ONT, PON OLT and PON ONU), Feedback Devices. Then from 11 October 2021, phase-III and phase-IV of the Manadatory Testing and Certification of Telecom Equipment was brought in force. Products included under Phase- III are Base station for cellular network, repeater for cellular network, compact cellular network, smart/CCTV camera, smart watch, smart electricity meter, tracking device, IoT gateway, end point device for environmental monitoring and equipment operating in 2.4 GHz and 5 GHz band. Products included under Phase-IV are Transmission terminal equipment (DWDM, DXC), optical fibre (single mode), satellite communication equipment, radio broadcaster receiver, mobile radio trunking system, HF radio, VHF/UHF Radio system Equipment, PTP PMP Microwave Fixed Radio Systems, IP Security Equipment, Router, LAN Switch, Precision Timing Protocol Grand Master Equipment, IP Multi Media Conferencing Equipment, Mobility Management Entity (MME) and Point of Sale Devices. While the date of Phase-III and Phase-IV coming into force is same, the dates of the certification becoming mandatory are different: 1 July 2022 (Phase-III), 1 February 2022 (Phase-IV - EMI/EMC and Safety) and 1 July 2022 (Phase-IV - Remaining ER parameters). Products included under Phase-V are Base station for cellular network for 5G, 5G Core, hypervisor, e band fixed radio delay systems, Converged Multi Service Application Access Equipment (C-MSAAE), IP Terminal, Hybrid Set Top box, for which mandatory certification requirement comes into force on 1 July 2024.

The date of implementation of Phase-III and Phase-IV was initially postponed to 1 July 2023 on request of the industry citing reasons that Phase-III and Phase-IV implementation could impact the 5G launch in India. This was pushed multiple times, first to 1 October 2023 for selected products, later to 1 January 2024 for 32 products (https://www.tec.gov.in/pdf/MTCTE/MTCTE_Amd_Notif.pdf), followed by a revised deadline of 1 April 2024 for 12 products (https://www.tec.gov.in/pdf/MTCTE/extension%20for%2012%20products.pdf), and a further revision to 1 August 2024 for 10 products, eventual revised deadline of 1 October 2024 for 5 products (final list: https://www.tec.gov.in/pdf/MTCTE/MTCTE%20Extension-%20Oct%2024.pdf).

Presently, such products can be tested and certified in laboratories globally, or at in-house laboratories of the manufacturers (self-certification). Mandatory testing and certification by Indian laboratories has been expected to trigger additional cost and unnecessary delays for companies. To facilitate, Indian government allowed the acceptance of test results/reports from labs accredited by ILAC signatories, until 30 November 2021 (for Phase-I and Phase-II products), 30 June 2023 (for Phase-III and IV products) – later revised (first to 31 December 2023, then to 31 March 2024, then to 31 July 2024 and eventually to 30 September for select products), 31 August 2024 for phase V products (with an extended deadline of 30 September 2024 for select products where deadline for mandatory certification has been extended). However, it is to be noted that on the date of submission of test reports, the test reports issued by ILAC signatories in such cases should not be older than two years. Link: https://www.tec.gov.in/pdf/MTCTE/MTCTE%20Extension-%20Oct%2024.pdf

While India has established 4 Regional Telecom Engineering Centres (RTECs) for testing and certification, the capacity of testing laboratories in India remains unclear. Meanwhile, the validity of the MTCTE test reports issued by TEC designated labs for all parameters has been extended to ten years. Starting in 2024, India has also started accepting valid certificates or test reports issued by Bureau of Indian Standards (BIS) or BIS-recognized labs against safety requirements; accepting test reports from Conformity Assessment Bodies (CABs) designated for Generic Requirements (GR) and Interface Requirements (IR) for the parameters of Essential Requirements (ER) under MTCTE; and accepting Source Approval Certificates. Additionally, the TEC has also brought 37 more products under the Simplified Certification Scheme (SCS) with effect from 1 January 2024, in efforts to reduce time taken for certification from eight weeks to two weeks, and to enhance ease of doing business. These products include media gateway, IP security equipment, IP terminals, optical fibre or cable, transmission terminal equipment, and others. With this, the total products under SCS have now gone up to 49 from 12.

 

The EU concerns refer to deviations from international standards, forcing companies to mandatory in-country testing, which could also lead to duplication of test efforts for the European companies, ad-hoc delays caused and additional cost burden incurred due to such tests. Indian government argues it is attempting to augment domestic testing capability to support domestic companies to take these tests within India, thereby helping them to save high costs incurred in taking these tests outside India. It is understood that EU telecom businesses such as Nokia and Ericsson have been manufacturing key equipment in India itself and therefore, they haven’t expressed much worries on the scheme. However, sufficient testing capacity in India still remains a concern for the companies.

Furthermore, India also intends to introduce security testing and certification for telecom equipment. The guidelines were expected to come into force from 1 July 2023, however the deadline was revised to 1 January 2024, and later extended to 1 July 2024 for models that have not undergone mandatory testing and certification of telecom equipment (MTCTE) certification, and 1 October 2024 for models that have already got MTCTE certificates. Telecom equipment manufacturers have urged the government to make the security testing voluntary and requested a two-year extension on the deadline citing limited testing capacity (only three accredited labs) and high costs of testing. It is expected to be integrated with the safety testing requirements and could further results in delays, additional cost burden for the European companies. Moreover, there are concerns related to Intellectual Property Rights (IPR), as the government intends to test the softwares vulnerabilities for backdoor access to data by third-party laboratories.

title: Compulsory registration and labelling of ICT products (notification IND/44)
description:
In September 2012, India issued TBT notification IND/44 on a draft law imposing the registration of 15 electronics products. After several postponements, the scheme entered into force on 3 January 2014. It was extended to further 15 products by order of 8 November 2014 (in force in the meantime for all these products). At the same time, an obligation was introduced to self-declare registration information (through screen-printing/embossing/engraving on the product or the packaging material). With regard to that some exemptions were temporarily introduced in the course of 2014 (such as the allowance of non-removable stickers or marking on the packaging for small products) but the gist of the burdensome scheme remains in place.

India has in August 2017 further extended the coverage of the registration scheme to an additional 13 products (in total 44 products). In April 2020, India further extended the coverage to an additional 12 products (in total 56 products). Later in October 2020, India again extended the coverage to an additional 7 products (in total 63 products now). In March 2021 India issued “Electronics and Information Technology Goods (Requirement of Compulsory Registration) Order, 2021” covering all 63 products with requirements kicking in from 18 September 2021 (link: https://www.meity.gov.in/writereaddata/files/CRO2021-and-ammenment.pdf). In July 2021, a deferred deadline of 6 months was granted to manufacturers that were already registered and met the criteria established for such exemption. In April 2023, television sets were added to the list bringing the total to 64 products. In April 2024, detailed security requirements were introduced for CCTV cameras. A transition period of three months (max) was provided, from the date of coming into effect of the Order for the particular product category, for affixing Standard Mark at the ports which are already having registration number from the BIS for clearance of goods from customs.

title: Telecommunications - Duties on ITA products
description:
Since 2014, in its drive to promote domestic manufacturing, India progressively increased customs and other duties on ITA products, encompassing diverse tax rates between 7.55% and 20%. India's increased duty rates affect imports of products such as mobile phones, mobile phone components and accessories such as static converters, base stations, or certain printers.

In April 2019, the EU requested consultations with India to address concerns around duties on selected ICT goods. In February 2020, the EU moved to request the WTO Dispute Settlement Body (DSB) to establish a dispute resolution panel (later joined by Japan and Chinese Taipei). After adjudication of the dispute by this panel in April 2023, it observed that India’s measures were inconsistent with its WTO obligations and were to be brought into conformity. India and the EU negotiated to arrive at a mutually agreeable solution following the ruling however, India appealed in WTO’s appellate body (currently not functional) against the decision of the panel in December 2023 after the EU filed for adoption of the panel report.

As of 1 February 2022, India accorded unconditional duty-free treatment to some of the identified ICT products – this was also recorded by the dispute adjudicating panel established by the WTO DSB as India being consistent with its WTO obligations with respect to such products. In February 2024, India reduced the import duty from 15% to 10% on some parts used in making mobile phones (such as battery covers, main camera lenses, back covers, other mechanical items of plastic and metal, GSM antenna, die-cut parts and other parts). Further, import duty on inputs used to manufacture these components was cut to zero. As of July 2024 (as part of the Union Budget 2024-2025), the basic customs duty (BCD) on mobile phones, printed circuit board assemblies (PCBAs), and chargers has also been lowered from 20% to 15%. The duties have been slashed to zero for oxygen-free copper used in resistor manufacturing and specific components for connector production. However, duties on PCBA for telecom equipment were increased from 10% to 15%.

title: Government procurement - Local content requirement
description:
Electronics and telecom equipment manufacturing – preferential market access policies: on 10 February and 5 October 2012 respectively, the Government of India published a new preferences policy to domestically manufactured electronic goods in procurement due to the security considerations and in Government procurement. After the suspension of this policy by the Prime Minister's Office on 8 July 2013, a new preference policy was adopted for electronic products in Government procurement on 23 December 2013, which eliminates security as a reason for preferences. Furthermore, this new PMA policy is limited to government procurement only, and not extended to private purchases. Local content and value addition requirements for government procurement, however, remain the same. A series of implementation notifications followed. A new preference policy for telecoms is still outstanding (together with implementing guidelines). On 29 August 2018, India issued a new notification, increasing the scope of the measure: The original PMA from 2012 reserved 100% preferences for 19 out of 23 telecom products listed.  In the new policy a total of 36 telecom products is listed; for 12 products PMA is at 100%. This policy will be applicable on projects funded by the central government.

Renewable energy – solar power plants: the Jawaharlal Nehru National Solar Mission (JNNSM) laid down local content requirements for solar power plants. The Solar Mission is to be implemented in three phases; the third phase will end in 2022. The first round of selection of projects took place in 2010-2011 based on certain local content requirements (e.g. use of cells and/or modules manufactured in India for solar PV projects). Phase 2 was launched in October 2013 mandating a domestic content requirement: out of the total capacity of 750 MW, 50% (so 375 MW) was kept for bidding with Domestic Content Requirement (DCR). Under DCR, 100% of the solar cells, modules and thin films used in the solar PV power plants must both be made in India. The US challenged this programme at WTO: in August 2015, the panel found that DCR measures were not justified. A notice of appeal has been filed by the Indian government. The DCR is also proving an obstacle to the development of local solar power production because India's manufacturing capacity is low, more expensive than foreign imports and of a lesser quality.

After India's appeal, the case dragged on with India claiming to have stopped applying the measures in question, and the US considering that this was not the case and asking the WTO to implement retaliatory measures. Eventually, this dispute was settled as part of the package of mutual agreement annouced by India and the US on 17 July 2023. However, it is unclear what this mutual understanding entailed. The JNNSM was foreseen to end in 2022, but it should be noticed that the Indian Ministry of New & Renewable Energy (MNRE) has annouced on 10 March 2023 that solar power commissioned before 31 March 2024 would be exempted from DCR. This might be part of the package deal with the US, but it is likely mostly motivated by the difficulties of solar power project developpers to source their modules from domestic producers. 

Iron and steel products: As part of PM Modi's "Make in India" Strategy, on 3 May 2017 the Cabinet approved a policy for the use of domestic steel products in government organisations.  The policy makes it mandatory to give preference to Domestically Manufactured Iron and Steel Products (DMI&SP) in government procurement.

Medical devices: DPIIT issued the Public Procurement order dated 16.09.2020, as per Order No. P-45021/2/2017-PP (BE-II ), whereby only local suppliers having a local content of more than 20% will be able to bid for any Central or any State Government tenders that utilises central funds, for tender value below 200 Crore INR. Subsequently, Department of Pharmaceuticals (DoP) issued an order F.No.31026/36/2016-MD, reiterating the adoption of the Order. Further, DoP issued two orders dated 16th February (Annex 1) and 25th March (Annex 2): F. No. 31026/36/2016-MD, and F. No. 31026/36/2016 – MD, respectively, restricting procurement of 130 diagnostics products and 19 categories of Medical Devices from class I local supplier only, with local content 50 % and above. This blanket declaration for 19 categories of medical devices where only class I local suppliers shall be eligible to bid in public procurement tenders adversely impacts EU companies. The revised PPO released on March 25, 2021 further indicates a list of manufacturers that may or may not have the manufacturing capacity to produce and supply these 19 medical devices categories that the Department of Pharmaceuticals deem India has sufficient manufacturing capacity for. However, the list fails to include global manufacturers that have invested significantly in India’s domestic manufacturing of quality medical devices that cater to both the local and global supply chains. The overlooking of local manufacturing units of such global innovators risks giving a negative signal to EU companies considering investments in India

2024

The government is planning to tweak its procurement policy. DPIIT - The industry department has floated a proposal to raise the minimum local content requirement for public procurement for Class-I and -II suppliers from 50 per cent currently to 70 per cent, and 20 per cent as of now to 50 per cent, respectively. A proposal rearding the same was shared by the government with the industry, including EU companies. The Head of Delegation in New Delh shared a Letter with the Senior Officials at the Indian Industries Department and the Department of Telecommunications in May 2024. In the letter the HOD highlighted the ill effects that such a hike in local content requiremenst may cause on the EU comapanies in India. 

The Trade Section of the Delegation also prepared a Note for the EU HQ Govt. Procurement team, negoatiating the EU-India FTA with India. The Note covered on various topics, such as the functioning and ownership of Central public sector enetrprises that are authorized for government procurement in India, espacially the CPSE's or any other Indian authorities related to Urban Railways, Electricity transmission, Airports, Water ports and Mines. This note was prepared for the 8th FTA round that was held in Brussels in June 2024.

title: Standards for food additives for alcoholic beverages
description:
The draft alcoholic beverage standards and food additives regulations need to include the maximum feasible list of permitted additives and to fully align its labelling provisions with international standards (CODEX STAN 1-1985). Further clarification is needed on applicability of legislation to ensure EU alcoholic beverages maintain their access to the Indian market. Despite some earlier improvements in certain Indian States, imported wines, spirits and beer still remain affected by taxation measures or by procedures/requirements, hindering their internal distribution and marketing, e.g. through licensing and pricing in various States (Delhi, Madhya Pradesh, Tamil Nadu, Himachal Pradesh, Haryana, etc.) - please see also NTB 12321 on taxation issues.

FFSAI has ruled the list of additives that can be used on different food categories, including for winemaking purposes. The final outcome on additives is globally satisfactory for EU wines as it integrates all the oenological practices permitted under OIV. However, a limited number of divergences from OIV standards remain.

Two amendent have bee published in 2020 allowing for specific colorants used for certain alcoholic beverages. It is a problem the colours cannot be used in combination and not the level allowed in the EU.

Following EU action, in 2021 the additives (colours E102 (Tartrazine), E122 (Carmosine), E133 (Brilliant Blue FCF), E110 (Sunset Yellow FCF), E124 (Ponceau 4R) and E129 (Allura Red)) have been permitted for use both individually or in combination in relation to food category 14.2.6 “Distilled Spirituous Beverages” (i.e. with more than 15% abv). However, no mention of food additives (colours) was made of food category 14.2.7 “Aromatized alcoholic beverages” (i.e. alcoholic beverages with less than 15% abv). Having this recognized would be key for consistency with international (and EU) standards.

FSSAI has published in the Official Gazette a new legal text in relation to food standards & food additives, which has been in force since September 2023: the “Food Safety and Standards (Food Products Standards and Food Additives) Second Amendment Regulations, 2023”.
Under this revised regulation, the following food colouring additives are now allowed:
• 14.2.6 - for spirits: food colouring additives Tartrazine, Carmoisine, Brilliant Blue, Sunset Yellow, and Ponceau 4R, Allura Red, alone and in combination.
• 14.2.7 - for aromatised alcoholic beverages: food colouring additives Tartrazine, Carmoisine, Brilliant Blue, Sunset Yellow, and Ponceau 4R, Allura Red, alone and in combination.

• One product is missing from that list: Carmine (E120) – even though it is part of the Codex list of permitted additives for our products.

title: Request for GM-free certificate for certain agricultural crops imports
description:
On 2 September 2020, India notified to the WTO TBT Committee the introduction of a new order (ref. G/TBT/N/IND/168), to originally enter into force on 1 January 2021, requesting that every consignment of certain imported unprocessed agricultural products for food purposes is accompanied by a certificate attesting its GM-free status. Such certificate will have to be issued by the relevant competent authority of all exporting countries.

Following concerns raised by trading partners, including the comments sent by the EU to the TBT notification of India, the entry into force of the order has been postponed to 1 March 2021.

The Commission and the EU Delegation to India have been liaising with the authorities of India, Member States and businesses to convince India to eliminate the certification requirements as, according to the information received so far by the Commission, not all Member States are in a position to issue the GMO-free certification.

2024

In a meeting with FSSAI the following points were made:

• FSSAI is concerned that sometimes GM fruits and vegetables might be routed through EU even if not produced in EU. Hence, the certificate is required.
• FSSAI said even Indian exporters are required to give this certificate for exporting to EU. They proposed that if EU can make sure that EU importers will not ask for this certificate from Indian exporters then FSSAI can also give this relaxation to EU exporters.
• FSSAI is currently not reconsidering a change on the GM free certificate requirement.

Though the MS have found a temporary solution they fear that it may not be prolonged.

title: Quality control order for toys
description:
As of 1 January 2021, all toys sold in India require licensing from the Bureau of Indian Standards (BIS). The issuance of licenses is based on applications made by toys manufacturers, followed by a physical audit of the manufacturing facilities by the officials of BIS.

The EU toy companies submitted applications to receive the required BIS certification for their manufacturing plants, including their overseas facilities, soon after BIS released the Quality Control Order (QCO) Product Manual in late August 2020. However, by the end of 2020, most, if not all, domestic manufacturing facilities have been audited, and granted licences, audits of overseas manufacturing plants were severely delayed due to COVID-related international travel restrictions. Now BIS inspectors have resumed travelling internationally and plants are getting audited, but such delays brought to the suspension of imports of EU for a considerable amount of time (and closure of India-based offices in some cases).

India is not accepting virtual audits nor audits carried out via thrid party certification. India is not accepting testing done in the country of manufacture by ILAC accredited labs. DPIIT on the other hands suggest that mutual recognition agreements (MRAs) could be a way to address the factory inspection requirement.

India has also indicated they may consider establishing an import license regime for toys in the near future, with the expectation that the regime would be utilized to impose quotas. Such an action would come on top of the country’s recent increase in the import duty on toys from 20% to 60%.

Basic Customs Duty was raised to 70% from 60% for heading 9503 by Finance Bill 2023.

title: Quality control order for man-made fibres
description:
India has notified Quality Control Orders (QCOs) for Man-made Fibres (MMFs). In order to export to India, the MMF plants must be certified by the Bureau of Indian Standards (BIS), which does in-person auditing of manufacturing facilities in the exporting country. The certification process is costly and includes requirements to submit commercially sensitive information, besides sampling in BIS recognised labs. The QCOs cover the following MMFs: 

- Polyester continuous filament fully drawn yarn 
- Polyester industrial yarn 
- Polyester partially oriented yarn 
- Polyester staple fibres 
- Polyethylene material for moulding and extrusion 
- Styrene Butadiene rubber latex 
- Synthetic micro-fibres for use in cement-based matrix

In addition, EU-produced MMFs are already subject to a detailed quality control within the EU before being exported. 

All the QCOs concerning MMFs have been implemented.

title: Automotive duties
description:
The Indian automotive industry is one of the key drivers of India’s economic growth and a major participant in the global automotive value chain. The Indian automotive industry is valued at $108 billion and is expected to reach US$ 300 bn by 2026. The automotive industry contributes 7.1% to India’s GDP and 35% to India’s manufacturing GDP. In 2023-24, India’s automotive industry manufactured 28.4 mn vehicles, of which 4.5 mn were exported. The automotive sector employs about 19 million people directly and indirectly.

India holds a strong position in the international heavy vehicles arena by virtue of it being the largest tractor manufacturer, second largest bus manufacturer and third largest heavy trucks manufacturer in the world. Two-wheelers and passenger vehicles dominate the domestic Indian automotive market. India’s automotive sector witnessed FDI inflows of US$ 36.26 bn during 2000-2024 (March), accounting for 5.34% of the total FDI inflows.

Very high import duties and India specific domestic standards deny market access to the Indian market. Compliance with these standards is not only burdensome and time consuming but has high economic costs for the foreign manufacturers, which consequently find doing business with India to be an arduous undertaking.

Import duty on passenger vehicles attract duties at the following rates:

With a CIF value of >US$ 40,000 or engine capacity >3000cc for petrol and >2500 for diesel vehicles or both, the duty is 100% and with a CIF value of <US$ 40,000 and engine capacity <3000cc for petrol and <2500 for diesel vehicles, the duty is 70%.

In SKD form containing engine or gearbox or transmission mechanism in pre-assembled for but not mounted on a chassis or a body assembly, the duty is 30%;

In CKD form containing engine, gearbox and transmission mechanism not in a pre-assembled condition, the duty is 15%;

title: Import Tariffs India - Diamonds
description:
On 26th September 2018, India increased its import tariff on polished diamonds for the second time in six months, and for the 4th time in 6 years. In an effort to narrow the current account deficit (CAD), the Indian government increased the import duty on 19 'non-essential items' including polished diamonds, gemstones and jewellery. The import duties on cut and polished diamonds, lab-grown diamonds and cut and polished coloured gemstones increased from 5% to 7.5%. The new rates went into effect immediately.

On 1st February 2022, the Finance Minister in her Budget speech announced that Basic Customs Duty rates on the following goods have been reduced:

  • Simply sawn natural diamonds imported under KPCS from 10% to Nil; The exemption on duty, which was valid till 30th Septmber 2024, has now been extended till 31 March 2026.  
  • Cut and polished natural coloured gemstones, diamonds including lab grown diamonds semi-processed, half-cut or broken and non-industrial diamonds including lab grown diamonds (other than rough diamonds) from 7.5% to 5%.

title: Quality Control orders in the automotive sector (wheel rims, safety glass, two-wheeler helmets and Brake linings)
description:
India has put several auto components under Quality Control Orders (QCOs), resulting in additional burden for foreign manufacturers, which are already complying with international standards and now have to comply with India specific standards. The additional burden entails extra economic costs, paperwork, redesigning of tools, marking fees and, in some cases, bank guarantees, which only the foreign manufacturers have to pay. The Bureau of Indian Standards (BIS) did not carry out audits of foreign manufacturing plants as international travel was suspended due to Covid-19. This resulted in disruption of supply chains and delay in audits of foreign plants by BIS officials.

Wheel rims: Ministry of Heavy Industries and Public Enterprises (Department of Heavy Industry), circulated a Draft Automobile Wheel Rim Component (Quality Control) Order 2020 on 25 May 2020 as per Notification G/TBT/N/IND/147. The draft order mandates wheel rims used in motor vehicles to bear the Standard Mark of the Bureau of Indian Standards (BIS) as per the Scheme I of Schedule II of the BIS Conformity Assessment Regulations 2018, with effect of 1st October 2020. Currently in India, quality and performance of the wheel rims are safeguarded mandatory with requirements of IS 9436-1980 / IS 9438-1980. Tests are conducted by notified type approval authorities assigned under Central Motor Vehicle Rules (CMVR) Rule 126 (namely ARAI / ICAT, etc.). All EU wheel rims exported to India mandatory fulfill the requirements of conformity standards IS 9436 and IS 9438 (1980) as well as the marking provisions of AIS 037 (Procedure for Type Approval and Establishing Conformity of Production for Safety Critical Components) as mandated under India’s Motor Vehicle Act (MVA, 1988) and the CMVR, 1989. On 22 October 2021, India delayed the entry into force to 21.09.2022.

Through an Order dated 8th June 2022, the implementation date of the QCO on Automobile Wheel Rim was extended to 22nd June 2023. However, following an intervention from the Delegation, the QCO on wheel rims was further extended by another Order dated 15th June 2023 to 22nd December 2023. 

Through an Order dated 19th December 2023, the Ministry of Heavy Industries issued Automobile Wheel Rim Component (Quality Control) Amendment Order-II 2023 concerning Automobile Wheel Rim Component. This Order shall come into force on 22nd December 2023.

According to the Order, it shall apply to goods or articles specified in the table: provided that nothing in this Order shall apply to said goods or articles meant for the following; namely:-

  • Import of up to 50,000 units of 4-Wheeler Automotive Wheel Rims (for 10,000 vehicles) per financial year, per 4-Wheeler vehicle manufacturer for manufacturing 4-Wheeler vehicles in India.
  • Import of up to 5,000 units of 4-Wheeler Automotive Wheel Rims (for 1,250 vehicles), by a 4-Wheeler vehicle manufacturer per financial year, for repairs or after sales service purposes.
  • Up to five wheel rims per vehicle w.r.t. rule 126A of the Central Motor Vehicles Rules, 1989, which grants relaxation from test, if number of vehicles sold in India for a given base model and its variants is less than 250 in any consecutive period of six months in a year;
  • Automobile wheel rims meant for export;
  • Import of up to 10,000 units of 4-Wheeler Automotive Wheel Rims (for 2,500 vehicles), per financial year, per 4-Wheeler vehicle manufacturer for R & D purposes.
  • Import of up to 24,000 units of 2-Wheeler Automotive Wheel Rims (for 12,000 vehicles) per financial year, per 2-wheeler vehicle manufacturer for repairs or after sales service purposes.
  • Import of up to 10,000 units of 2-Wheeler Automotive Wheel Rims (for 5,000 vehicles) per financial year, per two-wheeler vehicle manufacturer for R & D purposes.
