  • Import of up to 70,000 units of 2-Wheeler Automotive Wheel Rims (for 35,000 vehicles) per financial year, per 2-wheeler vehicle manufacturer for manufacturing 2-Wheeler vehicles in India, subject to not more than 25,000 Automobile Wheel Rim units of one type.

SAFETY GLASS: Through an Order dated 12 March 2020, the Department for Promotion of Industry and Internal Trade (DPIIT) notified the Safety Glass (Quality Control) Order 2020. The date of implementation was 16 September 2020. On 18 September 2020, through a Second Amendment Order, India exempted safety glass used in the vehicle imported in India by vehicle manufacturer under the provisions of Rule 126 of the Central Motor Vehicle Rules, 1989. On 25 February 2021, entry into force of this measure was postponed to 1 April 2022. However, through an Order dated 10th February 2022 on Safety Glass (Quality Control) Amendment Order 2022, India granted an extension of 1 year to the QCO on Safety Glass. The new date of implementation of the QCO on Safety Glass is 1st April 2023. 

On 17 February 2022, the Department for Promotion of Industry and Internal Trade (DPIIT) through a letter concerning the Safety Glass QCO, requested the industry/associations to clear their certification issues, which are pending with the Bureau of Indian Standards (BIS). DPIIT has also requested BIS to assist the industry in completing the certification process and prepare itself for the implementation of the QCO, which was extended .

The list of associations mentioned in the attached letter consists of glass industry, consumer electronics and appliances manufacturers associations. The list mentions only one name from the EU auto industry – Skoda Volkswagen India.

On 25th January 2023, the Delegation wrote to DPIIT for an extension of one year given that there are still few foreign plants, which have not been audited.  

On 24th March 2023, through an Order, the QCOs on Safety Glass was implemented. Following exemptions were given by India on safety glass:

  • Import of safety glass by a vehicle manufacturer for manufacturing up to 10,000 vehicles manufactured in India per financial year;
  • Import of up to 5,000 number of safety glass per financial year for the purpose of repairs or after sales service of vehicles.

NUTS, BOLTS AND FASTENERS: Through an Order dated 21st July 2023, the Department for Promotion of Industry and Internal Trade issued a Quality Control Order (QCO) for Nuts, Bolt and Fasteners. The Order entered into force from 21 January 2024. As per the QCO, for Small Enterprises, the QCO shall come into force w.e.f. nine months from the date of publication of the Notification and for Micro Enterprises, shall come into force w.e.f. twelve months from the date of publication of this Notification. Furthermore, nothing in this Order shall apply to goods or articles manufactured domestically by an enterprise, registered under "Udyam portal" of the Ministry of Micro, Small, and Medium Enterprises, wherein the investment in plant and machinery or equipment at original cost does not exceed twenty five lakhs rupees (€0.02 mn) and the turnover does not exceed two crores rupees (€0.22 mn) for the previous financial year as certified by a Chartered Accountant shall be exempted from implementation of this order. The QCO further states that provided further that nothing in this Order shall apply to goods or articles imported as a part of any finished good or sub-assembly or component. The QCO covers 19 products.

HELMETS: Through a draft Notification dated 30 July 2020, India added Protective Helmet for Two Wheeler Riders under mandatory certification. The effective date for the draft QCO to come into force was 1 March 2021. However, on the issue of protective helmets, there has been no input from the EU industry, whether in the EU or in India. It is also not clear whether India has notified this QCO to the WTO. The QCO on Helments entered into force on 1 June 2021.

BRAKE LININGS: Through a draft Notification of October 2020, the Ministry of Heavy Industries and Public Enterprise has issued a draft QCO mandating India-specific BIS markings for the “Replacement Brake Lining Assemblies and Drum Brake Linings for Power Driven Vehicles and Their Trailers”. Accordingly, the replacement brake lining needs to comply with Indian Standard 17132. The intension is to regulate the after-market brake lining suppliers. The brake linings used for vehicle manufacturing and supply as spares are exempted provided the brake lining type shall be same and vehicle model shall be homologated in India. The brake lining supply as spares for CBU vehicles which are imported in India under the homologation exemption rule are not exempted. This QCO is still in the draft stage.

Meetings and exchanges have taken place with the officials from DPIIT and the Bureau of Indian Standards (BIS) to reconsider their decision to remove QCOs on auto parts and to accept virtual audits or third party certification in absence of physical audits. However, India has been deferring the implementation of QCOs on auto parts because it was unable to carry out physical audits as India had imposed restrictions on international travel.

title: Health certificates to accompany the import into India of food consignments (dairy, pork, fish and their products)
description:
On 18 August 2022, the Food Safety and Standards Authority of India (FSSAI) sent to the WTO TBT Committee the notification ref. G/TBT/N/IND/233, which included three new health certificates to accompany the imported food consignments of milk and milk products, pork and pork products and fish and fishery products. 

The European Commission welcomed the:

  • Above-mentioned notification and asked India to reply in written to the EU comments, given the importance of providing exporting countries with clarity and certainty about India’s import requirements;
  • Two months postponement, with the FSSAI Order of 27 October 2022, of the entering into force of the new health certificates − from 1 November 2022 to 1 January 2023.
  • Further postponement unitl 1 July 2024, after a joint statement from the FSSAI and DAHD.

However, given the: (1) disruption to trade associated to the new certificates, even if they are not associated to new sanitary measures; (2) number of import requirements of India that are not aligned with international standards, without India peroviding any sicientifc justification for the divergences; (3) duplication of certificates requested by different authorities in India; (4) different products/food categories associated to the three certificates and to the registration of foreign food manufacturing facilities; and (5) importance of the competent authorities and companies in the exporting countries to have enough time to adapt, the European Commission asked India to further postpone the entering into force of teh dairy certificate until India provided a scientifc justification for all divergences with interntaoinal standards.

The FSSAI, the DAHD and the Commission continue to exchange information about these matters (which is regularly shared with member States and business organizations), and the Commission continues to monitor closely any possible trade disruption.

title: Standards on alcoholic beverages
description:
FSSAI published in April 2018 the Food Safety and Standards (Alcoholic Beverages - AB) Regulations, 2018 i.e. standards for distilled AB, wine and beer. It also specifies specific requirement for labelling of AB. The Regulation came into force with its publication in the Gazette, however the enforcement of the standards will start in 12 months i.e. from 1 April 2019.

In early June 2019 FSSAI notified to WTO trough SPS procedures further amendments to the regulation

While this regulation answers to some of the concerns raised by the EU, there are still some issues of concerns for the EU industry, in particular a) the lack of stock-exhaustion clause so as to minimise the impact for economic operators; b) lenghty and unpredictable approval process for registration of EU GIs in India; c) the presence of some technical specifications (maximum alcohol content, sugar content, …) not in line with international standards that could prevent some EU wines, spirits or beers to enter the Indian market; d) over-labelling (residues of additives in the final product) potentially triggering additional technical controls that might result in unjustified barriers to trade.

In December 2020 FSSAI published somean amendment which help to solve some issues, while others still remain, ie the stock exhaustion clause, maximum alcolhol content and some standards.

In December 2021, FSSAI published another amendment related to low alcohol beer.

title: Export restrictions - iron ore
description:
Through Customs notification (No. 27/2011) of 1 March 2011, the Indian Government increased the rate of export duty for all types of iron ore at a unified level of 20% ad valorem (the previous rates being 5% for iron ore fines and 15% for iron ore lumps). These duties were subsequently raised from 20% to 30% on 30 December 2011.

Export duty on iron ore pellets was removed on 4 January 2016. Similary, export duty of 15% was introduced through Customs Notification 66/2008-Customs dated 10.5.2008 on ferrous waste and scrap, re-melting scrap ingots of iron or steel.

As of 4 March 2022, export duties are on the following items were:

Iron Ore pellets (HS 26011210) - Nil, Bauxite (natural) not calcined or calcined  (HS 26060010 & 26060020) - 15%, Other aluminium ores and concentrates (HS 26060090) - 30%, Other aluminium ores including laterite (HS 26060090) - 15%, Ilmenite, unprocessed (HS 26140010) - 10%, Ilmenite, upgraded (beneficiated ilmenite including ilmenite ground) (HS 26140020) - 2.5%.

On 21 May 2022, India introduced export duties on some raw materials which go into the production of iron and steel. Export duty on iron ore pellets has been increased from Nil to 45%. Export duty on iron ore and concentrates (agglomerated) other than iron ore pellets has been  raised to 50%. Similarly, export duty on iron ore and concentrates (non-agglomerated) is now at 50%.

Export duty of 15% is applied on ferrous waste and scrap, re-melting scrap ingots of iron and steel. Similarly, on bauxite (natural) calcined and not calcined export duty is 15%. Export duty on Ilmenite unprocessed is at 10% and on Ilmenite, upgraded (beneficiated ilmenite including ilmenite ground) is 2.5%.

On, 18th November 2022, India made some announcements on the export duty and Basic Customs Duty (BCD) front covering goods such as iron ore, steel anthracite PCI coal, coking coal and ferronickel. On the export duty side, the government decided to do away with export duty on iron ore and several steel products, reversing its earlier decision to impose the levy amid soaring domestic steel prices.

Export Duties

HS Code Item Description Existing Revised
26011210 Iron ore pellets 45% Nil
7201 Pig iron and spiegeleisen in pigs, blocks or other primary forms 15% Nil
7208 Steel Flat rolled products of iron or non-alloy steel, hot rolled, not clad, plated or coated 15% Nil
7209 Flat rolled products of iron or non-alloy steel, cold rolled (cold-reduced), not clad, plated or coated 15% Nil
7210 Flat-rolled products of iron or non-alloy steel, of a width of 600 mm or more, clad, plated or coated 15% Nil
7213 Bars and rods, hot-rolled, in irregularly wound coils, of iron or non-alloy steel 15% Nil
7214 Other bars and rods of iron or non-alloy steel, not further worked than forged, hot-rolled, hot-drawn or hot-extruded, but including those twisted after rolling 15% Nil
7219 Flat rolled products of stainless steel, of a width of 600 mm or more 15% Nil
7222 Other bars and rods of stainless steel; angles, shapes and sections of stainless steel 15% Nil
7227 Bars and rods, hot-rolled, in irregularly wound coils, of other alloy steel 15% Nil

On the Basic Customs Duty (BCD), the government decided to withdraw BCD exemption on anthracite/PCI, coking coal and ferronickel.

BCD on anthracite/PCI and coking coal has been raised from ‘Nil’ to ‘5%’ and BCD on ferronickel has been raised from ‘Nil’ to ‘2.5%’. Though, iron ore is domestically available, for coking coal, India is dependent on imports. The country meets 85 per cent of its coking coal requirement through imports, mainly from Australia.

The changes came into effect from 19th November, 2022.

title: Medical devices
description:
Issue 1:

Clinical investigation is required for MDs from the EU while such requirement is waived for MDs approved and marketed for 2 years in the USA, UK, Australia, Canada and Japan. Despite a positive reccommendaion from the DrugTechnical advisory Board from June 2019, the EUwas not added to the list of exempted countries.

Issue 2:

Currently non- Local suppliers (with local content of 20 % and below) cannot participate in any government tender. Considering India imports 86% MD, especially life saving devices, this means Critically ill patients are not benefitting from global technologies. Moreover, Close- loop equipment already purchased by hospitals where only suppliers' reagents/ catheters/ spares can be used will be rendered useless. Ultimately, research work with new technologies in top research hospitals will be hampered. in early 2022 GoI has issued 2 lists of list of medical devices, Diagnostics & IVD’s categories which have been exempted from PPO by Ministry of finance from all tenders issued till 31st March 2023 ( 128 in the first list and 391 in the second). One more list is expected in March 2022.

Industry requests that all proprietary medical devices, implants, equipment and diagnostics that have no local manufacturing, but utilized by hospitals should be exempted from PPO. Moreover close –loop spares/ reagents/ catheters  of equipment already purchased by hospitals should be exempted to run the equipment.

Issue 3: Medical Devices have to comply with Legal Metrology Act and Rules. While Drugs are exempted from LM Act, MD (which since March 2020 have been included in the category of drugs) are not, despite being now considered drugs. Practically these labelling requirements can be complicated to put in practice for certain products (ex  labelling etc. 40% surface of products for disposable needles, etc)

Industry request is to exempt Medical devices from Legal Metrology Act and Rules like it already happens with Drugs

title: Technical barriers to trade (TBT) :  Halal Law and National Indonesian Standards (SNIs)
description:
a. Indonesian National Standards (SNIs) and marking requirements- Indonesia applies the Indonesian National Standards (SNI) certification system in a number of sectors and industries, including where internationally accepted standards or certifications are available. The Ministry of Industry has been introducing and enforcing Indonesian mandatory National Standards for an increasing number of products (cosmetics, fertilizers, tyres, automotive parts, electrical cables, baby clothing, ceramic tiles, toys, etc) and often at a short notice. Indonesia does not accept foreign companies to certify compliance with particular ISO standard, even if these companies are accredited by international agencies that are members of ILAC and other international bodies. Instead, Indonesia imposes specific testing carried out by companies recognized by Indonesia, duplicating procedures and creating a burdensome and costly process. Compliance with SNIs is verified by means of complex third party conformity assessment procedures. The EU also has strong concerns about the pre-market authorization system (certification and testing process).

In particular, Ministry of Industry Regulation 24/2013, as amended by Regulation 55/2013, on Compulsory Indonesian National Standards (SNI) on Toys requires, as of April 2016, a mutual recognition agreement for the acceptance of test reports from laboratories outside Indonesia. The EU is not aware of any existing mutual recognition agreements. Imports from the EU are subject to mandatory in-country testing in Indonesia to obtain certification under SNI for import.

Based on Ministry of Trade Regulation 73/2015, Indonesia requires stakeholders to strictly apply specific, individual marking requirements for textile based products, tableware and plastic household products. Alternative ways are not accepted.

The Ministry of Industry Regulation 45/2022 on Industrial Standardisation, issued on 4 November 2022, updates the requirements for obtaining and keeping National Indonesian Standard (SNI) certificates. The Regulation explains the procedures to which stakeholders have to abide from requesting a SNI certificate, the review process of requests for SNI till the (annual) assessments to determine whether certificates are eligible for extension. The Regulation covers the Technical Standard certificate (TC) detailing the technical specifications that need to be fulfilled while the Guidelines for Procedures (PTC) explains the procedures that have to be followed while producing the product and how production equipment needs to be maintained. The TC and the PTC are the basis for the issuance of the SNI.

The Regulation requires firms to have a presence in Indonesia in order to be eligible to apply for a SNI. The system will be e-managed with the Ministry of Industry being firmly in control of the process. The whole process seems to be very cumbersome with Conformity Assessment Agencies being appointed ad hoc. An international firm may have to deal with several agencies simultaneously. It seems very unlikely that European certification institutes can be appointed as Conformity Assessment Agency in the absence of a mutual agreement of technical specification between the EU and Indonesia. Outcomes of the approval process of SNI requests are not always predictable. International firms may apply and submit all appropriate documents. However, the Ministry of Industry has the right to turn down applications on the basis of threats to the domestic industry, especially small and medium enterprises. Another challenge is embedded in the implementation. Regular inspections should take place at least 2 times in a period of 5 years. These inspections may include factory visits and market surveys.

b. Industry Law (Law 3/2014) and Standardization Law (Law 20/2014), complemented by the Government Regulation 201/2000 on the National Standardisation, and the Head of National Standardisation Agency (BSN) Regulation 135/2010 on the National Standardisation System, are potentially trade restrictive, in terms of the strict use of national standards and preference given to local products.

c. The Halal Law 33/2014 sets out a broad and restrictive regime on halal products. The EU has been closely monitoring the situation to avoid bringing trade to a halt. As of September 2019, implementing rules are still unclear. The Government Regulation (Peraturan Pemerintah) PP No. 31/2019 on the Implementation of the Law No. 33 of 2014 on Halal Product Assurance, has been applied since 3 May 2019. The first stage of compulsory halal certification covers food and beverage products, starting from 17 October 2019 and ending on 17 October 2024. After 17 October 2024, all food and beverage products should already have obtained the halal certification. On 14 October Indonesia notified the TBT Committee a second draft implementing regulation, which further details the transition periods established for the implementation of mandatory certification for all category of products, other than food and beverages. Transition may last up to 2034 (goods for medical devices of risk C). The next stage for the halal certification is for traditional medicines, health supplement, cosmetics, chemical products, clothing, headgear and accessories, household appliances etc. and will last from 17 October 2021 to 17 October 2026.

d. The Law No. 11 of 2020 on Job Creation (Omnibus Law), which was passed by the Indonesian House of Representatives (DPR) on 5 October 2020 and took affect since 2 November 2020, reformulates a number of elements of the Halal Law. Re-instating halal-certification obligation for all products circulating in Indonesia, the Law stipulates that companies (domestic and international) failing to register their products prior to entering Indonesia are subject to administrative sanctions. However, it does not provide detailed guidance on international recognition and co-operation. The Law expands the reach of halal certification obligation to Indonesian micro, small and medium enterprises (MSMEs).

title: Investment restrictions
description:
a) Foreign ownership restrictions are specified in the "Investment Negative List (DNI)". The list is revised regularly. The last revision took place in February 2021 (Presidential Regulation 10/2021), replacing the 2016 DNI and change the list into a hybrid of priority and negative investment list. The revision is part of the structural reforms mandated by the Omnibus Law on Job Creation (Law No 11/2020). Overall, it is a positive development.

The Omnibus Law removed:

- The category of ‘sectors open with conditions.’
- The Government’s obligation to reserve sectors for MSMEs and cooperatives.
- Sectoral discrimination towards foreign investments from 5 sectoral law.

Presidential Regulation No 10/2021 further reduces the number of business activities subject to at least one investment restriction from 813 to 260.

The EU has interest in a number of sectors which previously restricted to foreign companies ("foreign equity caps") including in pharmaceuticals and their raw materials, telecommunications, IT, banking and insurances, horticulture, beverages, transport and logistics services, oil/gas, retail, etc. Restrictions on the majority of these sectors have been relaxed or removed in the last Investment List.

b) Some specific sectors are not covered by the DNI list, but are regulated by specific separate laws, for instance the Construction Law and the Horticulture Law.

c) minimum investment requirement for foreign investment of IDR 10 billion or approximately EUR 0.6 million (set by regulation 5/2013 from the Indonesia's Investment Coordinating Board - BKPM) and this excludes land and building assets. The government maintains this rule in the latest regulation (BKPM Regulation 4/2021) and even increases the paid-up capital requirement from IDR 2.5 billion to IDR 10 billion.  The regulations provide exemption for representative offices and foreign business entities. The Presidential Regulation No 10/2021 also provides exemption for technology-based start-ups located in Special Economic Zone.

d) Minister of Manpower Decree No 228/2019 issued on 27 August 2019 lists employment positions open to foreigners. The Decree increases the positions available for foreigners by more than three times (from 656 to 2.196 positions). However, job positions that are not included in the list remain subjected to ad-hoc, non-automatic approval by the Ministry.  Decree 10/2018 foresees that a foreigner’s employment plan should be validated by the Ministry of Employment. A minimum of 5-year experience and the employer’s obligation to provide training in Indonesian language are additional conditions.

In the latest positive development, in February and March 2021 the government issued Government Regulation 34/2021 and Manpower Minister Decree 8/2021 and revoked Manpower Minister Decree 10/2018. The new regulations simplify requirements to hire foreign workers and facilitate access to critical skills from abroad. The reform is part of the mandate of the Omnibus Law. On Decree 228/2019, the feedback from companies from the implementation have been positive.

title: Export restrictions
description:
a) Export taxes (raw minerals, palm oil and some of its derivatives, cocoa, wood, leather), lastly stipulated by MInister of Finance Regulation No 13/2017, and export restrictions (raw minerals, rattan).

b) The Trade Law (7/2014) confers powers to the Government to introduce export restrictions, if justified on national interests and to safeguard national resources. This concerns especially the exports of basic commodities, such as oil, gas and minerals.

c) Mining sector restrictions - Regulations 7/2012, 11/2012 and 20/2013 banned exports of unprocessed mineral and metal ores, except coal, with the objective to increase local value-added of minerals through processing and refining. Regulation 1/2017 allowed exports of unprocessed and semi- processed mineral ores until 2022. However, the relaxation requires the exporting company to build smelters within five years and convert their Contract of Work scheme into Special Mining Business License (with less investment protection and uncertain tax regime). Foreign miners must also gradually divest their shares up to 51% to a local entity after 10 years of production in order to extend their export permits. In parallel, a progressive export tax scheme from 20-25% in 2014 to 60% in 2016 on 65 mineral categories was introduced.

On 30 August 2019, in a move to secure supply for domestic smelters and support a national programme on electric vehicle, the Minister of Energy and Mineral Resources issued Regulation 11/2019 to bring forward the implementation of the export ban on nickel ores to 1 January 2020, two years ahead of the initial plan. Indonesia is a key global supplier of important metals such as nickel, copper and bauxite. While EU nickel imports from Indonesia are limited, the restrictions are having indirect economic effects on globally traded raw materials as well as on the EU industry.

b) Mining sector restrictions - On January 2014 Indonesia implemented export restriction to all raw mineral ores (11 metals, 8 non-metal minerals, and 19 stones) in an effort to develop the downstream industry of the sector, as mandated by the Law No 4 of 2009 on Mineral and Coal Mining. The full ban was planned to be implemented in 12 January 2017. As implementing regulations, Minister of Energy and Mineral Resources issued Regulations 7/2012, 11/2012 and 20/2013 on guidelines to increase local value-added of minerals through processing and refining. Furthermore a progressive export tax scheme from 20-25% in 2014 to 60% in 2016 on 65 mineral categories was introduced.

However, on 11 January 2017, the Indonesian government issued Government Regulation No 1/2017 which allowed companies to continue exporting unprocessed and semi-processed mineral ores, previously subject to full ban starting from 12 January 2017 mentioned above. Subsequently, as implementing regulations, the Minister of Energy and Mineral Resources issued Regulation No 5/2017, No 6/2017, No 7/2017, No 9/2017, and No 15/2017 to stipulate the technicalities.

The current regime stipulates that holders of Contract of Works (CoW), Operation Production Mining Licenses (OPIUPs) and Special Mining Business Licenses (IUPKs), producing concentrate forms of copper, nickel ore, and certain other metals, will be allowed to continue to export their concentrate and ore products, in quantities approved by the Ministry of Energy & Mineral Resources, for a maximum of five years from 11 January 2017 as long as they:

  1. In the case of CoW holders, convert the CoW status to Izin Usaha Pertambangan Khusus (Special Mining Business Licence – IUPKs), with less investment protection
  2. in the case of foreign-owned OPIUPs and IUPK holders, commit to divesting 51% of their issued shares to local parties within ten years of commencing production;
  3. commit to constructing domestic smelters within five years;
  4. have their smelter construction plans independently verified and approved by MEMR;
  5. make 90% ongoing progress in fulfilling their commitment to domestic smelter construction;
  6. renew their export permits every twelve months;
  7. for nickel ores producers, collectively supply 30% of the low nickel content ore required by domestic smelters; and
  8. pay the applicable export tax of up to 10% (stipulated by Minister of Finance Regulation No 13/2017)

Indonesia is a key global supplier of important metals such as nickel, copper and bauxite. While the EU imports from Indonesia were limited, indirect economic effects on the EU are likely to result from the impact of the restrictions on globally traded raw materials. In addition the EU is concerned by the systemic effect of a ban on export, one of the most extreme and damaging restrictions, setting a very damaging precedent in a time of resource nationalism.

In June 2020, Indonesia passed the new Coal and Mining Law. Export restrictions on raw minerals remain.

On 21 December 2022, President Widodo announced Indonesia will ban export of bauxite ores and washed bauxites starting from June 2023.

The export ban on bauxite ores has been enforced since 10 June 2023. According to Minister of Energy and Mineral Resources Regulation No 7/2023, export of other mineral ores (copper, iron, lead, zinc, anode slime) are still allowed until 31 May 2024, provided that producers meet certain progress in smelter construction. Mineral producers are still negotiating the possibility of exporting the ores after May 2024.

title: Exigence supplémentaire de certification (analyse microbiologique par lot et par expédition avec un dosage de certains métaux lourds) pour l’importation de produits cosmétiques
description:
Via le Texte règlementaire de référence de la FDA indonésienne n° 12 /2015 relatif au « CONTROL OF FOOD AND DRUG SUBMISSION », septembre 2015, entré immédiatement en application, les Autorités douanières indonésiennes réclament des certificats d’analyse microbiologique par lot et par expédition avec un dosage de certains métaux lourds. L’usage international en vigueur, également appliqué en Indonésie jusqu’à maintenant, est de fournir une fiche de spécifications techniques.

That triggers a costly test for heavy metals. The test appears to be applied only on imported products. 

A ce stade, des marques françaises du secteur de la parfumerie et de produits de soin pour les instituts de beauté ont des marchandises bloquées en douane.

In addition to the heavy metal test, in September 2016, BPOM announced that it will issue a new regulation regarding the hair dye, regulating 37 hair dyes that have not been included in the existing BPOM’s Cosmetic Ingredient Regulation. It means, 29 hair dyes will be banned , while 8 hair dyes accepted with usage restriction (2 out of 8 hair dyes have different restriction than the EU).

Indonesian regulation (32/2017) multiplies by three the registration fees to obtain the authorization for the marketing of cosmetic products. This increase is applicable only to non-ASEAN made products. At the Working group on Trade and Investment in January 2019, Indonesia explained that an ASEAN Mutual Recognition Agreement on cosmetics is the reason for the higher registration fee for non-ASEAN countries. The difference of, approximately, USD 111 for each formulation is significant for SMEs and can hinder their access to the Indonesian market.

title: Local content requirements
description:
a) Local content requirements apply in specific sectors, such as Telecom, Pharma, Oil and Gas, Retail, Franchising, Insurance, Defence, Industry, Construction, Electricity, Maritime Transport. Requirements mandate, inter alia:

  1. Most retail operators to source 80% of their products locally;
  2. Priority for local materials and components and requires defence users to use locally produced defence and security tools whenever available (up to 85%);
  3. Foreign companies to have a joint operation with local companies; increased use of domestic products across all sectors, especially when using state controlled resources;
  4. Local content requirements for power plants and transmission towers and solar panels; fairly stringent local content requirements for Long-Term Evolution (LTE) telecom towers, LTE-based standard of telecommunication devices and/or equipment;
  5. Local content for mobile devices;
  6. Local content for electronic devices;
  7. Exports of coal and crude palm oil and imports of rice and government procurement goods have to use national shipping lines and national insurance. Effective on 1 May 2020, the Minister of Trade Regulation No. 40/2020 on Terms of Use of National Sea Transportation and National Insurance for Export and Import of Certain Commodities requires coal and crude palm oil (CPO) exporters, as well as importers of rice and government procurement goods, to utilise domestic shipping lines and insurance companies. It revokes the Regulations No. 80/2018 and No. 82/2017. The Regulation No. 40/2020 stipulates the national flag obligation on ships with capacity of up to 15,000-deadweight tonnage (DWT). Nevertheless, the regulation obliges the use of national insurance for the stated commodities.
  8. In an attempt to boost the development of the local pharmaceutical industry Indonesia introduced 25% Local Content Requirements for raw materials for pharmaceuticals (Presidential Instruction 6/2016 5 and 6), ignoring the fact that over 95% of active pharmaceutical ingredients in Indonesia are still imported and that the domestic environment is not conducive to attract R&D investment. (See also barrier 12780 on domestic manufacturing requirements for patented products).

b) Government procurement: Indonesian legislation mandates the use of domestic products in government procurement in key sectors. Furthermore, Presidential Regulation n. 54/2010 as amended by Presidential Reg. No 18/2018 and Presidential Reg. No. 12/2021, foresees significant additional restrictions to foreign companies, i.e. forced partnership with local companies, increased local content requirements, and substantially higher threshold for foreign companies to participate in tenders (for construction services the new threshold is IDR 1 trillion from previously IDR 100 billion, for consultancy services IDR 25 billion from IDR 10 billion, and for goods and services IDR 50 billion from IDR 20 billion).

The regulations states that in the implementation of mandatory for local product purchasing, the planning, preparation, and vendor qualifications procurement should be taken into account.

The regulation requires procuring entities to seek maximum local content, use foreign components only when necessary, and designate foreign contractors as sub-contractors to local companies. Articles 66 and 67 (preferences for domestic products) make locally produced goods and services mandatory for use in procurements from all relevant ministries, institutions and regional governments. Local goods or services are defined to be those where at least 40 percent of the total value is comprised of local components or inputs. Foreign goods and services are permitted only when not available locally, and/or domestic production volume is not capable of meeting necessary demand.

c) The Government Regulation No. 29 of 2018 on the Empowerment of Industry underlines the increase usage of domestic products (Articles 54 to 56) and the obligation to use domestic products (Articles 57 to 64) as prerequisites to develop the national industry. The requirement remains, although some provisions of the regulation have been amended through the Government Regulation No. 28 of 2021 on the Organisation of Industrial Sector.

In September 2021, Indonesia frozed 79 medical device product groups, covering 5,462 imported products, in the e-Catalogue of government procurement, preventing their purchase by government health institutions. The decision to delist the medical device products was made solely after the meeting on local content chaired by the Coordinating Minister for Maritime Affairs and Investment in September 2021 that, if there are domestic medical devices that reach 40% Domestic Content Level, then National Public Procurement Agency (LKPP) is obliged to delist the imported products.

d. Using economic recovery as a pretext, Indonesia saw the COVID-19 pandemic as an ideal time to strengthen overall national industrial structure, to increase production effectiveness and output, and to overcome dependence on imports.

As of November 2024, through the Minister of Communication and Informatics (MCI) Regulation No 13/2021 (replacing Reg. 27/2015), Indonesia obliges LTE telecommunication devices produced or imported into Indonesia to meet a minimum local content of 35% for subscriber station (e.g. mobile phones, tablet devices) and 40% for base station (e.g. Base Transceiver Station/BTS and its associated equipment).

Minister of Industry (MoI) holds the authority to determine the methods to fulfil these LCRs. According to MoI Regulation 29/2017, industries can meet the LCRs for mobile devices through three methods:

Manufacturing: includes domestic manufacturing and assembly process, use of local materials and labour, etc. This  method has the highest weight, up to 70% in the total LCR calculation.

R&D: includes local content in software development, industrial and layout design. This method can account up to 20% of the total LCRs calculation

Innovation Development:  This third method allows companies to meet LCRs through investment in 'innovation'. The investment tiers range from IDR 250 billion (EUR 14.7 million) to over IDR 1 trillion (EUR 59 million), with higher investments granting higher LCR percentages, from 20% to 40%. The required investment amount is set through a feasibility analysis (assessing the benefit to the industry) and negotiation with the Ministry, which then formalised in the LCR certification.

title: Foodstuffs - Registration and other technical requirements.
description:
Burdensome registration and labelling requirements and import conditions for food products.

Registration issues: Indonesian Consumer Protection Law (2000) requires all foodstuffs sold to Indonesian consumers to be approved and bear a registration number. The process of approval by the Food and Drug Safety Agency (BPOM) is a cause of concern for European companies.

Lengthy procedures: Procedures require an average registration time of 6-9 months, while the legal requirement for BPOM is 45 days. However, recent reports show a considerable improvement in registration procedures, albeit still being burdensome.

Onerous requirements: each ingredient needs be declared together with an analysis report, a requirement of a process chart of manufacturing process, which is also an IPR issue, since information requested may require the revelation of proprietary trade secrets.

The Minister of Trade Regulation No. 73/M-DAG/PER/9/2015, amending the Regulation No. 10/M-DAG/PER/1/2014 and Reg. No. 67/M-DAG/PER/11/2013, continues to require burdensome labelling requirements in Indonesian language. The Regulation, however, allows stickering, embossment and/or inserting the label inside the product package.

Additional analysis: BPOM often additionally conducts its own laboratory analysis.

Due to inconsistent application of the rules, a registration applicant may have to submit additional information several times before the application is accepted.
Import licensing and other conditions.

Several food and beverages products are additionally subject to import licensing, pre-shipment verifications and entry port limitation under the Ministry of Trade Regulation No. 42/2018, modifying the Regulations No. 12/2018 and 94/2017, which had consequently amended the Regulation No. 87/M-DAG/ PER/10/2015 on Import Provisions for Specific Products. The Regulation No. 42/2018 took out the provision of Bitung Port in North Sulawesi as an entry port designated only imports of food and beverage, apparel and other ready-made textile products, footwear and electronic devices. Meanwhile, the Regulation No. 12/2018 continues stipulating processes for the import of certain goods that are classified as “specific products”, including food and beverages, traditional medicines and food supplements, cosmetics and household health supplies, apparel and other ready-made textile products, footwear, electronic devices, and toys (“Specific Products”). Only shipment or personal belongings of passengers or air crew with the value of up to USD 1,500 per person (FOB) – transported by air – are exempted from the obligation. The Regulation states that inspection on the imported products shall be conducted after passing through Customs Area.

The legislation for food self-sufficiency (Food Law 18/2012) sets out the frame for restricting imports into Indonesia . The Food Law 18/2012 was adopted by Parliament (DPR) on 16 November 2012. Its scope is very broad and affects all elements of food production, trade and marketing. It states, among others, that import and export of food shall only take place in accordance with national food needs effectively allowing to pose a ban on imports. It further stipulates labelling requirements that are unclear (’during entry’) and notes a government ’obligation’ to stabilise food prices. Article 34 mandates that "staple foods" can only be exported if domestic consumption is fulfilled and national food reserves are sufficient. Food can only be exported after considering domestic food consumption and national interests. Article 36 mandates that food can only be imported if domestic production is insufficient or the item cannot be produced domestically. Articles 46/51/55/56/108- Allows and notes a government "obligation" to stabilize the supply and price of "staple foods". This can be done, among other ways, by price fixing, provision and management of food supply and food trading, establishment of tax/tariff policy in favour of national interests, and regulation of import and export. Article 55 protects income and buying power of Indonesian farmers and fishermen, whereas article 56 allows establishing tax and tariffs in favour of national interests.

title: Regulation concerning provisions of tyre import
description:
On 11 November 2016 the Indonesian Minister for Trade issued a new text concerning provisions on tyre imports (77/M-DAG/PER/11/2016, hereinafter R77), which brings back the problems the tyre industry had identified in 2015, mainly the following:

  • Import quotas in the form of non-automatic licensing (on the basis of 6 months import plan) – Art. 6, art. 10, art. 13
  • Pre-shipment inspections with verification or technical analysis at port of loading – Art. 11, art 13
  • Possession of warehouses and means of transports – art. 6

In January 2018, the Indonesian Minister of Trade issued Regulation No 6/2018 to update provisions on tyre. The new added provision on post-border mechanism (goods can go directly to warehouses while inspection will be done based on risk management by technical ministry in post border) and remove a requirement to get recommendation from the Ministry of Industry to get import approval. However, other restrictions remained.

The Minister of Trade Regulation No. 117/2018, issued in December 2018, further amended the provisions on tyre. The regulation reinstates that imports can only be carried out through Bonded Logistic Centres, where inspection takes place. The regulation also re-introduces the requirement for import recommendation issued by the Ministry of Industry as a pre-requisite for import approval issued by the Ministry of Trade.

The Ministry of Industry issued Regulation No. 31/2019 that amends Regulation No. 1/2017 on the guidelines for issuance of tyre import recommendation. Effective since October 2019, the new regulation divides import for further production, i.e. "producer", into two category based on the industry: automotive industry and non-automotive industry. Application of tire import recommendation is conducted online through SIINas. Requirements for producers include tyre import plan, plan for production that will utilise the imported tyre, and import realisation. Meanwhile, requirements for general importer includes tyre import plan and realisation.

Some of the difficult processes and requirements that Indonesia has been imposing since 2021, i.e. cumbersome import quota request mechanism and uncertainties in extension of Indonesian National Standards (SNI) extension, remained in 2022. The process of obtaining the SNI for the European automotive sector thus continues to be costly and burdensome. For instance, as of July 2022, restrictions related to inspections of European plants remain.

The industry also highlighted the likelihood of Indonesia’s commodity balance affecting their business operations in the future.

title: tax discrimitaion on alcoholic beverages
description:
1) Ministry of Finance Regulation No. 237/PMK.04/2009 exempts certain products produced locally from the excise tax. Alcoholic beverages are exempt from the excise tax, if: a. made by the people in Indonesia; b. manufacturing done in a simple, using simple equipment commonly used by people of Indonesia and its production does not exceed 25 (twenty five) liters per day(...)". Update on 9 May 2017: the regulation was replaced by Ministry of Finance regulation 59/PMK.04/2017. However, as the regulation did not contain any significant updates relating to the discriminatory excise policy, this intervention continues to be marked as in force. 2)  Amendment Ministry of Finance Regulation No. 207/PMK.011/2013 of the initial regulation 62/PMK.011/2010: The new law concerned involves an excise tax but it discriminates against imported alcoholic beverages. Compared to previous regulation where the excise tax for beverages with 5-20% of ethyl alcohol was 30'000 IDR/litre for locally produced bottles and 40'000 IDR/litre for imported ones, the excise tax was raised for both cases by 10%. Also, the excise tax for the category with over 20% of ethyl alcohol has been changed. Locally produced bottles will be taxed 80'000 IDR/litre (previously 75'000 IDR/litre), while imported ones 139'000 IDR/litre (before 130'000 IDR/litre). The applied tax rates discriminate against imported spirits for drinks >5% alcohol. 

 

 

3). In July 2015, the import tariff scheme for cider, class B alcoholic drinks, and class C alcoholic drinks was changed from a specific tariff to an ad valorem tariff following the issuance of Ministry of Finance Regulation No. 132/PMK.010/2015. The import tariff is set at 90% of the market price for cider and class B alcoholic drinks and at 150% for class C alcoholic drinks. This resulted in a steep increase in the unit price of imported wine and spirits, and widened the price gap between local and imported products. At the same time, the increase in import tariff creates higher incentives for illegal trade of alcoholic drinks in Indonesia.
