title: Government Procurement - discrimination in favour of local suppliers and lack of transparency
description:
Malaysia used GP to carry out its national objective of protecting its Bumiputera – ethnic Malays that comprise a majority of its population

Despite the recent improvement in the transparency of the government procurement regime, important restrictions still persist. Auditor General Reports repeatedly highlight cases of procured goods, services and works that are being paid for well above market prices, under-utilised, and substandard:

1) International tendering is only allowed when goods and services are not available locally or local companies do not have the necessary expertise and capacity AND a joint venture is not possible, and in most cases, foreign suppliers require a local partner/intermediary to be permitted to tender.

2) In tenders open to international participation, domestic tenderers benefit from preferential treatment. International tenderers are required to provide a tender deposit whereas local companies are exempted. Performance bonds are required over a certain threshold and must be obtained from domestic financial institutions.

3) All individuals, companies or corporate bodies intending to participate in government procurement of works, supplies and services are required to be registered with the Ministry of Finance. Foreign companies must establish a local subsidiary company in order to register with MOF and be eligible to participate, except for branch offices of consultancy firms.

title: Investment  - restrictions and equity caps remain in place in spite of recent liberalisation
description:
In 2009, Malaysia removed the requirement for a Foreign Investment Committee (FIC) to screen proposed investments and repealed FIC Guidelines on the acquisition of interests, mergers, and takeovers, thereby reducing the minimum equity requirement for bumiputera in locally incorporated companies from 30 % to 12.5% for newly listed companies. With the abolishment of the Foreign Investment Committee, Malaysia removed its all-round foreign equity ceiling of 70%. Despite the fact that the general cap is removed, foreign equity restrictions remain in certain sectors. These are imposed by the different Ministries, rather than by a central body. Apart from formalized regulation on the matter, Ministries may also impose equity restrictions as a condition to obtain a license.

A separate set of regulations is imposed to reserve equity in businesses for ethnic Malays or Bumiputera. The rationale is to increase business participation of the Bumiputera. While ethnic Malays are the majority racial group in Malaysia, they are underrepresented in the country’s business community, which is largely made up of ethnic Chinese and Indians.

In these cases, the restrictions on foreign equity are not in favour of nationals of Malaysia, but ethnic Malay. In other words, a foreign invested company where the non-foreign equity is held by individuals who aren’t ethnically Malay would still fall foul of the law. The issue continues to be politically sensitive.

Areas which are subject Bumiputera reservations include banking and finance, water, batik production, agriculture, defense, energy and telecommunications.

Generally, investment in manufacturing is fully liberalised but investment in services remains subject to foreign equity caps in many sectors.

Nevertheless, the Government retains the authority to review and approve all investments by both domestic and foreign investors through the issuing of licences by the relevant Ministries, which generally enjoy full discretion in regard to licensing decisions. The licensing requirement applies to investment in manufacturing over RM 2.5 million, or having more than 75 employees. Licenses are required to carry out nearly all services activities. Foreign equity caps remain, notably for investment in telecommunications (70% for network services/facilities providers), oil and gas services (49%), insurance (70%), and transport. Foreign investment in newly privatised entities is limited to 25%. Malaysia makes extensive use of investment incentives and performance requirements are imposed on investors.

title: Lack of protection and enforcement of Intellectual Property Rights
description: The huge market for counterfeit and piracy goods in Mexico is a major obstacle for the sale of certain authentic products. Effective controls and sanctions are needed to diminish the importation and commercialisation of counterfeit goods. The European sectors most affected include pharmaceuticals, luxury goods, electronics, alcoholic beverages, personal care, auto parts and tobacco industries among others as well as entertainment and cultural products in both physical and digital format and illegal software.

title: Lack of protection of Geographical Indications and EU names
description:
The registration in Mexico of foreign geographical indications (GI) as such used to be impossible and alternatives offered only weak and uncertain protection. This led to a number of imitations and usurpations of European names and GI’s, which affect the access to the market of the authentic products and raise confusion among consumers. The new FTA contains provisions for the reciprocal protection of a selected list of Geographical Indications of the EU; 340 names for foodstuffs, wines and beers will be protected. This is on top of the already existing protection for EU spirits GIs protected through the 1997 EU/Mexico Spirit Agreement, which will also be incorporated into the new agreement, raising its level of protection.

 

Background

The EU has a wide variety of protected GIs. They represent an important pillar of the EU’s quality policy on agricultural products and constitute a genuine interest for producers as they unlock value by capitalising on consumer’s desire for diversity and quality products.

The registration of foreign GIs in Mexico used to be difficult despite Mexico’s obligations under the TRIPS Agreement, as the national GI legislation was unclear as regards GI protection and inappropriate for foreign GIs.

The registration of a foreign GI as such used to be technically impossible in Mexico, since the legislation stated that the Federal State is the owner of any Denomination of Origin (DO). The only ways for a European GI to obtain some protection within the Mexican territory were to register its name as a collective trademark at the Mexican Institute of Industrial Property (IMPI), or when covered by the Lisbon Agreement (of which Mexico is a party) or by the EU-Mexico bilateral Spirits Agreement signed in 1997.

 

Some EU right holders have tried without success for a long time to protect their rights via the trademark system, which handles applications in a sometimes non consistent way  Registration of a GI as a collective trademark does not provide sufficient protection since the compliance to the Mexican quality standard is voluntary (while it is compulsory for Mexican DO), and also because any disputes would have to be solved in court, which involves lengthy, costly and uncertain procedures.

 

In April 2017, the Senate approved a major revamp to the IPR Law, which included some significant changes for national and foreign GIs. The amendments include very important changes with respect to Appellations of Origin (AOs), and for the first time in Mexico specific protection for Geographical Indications (GIs) is included.  Regarding foreign GIs, IMPI will recognise those protected in a foreign country upon the terms of the International Treaties. The owner of a DO or GI protected in a foreign country will be entitled to apply for its recognition by filing an application before IMPI and enclosing the document showing the protection under the laws of the corresponding country or according to the international treaties.  The grounds of refusal, opposition rules and invalidation are set identically as those for national applications. Cancellation, however, will proceed when the document showing foreign protection is not valid any longer in such country.

 

In addition, the new FTA contains provision for the reciprocal protection of a selected list of Geographical Indications of the EU; 340 names for foodstuffs, wines and beers will be protected. This is on top of the already existing protection for 217 EU spirits GIs protected through the 1997 EU/Mexico Spirit Agreement, which will also be incorporated into the new agreement.

 

Before the new FTA comes into force however, EU food products continue to suffer from another widespread practice; the misuse of expressions such as "tipo …" or "estilo …" on labels. These branding practices generate unfair competition, consumer confusion and contribute to undermining the reputation and image of the genuine products. The latest IPR reform also addressed this issue, with the imposition of administrative offences, as it prohibits the production, storage, transport, distribution or sale of a product equal or similar to those protected  under a DO or GI national Declaratory or those foreign DOs or GIs recognised by IMPI, using any type of indication or element misleading consumers as to the quality or origin of the products, including those as "kind", "type", "manner", "imitation" or the like.

title: Requirements to import sawnwood
description:
According to Mexican standards NOM-016-SEMARNAT-2013 all imported sawn wood must be bark-free, in addition to a number of prescribed treatments.

This is considered excessive by the EU industry, as exemplified in the international standard for packaging wood, ISPM 15. In this standard, small bark residues are allowed in the wood.

The removal of 100% of the residues after mechanical de-barking imposes a substantial cost without justification from a phytosanitary point of view.

november 2022: No progress whatsoever

title: Lack of recognition of EU regionalisation measures for African Swine Fever (ASF) and ban of safe commodities
description:
Mexico does not recognise the regionalisation measures introduced by the EU in response to outbreaks of African Swine Fever (ASF) in several Member States.

African swine fever is an WOAH (World Organisation for Animal Health) listed disease. WOAH has set clear international standards and defined recommendations and conditions, which guarantee safe trade (and includes zoning/ regionalisation measures).

The EU has adopted a specific and complete set of legislation and guidelines on ASF preparedness, control, diagnoses and zoning/ regionalisation that is in line with WOAH standards and kept up to date on the basis of regular scientific advice provided by the European Food safety Authority (EFSA).

 

On this basis, the EU can guarantee safe trade of live pigs and pig products from disease-free areas.

The disease has occurred in the EU since January 2014 with different EU Member States affected, and occasional outbreaks continue to occur in the EU

 

Mexico should immediately lift the trade restrictions after EU MS have regained freedom (in the whole or part of their territory) from ASF in line with international sanitary standards (WOAH) and WTO rules (SPS Agreement). Furthermore, trade restrictions should not be imposed on pigs or pig products originating in ASF free zones/regions of Member States.

Mexico should not put in place any trade restrictions on pig products which have been heat-treated or processed in a way that ensures the destruction of the virus.

As required under the WTO SPS Agreement (Article 6), MEX  shall accept the sanitary status of EU Member States (and regions within them under the principle of zoning/ regionalisation) and the animal health standards for international trade in live pigs and pig products in line with the sanitary and trade recommendations and criteria of the WOAH, and NOT impose any restrictions/bans which go beyond those standards. This means that any justified restrictions should ONLY apply to the affected area and not to the whole country concerned. Country-wide bans are disproportionate and not justified and go against the WTO SPS Agreement.

At October 2023, Mexico has  imposed country-wide bans to BE, DE, IT , PL and SE

Mexico does not recognize the principle of "regionalization" or the effectiveness of the cooking or curing treatments of pork which WOAH has declared capable of inactivating the ASF virus

title: Procedure for the approval of establishments without prior inspection and cost of the audits.
description:
Mexico applies a burdensome and costly procedure to approve establishments of meat and meat products, with on the spot inspections for each new establishment. The cost of this procedure is covered by the EU establishments visited. However, the EU grants to Mexico the approval of the list of establishments from which to import without prior inspection (the so-called prelisting system). The system is not in place for EU exporting establishments for meat and meat products . It only exists  partially for dairy products.

As of 2022, there is no meaningful progress with MEX on the application of pre-listing.

Until March 2023, only NL and ES had got MEX to list porcine establishments. In March few others were added to the list for ES as regard poultry and porcine establishments but the listing is always via audit to each of the indicidual establishments.

title: Fresh fruit and vegetables import restrictions.
description:
Import restrictions on fresh fruit and vegetable due to cumbersome administrative procedures import protocols which include a disproportionate mitigation measures (cold treatment) and pre-shipment inspections in the country of origin paid by the industry (preclearance).Disproportionate and trade-disruptive measures, which are also against the IPPC, impede effectively EU export of fruits to Mexico, despite the EU-Mexico Free Trade Agreement in force. Mexico has not yet provided the basis of their risk assessment to apply this wide range of pests and mitigation measures.

Mitigation measures. The list of measures to mitigate quarantine pests for citrus, apples, pears, kiwis and peaches are numerous and strict. Mexico argues that the whole territory of the EU is taken in consideration and a wide range of pests and pest mitigation measures is imposed.

Inspections visits. The interested party has to pay the related costs.

List of quarantine pest. Mexico does not have a fixed quarantine pests list for the concerned products. Therefore each product is subject to a case-by-case study, to allow its entry to Mexico. The provided quarantine pest lists were changed by Mexico without any risk assessment justifying the modification of the list

title: Registration and approval of health products and agro-chemicals
description:
EU companies continue to suffer from longstanding bottleneck with health product registrations before the competent authority: Comisión Federal para la Protección contra Riesgos Sanitarios (COFEPRIS). The main concerns include:

- excessive delays in obtaining product approvals, import permits and/or clinical trials, whether these be medicines, medical equipment, or agricultural inputs;

- lack of clear approval criteria and uneven application; and

- lack of access to and transparency from COFEPRIS.

title: Import and commercialisation prohibition of heated tobacco products
description:
The importation and commercialisation of heated tobacco products (HTPs) has been prohibited in Mexico as of December 2022.

The prohibition of imports (and exports) of HTPs is included in the Decree issuing the General Import and Export Tax Law (Decreto por el que se expide la Ley de los Impuestos Generales de Importación y de Exportación), published in the Mexican Official Gazette on 7 June 2022: https://www.dof.gob.mx/nota_detalle.php?codigo=5654292&fecha=07/06/2022#gsc.tab=0. It affects products classified under tariff lines 2404.11.01, 2404.12.01, 2404.19.01, 3824.99.83, 8543.40.01 and 8543.90.03.

The prohibition of circulation and commercialisation is contained in a decree published in the Mexican Official Gazette on 31 May 2022  and it affects Electronic Nicotine Delivery Systems (ENDS), Alternative Nicotine Delivery Systems (ANDS), and Electronic Non-Nicotine Delivery Systems (ENNDS), e-cigarettes and vaping devices with similar uses as well as the liquids, mixtures and others used with them: https://www.dof.gob.mx/nota_detalle.php?codigo=5653845&fecha=31/05/2022#gsc.tab=0

title: Discrimination against EU companies in Public Procurement
description: Public procurement is included in Article 134 of the Mexican Constitution. The Law of Public Sector Acquisitions, Leasing and Services (Acquisition Law) and the Law of Public Works and Related Services (Public Work Law) are implementing Article 134. At local level, each of the 31 states and the Federal District has different public procurement laws. After 2007 the Mexican government undertook to modernise its procurement procedures with some success. The current Procurement Laws foresees 3 types of public tenders: national public tenders, international public tenders conducted under international free trade agreements to which Mexico is a party, and open international public tenders. In national public tenders, only Mexican nationals may participate. The commodities covered by the tender must be produced in Mexico and their content must be at least 50% of national origin. The proportion of tenders open to foreign companies in 2013 is not an exception (=only 10% on average of PPs are international, although in terms of value, the % may vary between 30 to 35%).

title: Arbitrary customs procedures
description:
Excessive document requirements for importers are causing delays and represent a non-tariff barrier. EU companies report that customs procedures are sometimes not transparent nor consistent with the rules stipulated in the EU-Mexico Free Trade Agreement. These issues have been partially addressed in the customs reform of 2013 and later during the negotiations of the modernised FTA. 

Background

Customs procedures in Mexico continue being considered as inefficient mainly because of their complex and irksome technical requirements. A simplification of procedures and reduction of administrative costs would not only facilitate trade, but also release public resources that could be allocated more efficiently elsewhere, such as for security concerns or intellectual property (IP) enforcement.

The Government partially addressed these issues with a customs reform in 2008, as it sought to abolish the estimated price system, cancel the importers’ register, eliminate the need to present a formal certificate of origin for sensitive products and eliminate certain monopolistic measures such as the single channel for imports. Further encouraging steps to facilitate trade were taken in the recent customs reform of 2013, which was published as law in the official gazette on 9 December 2013 and came into effect on 10 December 2013 (Decreto por el que se reforman, adicionan y derogan diversas disposiciones de la Ley Aduanera).

The reform of 2013 aimed to reinforce trade facilitation by creating a customs electronic system, meaning that all import and export customs declarations are now to be filed electronically. Another important and long standing issue, which this reform addressed, was the abolishment of the obligatory use of custom brokers. Importers and exporters are able to carry-out their own customs clearance. As far as risk analysis is concerned, the reform eliminated a second round of customs inspection and established that the customs inspection has to be carried out with the use of non-intrusive technology.

However, concerns remain at certain customs procedures such as the lack of prior notification of procedural changes and inconsistent interpretation of trade requirements at the different ports of entry.

With regard to security issues, the Government has been working on strengthening border control via updates of security control equipment and reinforced cooperation with the US, but customs’ role and capacity in combating illegal trade, notably piracy and counterfeit products remain weak, partly due to the fact that legislation does not grant them ex officio powers.

title: Morocco - registration requirements for foreign food establishments
description:
Morocco notified to the WTO SPS Committee a new set of registration requirements for foreign food establishments active in the food sectors listed above on 17 May 2023. The EU was engaging with Morocco on this issue to gain sufficient understanding on the new requirements, that would ensure compliance for EU MS establishments, via the notification channel and bilaterally. 

Following several exchanges on this matter, the final issue remained whether when certifying compliance, Morocco would accept that the EU Member State competent authorities do so based on the EU requirements, as those are equivalent to level of safety required by Morocco. The Commission considered that this would facilitate the process of registration on the EU side by providing a clearer legal situation, in which certification is based on EU requirements and not directly the Moroccan ones.

The European Commission proposed a language according to which the EU Member State competent authorities would certify that the food establishments ‘are subject to official controls under the European Food Law’.  

On this proposal, Morocco stated in writing that they considered that there was no major divergence between the Moroccan and EU food legislation. Furthermore, Morocco recognised the competence of the competent EU Member State authorities and their level of effective safety controls on food in the EU.

In our views, this has created more legal certainty when registering EU establishments on this final main issue. Nevertheless, the European Commission continues to follow the implementation of these requirements. 

The written exchanges between the EU and Morocco on this issue are attached.

title: Morocco - requirements on Xylella fastidiosa
description:
Morocco's measure, notified to the WTO SPS Committee on 7 October 2021, as MAR/67 Add. 1, introduced major barriers for EU plant products. It introduces a ban of orgamental plants from countries affected by Xylella fastidiosa and regionalisation rules for fruit plants from these countries. Furthermore, also countries where the pest is not present, have to undertake burdensome reporting and documentary requirements. The EU has been engaging with Morocco both in the WTO SPS notification framework and bilaterally. Morocco is still to effectively engage with those EU MS where the disease is present. 

During the June WTO SPS Committee, Morocco seemed open to organise a meeting with the COM and the relevant MS. However, the official request of the COM (as attached) remains unanswered for the time being. Morocco proposed meeting the 4 affected MS on a side of a phytosanitary meeting in Malta, Nov 2024. The COM had a preparatory meeting with the MS interested on 20 Nov and will still insist on having the meeting as requested officially.

title: Externalised conformity assessments and compulsory standards
description:
Imports into Morocco of industrial products covered by Law No. 24-09 on the safety of products and services, other than food and pharmaceutical products are subject, since February 2020, to conformity checks executed by five private companies designated by the Moroccan Ministry of Industry and Trade (Bureau Veritas, Applus-Fomento, TUV Rheinland, SGS Maroc and Intertek Labtest). Domestic goods are not subject to the same assessments. In addition, Morocco uses domestic compulsory standards that are de facto technical regulations.

According to Law 24-09, all economic operators (producers, importers) are expected to respect the general obligations of safety and place on the market products that comply with safety requirements according to the applicable technical regulation. However, even if the standards and technical regulations are the same, there is a difference in the way controls/conformity assessments are carried out on local and imported products.

The externalised conformity assessments for imports have been introduced on 1 February 2020[1] in the framework of a reform of the system of market surveillance. Some of the targeted products also need to be accompanied by the Moroccan marking Cmim (separate market access entry in Access2Markets[2]). The system was originally presented as a way to facilitate imports into Morocco of products meeting EU standards but this is not proving to be the case.

For the majority of products subject to the system, exporters need to obtain the conformity assessments in the country of origin (produits controlés à l’origine), while for the others they will need to obtain them upon arrival in Morocco (produits controlés à l’arrivée au Maroc).

The system has proven costly, time consuming and redundant, duplicating assessments already carried out in the EU, especially if the standards used are the same. Furthermore, sometimes exporters got contradictory information from the conformity assessment bodies mandated to undertake assessments; some were requested to submit sensitive commercial information.

According to the website of the Moroccan Ministry of Industry and Trade, conformity assessments carried out in the country of export are only acceptable if carried out by the authorised Moroccan conformity assessment bodies or if Morocco and the country have concluded a Mutual Recognition Agreement.

Controls/conformity assessments on local products aimed at ensuring market surveillance and risk management are carried out by the regional and provincial delegations of the Ministry of Industry and Trade. Officials from the Ministry collect samples from producers and distributors, which are analysed by one of the Moroccan conformity assessment bodies recognised/mandated to carry out checks depending on the type of product. These checks are not systematic.

At the same time, it appears that Moroccan standards are developed based on international and/or EU standards, but that minor variations are introduced, implying that EU exporters have to undertake again third party conformity assessment based on Moroccan standards, with associated delays and costs, even when the same third party certification has been done in the EU for virtually the same standard. Morocco does not justify in each and individual case why the international standard has not been used/derogated from as a basis for the technical regulation.

 

[1]      http://www.mcinet.gov.ma/fr/content/surveillance-du-march%C3%A9

[2]      https://trade.ec.europa.eu/access-to-markets/en/barriers/details?barrier_id=14862

title: Customs duties for used products
description: A tariff-dismantling timetable for the used products listed in Annex 6 of the Association Agreement (with the exception of worn clothing and other worn articles) should have been established by the Association Council three years after the entry force of the Agreement, ie by March 2003 (article 12 §2.b). This timetable still needs to be established.

title: Export ban on hides and skins and wet blue
description:
In 2000, Morocco started blocking the access to leather raw materials through the operation of an export ban. In 2001 Morocco converted the export ban in a system of export licences, alleging sourcing scarcity for the domestic industry as well as environmental reasons. The list of leather products subject to export licence was initially very long and - following pressure from the EU- was subsequently reduced to cover currently only raw hides and wet-blue leather. No export licenses are de facto delivered for these products, which results in an export prohibition.

Domestic legal reference:

- Circulaire n° 4703/311 1 juin 2001

- Circulaire n° 5037/311 du 30 janvier 2007

title: Public procurement regulation laws
description:
On 10 September 2020, the head of government addressed circular n°15/2020 to ministerial departments and public establishments calling for the application of the domestic preference and encouraging the use of made in Morocco products in public procurement. Decree n°2-19-69 of 24 May 2019 foresees a margin of preference for domestic companies of 15% (article 155) and that 30% of the contracts should be reserved for domestic SMEs, cooperatives, cooperative unions and self-employed entrepreneurs (article 156). The possibility to grant national preference was already foreseen in earlier public procurement legislation (decrees of 1998, 2007 and 2013) but de facto rarely applied. Decree 2-12-349 of 20 march 2013 also already foresaw a portion reserved for domestic SMEs (20%). To be noted that Morocco is not party to the WTO Government Procurement Agreement.

In addition to recalling the fact that offers presented by foreign companies are increased by a percentage not exceeding 15%, the circular of September 2020 foresees that companies participating in public procurement contracts and using foreign imported products should issue a certificate proving that there are no national products that meet the required standards. Public procurement contracts above 100 million dirhams (around € 9bn) are subject to prior authorisation by a special commission chaired by the ministry of Finances (for public administrations) or the ministry of Interior (for territorial authorities) and subject to a lower rate of domestic preference of 7,5%. The Circular also refers to the obligation to respect Moroccan standards.

Morocco adopted a new decree on public procurement on 29 December 2022, which consolidates and tightens the above described already onerous restrictions on public procurement in Morocco. The decree has been published on 9 March 2023 and entered into force on 1 September 2023.

While most of the restrictions provided for in the new public procurement decree already existed previously, the decree consolidates them and seems to extend their scope in the following areas:

  • The new mandatory generalised application of the national preference scheme was optional in the 2014 Decree and the new Decree will restrict the access of the EU companies notably SMEs to the public procurement markets.
  • In the same vein, the broad general ban of subcontracting to economic operators located in third countries, optional in 2014, will deeply impact EU SMEs.
  • In addition, the SME set aside was already included in the 2014 Decree, but the new Decree raised the level of the set aside from 20% to 30%.
  • Similarly, the local workforce set at 10% in the 2014 Decree was raised to 20% in the new Decree.

title: Requirement to sign and stamp origin declarations by customs authorities in Morocco
description:
Moroccan customs authorities require declarations of origin for imports into the country signed and stamped by the MS customs authorities despite the fact that, for authorised exporters, the requirement to stamp and sign the origin declarations should not be necessary, according to the provisions of the EU-Morocco Association Agreement. This exemption for authorised exporters is also included in the instructions by the Moroccan customs authorities. The EU Delegation was in contact with Member States embassies in Morocco and confirmed that the problem is widespread. 

In a reply to a letter from the European Commission provided on 13 February 2023, the Moroccan Customs indicated that the contractual provisions laid down in Circular No 4978/233 of 30/12/2005, adopted for the application of the rules of origin contained in the EU-Morocco Agreement, remain valid. Morocco confirmed further that there is no general obligation in Morocco to sign invoice declarations made out by approved exporters. However, EU industry representative confirms that in practise the Moroccan Customs do not respect their legal obligations and continue insisting on the signed and stamped declarations of origin, which creates an additional cost and time delay for the exporters.

title: New foreign trade law - protection of domestic production
description:
The foreign trade law n°9-14 of 2 March 2014 devotes 12 articles out of a total of 34 to the protection of domestic production (Chapitre IV "Des mesures de protection de la production national"). Ahead of its adoption, the EU had repeatedly shared its concerns, both bilaterally and on the occasion of the WTO Trade Policy Review of Morocco, which led to some improvements of the text. The law foresees, without prejudice to Morocco's international obligations, the possibility to grant protection to domestic producers via tariffs and quantitative restrictions, whenever this is required by the general interest. More specifically, protection may be granted to infant industries ("productions nouvelles") and producers of agricultural goods.

No concrete problematic cases were brought up by EU stakeholders (MS, industry) in Morocco in recent years in the framework of the application of the law. In December 2019, the Commission considered that no further action was needed on this issue and decided to close the file.

However, the Commission remained vigilant notably in view of the possible adoption of the decrees implementing the law.  

The case was therefore reopened in March 2022 as it was brought to the Commission's attention that a draft decree, implementing the law, has been prepared by the Moroccan Ministry of trade and was submitted to the Secretariat General of the government for adoption. 

Draft Decree 2.22.30 contains several problematic features:

- it foresees the mandatory registration of all exporters and importers to a new Registry administered by the Ministry of trade, whereas the conditions and criteria for registration will only be known subsequently (via arreté). The purpose of such a Registry is not specified but it appears to be motivated by the desire to better identify active traders and fight informality.

- for some sectors to be determined, the draft decree foresees the establishment of "specifications" (Cahiers de charges), drawn by competent authorities in consultation with local sectoral associations, whereby importers and exporters of products covered by such specifications will need to declare their compliance with the conditions provided therein. The rationale for such system is unclear. It seems it will be additional to the existing system of third party conformity assessment, which is already considered burdensome by exporters to Morocco.

- it also establishes a consultative Commission on imports, located within the Ministry of trade, whose responsibility is to examine all requests for protection (via tariffs or quantitative restrictions). This will be additional to the existing structures responsible for examining and implementing trade defense measures, which Morocco is an active user.

title: Mandatory cmim marking
description:
The measures relates to mandatory conformity assessments for Electric material and toys, with a view to obtain Cmim marking (Moroccan Conformity Assessment). The measure is being implemented since 1 February 2019.

As of 1 February 2019, the Moroccan Cmim marking became compulsory for the sale in Morocco of electrical products subject to technical regulations 2573-14 (low voltage) and 2574-14 (electromagnetic compatibility), as well as toys subject to technical regulation 2574-15 on toy safety. This measure results from the implementing decrees of Law 24/09, concerning the Safety of Products and Services.

The measure applies to several electrical equipment designed for incorporation into other apparatus and equipment for use as such. Although the Cmim marking is largely equivalent to the European CE marking, the latter no longer suffices on products imported into Morocco. The Moroccan Ministry of industry has expressed tentative interest in negotiating a mutual recognition agreement with the EU.

In practical terms, for obtaining the Moroccan Cmim marking, indispensable to access the market of Morocco, the products must undergo conformity assessments on security and electromagnetic compatibility. For the assessment, it is mandatory the preparation of a “technical dossier” containing information on the conception and production of the material, including circuits, components, and also designs on the functioning of the products.

In response to concerns from importers and to facilitate the adjustment to the new system, and following an additional extension of the transition period over the summer, the Ministry gave the possibility to importers, upon arrival of the goods to Morocco, to affix the marking up to 31st of December 2019. At the end of that transition period, the responsibility rests exclusively with the producers and, if applicable, their authorised representatives in Morocco.

title: Conditions for marketing authorisation of pharmaceutical products
description:
Morocco requires the presence of an industrial unit in Morocco in order to get the marketing authorisation (Autorisation de Mise sur le Marché AMM), either directly or indirectly. In practice, the drugs of foreign producers will only be authorized for sale on the Moroccan market either if they establish a production lab in situ, or if they cooperate with a local industrial partner for the purposes of production or distribution (the local partner becomes the legal holder of the marketing authorisation).

Domestic legal references: Loi n°17-04 portant code du médicament et de la pharmacie datée du 22 novembre 2006, publiée le 7 décembre 2006 (en pièce jointe) and Chapitre II du Décret AMM publié au BO 6388 (sur le transfert d’Authorisation de Mise sur le Marché).

The Moroccan Direction du Médicament et de la Pharmacie (DMP) justifies this localisation requirement with the need to guarantee the quality of imported products and ensure the sufficient availabilty of locally produced pharmaceuticals, notably essential ones.

An additional constraint is that no new marketing authorisations are granted if the pharmaceutical products are already produced domestically.

title: Import ban on energy drinks and flavoured synthetic drinks
description: The Government of Nepal imposed on 17 June 2019 a ban on the importation of 30 category of products which included “Caffeinated Energy Drinks” and “Flavoured synthetic drinks” into Nepal. The Government did not provide any scientific or legal justification in support for the ban. Moreover, there was no prior notice given to the industry. It is perceived that the objective of the ban was to curb the trade deficit of the Government.

title: Nigerian postal legislation
description: In August 2021, a new Nigerian postal legislation [Bill SB.657 for an “Act to repeal the Nigerian Postal Service Act Cap N127 LFN 2004, and establish the Nigeria Postal Commission to make comprehensive provisions for the development and regulation of postal services and for other related matters”]. In March 2022, the Senate approved it's amended version of the Bill. It has been been awaiting the President's signature.

title: SON-CAP and e-Registration of machinery and electronic equipment (standardisation measure)
description:
Mandatory pre-shipment registration and e-registration of products, both locally manufactured and imported, with Standard Organisation of Nigeria (SON). Combined procedure is burdensome and costly, especially where several different products are required.

Under the SON-CAP regime, imported goods need to undergo pre-shipment certification through authorized service providers. Goods are only released at arrival upon production of completed SON-CAP certificates. The cost of this procedure amounts to some $600 per container/per product; meaning that for mixed shipments (containing different products) this fee will multiply accordingly. Validity of certificates varies between 6 months and 1 year.

Under the obligatory e-registration scheme, introduced in 2013, all products (i.e. both imported and locally manufactured) in the above sectors have to be registered electronically on Standards Organisation of Nigeria’s online platform. The goal is to provide an online database to support SON in tracking and tackling substandard goods in the Nigerian market. http://www.son.gov.ng/.

Discussions with concerned parties/stakeholders indicate that per product and model (even change of colour, size or type), registration costs about (additional) $ 600 per item. The maximum validity period for e-registration is 1 year only. This duration is short and represents additional costs for the importer, who is required to renew registration after a year, at most, even when there is no change in the product.

In addition to the huge fees, importers face difficulties in using SONs online platform, where key documents and information on the new e-registration system are absent

title: Registration of foodstuff and drugs (sanitary measures)
description:
The registration needed to import a number of products is complex and burdensome. All production facilities of any new products sold in Nigeria are physically inspected and the import rights are linked to a Nigerian partner needed for the registration at the National Agency for Food and Drug Administration (NAFDAC).

All products to be imported in the sectors of agriculture and fisheries, wines & spirits, food and beverages, chemicals, pharmaceuticals and some other industries have to be registered at NAFDAC. The registration process is very complex and takes a long time. The continuous increase of registration fees is excessive and appears to be much higher for imported products compared to locally manufactured products. Since the NAFDAC procedures changed in 2002, NAFDAC representatives physically inspect all production facilities of any new products sold in Nigeria. This increases the costs. Companies have to register every product type and a separate registration fee has to be paid for different sizes of the same product type.

Foreign companies also complain that in practice it is too difficult to register their goods themselves at NAFDAC although the procedure allows for it. A Nigerian partner (such as a distributor) is required who registers the product in his name. Consequently the Nigerian partner (and not the foreign exporter) obtains the import rights, which can create problems in case the partner needs to be changed. For more information see http://www.nafdacnigeria.org/.

title: Import substitution measures: Import Prohibitions, Licensing and Special Levies
description:
Import bans:  Nigeria introduced bans on the import of various products in 2002 which have been repeatedly modified since. In the most recent amendment of the list some items have been removed (furniture; and sanitary wares of plastics) while tomato paste or concentrate put up for retail sale has been added. The most recent import prohibition list includes 24 categories of products, among which: poultry, pork, beef, eggs, vegetable oil, noodles, waters, beer, bagged cement, some medicaments, soaps and detergents, corrugated paper and paper boards, some textiles, footwear, bags, and tomato paste. "Absolutely" prohibited are arms, second hand clothing, some spirits, counterfeit articles etc. The most recent import ban list can be consulted here: https://customs.gov.ng/?page_id=3075 

Cement: The import bans on bagged cement, in force since November 2009, has been complemented by an import licence quota for bulk cement, set in August 2010 at the level of 2.5 million metric tonnes. Import licenses were given to seven Nigerian entities that have established production facilities in the country under the backward integration policy.

title: Burdensome customs procedures
description: The long time needed for customs clearance (under the destination inspection), the overuse of physical inspections and the erratic valuation methods experienced by EU exporters in Nigeria create additional unnecessary costs for imports in that country.

title: Development of Nigeria Content Act - oil and gas
description:
The law of 21 April 2010 imposes local content requirement for investment in the oil and gas industry. Nigerian companies would retain a substantial share of contracts and projects awarded in the oil and gas sector and would also obtain preferential treatment in the awarding of oil blocks, oil field licences and oil lifting licences. Minimum Nigerian content is defined, as are the preferences for Nigerian operators. A Nigerian investor is granted a 10% advantage over a foreign bidder. The Nigerian Content Monitoring Board is set to supervise the compliance with the law.  The law builds on the previous local content policy, with the aim of fostering local industry capacity building; it raises, however, questions about the feasibility and implementation.

On June 2nd 2015, a bill was passed by the National Assembly seeking to amend the Nigerian Oil and Gas Content Development Act by permitting a derogation from the local content requirements where there is inadequate capacity to meet any of the local content targets provided in the Act. The amendment bill, however, has not been assented by the President and has therefore elapsed.

title: Higher ad valorem duty on certain cheeses based on origin.
description:
Before 2012 cheese under classification 04.06.909 were charged by Norway a duty of 27.15 NOK/kilo.

In  2012 Norway had decided to raise the tariff on import of cheese. With the change, all cheeses under this category were  charged an ad-valorem duty of 277%, the MFN bound duty. The only exception was a list of 14 cheeses  which kept the old tariff of NOK 27.15 per kilo, based on their name and origin.

Hard type cheeses are classified by Norway under tariff line 04.06.9098 and face an MFN import tariff of 277%.

title: Export ban on Norwegian Atlantic farmed salmon (production grade)
description: Under Norwegian Regulation No. 844 on fish and fish products quality, Norwegian farmed salmon is sorted and marketed, in three quality categories: “superior”, “ordinary” and “production”. Pursuant to Article 17 of the Regulation, salmon is placed in the lowest quality category (“production”) when the fish has wounds, malformations, treatment errors or similar minor defects. Salmon qualified under this quality category is prohibited by Norwegian law from being exported before these defects are corrected at Norwegian processing plants.

title: Non-Tariff Barriers to import food products
description:
Order SRO 237 (I) 2019 from Ministry of Commerce and Textiles establishes that, from the day of its publication date (February 19, 2019) and without a transitional period, all food imports ("All edible products") will need:

  1. minimum of 66% of useful life (prior to expiration), at the time the entry of goods is validated by customs.
  2. Obligation to label in English and Urdu. All information must be contained on the label and no additional sticker will be accepted.
  3. For halal accreditation to be valid it must come from a halal authority that is a member of IHAF or SMIIC. The halal seal must be printed on the label.

title: Pricing issues faced by the pharmaceutical industry
description:
Drug Pricing Policy 2015

Government prices for pharmaceuticals have not been revised (and have not increased) since 2001 in Pakistan despite increased costs for production and distribution, a rapid increase in the inflation rate and rupee devaluation. In March 2015, the Government launched a new "Drugs Pricing Policy" in the form of a Notification (9-12/2014) by the Drug Regulatory Authority of Pakistan within the Ministry of National Health Services, Regulations and Coordination.

The drug price policy was revised in 2018 which included a provision of External Reference Pricing.

The concept of External Reference Pricing (third world countries like Pakistan, the reasons are mentioned below; Multinational manufacturers launch their products in a tactical manner in market. In response to ERP, they first introduce their products in those countries anywhere they can adjust prices freely or negotiate comparatively high prices ( countries where they operating their headquarters) delay and abstain from launching in comparatively lesser price countries and maintain synthetically high list prices even when they are willing for constant to confidential rebates. They use the strategies of drug proliferation i.e. release of products with different formulations, strengths and package size.

Another major factor which cause drastic increase in drug prices is transfer Pricing ( over pricing) which is unfortunately not managed by Regulatory Authorities. A commonly used transfer pricing definition is “the price charged by one member of multinational organization to another member of the same organization for the provision of goods or services or the use of a property, including intangible property. In other words, transfer pricing relates to the price applied to inter-company transactions. These transactions can include the sales of products, the provision of a service and use of (intangible) assets.

title: Export measures on hides and skins
description:
With effect from 1 September 2005, Pakistan had re-introduced a 20 % export tax on leather raw materials and leather products, covering the following products raw hides and skins; tanned or crust hides and skins (including wet state/wet blue) and finished leather (hides and skins) after one year of standstill. The re-introduction of export taxes adversely affects the European tanning sector. The Commission considers that there are no convincing reasons for Pakistan to keep its export taxes in place and has requested Pakistan to normalise the situation as soon as possible.

On 30 June 2021 however, the Ministry of Commerce announced reduction in the regulatory duty from 20% to 10%. This is a positive development.

title: New Automotive Policy
description:
On 1 July 2016, a new Pakistan Automotive Policy came into force for the period 2016-2021. The main aim of the policy is to attract new investors into the in-country car-assembly and car part manufacturing business. To this end, the auto policy provides benefits to the new entrants by creating discrimination towards imports. This discrimination notably affects EU car manufacturers, none of which is currently established on the Pakistani market. The EU’s view is that this discrimination should be removed.

Message to be conveyed:

  • Highlight the discriminatory elements in the auto policy toward EU manufacturers of car parts exporting to Pakistan.
  • Seek clarification of some unclear aspects on the policy such as how the government’s intention to promote "indigenised" components.
  • Encourage a review of the policy to eliminate any discriminatory practices

 

 The new EV is also expected to affect this fiche. The EU DEL is waitng for the end of the fiscal year in June 2025 for a new assesment of the situation.

title: Pre-shipment inspections for power inverters exported to Pakistan
description:
Pakistan’s Import Policy Order of 22 April 2022, Appendix H, lists six companies – certification bodies, which are accredited for pre-shipment inspections (PSI) to Pakistan. This regulation also specifies the objective of the PSI, i.e. “Relocation of project machinery and equipment shall be subject to fitness certificate by any of the pre-shipment inspection companies listed at Appendix-H to the effect that the machinery and equipment are in good working condition and the remaining life is not less than 10 years” .

However, as of 2023 none of the six certification companies can carry out PSI in the EU. Therefore, EU companies interested to export to Pakistan have to ship their goods to other third countries (such as China, Thailand, Indian UAE, Turkey, USA) to carry out the PSI in these countries.

title: Import duties on luxury products under Pakistan mini-budget
description: In September 2018, Pakistan adopted a mini-budget in order to address the current account and trade deficits. To this end, the mini-budget significantly increases import duties in order to restrict imports of so-called luxury items, including cheese, dry milk, cosmetics (including perfumery), leather, marbles and automobiles. The measure disproportionately affects EU imports.

title: Lack of progress on export applications of fresh animal products and on the registration of list of pre-approved establishments (Pre-listing)
description:
Export applications, particularly of meat, suffer from excesively  long approval procedures

The latest information obtained by the COM indicated that the risk assessment at technical level was completed, and that no audit would be necessary. A final evaluation by certain Panama interinstitucional Committees would be the last step/s in the approval process.

However, the export applications have not been approved and there is no indication of any sanitary concern from Panama which is an obstacle.

The COM has reached out repeatedly to Panama AUPSA asking for information on the state of play and conclusion of the approval process if there is no pending sanitary difficulty. The COM flagged concerns on the compatibility of this delay and lack onf information with provisions in the Association Agreement.

This has been raised in the context of the Association Agreement SPS Subcommittee in 2018 to  2022, and letters and bilateral meetings. Panama has not provided any meaningful answer in any of these occasions.

From Summer 2021, Prelisting requests whether to renew or update the list of approved establishments are stuck.

  • In June 2021, Panama replied to ES and DE indicating that information supplied did not allow PAN to establish the eligibility of the new establishments.
  • In February 2022, APA notified DE, BE and NL that pending applications would require a full audit of the exporting MS. Applications from IT, FR, PT and PL remain without unanswered to date ( March 2022)

EU establishments already registered by AUPSA (and its successor institution the Panamanian Food Agency (APA)) and authorized to export to Panama are only granted an export authorization with a limited duration in time. At the end of the first period granted for two years, MS are compelled to submit a renewal request. As the process of renewal this creates legal and business uncertainty.

The measure imposed by Panama is incompatible with the provisions of our bilateral agreement (Articles 145 and 147 ) and it also be incompatible with WTO law: it would contravene Article XI (QR) , Article 4 of the Agreement on Agriculture, and different provisions of the SPS agreement (articles 2.2,  3.1, etc; Annex B on Transparency Of Sanitary And Phytosanitary Regulations and Annex C on control, inspection and approval procedures point 1(a), (e),  

10 October 2022, all German establishments that were already listed for exports to Panama got an extension of registration until 31.12.2025.

Since july 2023 some establishments had been approved following bilateral discussions. Panama also stated that on 30 May 2023, it held a technical meeting with representatives of EU member States within the framework of the EU-Central America Association Agreement, during which Panama reported that it was working on the authorization of approximately 70 plants and would discuss pending issues at the next meeting in December 2023.

On 9 October 2023, ES confirmed that certain advances on the number of establishements prelisted, however the pace of listing them is still slow. Other MS did not inform of any advances in their listing.

title: African Swine fever, country wide restrictions on PL, BE and IT
description:
By Resolución AUPSA CTI 98 - 2019 de septiembre 2019 Panama withdrew the permit to import products derived from pigs, because of African Swine Fever outbreaks.

The COM undertook demarches and contacts and in addition sent a letter dated December 2019 underlining concerns with:

  • lack of recognition of the EU regionalization policy
  • Unnecessarily broad trade restrictions
  • Uncertainty on the scope of products affected by the measure and the rationale behind the ban
  • Lack of communication and notification as outlined in the provisions of the Association Agreement

Panama has not reacted to the letter.

While this fiche indicates certain products probably covered by the ban, the lack of responsiveness from Panama makes unclear the extent of the bans.

On 18 March 2022, the COM discussed with PAN about the lack of recognition of EU regionalisation for ASF. PAN reconfirmed its position arguing that the desease is exotic for them and they followed the notifications of WOAH. No progrees either at the Central America SPS Subcommitte meeting on 23 June 2022.

On 4-5 June 2024 Subcommittee meeting, PA informed that they ban the trade of pig products from IT due to the outbreaks of ASF. They do not acecpet regionalisation. 

They have also banned the trade of Italian safe commoddities becuase lack of trust on italian certificates. They are going to send a questionaire to IT in summer 2024.

title: Discrimination in Public Procurement
description:
Access to public procurement for foreign bidders is restricted to specific cases and conditions. International public competitive bidding in Paraguay is used as an exception to national bidding only in specific circumstances and, in the event of equivalent offers, preference is given to the offers which incorporate certain levels of local content. In addition when assessing the economic value of different bids, contracting entities may grant a certain margin of preference of up to 10%. In 2010 Paraguay introduced with decree 4008/2010 price preferences for goods and services of Paraguayan origin for a period of one year. Decree 6225/2011 and law 4558/2011 replaced decree 4008/2010 and continue with similar margins of preference for local content. These preferences from 5% up to 70% and have the aim of increasing national production and local employment.

 

Background

According to Paraguayan legislation (Ley 2051/2003 de Contrataciones Públicas), access to public procurement for foreign bidders (not domiciled in Paraguay) is restricted to the following cases: obligation under an international treaty, agreements with international organisations (such as a loan agreement with a multilateral institution), insufficient local supply of goods and services of the quality required or price of such goods or services is not suitable, and in the case that no proposal was submitted in a national tendering procedure (Article 18 of Ley 2051 of 2003 ). Moreover, companies from countries with no reciprocal treatment for Paraguayan firms can be excluded from bidding.

International public competitive bidding in Paraguay is used as an exception to national bidding only in specific circumstances and, in the event of equivalent offers, preference is given to the offers which incorporate more that 50% of local content. In addition when assessing the economic value of different bids, contracting entities may grant a margin of preference of up to 10% (Article 18 of Ley 2051/2003).

On 26 February 2010 Paraguay introduced with decree 4008/2010 national price preferences in public tenders for a period of one year, which was replaced by decree 6225/2011 and law 4558/2011 (see below). Paraguay has introduced these temporary preferences in order to increase national production and local employment to overcome the international economic crisis. The margin of preferences shall be determined by the contracting entities and range between 5% and 70% for manufactured goods and between 20% to 70% for primary products of agricultural origin. For construction services, the contracting entity can require the contractors to have at least 70% of the personnel locally recruited.

On 4 March 2011 Paraguay published decree 6225/2011 which replaced decree 4008/2010 regarding public works and infrastructure. The margin of preferences may range between 5% and 70%, for manufactured products 40%, for primary products of agricultural origin between 20% and 70%, for construction services at least 70% of the personnel must be locally recruited, and for services 10%.

On 15 December 2011 Paraguay published Law (Ley) 4558/2011 regarding good and services, which foresees in national tenders a margin of preferences of 20% for local products and services. National products are defined as being from Paraguayan origin or with an imported part of up to 40%, while national construction services require at least 70% of the locally recruited personnel. Decree 9649/2012 of 7 September 2012 provides details on regarding the determination of national origin concerning the Law 4558/2011.

In November 2020, Paraguay published Law 6575/2020 changing Art. 2° of the Law 4558/2011, which increases the local price preference from 20% to 40%. The Law was vetoed by the President but the veto was rejected by the Parliament.

title: IPR - Piracy
description:
Intellectual property rights (IPR) violations in Paraguay include piracy (music, films, videogames, software and books), counterfeits (tobacco, spirits, clothes, footwear, domestic appliances, electronic devices, sunglasses and luxury items), infringement of pharmaceutical and cosmetic patents and delays in granting patents.

 

Background

The main areas of intellectual property rights (IPR) violations in Paraguay are as follows:
1) Piracy: music, films, videogames, software and books.
2) Counterfeiting of trademarks and smuggling: tobacco, spirits (whisky), clothes, footwear, domestic appliances, electronic devices, sunglasses and luxury items.
3) Infringement of pharmaceutical and cosmetic patents.
4) Delays in granting patents: the lack of a implementation decree for the patents law 2593/2005 makes the application of patent legislation impossible; therefore no patents, especially for pharmaceuticals, have been granted for several years. At the end of 2010 some 800 patent applications were pending for examination and grant.

Paraguay is also a centre of transit for pirated and counterfeited goods. Products which violate IPR are mainly destined for export (in particular to Brazil and Argentina) but also for the small local market.

title: Representation Law
description:
The Representation law 194/93 regulates relations between foreign companies that export to Paraguay and local representatives / distributors in Paraguay. Under this law compensation has to be paid to the representative, when foreign exporters, without a justifiable reason, cancel, revoke, modify or do not renew their contract with a local representative / distributor in Paraguay. The amount of compensation is set through the judiciary or through arbitration. The law provides only broad criteria, leaving much to the discretion of the courts, which creates a situation of legal uncertainty for European exporters. There is a current legal draft in discussion to reinforce even more the protection of local representatives / distributors.

 

Background

The Representation law (Law No. 194 of 6 July 1993, which replaced the Decreto-Ley 7 of 27 March 1991), establishes the legal framework governing relationships between foreign companies that export to Paraguay and their Paraguayan representatives. The law requires that exporters to Paraguay prove just cause when they terminate, modify or fail to renew contracts with Paraguayan distributors or agents. If such a relationship is ended without proving just cause, the foreign company must pay its representative an indemnity, which is not fixed in the law. This is giving rise to broad discretional criteria of the court to fix this amount, which creates a situation of legal uncertainty for foreign firms. It seems that in some cases foreign companies paid large sums when ending distribution relationships in Paraguay to avoid lengthy court cases or have maintained ineffective representatives to avoid such payments.

Under Law 194/93, the amount of compensation is set through the judiciary or arbitration based on (1) the length of the agreement and (2) the gross earnings of the representative / distributor. All foreign exporters / importers can cancel, revoke, modify or not renew their contract with the local representative/distributor without paying compensation provided there is a justified reason for it, notably one of the following:
a. breach of the contract;
b. fraud or abuse of trust in the duties entrusted;
c. ineptitude or negligence;
d. any act imputable to the representative/distributor, which results in damage to the sales, distribution etc.;
e. conflict of interest.

Before claiming any of the above the exporter shall ask the representative / distributor to solve the problem within 120 days. Following this period, the exporter can claim its rights immediately except in cases of fraud or abuse of trust. The importer should make its claim before the judiciary or through arbitration, otherwise unjustified reasons will be assumed. In the event of cancellation, irrespective of the compensation awarded, the representative / distributor has the right to sell the existing stock to the exporter at market price (i.e. including profit).

The agreement between importer and representative/distributor can be demonstrated by one or more of the following:
- Authorising letter to manage the local market.
- Bills that demonstrate trading deals between the parties.
- Payment for a commission to the representative / distributor for trading deals during at least the last two years before the entry into force of this law.
- Advertising and publicity expenses claiming the representative/distributor role, the importer being aware of it and not opposing it.
- Claims by representative / distributor of commissions for operations not done through him, which have been paid by the importer.

This legal uncertainty has the effect of deterring EU companies from exporting to Paraguay. These restrictions could deny the Paraguayan economy inputs that are necessary for its development. In addition, by offering disproportionate protection to local operators, beyond their legitimate needs, the law protects and rewards inefficiency, which does not serve the interests of the Paraguayan economy.
The termination indemnities and other requirements apply only to foreign suppliers. Local suppliers are not obliged under this law or under similar conditions regarding the relationships with distributors or agents.

title: Country-wide bans imposed by Peru on products considered safe commodities by the WOAH
description:
Resolución Directoral nº 0051-2019-MINAGRI-SENASA-DSA (notified to the WTO SPS mechanism under G/SPS/N/PER/865, dated 15 January 2020) bans trade of pigs and products thereof from any country with presence of African Swine Fever (ASF).

In the version currently available in SENASA’s website and dated September 2023, the following EU Member States are subject to these country-wide bans:

Germany (OIE – 10 September 2020), Belgium, Bulgaria, Croatia (WOAH – 1st August 2023), Slovakia, Estonia, Greece (OIE – 07 february 2020), Hungary, Italy (Sardinia/ Cerdeña), Latvia, Lithuania, Poland, Czech Republic, Romania, Sweden (WOAH 7 September).

The ban ignores the EU regionalization policy and prevents any export of raw pork meat. Yet what is more pernicious is the ban on what the WOAH deems “safe commodities” which in this case corresponds to pork derived products.

 

These measures contravene the terrestrial code of the World Organisation for Animal Health (WOAH). Articles 15.1.2 and 15.1.23. The terrestrial code firmly states regarding safe commodities that ‘regardless of the health status of the country or zone of export concerning African swine fever, veterinary authorities should not require any conditions related to this disease when authorizing the import or transit through their territory of the following safe commodities.’ These articles explicitly mention two of the commodities considered safe (‘gelatin and any meat packaged in a hermetically sealed container with an Fo value of 3 or higher’), as well as the procedures for inactivating the African swine fever virus in meats, thereby making them safe for export.”

In the case of Italy, SENASA, the official health authority, has refused to exclude “safe commodities” from the ban and refused to conduct a risk analysis on Italy’s pork product chain. Moreover, it pressured Italy to request a Community Risk Analysis (ARC) to the Andean Community (CAN) despite the fact CAN norms require the importing country (Peru) to make the request.

COM requested PERU in the 2021, 2022 and 2023 SPS EU-Andean subcommittees to correct the document in their website; to take into account the pest free areas established at the EU level; and remove countries which have not had ASF outbreaks in the past years (BE, CZ).

In parallel, the CAN started the ARC on Italian pork products. In at least two stages, the CAN could have excluded “safe commodities” from the analysis. It did not. As of today, the CAN has requested an in-situ audit.

COM and EUDEL met with Peru in the May 2024 implementation mission and reiterated that point.

COM sent Peru on 20 June 2024 a letter requesting to open the market for safe commodities and excluding them from the risk analysis.  Otherwise, if market not open inmediatly, COM may escalate this issue to the next levels.

title: Tax discrimination on spirits
description:
In 2018, the government revamped the structure of the Selective Tax on Consumption (ISC in Spanish initials), an excise tax applied on products that are detrimental to human health. This includes alcoholic products that pay an increasing tax rate according to their alcohol level. The tax paid is either an ad-valorem rate or a per litre rate (whichever is higher).

In that vein, on 9 May 2018, MEF introduced new regulation worsening the situation for imported spirits in Peru by further raising ad-valorem rates for spirits with over 20º if alcohol from 25% to 40% while keeping the tax rate for Pisco (which should fall in that category) at 1.5 PEN/l. 

It was calculated that, under the 2018 structure, difference between ISC effective rates for Pisco vs spirits, increased 16 times.

The government planned to revise the ISC tax rates periodically and in that vein, it revised the norm in 2020, 2021, 2022 and 2024 through ministerial resolutions. The results can be seen in the table below, with the changes in bold. The Ministerial Resolutions have included changes to Pisco tax rates, but they remain a separate category from other spirits, which constitutes a case of discrimination.

As of 2024, spirits with an alcohol content of over 20º are taxed at 3.63 PEN/l or 40% of the sales price, whichever is higher. However, Pisco is taxed at 2.48 PEN/l. This is an increase compared to 2018 but the per litre rate remains lower 38% lower than for other alcohols. Besides, in practice other spirits pay the ad-valorem rate, because it is higher, an obligation Pisco does not have.

title: Ban on imports of live bovines, bovine products and derivates.
description:
In the Andean Community Resolution 1587 (which entered into force in May 2013), banned imports on Bovine Spongiform Encephalopathy (BSE) of several products such as: live bovine animals, bovine products and by-products. Concentrated meat containing meat/blood/bone meal, bovine meat, bone meal and mammalian offal meal or food additives that contain ruminant proteins for feed animal use from the countries concerned and with different status of negligible risk, are also banned.

However, this regulation excludes some products such as: milk and dairy products, semen and bovine embryos, sebum without protein, di-calcium phosphate, hides and skins, gelatine and collagen. Also, veterinary products not elaborated with risk products identified in Terrestrial Animal Health Code, as long as these products come from animals of negligible risk, as well the feed for felines and canines which comply with the same requirements, are allowed. Deboned bovine meat of animal less 30 months of age is allowed complying with several conditions.

The following EU Member States are listed in Andean Community Resolution 1587 because they have reported cases of BSE, i.e. Austria, Belgium, Check Republic, Denmark, France, Germany, Ireland, Sweden, Poland, Portugal, United Kingdom, Netherlands, Luxembourg, Italy, Finland, Spain, Greece, Slovakia and Slovenia.

The COM pushed on this in the 2018 Subcommittee in Quito, with Peru and Colombia and Ecuador. The countries, including Peru, committed to prioritize the assessment of this issue in the next COTASA meeting, with the aim to further align with OIE standards. This was again discussed in the 2019 Subcommittee, with the countries indicating that a new Resolution (Allegedly now complying with OIE standards) would be published shortly. However this did not happen as of October 2020

Meanwhile the measure has also impact on the negotiation of harmonized certificates for exports from the EU as follows:

a) Negotiation of a harmonized certificate for export of only deboned bovine meat to Peru (debone bovine meat is a safe category as per OIE)

b) Negotiation of a harmonized certificated for processed meat products to Colombia (including bovine meat products) > Here in December 2019 Colombia indicated that  a certificate would be only valid for Member States with a negligible risk status in the OIE. As an update, in 2020 Colombia accepted imports of cooked products from Member States with controlled risk status. However the certificate is not yet concluded.

February 2022, At the MADB Matrix for animal products, MS did not raise any problem with BSE barrier however, it is not officially clear if Andean Community Resolution 1587 is still valid. To confirm if the resolution is over, this barrier will be included in the agenda of the 2023 SPS subcommittee to be discussed. In any case, the harmonised certificate negotiations are still ongoing. In view that all MS have negligible control status except one that has controlled risk, it is not expected that MS bilateral trade of bovine products with Peru may get into problems. Despite the status of MS, the COM is pushing ahead the new harmonised certificates.

 In 2023 SPS Subcommitte , PE confirmed that the resolution is stil valid but they want to updated
