The minimum threshold for local content reached 45% in the latest round with the target being 60%.

REI4P projects are evaluated using a 70/30 weighting, where 70% is based on price, and 30% is accounted for by various Economic Development Criteria. The non-price criteria were introduced to encourage the development of remote areas, and bidders are required to identify opportunities to invest in skills development, local suppliers, and entrepreneurs, as well as providing ownership opportunities to local communities. Within the Economic Development criteria, local content accounts for 25% of the weighting, which is equivalent to 8% of the overall project score

Local content requirements also feature strongly in the Broad-based Black Economic Empowerment (B-BBEE) legislation. The Department of Trade, Industry and Competition (DTIC) published amendments to the Codes of Good Practice on 31 May 2019 with a six-month transitional period to be effective from 1 December 2019.The codes have to be complied with for any economic activity with a public institution or entity. The Codes emphasize i) Ownership; ii) Skills Development; iii) Enterprise, and Supplier Development as priority elements which require a 40% sub-minimum compliance.

Private procurement in the key economic sectors might also become subject to local content requirements. In particular the new mining charter (27 September 2018 in force since March 2019) stipulates that a minimum of 70% (by value) of mining goods must be manufactured or assembled in South Africa – this requires that at least 60% local content be used during manufacture or assembly and 80% of services required by holders of mining rights must be procured from local manufactures who must also comply with the B-BBEE regulations. In addition, all local content used in the manufacture of goods must be certified by the South African Bureau of Standards (SABS) – the cost of which may be covered either by the mining right holder, or by the supplier.

The 70% of total spend on mining goods procurement must be apportioned as follows

  • 21% to be spent on South African manufactured goods produced by Historically Disadvantaged Persons (HDP) owned and controlled companies;
  • 5% to be spent on South African manufactured goods produced by women or youth owned and controlled companies; and
  • 44% to be spent on South African manufactured goods produced by BEE compliant companies.

A minimum of 80% of the total spend on services (including non-discretionary expenditure) must be sourced from South African companies and allocated as follows:

  • 50% must be spent on services supplied by HDP owned and controlled companies;
  • 15% must be spent on services supplied by women owned and controlled companies;
  • 5% must be spent on services supplied by youth owned and controlled companies; and
  • 10% must be spent on services supplied by BEE compliant companies.

There are two fundamental problems with the Mining Charter’s approach of setting a blanket 60% local content target:

  1. It does not recognise the different opportunities, challenges and constraints faced by different sub-sectors of the industry in terms of achieving local content targets.
  2. It does not promote exports, which are critical to both the growth and sustainability of the industry.

The Mining Charter further introduces Local Content verification requirements to ensure the mining goods meet the thresholds in the Charter. The South African Bureau of Standards (SABS) should verify the local content percentage, the costs of which must be borne by the mining right holder or the suppliers. Certification certificates from SABS will not be required for the first 2 years of the transitional period (until March 2021).   

On 4 October 2021, the Acting Chief Procurement Officer at National Treasury issued a circular stipulating a minimum threshold of 100% is to be implemented on local production and content in the cement sector, effective 4 November 2021.

All EU MS affected.

title: Import ban pig meat (African swine fever) fresh and frozen
description:
South Africa does not recognise the regionalisation measures introduced by the EU in response to outbreaks of African Swine Fever (ASF) in several Member States.

African swine fever is an WOAH (World Organisation for Animal Health) listed disease. WOAH has set clear international standards and defined recommendations and conditions, which guarantee safe trade (and includes zoning/ regionalisation measures).

The EU has adopted a specific and complete set of legislation and guidelines on ASF preparedness, control, diagnoses and zoning/ regionalisation that is in line with WOAH standards and kept up to date on the basis of regular scientific advice provided by the European Food safety Authority (EFSA).

On this basis, the EU can guarantee safe trade of live pigs and pig products from disease-free areas.

The disease has occurred in the EU since January 2014 with different EU Member States affected, and occasional outbreaks continue to occur in the EU.

The fresh pig market on October 2023 is still close for DE, EE,  IT and PL  Other MS such as FI could be affected also due to the lack of regionalisation

title: Delays/restrictions in issuing and/or modifying import permits and veterinary health certificates for meat, meat products and genetic material
description:
According to Annex C of the WTO SPSA, WTO Members are asked to ensure that their import SPS procedures are (inter alia) undertaken and completed without undue delay and in no less favourable manner for imported products than for like domestic products, that the standard processing period of each procedures is published or that the anticipated processing period is communicated to the applicant upon request.

ZA authorities take several years to evaluate questionnaires used in the negotiations of import permits and health certificates by new applicants (such as in the case of a number of EU MS).

For pork and other meats, ZA operates a queue system with no indication of duration for the handling of the application. ZA authorities affirm that delays are due to lack of resources and that no applicant is treated more favourably than others. In any event, this results in undue delays in the processing of market access applications. 

At the SPS session in the framework of the TCC on 20 October 2021, the COM raised the same concerns about the lack of improvements on the procedures of approving market access to EU MS. It was requested to ZA a commitment to speed up the approval process for Member States’ pending market access applications (53 pending files in the Market Access Data Base (MADB) for which action on South African side was pending) with clear time lines and process. The answered was the same as previous meetings: lack of resources for evaluating all the applications from all over the world and not prioritization system for the EU applications just "first come, first served basis, despite we are trade partner"  

On 9 November 2022, Commission had a technical meeting with ZA. For that occasion, MS had updated the SPS matrix and 6 issues on animal products have been resolved for: BE on porcine meat, CZ on bovine semen, DE on casinngs, LT on eggs products, NL on heat treated pork meat and DK on dairy products. 

2023 October

There are 45 SPS pending market access applications in total. 7 are due to the lack of recognition of the EU regionalisation principle, for Highly Patogenic Avian Influenza(HPAI), African Swine Fever (ASF). This table gives an overview of the remaining 33 pending market access applications for exporting other commodities to South Africa (SA). Some of them date back to many years ago.

 There are 4 main delay problems which explain why they have not been solved yet:

  1. For 20 of them, there are delays in replying first applications, in finalising the health certificates or not replying to questionnaires. There have been multiple requests for additional information for each application and the process could not be finalised. Requests of information should be streamlined with a straightforward procedure and clear timelines. For 7 of them, the applications have not even been taken into consideration due to lack of resources. Being a trade partner, we would expect that the requests for authorisation be treated with priority and not on a first come, first served basis
  2. For 5 of them related to bovine meat, issuing the veterinary health certificate has been delayed due to further considerations of Bovine Spongiform Encephalopathy (BSE) status (Bovine Spongiform). The EU requests SA not only recognise the EU negligible BSE risk status of the whole EU (except for Greece that has controlled BSE risk status), but also to not request any BSE related conditions for the safe commodities according to the Terrestrial Animal Health Code (WOAH Code).
  3. Three of the 8 fruits applications have not advanced due to the long process of pest risk assessment (PRA) with many delays due to requests of additional information. Requests of information should be streamlined with a straightforward procedure and clear timelines.
  4. Finally, the prelisting for bovine, porcine or poultry meat establishments takes years to be completed. The process should be acc

title: SPS measures following avian influenza outbreaks in the EU
description:
South Africa does not recognise HPAI free zones and it has been difficult in recognising the regaining of free status through WOAH self-declaration of HPAI from EU MS.   

Under Article 6 of the SPS Agreement, WTO Members are obliged to recognise the concept of disease-free areas. Disease control measures must be targeted, be proportionate to the risk and minimise trade disruption as much as possible. Under WOAH terrestrail code, it is describe the procedure to regain the HPAI free status. 

The EU has successfully implemented and applied the concept of zoning/regionalisation for many years for Avian influenza, both internally (in its own territory) and for imports from third countries. There is no case reported where avian influenza had been transmitted via legitimate trade of poultry or poultry products.
From the older to more recent event, here below it is  described the difficulties  for trading poultry fresh products , including eggs and genetic material, due to alternatives waves of HPAI outbreakes

Eight out of the 10 EU MS exporting poultry to South Africa kept being banned by South Africa since the 2016 EU HPAI outbreak, despite the fact that some of them had been declared HPAI-free in accordance with the international standards of the WOAH terrestrial code.

 Many EU trading partners had taken measures related to the 2016 outbreak, but most restrictions against EU MS were lifted by end-2017.

At that time South Africa did not recognise nor the HPAI free areas neither the self declarations of freedom and claimed, that a new country inspections were needed before trade could resume. The objective of such inspections were  not clear, given that the influenza episodes were stamped out.

In 2018, following some audits carried out in these Member States, South Africa re-authorised exports from Poland and Spain.

However In 2019/20 Poland was closed again due to a new outbreak of HPAI. Poland applied for country freedom recognition on 13 August 2020.

The Netherlands was re-opened in early 2020.

As of Oct 2020, Belgium, France, Hungary and Poland were waiting for a re-instatement for export of poultry meat to South Africa ().

In Jan 2021,  all MS markets were closed following a new HPAI outbreaks in the EU.  In September 2021 HPAI free status were  restored for FI, BE, FR, HU, IE, PL but again, they lost them by autumn 2021 due to new outbreaks of HPAI 

Following the outbreaks of avian influenza in the winter of 2021, EU Member States were not eligible for exports of poultry meat (fresh or frozen) to SA, as it did not recognize EU regionalisation system.

In September 2022: 16 MS had lost the free status due to different new outbreaks: DE, BE, BU, CZ, CR, DK, SL, SK, ES, FR, HU, IT, NL, PL, PT and RO

In November 22: HU, IE and DK lost again the free status 

Finally in January 2023: Despite IE, PT, SL, SE and FIN have currently regained HPAI free status through self-declarations at WOAH, SA did not considered the self declarations of these MS

In April 2023: South Africa opened the market for fresh poultry meat for IE, therefore it was the first time that ZA considered the WOAH HPAI self-declarations.

On the 25th week 2023, the Netherland also resumed trade on poultry meat requiring minor administrative amendments done to the bilateral certificates. The rest of MS with HPAI free status which still have blocked their trade were: BE, DK, ES, FI, PT and SL and have to wait a little bit more

On 1 August 2023, South Africa confirmed the Spanish health certificates and lifted its trade restrictions to ES. SA loaded the health certificates into their system and importers could already apply for permits

title: Electromagnetic Interference and Compatibility Conformity Assessment Procedure
description:
Electrical and electro-technical products that want to access the South African market need to obtain a Letter of Authority (LoA) from the National Regulator for Compulsory Specifications (NRCS) as proof of compliance with all of South Africa's compulsory technical specifications (energy efficiency, energy saving and safety requirements). As of June 2017, some of these products also need to meet a new more stringent conformity assessment procedure for EMI/EMC certification (Electromagnetic interference and electromagnetic compatibility) from the South African Bureau of Standards (SABS) in the form of a Certificate of Conformity (CoC).

1.Energy efficiency certification and labelling

SCOPE: Electrical and electronic apparatus

LEGISLATION: New in 2015: Compulsory specifications - VC 9008  (SANS 941 This standard covers energy efficiency requirements (minimum energy performance standard MEP), measurement methods and mandatory energy efficiency labelling)

https://www.nrcs.org.za/siteimgs/vc/VC9008.pdf

EQUIVALENCE OF STANDARDS: Standards by different standardization bodies such as ISO, IEC and EN, will be accepted if it is proven, in the form of a declaration report from an accredited conformity assessment body*, that they are technically equivalent to the relevant SA National Standard. The applicant shall be responsible for obtaining such a declaration report.

*Be from a laboratory accredited by a national accreditation body affiliated to the International Laboratory Accreditation Cooperation (ILAC), the International Accreditation Forum (IAF), and/or be an IECEE CB Scheme member (Operated by the IEC System of Conformity Assessment Schemes for Electrotechnical Equipment and Components (IECEE). The IECEE CB Scheme is an international system for mutual acceptance of test reports and certificates dealing with the safety of electrical and electronic components, equipment and products.

SABS set the national standards and test procedures for the appliances.

TESTING: Accredited in-house, national and international laboratory testing allowed. As long as testing is from a laboratory accredited by a national accreditation body affiliated to ILAC and/or be an IECEE CB Scheme member. SABS also provides the facilities to test appliances.

For energy efficiency SABS is planning to have an effective testing facility early 2019 after failed attempt in 2017.

VERIFICATION: The NRCS is the regulatory body charged with verifying compliance with the compulsory specifications by issuing a Letter of Authority. Safety/energy saving and energy efficiency are evaluated simultaneously.

2. Safety and energy saving certification

SCOPE: Electrical and electronic apparatus

LEGISLATION: Compulsory specifications - VC 8055 plus a broad array of applicable Standards issued by SANS for each type of product: https://www.nrcs.org.za/siteimgs/vc/VC8055.pdf

 

3. Electromagnetic interference and electromagnetic compatibility (EMI/ECM)

SCOPE: Non-telecommunications electronic and electrical equipment and products

LEGISLATION: 1 June 2017, SA legislation 'Modification of the South African Bureau of Standards Program on Issuance of Certificates of Compliance Related to Electromagnetic Compatibility for Manufacturers' imposes a new more stringent conformity assessment procedure for EMI/EMC regulations already in place: ICASA General Notice 46-2010 ‘Regulations in Respect of Technical Standards for Electronic Communication Equipment’

Measure was notified to WTO after its implementation (September 2017)

EQUIVALENCE OF STANDARDS: No equivalence. International certification schemes like ILAC or IECEE CB-FCS schemes are not accepted by SABS.

TESTING: Only in SABS accredited third party laboratories. Since December 2018:1 lab in SA and 2 labs in Europe. In addition 36 in Asia, 7 in the US.

VERIFICATION: The NRCS is the regulatory body charged with verifying compliance with the compulsory specifications by issuing a Letter of Authority. Safety/energy saving and energy efficiency are evaluated simultaneously. SABS is responsible for the issuance of Certificates of Compliance (CoCs).

System remains manual despite announcing already in 2017 that it would be online.
EMC/I compliance must be confirmed before issuing an LoA by NRCS.


 ASSESMENT

Products: the products that seem to be covered by the conformity assessment procedure for energy efficiency and electromagnetic compatibility are low risk electrical equipment.

Standards: not based on essential requirements but on specific technical requirements for each product, this makes the system burdensome and complicates finding equivalent international standards, in particular for energy efficiency as EU accepts self-regulation based on a common standard that is very different –in fact more onerous - from SAs requirements.

Testing: Accredited in-house, national and international laboratory testing allowed for obtaining LoAs but there have been delays in establishing South African testing facilities for energy efficiency standards since 2017.

For obtaining EMC/EMI CoCs only testing allowed is from accredited SABS third party laboratories (SABS A-Lab) Program) for which there is no ILAC Mutual Recognition Arrangement. There is a non-refundable application fee for laboratories of R 189,951 for year 1 and then a subsequent payment of R 94,969 for year 2 and another R 94,969 for year 3. In addition, laboratories established outside South Africa (for example in Europe) will be obliged to incur extra unnecessary costs, compared to a local laboratory, e.g. air flight and accommodation and local travelling costs for the South African assessors must also be covered. Moreover a non-refundable certification fee of R 16,000 is payable by the manufacturer per application submitted (covers 4 products).

Verification: Conformity assessment procedures in place for both certifications remain manual processes and not risk based. Lead time at SABS is established at 30 working days, while NRCS has established a target of 120 days. This means that in the best scenario an electronic or electrical product requiring both certifications cannot expect place their products in the market before 5-6 months, irrespective of their origin and risk profile. The current manual process also lends itself to lack of transparency, consistency and predictability.

The EU believes that some of the different elements of the conformity assessment system for electrical and electronic products constitute a barrier to trade.

The EU believes that mandatory certification by national conformity bodies (NRCS/SABS) is stricter than necessary given the risk profile of the products. The EU understands as well that it is the prerogative of the South African government to impose a pre-market conformity assessment procedure based on a mandatory certification system. Nonetheless, the EU believes that some of the different elements of the system constitute a barrier to trade.

There is no justification for not accepting international standards, and if accepted the burden of proof on the manufacturer is excessive. SA standards should be brought into conformance whenever possible with the international standard.

There is no justification of rejecting results (test or inspection reports, certificates) which have been issued under internationally recognized systems like the IEC schemes (IEC CB) or by conformity assessment bodies (CABs) which have been accredited under a Multinational Recognition Arrangements like ILAC and IEC CB, of which South Africa is a signatory.

The cost of compliance in terms of money and time is excessive and disproportionate given the risks associated with noncompliance.

(A separate market barrier ID 11900 exists on the cumbersome aspects related to the conformity assessment procedure due mainly to capacity constraints)

title: Cumbersome compulsory conformity assessment for electro technical products
description:
To be placed in the South African market, electrical and electro-technical products need to obtain a Letter of Authority (LoA) from the National Regulator for Compulsory Specifications (NRCS) as proof of compliance with all of South Africa's compulsory technical specifications (energy efficiency, energy saving and safety requirements). As of June 2017, some of these products also need to meet a new more stringent conformity assessment procedure for EMI/EMC certification (Electromagnetic interference and electromagnetic compatibility) from the South African Bureau of Standards (SABS) in the form of a Certificate of Conformity (CoC).

The procedures in place by NRCS and SABS for obtaining these LoAs and CoC are proving to be serious hurdles for manufacturers and importers of electric and electro technical products wanting to access the South African market.

1.Energy efficiency certification and labelling
Scope:  Electrical and electronic apparatus: appliances (ovens, dishwashers, freezers, refrigerators, washing and drying machines, and air conditioners) and audio/video equipment
Testing: Accredited in-house, national and international laboratory testing allowed. But NO national accredited laboratory. SABS is planning to have an effective testing facility early 2019 after failed attempt in 2017.
Verification: NRCS issues LoAs. System is manual and doesn't incorporate a risk base approach. Delays exceed 250 days

2.Safety and energy saving certification
Scope: Electrical and electronic apparatus: Lighting industry (Electrical cords, lamps, sockets, plugs, etc); appliances, tools and audio/video/IT equipment
Testing: Accredited in-house, national and international laboratory testing allowed. In certain instances local test facilities are not accredited to test or have no capacity or capability to test. For example, there were no local test facilities to test the energy efficiency requirements of air conditioners.

(A separate market barrier ID 13562 exists on the nature of these compulsory standards and their verification system, while the cumbersome aspects related to the conformity assessment procedure due to capacity constraints will be dealt with in this market barrier.)

Since the introduction for electrical and electro-technical products of new compulsory requirements for energy efficiency in 2014 (VC9008), adding to the safety and energy saving requirements (VC8055) already in place, NRCS has come under strong criticism due to critical delays in the issuance of LoAs by its electro-technical unit, taking on average between 240-500 days (previously max 120 days but usually significantly less).

Though equivalence of standards and different testing formulas are contemplated, these are costly and burdensome; and with regards to energy efficiency testing, despite various failed attempts there continues to be no national testing facility, forcing testing to be done abroad. Nonetheless, once testing is complete, a LoA can only be issued by a capacity constrained NRCS with no effective online risk based procedure in place. The current manual process also lends itself to lack of transparency, consistency and predictability. An added layer of complication is the fact that in SA there are currently no energy efficiency testing facilities (failed attempt in 2017, new promise for early 2019).

The delays in LoAs issuance have a negative effect on importers, foreign manufacturers and the domestic industry alike, affected by staggering demurrage costs, losses of sales revenues, and delays in projects that need specific electrical and electro-technical components.

2020: as part of a project under the Partnership Instrument 'EU SA Partners for Growth' the EU financed a consultant to assist with the implementation of an online tool (Energy Efficiency Online LoA Registration for Appliancesto) to automize the frist phase of the application process. A series of workshops with NRCS and business were held in August 2020 to rollout the application.  The rollout should be complete and the manual procedure fully substituted by the online application by mid 2021. For now it has gone smoothly and issuance of LoA are below 15 days. A key constraint remains which is lack of local testing facilities.

title: Repaired goods
description:
There is no provision in the EU-Korea FTA which would exempt repaired goods from customs duties on re-entry to Korea after repair in the EU (or vice versa), whereas Korea's FTA with the US includes such a clause.

In 2018 the National Assembly exempted repaired goods from customs duties, at least for aircraft parts, which was the main issue. The exemption was effective for 3 years. The exemption was renewed in 2021 for another 3 years, until 2024. While these are temporary solutions, the EU will nonetheless continue to seek a permanent solution to this matter.

title: Reiterative testing for baby clothing
description: Imports of textile products for infants (up to 36 months) have become increasingly difficult since February 2018 when Korea introduced a requirement for third-party safety testing and certification procedures to be performed by designated laboratories located in South Korea. Due to the measure, a very large amount of clothing samples have to be sent to Korea for local testing, resulting in a substantial increase of testing and certification costs for European manufacturers.

title: Import ban due to Bovine Spongiform Encephalopathy (BSE)
description:
Unjustified import restrictions on bovine meat and meat related products relating to Bovine Spongiform Encephalopathy (BSE).

In 2001, the Korean market was closed to imports from 15 EU Member States due to outbreaks of Bovine Spongiform Encephalopathy (BSE), despite stringent EU measures guaranteeing the safety of EU beef. The EU is known for providing high-quality and safe beef products, but it faced a trade blockade imposed by Korea in 2001 due to the BSE outbreaks.

South-Korea's application procedure is overly burdensome and lengthy. The procedure to import beef includes a step whereby the Korean National Assembly needs to make a deliberation on the imports. This procedural steps further delays the application process as it might take several years before the National Assembly schedules the application deliberation of one or more countries on its agenda and creates thus additional undue delays.

In general, South-Korea does not import beef and other products from EU Member States due to Bovine Spongiform encephalopathy (BSE) related restrictions but resumed the import from other countries with the same OIE status (USA, CAN). EU considers the measures by Korea unjustified, discriminatory and in breach of OIE status. 

The issue has been raised with Korea in  numerous bilateral meeting at different levels as well as in the general session of the WTO SPS Committee. The issue continues to be raised with South Korea.

In August 2019, imports from Denmark and The Netherlands were finally approved.

Several other EU Member States have applications pending which are long overdue.

On 20 December 2023, the Korean National Assembly voted in favour of allowing market access from both France and Ireland. 

In June 2024, market access was granted for beef from Ireland and France.

However as of November 2024 beef import applications are still pending for 8 EU Member States (AT, BE, DE, ES, IT, PL, PT, SE) and Korea did not provide timelines for a possible approval.

title: Slow procedures on applications to allow import of animal and plant products
description:
The EU exporters face difficulties entering the Korean market due to long approval procedures. Korea has import procedures in place for both animal products and plant products. These are the so-called 8- step procedures. The procedure as such is transparent, but excessively long for getting access to the Korean market.

More specifically concerning fruit and vegetables: new types/origins of fruits and vegetables are not allowed for import before the phytosanitary requirements have been set by the national authorities. The import requirements include a pest risk analysis PRA, which may take several years to conclude. The capacity to handle applications is limited, meaning that only a limited number of applications can be handled at the same time. ...

On 21 June 2022, Korea authorised imports of feed of plant origin (in particular alfalfa) from Bulgaria, an application which was initiated in 2018.

In June 2022, Korea authorised imports of egg products from Finland, an application which was initiated in 2017

On 22 February 2023, Korea authorised the imports of carrot seeds from France without the use of a RT-PCR analysis which detects the Candidatus liberibacter solanacearum bacteria, which is a trade facilitating measure.

On 1 January 2023, Korea authorised imports of several dairy products from Bulgaria.

On 23 June 2023, Korea authorise imports of several dairy products from Slovakia

title: Non-recognition of EU's regionalisation measures implemented due to African Swine Fever and Avian Influenza
description:
Korea is imposing country- wide bans on EU Member States where African Swine Fever (ASF) or Avian influenza (AI) was detected. The international standards for animal health (OIE) clearly define conditions to allow safe trade to continue from non- affected areas and on which products can be safely continued to be traded when an outbreak of African Swine Fever of Avian Influenza occurs.

The Commission continues to raise the matter with Korea in bilateral meetings and WTO SPS meetings as a Specific Trade Concern and calls Korea to respect its obligations under the WTO SPS Agreement and the international standards. 

Since September 2019 Korea is witnessing cases of African swine fever in feral and domestic pigs, giving the country a disease status that is no different from that of EU Member States from which imports are suspended.  

Since 2006, Highly pathogenic Avian Influenza outbreaks are also regularly reported to be present in south Korea.

As a result of intense high-level engagement between the European Commission and the Republic of Korea, EU countries can, as of 5 September 2022, export pork and poultry to the Republic of Korea more easily. The Ministry of Agriculture, Food and Rural Affairs of the Republic of Korea (MAFRA) has decided to remove a longstanding trade barrier which affected EU exports of pork and poultry products, as the Republic of Korea now recognises the EU’s stringent regionalisation measures to control outbreaks of African swine fever and the highly pathogenic avian influenza.

End 2022 and beginning 2023: Korea is in the process of updating bilateral certificates including the agreed regionalisation conditions and is listing the establishments for approval to export to Korea. Trade has taken place already under the new regionalisation conditions for some commodities from several EU Member States.

In August 2023, first shipments of pork products from Germany to Korea have started. Hungary and Poland are still in the process of establishments to be approved by Korea. The Commission continues to be in close contact with the Korean authorities to address the outstanding issues that would allow for trade to resume from previous affected Member States.

title: Limitations to online sales of alcoholic beverages by South Korea
description:
Under the current limitations in South Korea to the online sales of alcoholic beverages, liquor has to be bought together with online-ordered food (where it may only represent 50% or less of the total amount), or ordered liquor has to be picked-up by the person who
actually ordered it at the shop (“Smart order”). However, these restrictions do not apply to ‘traditional liquor’.

Current South Korean legislation appears to apply different treatment to the online sales of traditional alcoholic beverages and non-traditional foreign ones. The Ministry of Agriculture, Food and Rural Affairs (MAFRA) has been working on new classification criteria for ‘traditional liquors’ and the EU industry fears that a more extensive definition will put imported alcoholic beverages at further disadvantage, not only for online sales (as is the case already now), but also in terms of taxation.

title: IPR: Public Performance Rights
description:
South Korea has a public performance rights system in place, but it includes important loopholes and only awards royalties at an insignificant level.

Regarding the scope of its application, the basic law is Article 29(2) of the Korean Copyright Act. 

This act allows for musical works to be played and performed publicly (for free) if no benefit in return is received from the audience. It then provides for the possibility of determining, by Presidential Decree, that certain categories of users of music cannot benefit from this broad exception.

Presential Decrees stipulating the obligation to pay royalties include shops of a size of 3000m2 or above, karaoke and dance venues, ski resorts, and baseball venues.

This mere "positive list" does not cover many kinds of commercial venues that regularly exploit music and exempts them from their obligation to obtain a licence and pay royalties, such as restaurants, hair salons or car shops.

In 2016, a revision of the Korean Copyright Act even increased the scope of the payment exception by Article 29(2) through changing its wording from "phonograms for sales" to "commercial phonograms". This change had the effect that also digital music, including self-produced music collections, can be played for free in all the venues that are not covered by a Presidential Decree.

In 2018, the Korean government, in view of the mounting pressure of the EU, added by Presidential Decree coffee shops, gyms and bars above a size of 50m2 to the positive list. The amendment was only meant being a temporary pragmatic solution, in an attempt to make Korea meet its FTA commitment.

However, the present situation still exempts from any royalty payment large parts of relevant venues, such as restaurants, relevant venues below a size of 3,000 m2, hair salons, car shops, and coffee shops, gyms and pubs that do not surpass the size of 50m2.

The second important issue is the very low royalty fees that the venues that are included in the positive list have to pay.

In 2018, the Ministry of Culture, Sports and Tourism (MCST) set tariffs applicable for the use of music in public venues such as coffee shops, non-alcoholic beverage stores and draft beer restaurants.

These tariffs are much below international standards, for example coffee shops only have to pay 1.40 Euros per month. Courts have in the meantime applied these very low tariffs to other venues, such as convenience and cosmetic stores.

title: Pricing of pharmaceuticals and medical devices
description:
The Ministry of Health and Welfare (MoHW) implements a series of substantial price cut or price-containment measures, affecting in particular the prices for new and innovative drugs. The MoHW earlier committed itself to putting forward the pricing reform methodologies to properly reward innovation, but has yet to suggest any measures which can have a substantial impact on new drug pricing.

Although the MoHW made some improvements aiming at facilitating patients' accessibility to new drugs the measures are not considered to lead to actual market facilitations. Improvements made were : i) procedural improvements for new drug listing through the introduction of "fast-track"; ii) exemption of pharmaco-economic assessment for pricing of drugs for rare diseases and certain cancer; iii) introduction of refunding system for a limited number of drugs.

However, in 2016, the MoHW released the revised premium pricing policy (so- called 7.7 pricing policy) as one of the results of a Consultation Body initiated by the Korean government which included clearly discriminatory elements against innovative multinational companies by revising the existing unfair conditions to satisfy for selecting Innovative Pharmaceutical Companies (IPCs) – which are entitled to be granted premium pricing for new drugs - in a manner to be further unfavourable to multinational companies.

End of 2018, MoHW announced the criteria of defining innovative drugs, which eliminated discriminatory elements, but seems to include criteria that both multinational and local companies cannot fulfil. The existing unfair conditions to satisfy for selecting Innovative Pharmaceutical Companies (IPCs) were not revised.

title: Pre-clearance requirement for imports of plants and plant products
description:
Preclearance is a procedure that Korea applies for imports of certain plants and plant products with conditions as laid down in the Plant Protection Act of Korea. This preclearance procedure entails that the phytosanitary certification and/or clearance in the country of origin is performed by or under the regular supervision of the National Plant Protection Organisation of the country of destination, in this case Korea. Examples where this preclearance procedure is applied by Korea are for exports of kiwis, oranges, flower bulbs from the EU to Korea.

This preclearance procedure requires the presence of a Korean plant quarantine officer or a Korean employee of the International Plant-Quarantine Accreditation Board of Korea to be present in person in the exporting country to take phytosanitary measures for plants, etc. to be imported into Korea.  The costs of such an official have to be paid by the exporting country. Therefore, this requirement is considered overly costly, burdensome and more trade restrictive than necessary as the EU believes that instead, such controls should be delegated to the authorities of the exporting EU Member State to carry out the necessary phytosanitary controls, which is more efficient and guarantees a high level of control that the Korean import conditions are being respected. At multiple occasions, the EU has requested Korea to accept workable alternatives to preclearance in line with international standards stating that the issuance of phytosanitary certification of regulated articles remains the exclusive responsibility of the National Plant Protection Officer of the exporting country.

title: Excessive required size of samples for imports of saffron and cured ham
description:
High volume (and hence cost, being highly priced products) of samples required for customs inspection, far exceeding ISO standards. Specifically: Saffron: If the saffron is imported as processed food the volume of sample is 600g; cured ham: For bacteriological examination, minimum 6 unit or 800g are necessary. For these two products the issue is affecting seriously the continuity of the business and might cause a trade disruption. These are gourmet products with a very high unit price and the import volume is never large since the market is always small.

HS code(s): 091020, 021011

title: Pre-listing of establishments
description:
The EU experiences differences between countries exporting to Korea animal products whereby Korea allows sometimes countries to add establishments to the Korean list of authorised established to export these products to their country (= pre-listing).  For some countries this is not allowed and Korea requires an on-site inspection before an establishment can be added to the Korean list of authorised establishments.

The EU has been requesting Korea at multiple occasions to increase transparency and to apply pre-listing for all EU Member States as all exporting establishments are under control of the certifying competent authority. Therefore, Korea is requested to apply pre-listing and to require on-site visits of each establishment as this is considered not in line with international standards and more trade restrictive than necessary.

title: Direct transport
description: The EU-Korea FTA includes, in its Protocol on Rules of Origin, a provision establishing that, in order to benefit from the preferential treatment, the originating goods have to be transported directly from one Party to the other, without having been altered. For efficiency reasons, some companies might however use a regional hub for repackaging and redistribution purposes. Resolution of the issue would necessitate an amendment of the direct shipment provision. However, to date, engagement with Korea to discuss a possible modification of this provision has proved unsuccessful.

title: Modification of electromagnetic compatibility (EMC) and electric safety certification regime
description: The objective of the Annex 2-B of the EU-Korea FTA was to improve market access by supporting Korea to gradually adapt its internal safety certification system for Electric Safety and Electromagnetic Compatibility and make it friendlier for economic operators by promoting the Supplier's Declaration of Conformity (SDoC) as the most common conformity assessment system. However certain issues persist hampering the full use of the benefits of the Annex 2-B. Notably, progress towards the simplification of conformity procedures is slow, with the latest technical assessment (Sept. 2020) leading to the reclassification to a lighter certification procedure (SDoC) of only two products. Besides, radio equipment testing is currently not within the scope of Annex 2-B although a growing number of products incorporate radio functions.

title: Restricted Access to Ship Classification Market
description:
No reciprocity in access to ship classification market due to quasi-monopoly of Korean Register (KR) for classification services due to:

1. KR's monopoly in statutory services (one single provider);

2. Bare Boat Charter-Hire Purchase Scheme

3. Financing and refund guarantees are only granted if KR certifies the newbuilding.

title: Homologation procedure of vehicles bound to preferential origin
description:
Article 3 a (ii) of Annex 2-C of the Free Trade Agreement between the European Union and its Member States, of the one part, and the Republic of Korea, of the other part states:
Each Party shall allow on its market the products originating in the other Party, in accordance with this Article: […] Korea shall accept any product that complies with the requirements listed in Table 1 of Appendix 2-C-3 as complying with the corresponding provisions of the applicable technical regulations.


Based on this article, Korea accepts a product pursuant to the EC regulations as equivalent to their own homologation standards. The wording however suggests an applicability only in case of originating products. A definition of “originating product” however, is not provided by the aforementioned provision. According to the Korean MOLIT provisions and local business partners, Korean authorities interpret the term “originating” exclusively as “preferential origin”.

Due to the increasing focus towards electric mobility, this could lead to significant disadvantages for European manufacturers entering the South Korean market, as additional time and man power as well as budget are needed for additional technical amendments and testing procedures.

title: Certification of car parts
description:
In May 2013, Korea introduced a new regime requiring self-certification and Korean KC marking for 5 car parts (brake hose, seat belt, head lamp, rear reflex reflector and rear under ride protection device). They later notified the WTO/TBT committee their intention of increasing the list and including also tyres. In 2014, Korea agreed to apply the UNECE requirements and E-marking for tyres.

In November 2018 new flexibilities were introduced by Korea regarding marking of products. In the future marking will be able to be done in the package if the parts have a tracking number.

title: Truck tractors
description: A segment of trucks, known as truck tractors, falling under HS Code 8701.20, was mistakenly included in the list of products to which the provisions of Annex 2-C of the EU-Korea FTA would not apply. As a result, those types of trucks do not benefit from equivalence between UNECE or EC standards and Korean standards and must comply with the Korean Motor Vehicle Safety Standards (KMVSS). The EU has proposed to include truck tractors in Annex 2-C in the context of a package of FTA amendments.

title: Sri Lanka import ban on several products during COVID-19
description:
• Sri Lanka introduced an exceptionally broad import ban due to the Covid crisis. The Government of Sri Lanka announced measures to reduce imports and ease pressure on the exchange rate and overall balance of payment. These measures were temporary in nature with an end day of 15 July 2020 but were extended on 30 June 2020 without further notice. A new Regulation was issued by Sri Lanka on 16 July 2020 with further adaptations and unlimited time-extension of the import ban. The interlinkages of these measures are not fully clear but they should be seen as a “package”.
  • The ban was implemented through 3 separate but related legal measures, each with explicit lists of banned goods. The government justified the measures as needed to tackle current account difficulties and lack of foreign currency. But some politicians also presented them as favouring Sri Lankan industry and agriculture.
  • From 16 July 2020 the importation of items in Schedule I was banned, and those in Schedule II where allowed under condition of credit facility of 90 or 180 day credit. The retroactive nature of the ban also caused problems, especially in the car sector where related letters of credit are not being honoured and products could not be delivered.

A link to the 122 pages of the regulations in its 16 July 2020 version can be found here: https://drive.google.com/file/d/1-xxjQCubbVRydtHClUhxZ2Q-EGSfECH6/view

In June 2021, a new Regulation was issued, further adapting the ban. While some items had been removed, the list of banned products was extended to a number of items (chemicals and fertilizers). In some cases, regulations are clearly targeted to protect a particular industry (e.g. banning of import of “batic textiles” or particular tyres).  

During the Joint Comission in February 2024, the Sri Lankan representatives explained that the restrictions are now limited to only 304 tariff lines related to motor vehicles. Furthermore, the Sri Lankan side informed us that the existing policy is expected to be reviewed in the third quarter of 2024, with plans for a gradual easing. This review would consider the country's foreign currency situation, along with its debt rescheduling and servicing requirements. Additionally, it was clarified that Sri Lanka currently does not impose any other quantitative restrictions on the importation of goods.

title: Extension of VAT liability and appointment of a fiscal representative
description:
Until now EU businesses providing services to Switzerland have to register for VAT in Switzerland if their annual turnover in Switzerland is above the threshold of CHF 100.000. The Federal Council has proposed new legislation which changes the reference from turnover in Switzerland to worldwide turnover. As a result, most EU businesses providing cross-border services in Switzerland would be required to register for and pay VAT. In addition, an EU based business would need a fiscal representative in Switzerland. Such a fiscal representative creates additional costs.

In addition, the rules for low value consignments which are exempt from VAT will be modified. Up to now, VAT below CHF5 was exempt. In the future, all imports from foreign companies with more than CHF 100.000 turnover from low value consignments will be subject to VAT (regardless of the value of the individual consignment). Coupled with high handling fees for customs procedures, this will make low value imports (notably through e-commerce) less attractive.

The measure entered into force on 1st January 2018 (1st January 2019 for regulation affecting Mail-Order Companies) .

title: Supply of services: 1) Implementation of the 8 Days Pre-announcement Rule for Workers; 2) Deposit requirement for foreign service providers; 3) Universal Application of Collective Agreements; 4) Oblig
description:
Implementation of the 8 Days Pre-announcement Rule for Workers

EU businesses posting temporarily workers in Switzerland for the supply of services have to announce in advance to the Swiss authorities 8 days prior to the deployment, detailing name and social security numbers; in certain cantons very drastic penalties apply in case of infringements. The announcement has to be made for each canton separately, an unnecessary burden for businesses active in several place (e.g.: maintenance agreements).

Deposit requirement for foreign service providers

Article 2(3) of the Swiss law on the minimal working conditions of posted workers authorises the discriminatory extension to foreign service providers of a deposit obligation prior to the supply of the service by means of a collective bargaining agreement.

Universal Application of Collective Agreements ("Normalarbeitsverträge)

The EU-Swiss Agreement on the Free Movement of Persons provides for the possibility to set out rules for minimum wages for the protection for the posted workers. The Swiss law on posted workers grants the possibility to declare collective agreements universally applicable which covers the whole range of employments, wages, emoluments and other charges thus discriminating EU service providers. Furthermore, for determining the applicable reference wages inspectors apply frequently the highest wage category.

Obligation to contribute to control fees and charges

Article 7, paragraph 4a of the Swiss law on the minimal working conditions of posted workers which was introduced by law of 17 December 2004 and became applicable as of 1 April 2006 provides for the possibility to charge general control costs also to businesses providing services. Within collective agreements the Swiss government authorises trade unions and employers to levy discriminatory control charges at EU service suppliers calculated as yearly fees for businesses and monthly fees for workers. Furthermore, many collective agreements provide for a kick-back to Swiss businesses as the contribution to the Swiss employers organisation and the Swiss worker’s contribution to trade unions can be deducted from those liabilities.

Disproportionality of sanctions

Swiss cantonal authorities have repeatedly imposed disproportionate sanctions, e.g. minor errors on wage declaration amounting to CHF 10 resulted in sanction of CHF 500.

The maximum applicable administrative sanction has been increased from CHF 5000 to 30000.

Blacklists

Sanctions include a ban on business activities for up to 5 years in case of serious or repeated breach. EU companies subject to a ban are put on a publicly available blacklist. Since autumn 2016, for certain infringements, a ban on activities can be imposed under more lenient conditions than in the past or cumulative to the imposition of a fine.

title: Trade restrictions due to non-recognition of EUs regionalisation measures for avian influenza outbreaks
description:
A country-wide ban of exports of live poultry is imposed by Taiwan on EU Member States upon notification of an outbreak of Highly Pathogenic Avian Influenza (HPAI) in birds, despite that strict EU control measures are imposed on the affected area in line with international standards.  This harmonised EU policy of regionalisation is strictly implemented in the whole EU whenever an outbreak of HPAI occurs and it guarantees that trade can continue of safe poultry and products originating from the areas/products free of HPAI. Detailed information on the control measures (regionalisation) implemented in the EU is shared with trading partners immediately when outbreaks occur. Therefore, the EU considers that a country-wide ban is not in line with international rules (WTO SPS Agreement and WOAH international standards) as it is considered more trade restrictive than necessary. In other cases, the impact consists on Member States export applications not being approved and facing significant delays.

the following link shows countries and regions acquiring or losing its status of free of HPAI and other diseases

List of Infectious Animal Diseases-free Countries (Zones) and Bovine Spongiform Encephalopathy Risk Status(Bureau of Animal and Plant Health Inspec) (aphia.gov.tw) 

In addition, recovery of free status after an outbreak is very cumbersome and much exceeds provisions on the WOAH Terrestrial Code Article 10.4.6

"If infection with high pathogenicity avian influenza virus has occurred in poultry in a previously free country or zone, the free status may be regained after a minimum period of 28 days (i.e. two flock-level incubation periods) after a stamping-out policy has been completed"

 (the EU policies fully comply with these requirements)

title: Cumbersome and undue delays of import application procedures
description:
Multiple applications from the EU for exports of animals/plants and their products are pending for years without any indication when the process will be finalised.

The import procedure lacks clarity and predictability, being considered not transparent, overly burdensome and unnecessarily lengthy for the EU. Applications from the EU related to SPS measures can take several years without any information on a standard processing period of each procedure or without any justification for the delays provided by Taiwan.

This procedure is against WTO SPS Agreement which states that these procedures should be undertaken and completed without undue delay and in no less favorable manner for imported products than for like domestic products.

title: Import ban on bovine and bovine products due to BSE
description:
The Competent Authority of Taiwan has banned imports of some EU bovine and ovine products due to Bovine Spongiform Encephalopathy (BSE). A wide range of products are affected by this measure (entered into force in February 2001), such as: bovine meat, bovine products ovine products and even cosmetics made of cattle and sheep tissue.

Such a ban is not in line with the World Organisation for Animal Health (WOAH) standards, which provide for safe trade conditions. These conditions are strictly respected by the EU and therefore the EU guarantees safe bovine and bovine products, not only for EU consumers but also for the exported bovine and bovine products. By keeping this import ban in place on EU bovine and bovine products, Taiwan is breaching its commitments under the World Trade Organisation (WTO) agreement on the application of Sanitary and Phytosanitary Measures (SPS).

Moreover, Taiwan, by accepting meat from trading countries than EU with a similar WOAH BSE risk categorisation status, acts in a discriminatory way.

The European Commission addressed this issue with Taiwan since several years.

title: Non-recognition of regionalisation in the EU due to African Swine Fever (ASF)
description:
In February 2014 African swine fever (ASF) has been detected in Poland and in subsequent years also in BG, CZ, HU and BE and other Member States. The EU took immediate measures to restrict movements out of the well-defined infect areas.  Subsequently BE and CZ recovered their free status in all suidae species. Taiwan received detailed information but the Competent Authority of Taiwan continues to maintain its over-restrictive import policy.

Regionalisation/zoning is a well-establiched concept in international standards and also in the WTO SPS Agreement. Taiwan is breaching its international obligations by not recognising the disease free areas in the EU.

title: Wind energy – localisation requirements
description:
Local content requirements (LCRs) apply, with obligatory localisation plans to be submitted by developers that need to cover the full localisation of e.g., the wind turbine production or marine vessels used by developers for site investigation or construction. These measures have been in place since 2015.

Phase 3 of the Energy Plan (2026-2035) unveiled in December 2021 maintains strict LCR. This has now crystallised what were so far a series of informal guidelines into a policy framework/piece of legislation.

1. Local content requirements: the specific requirements (the items that should be localised) and mainly their level (which percentage) have been evolving, with the Industrial Development Bureau (IDB) requiring 100% localisation for a large number of items. In order to qualify to participate in the auction, foreign companies will be required to present a letter of intent/undertaking (specifying the quantity of products purchased locally as well as the “core process” for each item) about future contracts with local companies that are set out in the list provided by the IDB.

2. The localisation requirements extend to the marine vessels used by offshore wind power developers for the purpose of site investigation and construction, with limited flexibility.

The LCRs for round 1 of Phase 3 (covering allocations for projects for years for 2026-2027) was announced on 6 December 2021. The EU engaged with Taiwan on multiple occasions seeking to persuade Taiwan to drop the LCRs, or at least substantially weaken them, in close coordination with the EU industry. Taiwan however only undertook minimal changes. After significant delays due to the stringency of the rules and the difficulties by most developers to comply, Phase 3.1 was nevertheless finalised in September 2023. 

The draft rules for Round 2 of Phase 3 (covering projects for the years 2028-2029) were published on 27 September 2023. Contrary to assurances from Taiwan that it would gradually reduce the amount of LCRs, the initial draft guidelines were even more restrictive than under Phase 3.1. Following consultations with the EU and industry, the Taiwanese government seemed open to make some concessions before publishing the final rules. The EU is seeking a further consultation.

title: Local content requirements in public procurement for transports
description:
The Ministry of Transports and Communications (MOTC) adopted on 17 September 2019 a new directive “Tramway System Procurement Guidelines” applicable to future calls for tenders for the construction of tramway lines in municipalities not part of the Government Procurement Agreement (only Taipei City and Kaohsiung City are under the GPA).

The directive indicates that future calls for tenders for tramway contracts (with the exception of Taipei City and Kaohsiung City) will be subject to a localisation of at least 50%.

title: Non-automatic licensing on feed wheat
description:
Thailand requires since January 2017 an import license for animal feed wheat. The measure was introduced as temporary to address the depressed prices of domestic corn. Only animal feed millers can apply for an import license and the quantity of imports allowed is tied to the quantity of domestic maize purchased (at a ratio of 3 portions of maize for 1 portion of wheat at a guaranteed price of 8 Baht/KG). A lower proportion of domestic corn purchase is applied for imports of animal feed wheat that is used as input for pet foods or as feed for the production of shrimps.

In parallel to the import license, the Government has put in place different programs including price intervention to support financially corn farmers. These programs were discontinued in 2022 amid the increase of the corn price following Russia’s invasion of Ukraine. The local purchase requirement was temporarily suspended from May to July 2022, although the import licence requirement remained in place. Seven years after its introduction the import licence for feed wheat remains in place without an end date.

The EU has raised this issue at the WTO Market Accessand Import Licensing Committees. However, Thailand has never provided any substantive reply to the clarifications requested as regards the policy objectives of the measure, the licensing procedures, the number of licenses granted and the timeframe.

title: Customs issues
description:
The main legal framework for regulating the Thai customs regime is the Customs Act of 2017, which contains several problematic provisions. These cover in particular very high customs reward for customs officials and informants, high penalty for smuggling without the need to prove intent, stringent rules on goods in transit and a lack of notion of intent for offences other than duty evasion.

Some other customs issues were resolved or improved in the Customs Act of 2017, namely the removal of discretion of the DG of Customs to determine customs value deemed appropriate, introduction of a notion of intent for offences resulting in duty shortfall, improvements in the procedures related to duty-reassessment and appeal, and a more proportionate penalty regime.

title: Market access barriers for alcoholic beverages
description:
There are longstanding market access issues in Thailand for alcoholic beverages resulting from different regulations:

- Excise tax discrimination in favour of domestic white spirits: as the Excise scheme, traditionally based on ad valorem rates, penalises imported products, notably wines and premium liquors with higher suggested retail price, on top of a formal discrimination on imported white liquor subject to higher taxes than locally-produced white liquor (lao khao).

Building on the positive developments towards excise tax neutrality on the 2017 Excise Tax, the Thai Government restructured in January 2024 the excise tax for wines and other fermented spirits, in a further step to specific taxation, as part of the wider scheme to promote tourism industry. However, the excise tax discrimination in favour of local white distilled spirits remains unchanged.

 - Certain deviations of mandatory alcohol standards from international standards: as Thailand requires alcohol quality analysis (certificate of analysis) as part of the alcohol import licensing procedures, based on domestic standards that are not fully aligned with international standards.

Thai authorities have confirmed the acceptance of Certificates of analysis issued by foreign laboratories as an alternative to testing at the laboratories of the Excise Department that are free of charge and therefore preferred by importers. Thai authorities also allow for some flexibilities through the application of a margin of tolerance on the non-typical substances and the acceptance for the self-certification for the substances that are not permitted at the EU. These arrangements have avoided major disruption to trade flows.

- Stringent and non-transparent rules on labelling requirements, leaving discretion to the authorities to challenge regular labelling practices: the notification of the Excise Department on alcohol labelling in force since 2015 prohibits in a broad and unclear manner the use of messages that misleads consumer, promotes or induces alcohol consumption. Despite different guidelines issued by Thai authorities, there are still open questions about the use of expressions to characteristics and quality of the products (e.g. "finest" or "premium").

The Ministry of Public Health has also come in two occasions with proposals to impose tobacco-like graphic health warning labelling requirements on alcoholic beverages. The last proposal in February 2024 was finally discontinued following strong opposition from stakeholders. A new draft notification on alcohol labelling presented in mid-2024 would introduce messages to warn underage and drunk drinking which are very much aligned with the business practice.

title: Intellectual Property Rights - Deficient protection and enforcement
description:
The enforcement and administration of intellectual property rights (IPR) in Thailand remains weak despite the government's repeated policy statements and occasional efforts in the field.

The significant backlog in the examination of patent applications by the Department of Intellectual Property (DIP) remains a major concern for business. The digitalisation of the process (SMART DIP for the registration of IP rights) and the increase of numbers of examiners have not significantly reduced the delays in patent examination, especially for chemical and pharmaceutical products, but are seen as a step in the right direction.

Counterfeiting and trade of fake products continue to be widespread and highly visible on physical and online markets. In e-commerce, no effective form of landlord liability has made it into law. The existing remedies consist in voluntary, non-binding agreements between online market players and the authorities in the form of MoUs.

Thailand has taken a number of steps in recent years to strengthen the implementation and enforcement of IP rights. The authorities are engaged in awareness raising campaigns in physical marketplaces as well as in consultations with different stakeholders, including the Embassies, on IPR enforcement.  

On the legislative front, Thailand amended in 2022 the Copyright Act to enhance protection in the digital environment and to prepare for the accession of Thailand to the WIPO Copyright Treaty, which took effect in October 2022. Other key legislative acts to strengthen the legal protection of IPR are in the pipeline, including the amendment of the Patent Act covering utility patents and industrial designs, the amendment of the Act on Geographical Indications (GIs), and the accession to the Hague Agreement for the International Registration of Industrial Designs.

The EU-Thailand FTA currently under negotiation also includes a chapter on IPR.

title: Technical barriers to trade
description:
Thailand maintains cumbersome third party certification procedures (including testing in Thailand and mandatory factory inspection), which are costly, time-consuming and undermine the competitiveness of EU exporters. This affects a wide range of goods such as electronic products and telecom equipment, food & beverages or chemicals, among others. There are also growing concerns over the use of domestic product regulations as technical barriers to trade.

In the automotive sector, despite Thailand being a signatory of the UNECE 1958 Agreement, additional tests in Thai laboratories are required for vehicles and parts even if they have already been type-approved in accordance with UNECE Regulations and test results showing compliance with UNECE Regulations are made available.

In the EU-Thailand FTA under negotiation, the EU has proposed a chapter on TBT, with number of  WTO TBT+ elements, that aim at easing the existing structural TBT-related barriers, and an Annex on ‘Motor vehicles and equipment and parts thereof’ (Car annex) focused on the automotive sector.

title: Restrictions to foreign participation in services sector
description:
The Foreign Business Act 1999 (FBA) lays out the overall framework governing foreign investment in Thailand. The FBA covers horizontally all types of services and reserves certain activities in mode 3 exclusively to Thai nationals.

The FBA classifies services activities in three categories:

  • List 1 strictly closes to foreigners the following activities: farming, forestry, trading of antiques, trading of land and broadcasting.
  • List 2 imposes foreign ownership limits for business activities that involve national security, arts and culture, natural resources and the environment.
  • List 3 limits the foreign ownership in businesses to below 50% for a comprehensive list of services.

For activities in lists 2 and 3, a higher foreign equity is possible (maximum 75% for list 2 and 100% for list 3) subject to specific authorization (Foreign Business License). This authorization is only granted on a case-by-case basis by the government, Cabinet for list 2 and the Foreign Business Committee for list 3, after consultation with the relevant Thai business associations.

The current legal definition of a foreign juristic person in the FBA refers to equity ownership only. By strict interpretation, the FBA does not limit control or use of preferential voting shares to control a company by foreigners. In the past, Thailand has attempted to further tighten the rules for foreign participation beyond the capital limitation by adding foreign ownership criteria based on the control of companies (voting rights and/or management control). The Ministry of Commerce have also increased investigations regarding nominee recently. These rules have left the services market in Thailand largely closed to foreign majority owned companies with highly complex sharholding structure and it gives an advantage to influential domestic conglomerates.

Since 2016, the Ministry of Commerce has periodically issued exemptions to the list of restricted activities under List 3 of the FBA. The exemptions must be read with caution as businesses exempted are generally regulated under other specific rules and regulations. The relevant licenses still have to be obtained from responsible authorities. 

NEW: In 2024, the Ministry of Commerce finalised a list of 11 services activities which has been floated around since 2019 for exemption under the FBA. The exemptions include, inter alia, domestic trade of traditional agricultural products which is traded in the Futures Exchange Centre; Telecommunication License Type 1 (no network); Treasury Center Business; some services offered to affiliated companies; and software development business. The list is pending approval from Minister of Commerce. Then, it will be proposed to the Cabinet. Once approved and announced in the government gazette, the exemption will become effective. No timeline is indicated by the Ministry of Commerce.

In addition to the restrictions to ownership under the FBA, a number of service sectors are also regulated by sector specific laws e.g. insurance, banking, telecommunications, transport, etc. Similarly as in the FBA, regulators in certain sectors like insurance and banking, while maintaining a general rule on Thai majority ownership, allow a foreign majority on a case-by-case basis subject to a Cabinet decision. Other regulators, notably the National Broadcasting and Telecommunications Commission and Civil Aviation Authority of Thailand have introduced controversial foreign dominance criteria (e.g. management control, using preferential shares with different voting rights to control, etc.) into the operating licensing conditions in addition to the equity ownership.

title: Government procurement
description:
The 2017 Public Procurement and Supplies Administration Act (the GP Act) and its implementing regulations incorporate the principles of fair competition, non-discrimination and transparency, and are based on four main notions: value for money, transparency, efficiency and effectiveness, and accountability.  The GP Act standardises the public procurement process across the country for all government agencies, State-Owned Enterprises (SOEs) and other public organisations under the supervision of the State.

However, the GP Act and its implementing regulations are complex and contain elements, which could potentially undermine the underlying principles of fair competition and non-discrimination. This includes certain offsets and  preferential treatment accorded to domestic suppliers such as the “Buy Thai” policy (e.g. the provisions regarding products and services that the government would like to promote or support), the Thailand Innovation List, supporting to Thai SMEs,  as well as the exclusion of the procurement of the Public-Private Partnership Projects (PPPs) and the procurement of SOEs for commercial purposes.

title: Non-recognition of EU regionalisation policies - African swine fever
description:
Thailand Department of Livestock Developments does not recognise EU zoning measures and imposes country wide bans on several Member States, following outbreaks of African Swine Fever. Member States affected include, at least, Italy, Poland and Germany.

This bans are normally notified via the WTO SPS Mechanism and extended every three months.

The EU has provided comments via the WTO mechanism, in coordination with affected Member States, but Thailand has not provided so far a response. The EU has also raised this in the context of bilateral meetings, so far unsuccessfully.

The bans deviate from the WTO SPS Agreement provisions on regionalisation and WOAH standards on zoning, plus specific provisions in the relevant Chapters for African Swine Fever. In specific cases, a de facto ban has been applied also to products subject to treatments inactivating the virus, e.g. ham subject to curing process in excess of six months.

Thailand has not provided either indications on what steps, if any, can be adopted or information provided in order to obtain the lifting of the bans. In addition, and as of February 2024, Thailand is also affected by African Swine Fever

Some of latest related bans as notified to WTO are notification THA 720 on Italy, THA 748 Poland, THA 749 Germany. The EU has provided comments to these bans and raised the issue in repeated bilateral meetings.

title: Cumbersome and undue delays of import application procedures
description:
Multiple applications from the EU for exports of animals/plants and their products are pending for years without tangible progress.

Although some improvements were made over the past years, the import procedures are not transparent, overly burdensome and unnecessarily lengthy for the EU, given that all Member States apply the same, harmonised sanitary and phytosanitary rules. 

This policy disrespects the WTO SPS Agreement which states that approval procedures should be undertaken and completed without undue delay and in no less favourable manner for imported products than for like domestic products.

Incremental progress since 2019: Thailand agreed to regular meetings with EU delegation and Member State embassies to take stock of pending applications. Separate meetings are held every three months with the Department of Livestoock Development and the Ministry of Agriculture for animal and plant products, respectively.  

Partial resolution in 2020: during 2020, Thailand opened its market for apples from Belgium, Netherlands, Germany and Italy in addition to the already approved from FR and PL) and the authorisation for kiwis from HL (see barrier 16802).

Partial resolution in 2021: In 2021, Thailand authorised additional varieties of kiwis (golden and baby kiwis) from FR; Spain received a partial authorisation for the imports of pork and pig products from 5 establishments on 2 July 2021. 

Incremental progress in 2022:

  • Inspections of beef establishments are scheduled in Spain, Denmark, Poland and Ireland. 
  • Pork onsite audit in ES from 8-18 Feb. Planned beef onsite audit in ES and IE from 14 Mar to 1 Apr as well as in DK and PL from 24 Mar to 8 Apr.

Partial resolution in 2022: 

Animal and animal products

Pork onsite audit in ES from 8-18 Feb.  Beef onsite audits in ES and IE from 14 Mar to 1 Apr as well as in DK and PL from 24 Mar to 8 Apr.  Audit reports were submitted to the MS CVOs in the course June to September. Pending final approval by the DLD (exchanging information on corrective measures). The case of pork Spain is still unresolved as of September 2024.

Partial Resolution in 2023:

General: Following the 20th Informal contact Group Meeting on 2 Feb, the DLD agreed to simplify the approval process for “low-risk” processed animal products (no onsite audit required).

Following the 21th Informal contact Group Meeting in July, the DLD agreed to accept the World Organisation for Animal Health (WOAH)’s definition of “negligible risk products”. This means that the DLD will stop imposing a “country-wide ban” on the Italian cured meat provided that the Italian Veterinary Office submits an attestation that the products have gone through the process in accordance with the WoAH guidelines.

Plant and plant products: Spain received an approval a pre-shipment cold treatment facility for Cherries. In January, Spain received an official approval for pears and, table grapes while France got an authorisation for potatoes for human consumption. Audit on pears conducted in September 2023 in BE and NL.

17-Feb-2023       Positive Developments, the 21th Informal contact Group Meeting with the DLD, the DLD agreed to accept the World Organisation for Animal Health (WOAH)’s definition of “negligible risk products” for cured meat.

Aug-2023             Partial resolved, system authorisations for beef imports from Denmark,  and the authorisation for exports from certain establishments in Spain

COM pushes for the finalisation of the system approval for beef for IE and PL, not solved yet as of September 2024.

28 Aug-8 Sep     Positive Developments, pear combined audit in BE and NL, also of PT and IT. 

This has led to  final approval of pear applications by end June 2024 for all these 4 Member States, without any cold treatment required in case of NL.

title: Non-recognition of regionalisation - Avian Influenza
description:
Thailand imposes country-wide import bans in the event of an outbreak of avian influenza   in an EU Member State, despite effective zoning (regionalisation) measures are put in place in line with international standards.  This ignores the provisions of the WOAH Terrestrial Code, particularly in Chapter 4.4, zoning and compartmentalization, as well as 10.4 on HPAI. It also ignores provisions in Article 6.2 of the WTO SPS Agreement, which indicates how “Members shall, in particular, recognize the concepts of pest — or disease-free areas and areas of low pest or disease prevalence.”

The EU regionalisation measures are highly effective and guarantee that no further spreading took place out of the well-defined affected areas so that trade could continue in the non-affected areas.  

Trading partners should recognise this policy in line with their WTO obligations to minimise negative trade effects as safe trade can continue to take place and thus does not deserve a country-wide ban.

During 2024 Thailand has continued imposing bans on Member States affected by HPAI. These bans are notified to the WTO SPS mechanismo, for instance via notifications THA 718 Poland, THA 753 Germany, THA 710 Belgium etc. The EU has provided comments to these notifications of country wide bans. Thailand has not reacted  to the EU comments.

title: Specific Import duties on alcoholic beverages exceeding WTO bound rates
description:
Trinidad and Tobago applied MFN import tariffs for alcoholic beverages (specific duties) surpass its WTO bindings (100% ad valorem).
