The legislation is the Customs Act chapter 78:01 available at the link: http://www.customs.gov.tt/content/Customs%20Act.pdf

title: Higher tariffs on "non-essential" consumer products (including agricultural and processed products not covered by the AA)
description:
In May 2017 Tunisia announced the intention to increase MFN tariffs on "non-essential" consumer products.  

These measures were materialised on 1 January 2018 through the 2018 Budget Law, which increased MFN import tariffs on agricultural and industrial products (all agricultural products at 0% increased to 15%; a number of agricultural products and processed agricultural products increased to 36%; industrial products from 20% to 30%). Whilst, thanks to the Association Agreement, EU industrial exports are not affected, many EU agricultural products, not covered by the Association Agreement, face an increased MFN duty (frozen tuna, kiwi, honey, apples, figs, pineapples, avocados, and mangoes). All in all, EU agricultural exports worth € 3.6 million have seen a tariff increase from 20% to 36%. 

The 2018 Budget Law has also imposed an excise tax ranging between 10% and 340% on certain products, including cars.

The budget law 2022 adopted on 28 December 2021 provides for a new erga omnes increase of customs duties for a series of products. 

  • The customs tariff increase from 30% to 43% for products under the following HS chapters (in full or in part, for details see annex) : HS 25, 32, 33, 34 39, 40, 42,44, 48, 49,49, 65, 66, 67, 68, 69, 70, 76, 82, 84, 85, 87, 89, 90, 94, 95, 96.
  • The customs tariff increase from 36% to 50% erga omnes for products under the following HS chapters (in full or in part, for details see annex) : HS04, 07, 08, 09, 12,16,17,1819, 20,21,22, 57, 61, 6263, 64.
  • Customs tariffs for fresh bananas (080390) increase from 0 to 50%.
  • Customs tariffs for telephones (851712001)  increase from 0 to 20%.

title: Technical controls of imported goods
description:
Technical controls are  burdensome to importers.  There are three strands of control depending of the products: 

  • A: products such as toys, cosmetics, food, the technical control is systematic and can take different forms (desk review, possibly accompanied by sample testing, inspection of goods or analysis of samples).
  • B: products of moderate risk can be accompanied by conformity assessments delivered by authorised bodies – to assess conformity with applicable rules.
  • C: Products subject to technical specifications (single-use syringes; seats, furniture and parts thereof; ceramic tiles; electronic equipment of TV devices; tyres and wheels; linker, cement and lime).

Technical specifications and lists are published in a Ministerial decree.

 Main issues are:

Category A:

  • Although all products will be controlled, the modalities are not clear and give some discretionary power to the technical control authorities.
  • Controls are not based on a risk analysis.
  • In cases where a laboratory analysis is requested, this prolongs the delay before commercialisation and increases storage costs.
  • Tunisian norms are not notified to WTO.

Depending on the product, technical controls are carried out under the supervision of Ministries of: trade, agriculture, industry, public health, and technology and communication.

 Category B: barely used and under revision

 Category C:

  • Technical specifications are set up within committees made of Tunisian administration but also representatives of the sector, who tend to slow down the process to protect their market ( cahier des charges)
  • Each individual import operation requires prior agreement by the dedicated committee, which may take time
  • Respect of technical specifications does not exclude in certain cases sample testing. Products like ceramics and tyres are subject to double control: technical specifications ( cahier des charges ) and sample testing.
  • Local producers are not subject to the same procedure and technical specifications.

 An additional issue relates to situations where a product is expected to conform to technical specifications which are not yet available. This is the case since spring 2020 for chocolate, chocolate products and cheese (see NTB fiche 15769). In the absence of technical specifications, the import authorisation has a discretionary character and results to non-automatic import licencing.

 

Domestic Legal acts:

  • L’arrêté du Ministre de l’économie nationale du 30 août 1994, fixant les listes des produits soumis au contrôle technique à l’importation et à l’exportation,
  • L'arrêté du Ministère du commerce et de l’Artisanat du 15 septembre 2005, portant modification de l’arrêté du Ministre de l’économie nationale du 30 août 1994, fixant les listes des produits soumis au contrôle technique à l’importation et à l’exportation,
  • Le décret 2010-1684 qui énonce le principe de sélectivité des contrôles, et
  • L'arrêté de Septembre 2010 qui fixe les modalités de contrôle systématique pour les produits de la liste

Ceramics:

Since 2006, ceramic tiles have to qualify for technical requirements (“cahier des charges”) while these requirements do not apply to local production. In the last years, it has got more complicated to obtain the approval of the authorities regarding the technical requirements. The procedures to obtain the approval are blocked constantly. The authorities have seven days to check the goods but they do not fulfil the time limitation. Samples have to be tested twice a year. All in all, ceramic tiles are retained by the Tunisian custom authorities in the port at least for 2 months before the cargo is allowed to enter the market. This causes an increase in the cost of the final price. No complaints since 2021.

Tyres:

Tyres are subject to technical specifications and systematic testing. However, in the absence of a dedicated technical control center with the capacity to implement all necessary tests, the tests are partly outsourced and carried out for the Ministry of Industry within the premices of the STIP private company, which is the local tyres producer.  In addition, the STIP has experienced in 2023 temporary periods of technical lay-offs, during which the premises were closed and no tests could be carried out, hence empedding the techncial control procedures. 

As per Article 10 of the Tunisian “Cahier de Charge”/ technical specifications, Tunisian regulation requires tyres to comply with either European (ETRTO) or American (DOT/FMVSS) norms/regulations.  However, when it comes to the tests, they are performed according to different norms,  Tunisian norms. This is a contradiction. Finally the Tunisian norm is equivalent to ISO 10191 and ISO 10454, which are however obsolete.

More importantly, as a contracting party of UN58 having implemented UN Reg 117, Tunisia should accept E-marked tyres without further testing; any local test should be aligned to UNECE regulations R30 or R54.

Finally, Tunisia imposes the stictest time limit in the world, imposing that tyres must be no more than 6 months old by the time of release into free circulation.Ths appears to be disproportionate and not based on scientific evidence.

title: Burdensome customs procedures and taxation on imports
description:
Burdensome customs procedures:

In May 2017, Tunisia announced border measures aimed at limiting imports on the grounds of a deteriorating trade balance. Introduced as from October 2017, the following measures are still in place (with the exception of the prohibition to grant credit for the importation of goods, which was finally eliminated by the Central Bank on 21 December 2018): 

  • Export declaration. Tunisia obliges importers to submit the export declaration from the country of origin for a long list of products. The claimed aim is to fight under invoicing, especially from China. Despite reiterated EU concerns, Tunisia has not agreed to exempt EU products.
  • Free sale certificate. Importers of cosmetics, toys and school supplies are requested to provide a certificate of free sale in the country of origin. Tunisia has not notified the new measure to WTO, despite the EU request to do so.

Domestic legal reference:

  • Export declaration: May 2007 (Circulaire du Ministère du commerce)
  • Free sale certificate: May 2007 (Circulaire du Ministère du commerce)

 Taxation/ excise duties :

Excise taxes have been imposed on a large number of products and collected by the customs. No proof that these taxes are collected from the local producers , as unlike the VAT, the tax doesn't appear on the purchase invoices/ bills.

Domestic legal reference:several finance Laws

 Advance on taxes :

- An advance on corporate taxes has to be paid at the customs authorities prior to the customs clearance. It amounts to 10% of the total amount of the value of the imported goods (and not to the commercial margin, which is normally the tax bases).

The Finance law 2023 - with an entry into force on 1.01.24 - increased from 10 to 15% the advance on income taxes that has to be paid by certain categories of companies and added that in those cases  the advance can not be reimbursed. 

  • Augmentation du taux de l’AIR de 10% à 15% pour :
  • Les entreprises en défaut total ou partiel,
  • Les entreprises ayant des dettes fiscales n’ayant pas fait l’objet de calendrier de paiement, et
  • Les entreprises qui déclarent des revenus ou bénéfices minorés.
    • L’AIR au taux de 15% est reportable non restituable.

- An advance on VAT is also required for every imported consignment:  the importer pays to customs authorities, prior to the customs clearance, the totality of the VAT, as if the totality of the goods had been sold.

 Both measures impose severe cash-flow constraints on importers.

title: Import conditions for new pharmaceutical products
description:
The main obstacles to market access are :

  • Delays in obtaining Marketing Authorization (MA) : The duration of obtaining MA is prohibitive, often 4-5 years whereas the texts provide for 1 year. The number of innovative molecules that have been put on the market in Tunisia between 2010 and 2018 is particularly low, compared to other countries in the region. No reimbursement by the National Health Insurance Fund has been made for these medicines.
  • Significant delays in payments by the Pharmacie Centrale de Tunisie ( PCT) to foreign suppliers. Foreign laboratories are very worried. Local producers would not have this problem.
  • Risks of dinar depreciation: Since May 2013,  the PCT conditions its authorisation to buy and thus put on the market any new type of pharma products to the acceptance by the exporter to carry the risk of depreciations of the dinar, and this during a period of 4 years from authorisation. Exporters complain it creates an unacceptable uncertainty, and that the PCT imposes excessive and unpredictable conditions. This measure is still in place.
  • Protection of data submitted for regulatory approval of pharmaceuticals: This protection is provided in Tunisia but in practice, the PCT does not check systematically whether the data presented is protected or not, before granting marketing authorisations, referring laboratories that consider themselves injured to the courts. Several laboratories have reportedly won their cases in recent years before the courts.
  • There have been cases where the ministry of health authorised the sale of a generic, when the IPR of the molecule had not expired and the branded products had not even been authorised on the market.

title: Mandatory licences for import of certain products
description:
On 17 October 2022, Tunisia introduced mandatory licences for imports into Tunisia on 130 product categories, including textile, cosmetics, home appliances, cables and some agricultural products. The above list of products at 4-digit level is indicative and the list published by the Tunisian Ministry of Trade and Export Development is more narrow indicated at 8-digits level.

The measure was not published in the Official journal of Tunisia and there was no consultation with the EU or notification to the WTO. 

The Tunisian authorities argue that the measure was triggered by consumer complaints about the poor quality of products imported to Tunisia, hence, it had to be introduced as a reinforcement of Tunisian market surveillance system. The Tunisian authorities describe the measure as a one-off ex-ante control required when an operator wishes to import covered goods into Tunisia for the first time.

The measure adds to already very burdensome import procedures in Tunisia: the reform of market surveillance and technical controls in Tunisia has been a long-standing request by the EU with a registered trade barrier since 2016 under the MACFLOW number 10961.

Under the measure, importers wishing to import any of the covered goods into Tunisia, must first obtain an import licence from the relevant Tunisian ministry. For that purpose, importers must submit an importation file to competent authorities. There are no fees charged to the applicants. The application file must contain 8 documents, some of which have to be produced by the factory directly in attempt to bypass intermediaries (invoice, legal status, quality controls in place etc.). The required documents are:

  1. an invoice issued by the factory;
  2. a certificate issued by an official authority in the country of export relating to the legal entity of the factory and the license permitting it to practice its activity;
  3. proof that the factory has a quality control system in place (in practice: a certificate presenting the quality procedures in place, ISO standards, self-certification etc);
  4. list of products to be imported;
  5. the trademark of the product and the trademark that is produced under a license from the entity owning it (in practice: registered trademark in the country of origin);
  6. a model of the labels of the imported products;
  7. a free sale certificate delivered by the national authorities of the exporting party; and
  8. documents and reports confirming that the imported products meet applicable quality standards (in practice: ISO certificates, conformity certificates, analysis certificates, quality certificates by the producer).

On top of those minimum required documents, Tunisian authorities reserve the right to request additional documents to check the quality and safety of imported goods or request samples of goods to be imported for inspection.

There are no clear or published deadlines for processing the applications by the Tunisian authorities. According to the information available, the processing of applications may vary from 48 hours to 4 months. It is not clear whether in practice there have been any rejections of EU applicants so far.

title: Non-automatic import licences on chocolate, chocolate products and cheese
description:
The issue concerns the non-automatic import licences for chocolate, chocolate products and cheese, in the context of the Tunisian Réglementation des douanes of 5 May 2020 and the Réglementation 685 Authorisation suite controle technique systématique à l’importation.

In the absence of this " cahier des charges" with specifications setting the general conditions and obligations for the import and commercialisation of cheese (HS code 0406) and chocolate and chocolate products (HS codes 180631 to 180690), importers should request an  authorisation to import for these two kinds of products. TThis is in practice, a discretionary decision of the authorities.

title: Import Surveillance Regime
description:
The import surveillance mechanism consists of a requirement to obtain a surveillance license prior to the import of  several products if their price is below a certain threshold unit value defined by the authorities via different communiqués. The scope of this mechanism is broad and gradually expanding via regular new communiques. The Turkish authorities justify the measure by the need to prevent cheap exports from third countries (mainly Asian).

Prior to the import operation, if the imported products' price is below a threshold unit value, the importer has to apply for a surveillance license to the Ministry of Trade. The application file contains information about the importer, the declarant (if different from the importer), the exporter, the producer and information about the imported product. Documents such as the original or notary-certified copy of the list of the authorized signatures of declarant, copies of the pro-forma invoice or the commercial invoice.

In practice, after applying for a surveillance licence, exporters are requested to submit a number of additional documents containing confidential business information (total turnover, capacity, total production, total domestic sales, total exports, etc).  In such situation, given the extreme difficulty to secure the surveillance license, importers are de facto forced to declare the unit price determined in the communiqué instead of the real transaction value. This increases their declared customs value and the tax base upon which VAT is calculated. This leads to competition distortion between exporters and local producers.

A concurrent problem is that companies are not easily able to get refund of overpaid VAT amounts. Before July 2021, companies could sue for overpaid VAT amounts and were able to obtain court decisions in favour of refunds. However,  with an amendment of Article 211, paragraph 1 of the Customs Law (through an omnibus law published in the Official Gazette of 28 July 2021), Turkiye decided that “customs value of the goods subject to a trade policy measure increased by way of operator’s self-declaration”, whereby no remission or no repayment of customs duties is provided. Furthermore, a Presidential Decision published on the Official Gazette of 24 November 2023 abolished the right of sellers to deduct overpaid VAT as a result of application of surveillance and trade defence measures. 

Turkiye argues that if EU operators have specific problems to obtain "surveillance document" the Ministry may look into them. However, beyond the solution of individual cases, the systemic problem remains, creating obstacles to imports and leading to overpayments of VAT, which are never recovered.

title: Additional customs duties
description:
Since 2011, with a number of decrees published in the Turkish Official Gazette, Turkiye has imposed customs duties exceeding those of the Common Customs Tariff (so-called ‘additional duties’) on an increasing range of products. While products originating in the EU or FTA partners of Turkiye are not subject to these additional duties, the ones originating in third countries are affected when imported via the EU, even if they have been formally placed in free circulation in the EU.

‘Additional duties’ range between 1,9% and 50% and affect more than one third of Turkiye’s tariff lines (4-digit level). On 31 December 2020, Decree 3351 published in the Official Gazette abolished all the previous decrees pertaining to additional duties, combining them in a single text, while also lowering some of the rates. 

In February 2022, Turkiye removed around 500 tariff lines out of more than 4000 tariff lines to which it applies adiditonal duties. As of January 2023, some adjustments were made as per the scope (47 tariff lines were deleted, 87 new tariff lines were added and duty rates for 40 tariff lines have been increased).Subsequently, Türkiye made further revisions such as increasing duty rate for electical vehicles of Chinese origin to 40% (March 2023) and  (16 October 2023) increasing the rates for broad range of  textile and clothing products from 5111.20 to 6304.99. As of 31 December 2023 to be effective in 2024 Türkiye published new updated list of additional duties incorporating duty rate increases in textile products as well as the additional duty increase  to 40% exclusively on imports of electrical vehicles (EV) from China (8703.80) introduced with a footnote in March 2023. Additional duty on imports of EV from non-EU and non -FTA countries  remain 10%.The number of tariff lines additional duties apply is nearly 4500 as of September 2024.

In June 2024, Türkiye introduced additional duties of 40%  on imports of automobiles  (8703.21 to 8703.70) from China. In September 2023, a new additional duty of 15% has been also introduced on imports of a chemical substance on Pentaerythritol.

title: Import restriction of live bovine and beef
description: Turkey granted to the EU an annual quota right for frozen carcass beef under the Decision 1/98 of the EC-Turkey Association Council (amended by Decision 2/2006), which was amended in 2018 to include fresh and chilled beef as well. However, EU operators cannot benefit from these concessions due to restrictions on imports of live bovine animals and beef products mainly related to the non-transparent management of import quotas. In particular, the quotas for beef have not been opened and could not be used regularly.

title: Local content requirements in Turkey's law 6094 amending the law of 2005 on the utilisation of renewable energy sources for the generation of electricity
description:
Electricity from renewable sources in Turkey is supported through a feed-in tariff, which consists a fixed and a variable component. Depending on the renewable energy technology used, the Turkish Renewable Energy Law sets certain amounts of feed in tariff payments.

The Law on utilization of renewable energy resources for the purpose of generating electrical energy of 2005 was amended in 2010 (Law No. 6094) and entered into force on 8 January 2011. The amended law stipulates that electricity generation can benefit from a support scheme ("RER Support Mechanism") and where domestic mechanical and/or electro-mechanical components are used for the generation, the feed-in prices shall be topped up for a period of five years. The exact ratio of domestic components that are required to benefit from additional support and the calculation methods are set and updated by ministerial regulation, which was revamped in 2016. The last regulation modification was published in the Official Gazette n°31138 on 28 May 2020. Additionally, new support schemes were published in the Turkish Official Gazette on 18 September 2020 and 30 January 2021, enabling some producers to benefit from support system until 2030. On 1 May 2023 with Presidential Decision No. 7189, Türkiye further revised the support and additional local content support amounts (that will apply for 5 or 10 years) and calculation method that would be applicable for the companies that has started operation or will start between 1/7/2021 and 31/12/2030. Local content support  is set as 28,80 TRY cent kWh  or 38,45 TRY cent KWh for 5 years depending on the type of plant which operates between 1/7/2021 and 31/12/2030 .   :https://www.mevzuat.gov.tr/MevzuatMetin/20.5.7189.pdf

The ratio of renewable energy installations in the total installed power generation capacity increased from 45% in 2019 to 55% in 2023 (42% in electricity generation). The growth in Turkey’s installed renewable energy capacity was driven mainly by private investments benefitting from the preferential feed-in-tariff.

title: Additional liabilities (compensatory levy) arising from the difference between Turkish and EU GSP schemes
description:
In 2017 Turkey introduced so-called `additional financial liabilities` (by Decision 2017/10926 of the Council of Ministers of 11 September 2017). These are compensatory levies that raise the level of the EU`s Generalised Scheme Preferences (GSP) tariffs to the level of Turkey`s existing applicable duties for imports of several countries to which Turkey should normally apply the EU`s GSP tariffs – whenever those goods are imported into Turkey via the EU.

Turkey replaced Decision 2017/10926 with Decision 2018/11799 dated 22 June 2018 (attached please find a Turkish copy) and extended the scope to all products falling under the Customs Union except Chapter 93 and excluding ECS products and agricultural products (Chapters 5,9,13 to 15, 17 to 22, 24 and 44 to 46). The purpose is still to compensate the tariff difference for the products originating in several countries and imported with an A.TR document.

title: Barriers on Pharmaceutical Products
description:
Pharmaceuticals are subject to a pricing mechanism in Türkiye where reference pricing is used with some EU Member States set as reference countries whereas  the prices in Turkish lira are determined on a fixed exchange rate consistently below the market rate. The situation has become worse in the last 6 years with the gap widening between the real exchange rate and the fixed rate used. As the latest development, a Presidency Decision was published in the Official Gazette on the pricing of pharmaceuticals  on 22 July  2023. Accordingly, the fixed exchange rate value of EURO calculated for the pricing of pharmaceuticals has been increased by 30.5 % and is set at 1 EUR= 14.0387 TRY.   The rate was already increased by 36.37 % on 15 December 2022 to 1 EUR= 10.75 TRY, to be valid in 2023. Hence, this is the second increase for 2023, since December, given the strong depreciation of TRY.  This is still well below the current market exchange rate which is around 29.8 as of October 2023.

The situation creates an increasingly difficult and unpredictable operating environment for pharmaceutical companies.

Good manufacturing practices (GMP) requirements: Following a circular of the Turkish Ministry of Health issued on 31 December 2009, manufacturers of pharmaceutical products exported to Turkey must submit a Good Manufacturing Practice (GMP) certificate issued by the Turkish Ministry of Health or the authority of another country with which Turkey has reciprocal certification agreement.

Consequently, since 1 March 2010, Turkey has not been accepting the EU GMP certificates as it was the case previously. EU manufacturers are now obliged to submit a number of documents related to their manufacturing facilities and are subject to on-site inspections by the Turkish authorities. The introduction of this measure has led to significant delays in the registration and marketing in Turkey of new pharmaceutical products and to an important backlog of unprocessed requests.

title: Deficient IPR enforcement
description: Length of proceedings and deficient enforcement of the domestic IPR regulations especially with regard to preliminary measures such as search and seizure warrants are identified as one of the main weaknesses of the current Turkish IPR enforcement system. IPR infringements are widespread and affect several many industrial sectors. They concern particularly trademarks but also copyright and Regulatory Data Protection. IPR infringements include both counterfeit goods and online piracy.

title: Surveillance by registration of imports of textiles and materials used in the manufacturing of textiles
description:
Surveillance by registration has been in force since 2009 for textile products. It results in an artificial upward adjustment of the product value, if the invoice value is below the reference price at registration. According to the most recent Communique 2020/9, all textile exporters to Türkiye are required to register online with the Istanbul Textile and Apparels Exporters Union (registration centre). Reference values are not published in the Official Gazette but included in such online registration system: ithalat.ebirlik.org. Annexe to the Communique lists large number of products (by Chapters or tariff codes) as well as the forms and other information required for the registration. Registry document is valid for 90 days and covers single customs declaration form. Validity of the registry document cannot be extended and cannot be used for more than one customs declaration form. Additional documentation or information may be required by the Ministry of Trade (DG for Imports) for specific cases.

The registration process is burdensome and time-consuming, with significant financial implications on imports. In particular, it requires the submission of detailed commercial information in an Exporter/Producer information form and approval by official instances (such as consularisation). Recently, EU exporters have been extensively requested to submit certificate of origin and provide a financial guarantee in contradiction with the provisions of the Customs Union.

title: Export restrictions on hides, skins and wet-blue leather
description:
The Support and Price Stability Fund (DEFIF in Turkish) was established by Decision 88/13384 in 1988. The tax is collected at the exportation. DEFIF is also linked with the export registration requirement since some goods subject to the DEFIF tax are also subject to export registration. 

On hides, skins and wet-blue leathers, with Presidential Decision 1045 of 10 May 2019 (amending decision 2017/10876),  Turkey has been applying an export tax of 50 cent/kg to products under the  tariff codes 4101,-4102 , 4103 and 4104.11 and 4104.19 excluding pickled leather, and export tax at a level of 20% of FOB value in TL to products under the tariff codes 4105.10 and 4106.21. Turkey also requires an export registration for wet blue leather products (Communique 2006/7 on exports- items subject to DEFIF levies and specifically products under 4104.11, 4104.19, 4105.10, 4106.21 ).

title: Alcoholic Beverages – Restrictions on Banderols and Excessive Sampling
description:
Türkiye has been applying a banderol (strip stamp) to alcoholic beverages since November 2007. The banderol system was introduced to cope with tax evasion and counterfeiting of alcoholic beverages. A banderol is defined as a sale document applied to the inner packaging of alcohol and alcoholic beverages to be placed on the market. It indicates the supervision, inspection and compliance approval of the competent Authority (i.e. the Department of Tobacco and Alcohol - ‘TADAB’-, which operates under the Ministry of Agriculture).Before 15 June 2021, Türkiye was requesting an advanced payment of the excise tax (i.e.  Special Consumption Tax -‘OTV’ and the VAT related to this tax) in order to approve strip stamps/banderol requests of companies. This had operational and financial impacts for companies since applying the strip stamps took quite a long time as it was done manually and that meant that companies had to predict sales months beforehand and pay the tax accordingly.

On 15 June 2021, the TADAB published a new declaration on the Ministry’s website. With this new declaration, although “upfront tax payment” in relation to banderol request was not requested anymore on paper, a number of constraints still applied in practice:

  • The TADAB limits the number of strip stamps which can be ordered in one go to the equivalent of 1/12 of the planned annual sales activity, as indicated in the company’s “Alcoholic Beverage Distribution & Authorization Certificate”.  
  • The TADAB requests importers to pay the excise tax for a previous strip stamp order in order to accept a new order. Given the limitation on the number of strip stamps that can be ordered at once, this de-facto forces companies to pay excise taxes on the previous batch long before it has been sold. 
  • Importers are required to provide guarantee equivalent to the amount of the OTV (and the VAT related to this tax) to be paid at the time of import for the number of products for which banderols were requested and granted by the TADAB.
  • There is no time limit set in law with regard to TADAB’s approval process or the time it takes for ordered strip stamps to be printed.

Imported spirits bottles cannot be imported or leave the bonded warehouses until the company acquired the strip stamps in Türkiye and applied them on spirit bottles.

On 2 September 2021 the Revenue Administration published a new communiqué. The communiqué introduced, inter alia, the requirement of a guarantee in relation with the OTV and its related value added tax (‘VAT’) payments for delivery of banderols for sale of alcoholic beverages. The guarantee letter was meant to replace the upfront payment of taxes. However, in practice, the guarantee letter is not used by importers as it is very difficult, if not impossible, to implement (cumbersome and very time-consuming). 

In October 2022, the TADAB issued a new circular removing the limitation of banderol requests up to 1/12 of the annual  sales activity  if they had paid the SCT in advance or provided the guaranty. 

The EU Industry confirmed that TADAB request to pay the excise tax for a previous strip stamp order in order to accept a new order was removed. However, the EU Industry also indicted that the option to use of a letter of guarantee is so lengthy and burdensome that most companies do not see it as a valid solution. 

The EU Industry also indicated that Turkish customs authorities keep carrying out excessive sampling controls whereby, generally, at least 2 bottles are removed for analysis, on each depletion of stock from bonded warehouses. 

Türkiye has put in place an inspection regime and if companies apply for and submit to an authorisation check, the level of sampling can be reduced from 100% to 10%.

Since the EU has stringent controls on safety standards for alcoholic beverages such sampling controls in Türkiye are excessive within the Customs Union.

title: Import licenses for old-second hand-renovated goods
description:
Turkey requires for imports of old, second hand, renovated goods an import license. This limitation derives from the Article 7 of the Turkish Import Code (originally Article 7 of the Council of Ministers n°1995/7606 published in December 1995, replaced by the Presidential Decree 3350 published on 31 December 2020). On the basis of this article 7, the Undersecretariat for Foreign Trade (UFT) (restructed as the Ministry of Trade since 2018) issues a new communiqué every year as part of the Turkish Import Regime to list products which might imported with import licensing and under which conditions. Currently the Communiqué contains only one annex (list)  products that can be imported provided that certain conditions if stated such as type of product (for civil avaiation purpose or not), age/model, economic life, availability of domestic production and equivalent goods, CIF value are met and a license document is presented to the customs on release for free circulation. For instance, only certain retreated tyres for use on aircrafts could be imported with permission of the civil aviation authority and import license.

For the background, the  Communiqué 2014/9, adopted in December 2013, included the three different import regimes  and added 36 products to the list 1/A (fully liberalised products). 30 of these products were in the List 2 (goods liberalised only if above a minimum price) of the Communiqué 2013/9. This was a positive development. However, the list of fully liberalised products in the Communiqué 2014/9 did not include the products identified by the Commission's letter to the Turkish authorities of 14 March 2011. These products were only partially liberalised in 2012 (if above a minimum price). In addition, one of these products – the retreaded tyres – was not included in any of the liberalisation lists and the current import regime for these products is similar to de facto import ban. The reasons put forward by Turkey with regard to the import ban are based on environmental considerations (increase of waste accumulation because of their life cycle). However, retreaded tyres are type-approved under UNECE Regulations 108/109, and therefore legally accepted for commercialisation under same conditions (including guarantee) as new ones. Turkey is a signatory of those UNECE Regulations, and furthermore allows retreaded tyres on its market, but continues to ban the EU exports

title: Government procurement (Domestic preferences, off-sets)
description:
The legislative framework in the area of public procurement in Turkey, composed of Public Procurement Law No. 4734 (PPL), and the Public Procurement Contracts Law No.4735 and a comprehensive set of secondary and tertiary legislation, includes discriminatory provisions against foreign operators and goods, as it allows for (or requires) preferential treatment of domestic bidders and domestic goods and off-sets. Moreover, it provides for a set of quantitative thresholds for the procurement value below which foreign bidders may be excluded, but also competitive and transparent provisions do not apply, which therefore may be used as an additional tool for discriminatory treatment. Furthermore, since the enactment of the PPL in 2002, and in particular following the transition to the presidential system in 2018 granting ever increasing legislative powers to the Presidency and directorates and offices established by it, the number of exemptions and exceptions, derogating from the basic principles of public procurement rules, has considerably increased.

Furthermore, Turkey's 12th Development Plan (2024-2028) aims at protecting domestic production against the damages and threats caused by imports by taking the international obligations of the country into account. The plan prioritizes and commits to supporting localization in selected sectors (e.g., chemicals, pharmaceuticals, medical devices, machinery, electronics, electrical equipment, rail systems, automotive) and to expanding the scope of savings-oriented central public procurement policies.

 Article 63 of the PPL provides for four different forms of domestic preferences:

 - Foreign bidders may be excluded from procurement procedures below certain thresholds (financial thresholds are provided in Article 8 of the PPL).

 - Price advantage of maximum 15% (preference margin) may be granted in favour of domestic bidders in services and works procedures regardless of the value of contract.

 - Price advantage of maximum 15% may be granted in favour of domestic goods offered by bidders in procurement of goods (supply). This may apply to both domestic and foreign bidders. There are also certain cases where the application of 15% price advantage for domestic goods becomes mandatory (medium and high technology products identified by the Ministry of Industry and Technology and for domestic software products).

 - Use of domestic products such as materials, equipment and machinery in construction works or all or a certain part of the software may be requested. Moreover, use of domestic medium low, medium high and high technology material, machinery and equipment to be listed by the relevant ministries is obligatory for the works procurements.

 The first two types of preferences are related to the origin (seat) of an economic operator (bidder), the others concern origin of goods offered or used for the purposes of execution of public procurement.

 Turkey has also created a special mechanism in public procurement, so-called Industry Cooperation Programme similar to off-set practices, used in particular in the transportation, energy and health sectors. According to this mechanism, foreign companies awarded procurement contracts containing innovation, technology transfer and localisation are obliged to co-operate with Turkish companies in a joint production and investment activity and/or have to purchase from the Turkish companies in the domestic market. There is no legal limit determining a degree of such joint production/investment/import. The procuring public authority can determine such a percentage depending on the sector.

title: Resource Utilization Support Fund
description:
The Resource Utilization Support Fund (RUSF or KKDF in Turkish) was established as an extra-budgetary fund in 1988 with the apparent aim of discouraging debt. It is levied on many credit transactions including those linked to imports. It was abolished – in as far as import credit was concerned – in January 1996 coinciding with the entry into force of Decision 1/95 and reintroduced later that same year.

As a result, a charge of 6% is applicable on certain importations depending on the terms of payment agreed. A number of exemptions particularly apply as of 2015. In particular certain imports   which are exempt from customs duties and VAT such as  those under inward processing i.e intermediate products used in manufacturing are exempt from the KKDF charge. Unlike the KKDF charges on other financial transactions (credits in general), the KKDF at importation is collected on the value of imports when the customs duty liability arises (registration of the customs declaration). No KKDF charge applies to exports with term payments.

title: Conformity assessments (test reports and TAREKS inspections)
description:
TAREKS is an electronic risk-based import control system in place since 2011. Importers need to register on the TAREKS system and carry out their applications via this system. The system generates a risk analysis and determines if the product requires a conformity check.

EU products and third countries products entering Türkiye via the EU are exempted from conformity assessment checks if they are processed through TAREKS. Normally, products in free circulation in the EU with a A.TR. certificate should have direct access to the Turkish market except where checks are justified on the basis of a risk analysis.

However, EU companies have experienced excessive requests for documentation and submission of test results when importing into Türkiye. In some cases, Türkiye has required that testing is carried out by the Turkish laboratories refusing to accept test results from accredited EU laboratories. The sectors particularly affected in 2023 were construction equipment and machinery although there were similar problems reported in the area of toys, footwear, electrical equipment and lighting products in previous years.

 The checks are usually initiated upon the inaccuracies or missing information regarding the Declaration of Conformity document and do not appear to be justified on a detected risk level regarding product safety.

title: Import regime regarding the agricultural component of sweetcorn
description: In 2016 Turkey increased the agricultural component (EA) applied to imports of sweetcorn products from the EU from 2.91 Euro/100 Kg/net to 23.32 Euro/100 Kg/net.

title: Uganda National Bureau of Standards (Enforcement of Compulsory Standard Specifications) Regulations, 2016
description:
Uganda National Bureau of Standards (UNBS) has developed a safety and quality program for products sold in the domestic market.

Concerns about the impact the proposed regulations will have on the regulated community without measurably enhancing safety.

title: Import of pet food
description: Restrictions applied regarding materials derived from ruminant animals in pet food exported from EU to Ukraine.

title: Ban on imports of pigs and pork products from several EU Member States due to African Swine Fever
description:
Ukraine imposed temporary bans on imports of domestic and wild pigs and their products, including pork meat from several EU Member States: Latvia, Hungary, Slovakia, Bulgaria, Germany, Estonia and Romania due to outbreaks of African Swine Fever (ASF).

The country-wide bans are considered by the EU not to be in line with the WTO rules,  with the OIE standards, as well as with article 65 of the EU-Ukraine Association Agreement.

title: Amendments to the Public Procurement Law introducing LCR
description:
There are currently two draft proposals requiring local content in Ukrainian tenders. Both proposals would breach the equal treatment and the non-discrimination principles in the public procurement chapter of the EU-Ukraine Association Agreement and in the WTO Agreement on Government Procurement (to which Ukraine is a party).

 The draft measures at stake are the following:

 - The first measure is a draft government decree (draft Resolution of the Cabinet of Ministers of Ukraine: 'Certain Issues of Implementing a Pilot Project on Procurement of Machinery in the Field of Mechanical Engineering with a Confirmed Degree of Production Localization'). It intends to introduce local content requirements for machinery products. It is in form of a pilot project and would last for 1 year.

 - The second measure would amend the Law on public procurement (draft law 3937). It would introduce a 40-50-60% local content requirement in a wider range of sectors, such as vehicles, turbines or railways for a 10 years’ time-frame. These amendments would de facto ban EU products in those sectors in Ukraine.

 The measures were adopted in first reading in June 2020 and are awaiting adoption in second reading. For the time being (as of January 2021), they are being discussed in the relevant parliamentary committee.

title: Export ban of wood
description:
Ukrainian Law No. 325 of 9 July 2015 which was signed by Ukrainian President Poroshenko establishes a moratorium on exports of raw round wood (excluding pine) for 10 years as of 1 November 2015, a moratorium on exports of pine raw round wood for 10 years as of 1 January 2017 as well as certification obligations for wood species not covered by the moratoria.

title: Restrictive patentability criteria of medical products
description:
Art 7(7) of the Patent Law 816-IX of Ukraine, adopted in 2020, excludes new forms of known medical products from patentability. New forms of medication would be defined as forming part of the state of the art pursuant to Art. 7(7),'if they do not differ significantly in their properties in terms of efficiency'.

This means that any incremental invention resulting in a compound having desirable and useful properties (in that it e.g. is cheaper to produce, has a longer shelf life, is easier to store, transport or to administer, or causes fewer or less severe side effects but without significantly enhancing the therapeutic effect of the medicinal product) would not qualify for patent protection, as it would be deemed to form part of the state of the art.

According to the WTO TRIPS Agreement, to bring valuable new medicines to patients, biopharmaceutical innovators must be able to secure patents on all inventions that are new, involve an inventive step and be capable of industrial application (these are the 3 patentability criteria laid down in Art 27(3) of the TRIPS Agreement).

title: Trade restrictions due to non-recognition of EUs regionalisation measures for avian influenza outbreaks
description:
A country-wide ban of exports of live poultry is imposed by the United Arab Emirates on any EU Member State upon notification of an outbreak of Highly Pathogenic Avian Influenza (HPAI) in birds, despite that strict EU control measures are imposed on the affected area in line with international standards.  This harmonised EU policy of regionalisation is strictly implemented in the whole EU whenever an outbreak of HPAI occurs and it guarantees that trade can continue of safe poultry and products originating from the areas/products free of HPAI. Detailed information on the control measures (regionalisation) implemented in the EU is shared with trading partners immediately when outbreaks occur. Therefore, the EU considers that a country-wide ban is not in line with international rules (WTO SPS Agreement and OIE international standards) as it is considered more trade restrictive than necessary.

However, the EU welcomes that the Competent Authorities of the United Arab Emirates recognise the regionalisation policy of the EU for HPAI with allowing imports of most poultry products (such as meat) to continue as the United Arab Emirates limit its trade restrictions to those areas affected with HPAI and which are put under control by the competent authority of the exporting country.

The international standard of the OIE clearly states that a free status of the country, zone, compartment, can be regained three months after a stamping-out policy has applied. The EU policy applies a strict stamping-out policy in accordance with international rules of the OIE and informs the OIE and trading partners accordingly. It is regrettable that the United Arab Emirates often lifts its trade restrictions later than this three-month period which is thus considered as an unnecessary barrier to trade.

UAE lifted bans on poultry from Germany and Czech Republic - this was done on 6 July 2020 and 28 June respectively.  The ban was in place for a period of about 4 months.

title: Different registration systems for cosmetics within the UAE
description:
In spite of a centralised registration in the UAE (via the Emirates Authority for Standardization and Metrology (ESMA)) the municipalities in different Emirates are still asking for separate registrations.

In addition, in the UAE the registration validity is of 1 year only currently (very burdensome for companies to re-do every year) whereas there is no validity timeline in the EU.

title: Sponsorship Scheme
description: In 2022 the UK reformed its point-based Sponsorship Scheme, which requires third-country nationals to be “sponsored” by a UK-based entity to work in the UK on a temporary basis. The Scheme designates five Global Business Mobility routes for temporary workers entering the UK, some of which correspond to service suppliers that are also covered in the EU-UK Trade and Cooperation Agreement

title: US Customs Administration’s misclassification of multilayer parquet
description:
The barrier revolves around an unilateral classification by US customs of multilayers parquets which is contested by the industry since 2001. As an effect, the classification imposed by US customs applies a higher duties rates (8% instead of 5%). Duties rates have been irregularly and randomly applied by US Customs to some companies since then.

EU producers reported that EU products are being considered under plywood code 4412.94.3105 and were charged 8% duties instead of being considered under HS 4418.75.7000 and imposed 5% duties. After several developments, the barrier disappeared in July 2020 but was reopened in February 2021. It disappeared again before resurfacing in 2024. It seems that US customs are sporadically applying misclassification on these products.

In mid-2024 one EU parquet business (the biggest in the EU) reports the barrier is still active for 3 multilayer parquet which does not qualify for the HS classification under 4418 75 70 with 5% of FOB value and the US Customs Administration classifies their products under 4412 94 31 05 with 8% import duty.

title: Procurement: Buy American
description:
Overview

“Buy American” and “Buy America” (referred to collectively as “Buy America(n)”) are domestic content requirements for public procurement applied in the United States. Their purpose is to boost domestic production. The US adopted such requirements as early as 1933, during the Depression and has expanded them in the recent years.

Despite these requirements, EU suppliers can access certain parts of the US procurement market, either because the US do not apply these requirements to some procurement covered by the WTO Agreement on Government Procurement ("GPA"), or because it sometimes waives their application to other types of procurement (not covered by the GPA), or for the practical reason that an EU company has invested in production in the United States and supplies from its U.S. base.

The following fiche explains the conditions under which EU suppliers have access to the US procurement markets, the applicable rules, limitations, as well as the recent developments tightening the Buy America(n) conditions and their impact on the EU suppliers.

 1. The US public procurement commitments towards the EU

The GPA is the only instrument in which the United States has taken binding commitments regarding the access of EU operators, suppliers and services to the US procurement market. The US commitments cover federal entities (departments and agencies) and 37 out of the 50 US Federal States.

However, these commitments are subject to certain exceptions. One of the most substantial exceptions allows the United States to apply Buy America(n) requirements in procurement linked to federal funding in specific areas such as aviation and mass transit and highway projects. Another substantial exception allows federal agencies to set-aside Federal procurement for US small- or minority-owned business. The US uses this flexibility, as its domestic law requires federal agencies to set aside for small US-based business all contracts above the “US Simplified Acquisition Threshold”. As of January 2018, this threshold was increased from US$150K to US$250K. Therefore, contracts under US$250K are now automatically set aside for small businesses and foreign companies, including EU companies, cannot bid for them unless they establish, pay taxes and employ staff in the US.

Moreover, the US has excluded from the scope of its GPA commitments some services sectors and therefore Buy American requirements can fully apply to them. This is the case, in particular, of "dredging services". This is to allow for the application of the "Jones Act" (see below), which reserves domestic maritime services to US-built, US-owned and US–crewed ships (even if the US occasionally grants individual waivers from the Jones Act requirements).

In addition, the US excluded from the scope of its GPA commitments some procurement by the Department of Defence. 

2. The US Federal Government level procurement rules (including rules applicable to the State level)

A. The Buy American and Buy America restrictions

The US has over time adopted a number of Buy America(n) restrictions, with the major ones being the following:

In the shipbuilding industry, the Jones Act[1] (1920) requires goods shipped between U.S. ports to be transported on ships that are built, owned, and operated by United States citizens or permanent residents.

The 1933 Buy American Act, introduced during the Depression to boost domestic activity and create jobs, imposed US content requirements to federal procurement of goods (i.e. purchases by federal agencies and departments).

In the defence area, the so called "Berry Amendment"[2] (dating back to 1941) established that the US Department of Defence can only procure US-products (including "non-war" material, such as textiles).

The 1978 Buy America Act introduces a group of local content requirements  for infrastructure projects that receive federal funding by the US Department of Transportation (Federal Highway Administration, Federal Transit Administration, Federal Railroad Administration and Federal Aviation Administration) and some other federal entities [3]. The act requires the use of domestically produced iron, steel and some other manufactured products in such projects, and was adopted as a complement to the Buy American Act (which did not cover most transit projects, including metros and highways) as they were carried out by States or other sub-federal entities). The 1978 Buy America Act creates one of the most important obstacles for access to US procurement.

Buy-America-type of provisions have become a regular feature of bills for Federal funding to States, municipalities or transit authorities and have extended beyond transportation (see for example, regarding environmental projects, the 2014 Water Resources Reform and Development Act, which imposed local content requirements on projects funded by the Environmental Protection Agency's Clean Water infrastructure fund).

For interaction of these domestic rules with the US’ GPA commitments please see part 3.

B. The “Made in America” Executive Order[4]

On 25 January 2021, President Biden signed the Executive Order on Ensuring the Future Is Made in All of America by All of America’s Workers (the “Made in America” order). This order directed agencies to strengthen the application of existing Buy American requirements, including by limiting waivers. Moreover, it created the “Made in America Office” (the “MIAO”) as part of the Office of Management and Budget of the White House (the “OMB”), tasked to oversee the implementation of Buy America(n) policies and to increase transparency of the waiver processes.

To implement the “Made in America” order, on 4 March 2022 the Federal Acquisition Council issued new rules updating and supplementing the 1933 Buy American Act, including:

  • an increases of US content requirement for goods from 55%  to 60% as of 25 October 2022, 65% as of 2024, and 75% as of 2029.
  • a framework for price preferences for selected critical products, or products containing critical components (the list of products and price preferences still needs to be established)

C. The Infrastructure Investment and Jobs Act [5] of 2021

The US Infrastructure Investment and Jobs Act (“IIJA”) was adopted on 15 November 2021 and authorised $1 trillion in spending on a broad range of infrastructure projects. As part of the IIJA, the US also adopted the “Build America, Buy America Act” (“BABAA”), which extended the application of local content requirements to all federally funded infrastructure projects (so-called ‘flow down funding’). As a result, infrastructure projects cannot benefit from federal funding unless all the steel, iron, construction materials  and manufactured products used in the project are produced in the US. 

These rules were recently further implemented by a revision of the OMB Guidance for Grants and Agreements part of the Federal Code of Regulation[6] (the “Guidance”). In effect as of 23 October 2023, the Guidance serves to ensure consistent application of the Buy America preference across funding federal agencies and provides definitions and manufacturing standards for what is considered a construction material, i.e. non-ferrous metals, plastics, polymer-based products, glass, fibre optic cable, lumber, engineered wood and drywall.

In addition, the OMB has issued a revised Memorandum M-24-02 (the “Memorandum”) providing further information to federal agencies complementing the Guidance. It rescinds and replaces an earlier provisional guidance (M-22-11), including on waivers for Buy America requirements. The revised Memorandum contains rules on (1) the application of Buy America requirements for infrastructure projects and (2) the process for waivers, providing important clarifications how the rules will be applied vis-à-vis US’ international commitments and foreign suppliers (see part 3).

Further information about the exemptions from these new requirements applied by the federal departments and agencies is accessible on the Made in America website.  

C. US State level procurement

The GPA commitments regarding the 37 US States covered  apply to certain entities of the State Government, but not to cities. Furthermore, there US excluded some products in the case of some States (e.g. it excluded the procurement of vehicles by the States of Delaware, Florida, Illinois, Iowa, Maine, Maryland, Michigan, New York, New Hampshire, Oklahoma, Pennsylvania and  Wyoming).

Besides, the States' legal framework in procurement is very fragmented, which causes de facto barriers. Each of the US States has their own laws and they impose new and additional Buy America(n) requirements giving favourable treatment to products which have been manufactured in the US. In particular, 27 States impose obligations within state-law to give favourable treatment to "American made products". Furthermore, some States impose obligations to favour US manufactured products when local entities use State-funds.

In addition, many States also impose preferences which give favourable treatment to products manufactured within a specific State. On top of State-law based preferences, additional requirements are applied for example by many US cities.

Finally, many US States apply specific set-asides for US SMEs established within their respective State.

3. Interaction between Buy America(n) requirements and the US international obligations, both at US Federal Level and at US State level

To implement the commitments in the GPA and other trade agreements, the US adopted the Trade Agreements Act of 1979[7]. This Act authorised the President to introduce “waivers” regarding government procurement. For procurement at federal level covered by the US obligations under the GPA and other trade agreements (“FTAs”), the Office of US Trade Representative (“USTR”) has formally “waived” the Buy American requirements in a general manner[8]. This means that, for the covered procurement at federal level, bids of eligible foreign products, which include those produced in the EU, should receive equal consideration with domestic products. 

In contrast, the US has not waived Buy America requirements in a general manner for GPA covered procurement at State level.

Specific to the federally funded infrastructure projects and the recent Buy America requirements of the BABAA, the US explains extensively the interaction with international obligations and the use of waivers in Memorandum M-24-02. Among others, the Memorandum stipulates that ”[i]f a recipient is a State that has assumed procurement obligations pursuant to the Government Procurement Agreement or any other trade agreement, a waiver of a Made in America condition to ensure compliance with such obligations may be in the public interest.” [emphasis added]. In addition, the Memorandum does not contain instructive language to State level entities to issue general applicability waivers for compliance with international obligations nor provides automaticity of the individual waivers.

Apart from the case of procurement covered by the US GPA/FTAs obligations, Federal procurement regulations provide five other government-wide exceptions from the “Buy American” requirements:

  • if a domestic end-product is not reasonably available in sufficient quantities of a satisfactory quality;
  • if the cost of a domestic end-product would be unreasonable;  
  • if the purchase of a domestic end-product would be contrary to the public interest;  
  • in the case of purchase of commercial information technology; and
  • in case of purchase for commissary resale.

4. Lack of transparency

The US does not have a single electronic portal for public procurement notices/summaries. In addition, in many States, to receive information on contracts and in order to bid, companies first have to register with the State. For this each State applies its own requirements. Some States require a payment to register as a bidder. Registration requirements act as further market access obstacles.

The lack of easy access to information on procurement opportunities in the US States is a key deterrent to participate in US procurement. EU businesses can bid for contracts only if they are able to find information on them. EU companies need to navigate through hundreds of different procurement portals and suffer from various obstacles to register as bidders.

Furthermore, in relation to the IIJA and Memorandum M-24-02, the established system of exemption and waivers, which can be granted ad hoc or as general applicability waivers, represents another element of complexity in the US procurement system. Notably, there is no clear guidance to issue waivers for compliance with international obligations and in connection with the general applicability waivers, federal agencies can define additional requirements for specific funding programmes, adding to the patchwork of applicable rules.  

[1] 46 U.S.C § 55102. The Jones Act is Section 27 of the Merchant Marine Act of 1920, which provided for the maintenance of the American merchant marine.

[2] The Berry Amendment is implemented through the Defense Federal Acquisition Regulation Supplement (DFARS) at 225.7002. It was originally passed by Congress in 1941 to promote the purchase of certain U.S. goods.

[4] Executive Order 14005 of January 25, 2021.

[5] PUBLIC LAW 117–58—NOV. 15, 2021.

[6]  Title 2 of the Federal Code of Regulation, part 184 – 2 CFR part 184as.

[7] 19 U.S.C.2501, TRADE AGREEMENTS ACT OF 1979.

[8] Federal Acquisition Regulation (“FAR”), section 25.402 General

title: Restriction/Ban on sturgeon import
description:
Restriction/ban of sturgeon and sturgeon based products based on environmental constraints.

On May 25, 2022, the Fish & Wildlife service issued a draft regulation to classify four new species of sturgeon on the list of endangered species under the ESA.  This is in addition to the process already well underway for Amur Sturgeon (Acipenser schrenckii). The  proposed requalification of the status of the four Ponto-Caspian species (A. gueldenstaedtii, A. persicus, A. nudiventris and A. stellatus) by the US Fish and Wildlife Service (FWS) would automatically lead to a ban on trade in these species (included farmed species) and related products, such as caviar, affecting EU exports of such products. The Fish & Wildlife Service was expected to announce any decisions/further action in September 2022, however the process has been postponed.

title: Import restrictions on bovine animals and products.
description:
Unjustified import restrictions on a number of animals and animal products relating to Bovine Spongiform Encephalopathy (BSE). In 1997, US introduced rules on the import of ruminant animals and products thereof from all European countries based on concerns about Bovine Spongiform Encephalopathy (BSE). US finally aligned import requirements to the OIE standards by drafting a ’BSE comprehensive rule’ in March 2014. 


However, before trade can resume, establishments must be approved and Member States re-instated by FSIS for compliance with hygiene rules.This process is unnecessary lengthy and burdensome and is ongoing for several EU Member States without any clarity provided by the US on when this procedure will be finalised and thus when exports can start to take place.The US has not provided any justification based on science for these undue delays.

title: Slow procedures on applications to allow import plants and plant products.
description:
US legislation requires formal import authorisation and pest risk assessments for all food crops, including edible fruit and vegetables. 

For ornamental plants, import may be allowed without pest risk assessment. However, so called NAPPRA products ('not approved pending pest risk analysis') cannot be imported into USA before the phytosanitary requirements are decided on by the USA plant health authorities and afterwards included in US import legislation.

The US import authorisation procedure may take several years because the USDA / APHIS claims that its capacity to do pest risk assessments is insufficient. For some products the EU has been confronted with procedures lasting more than 25 years before market access can be granted and where there is no technical justification provided by the USA for not allowing access of the products concerned to its market. The EU has many applications pending, several of these are pending for more than a decade without any indication provided by the US on when these dossiers will be finalised and allowed for market access into the US. This is considered not in line with the obligations under the WTO SPS Agreement..

title: EU Food safety systems recognition by the USA
description: The US FDA (Food and Drugs Administration) rules foresee in the possibility to recognise foreign food safety systems as being comparable to that of the US FDA. Work is ongoing between the EU and the USA to mutually recognise their food safety systems as being comparable via Systems Recognition. Once recognised this would further facilitate trade and in particular would reduce the administrative burden, while fully respecting each side's legislation on sanitary and phytosanitary matters.

title: Import restrictions on poultry meat and egg products
description:
The EU has stringent harmonised sanitary measures in place for the production of animals and animal products. This EU system guarantees a high level of food safety and animal health in all EU Member States and also for products exported to trading partners.

The US maintains a lengthy process to allow imports of poultry meat and egg products on its market. The US application procedure is complex and contains multiple steps where several US departments are involved. However, before trade can take place, establishments must be approved and Member States re-instated by FSIS for compliance with hygiene rules. This process is unnecessary lengthy and burdensome with several EU Member States applications are pending for multiple years without having any clarity on when exports can start to take place...

title: Sheep and goat meat market access to the USA
description:
The USA market has been closed to any EU sheep/goat meat since 1998, when USA introduced import restrictions on meat of ruminants on the basis of Transmissible Spongiform Encephalopathy (TSE) concerns. In 2016, finally, the US published a proposed (draft) TSE rule to bring its legislation in line with the international standards (WOAH). In addition, once this new rule would allow for imports as regards animal health requirements, a lengthy application process is imposed on each interested EU Member State that wants to bring sheep/goat meat to the US market, to show compliance with food safety requirements. The EU continues to work with the USA to find a solution on this matter . 

On 2 December 2021, finally the US published its final rule amending the import conditions for sheep and goat and their products to bring it in line with international standards: https://www.aphis.usda.gov/aphis/newsroom/news/sa_by_date/sa-2021/ruminants-import-regulations .

This publication is a welcome step as it allows for the US to finalise the long overue approval procedures pending of several EU Member States so that trade could start. 
 
Following the publication of this US final rule, on 3 January 2022, Ireland has been listed by the USA and being considered for having equivalent  controls to the US regulatory systems and being thus eligible to export raw sheep products.
 
On 24 April 2022, Ireland agreed with the US on a bilateral veterinary health certificate for exports of sheep meat to the US. Shipments can take place once Irish establishments are being listed on the USDA website for being approved by the US to export sheep meat.  
 
This barrier is herewith partially resolved as several other EU Member States have still applications for sheep/goat meat to the US pending since many years. As these EU Member States implement the EU harmonised legislation on food safety and animal health and thus guarantee the same high level of safety, the EU expects the United States to finalise now the applications from other interested Member States in due course.

title: Sanitary measures applied by the USA for imports of live bivalve molluscs.
description:
An equivalence exercise is ongoing between the US (FDA) and the EU on each others food safety systems for the opening of trade of live bivalve molluscs.  For this excercise pilot EU Member States and pilot Federal States of the US are involved. The two different food safety approaches of the EU and the USA achieve the same level of protection, and therefore should be regarded as equivalent, within the framework of Article 4 of the WTO/SPS Agreement (Sanitary and Phytosanitary). A formal agreement on 'equivalence' is still pending. A constructive dialogue between the EU and the USA is ongoing aiming at granting market access for the US Federal States and EU Member States concerned. On 9 March 2018, the US published a notice for comments in preparation of the final decision to mutually recognise equivalency of food safety conditions of raw molluscan shellfish products. Web link: https://www.federalregister.gov/documents/2018/03/09/2018-04772/equivalence-determination-regarding-the-european-union-food-safety-control-system-for-raw-bivalve   

Further progress was seen with the publication of the final Federal notice of the US on 24 September 2020: web link: https://www.fda.gov/news-events/press-announcements/fda-achieves-key-milestone-finalizes-framework-will-resume-shellfish-trade-europe-first-time-10

Both sides are in the process of finalising now the last remaining administrative steps before the mutual trade can start.

As from the end of February 2022, trade of molluscan shellfish - such as mussels, clams, oysters and scallops – resumed between the EU and the US. Two EU Member States (Spain and the Netherlands) are allowed to export molluscan shellfish to the US, whilst two American states (Massachusetts and Washington) can do the same to the EU. 

Cooperative work is ongoing to allow for adding additional States  being approved (on both sides).

title: Unjustified trade restrictions due to a non recognition of country freedom and pest free areas of EU Member States for the Citrus and Asian longhorned beetle
description:
The U.S. Federal Order (FO) classifies the EU as being affected with Asian longhorned beetle (ALB) and the citrus longhorned beetle (CLB) – while these pests are absent in the majority of the EU Member States. In addition, these pests are under official control in the EU as these pests are regulated in the EU. Since 2012, the EU has requested the US to recognise those EU Member State countries being pest free and also to recognise the well-demarcated and regulated pest free areas in the EU,  as this U.S. measure is unnecessarily blocking trade.

Namely, plants with stem and root collar diameter 10 mm or less are not regulated for A. chinensis (ALB) and/or A. glabripennis (CLB) under this FO meaning that under the current FO, the EU cannot ship plants with stem and root collar diameter >10 mm!

On 12 June 2024, the US finally published its long awaited final notice, herewith recognising the country free status of ALB and CLB for 21 EU Member States, which is of great importance.  

In practice it means that now Belgium, Denmark and The Netherlands can export plants for planting with a stem diameter greater than 10 mm, while they were up until now allowed only to export plants with a stem diameter below 10 mm. Namely those countries had several plants genera authorised by the US that fall under this scope of these pests.

The Commission continues to work with the US on its outstanding demand to recognise the country free status for Finland, Austria and the pest Free Area status for the four remaining EU Member States Croatia, France, Germany, and Italy

title: Inflation Reduction Act
description:
The Inflation Reduction Act is a complex “omnibus” law ranging from appropriating federal funding to parts of the US government and making changes to US health system to offering a broad range of subsidies to foster the US transition to a more climate friendly economy. Of particular concern is the fact that it has introduced discriminatory local content provisions in at least 9 subsidy programmes. The intended effect is to support US net-zero technology leadership by incentivising companies to move investments to the US and purchase US products. The broadness of the targeted technologies, and the uncapped and non-transparent nature of the subsidies provided means that the US is aiming to re-shore large parts of the value chains of key net-zero technologies, establishing itself as global technology leader and production hub at the cost of its largest trade and investment partners, including the EU. The effect of this is already visible in public investment announcements.

A strong indirect effect of the Act is that it tilts the level playing field between the EU and US across all industries as they decarbonise. The damage will likely be most pronounced for energy intensive industries, with indications that especially the EU automotive, machinery and chemical sectors will feel the largest effect.

The Act’s discriminatory elements are not only damaging to EU interest, but also appear illegal under international trade rules. The Act seems to breach core WTO principles, namely national treatment and most-favoured nation.

title: Spanish ripe olives
description:
On 1 August 2018, the US imposed anti-subsidy and anti-dumping duties of together between 30% and 44% on imports of Spanish ripe olives. The duties have been in force since then.

We consider those duties to be contrary to certain provisions of the GATT 1994, the Agreement on Subsidies and Countervailing Measures (SCM Agreement) and the Agreement on anti-dumping.

The EU therefore challenged these duties before the WTO (panel established in June 2019). The final panel report in this WTO dispute concerning the anti-subsidy and anti-dumping duties imposed on ripe olives from Spain (DS577) was published on 19 November 2021 and was adopted on 20 December 2021. Overall, the panel ruled in favour of the EU and confirmed the illegality of the anti-subsidy duties.

On 19 January 2022, the US sent a letter to the DSB body announcing its intention to implement the recommendations and rulings of the DSB and that they had begun to evaluate options for doing so.  The US also expressed the need for a RPT to implement the recommendation. On 1 July 2022, the US eventually agreed on a RPT expiring on 14 January 2023.

In mid-July 2022, USTR instructed the Department of Commerce to commence legal process to implement the WTO panel report (DS577), i.e. the Section 129 procedure. 

On 20 December 2022 the US Department of Commerce adopted its final determination in the Section 129 proceedings which confirmed the preliminary conclusions reached in preliminary determination.

At the Dispute Settlement Body meeting on 27 January 2023 the US confirmed that they considered implementation of the panel recommendations completed. The EU expressly disagreed with the conclusions of the US and reserved its right to take further legal steps.

 On 28 April 2023, the EU requested consultations with the United States (US) on the measures adopted by the US Department of Commerce to implement the findings and recommendations of the WTO panel report in the Olives dispute (DS577) adopted in December 2021. The request for consultations focused on the implementation of one of the three panel findings, namely the inconsistency with WTO rules of the US legislation on the pass-through of benefit received from producers to transformers of agricultural products (Section 771B of the US Tariff Act of 1930).

 The consultations took place in Geneva on 24 May 2023 and failed to resolve the dispute.

On 14 July 2023, the EU notified the US and the WTO the request for the establishment of a compliance panel to rule on the implementation by the US of the pass-through panel finding.
On 31 July 2023, the Panel was composed from the same members having ruled in the initial proceedings and adopted its terms of reference.

On 20 February 2024, the DSB circulated the final report of the compliance panel, which concluded that the United States had failed to implement the relevant aspects of the adopted DSB recommendations and rulings that Section 771B is "as such" and “as applied” inconsistent with Article VI:3 of the GATT 1994 and Article 10 of the SCM Agreement. The final compliance report was adopted on 19 March 2024.

The EU is now preparing internally for the next steps to make sure that the rights of the olives producers are restored.

title: USA import restrictions on apples and pears
description: The EU has an application pending for market access to the USA of apples and pears from several EU Member States under the so-called system approach, instead of the current overly-costly preclearance approach.
