The process was initiated already in 2008 and despite the finalisation of the main scientific work already end 2014, the USA has still not finalised its procedure. The publication of the final notice is the only missing element to allow safe trade to start, but this publication has been unnecessarily delayed without any scientific reason being provided. The publication was planned by the US already to take place in 2016 but has been further postponed without the US providing any indication on when the publication of the final notice will be issued .

title: Section 232 tariffs on steel and aluminum imports
description:
On 8 March 2018, President Trump signed two Proclamations to impose additional duties of 10% and 25% respectively on certain imports of aluminium and steel products into the United States. These measures took effect on 23 March 2018. They follow investigations carried out by the US Department of Commerce, which concluded that imports of these products threatened US national security and recommended action to restrict imports (the so-called Section 232 investigations). The EU was temporarily exempted until 1 May, later prolonged to 31 May, with additional duties applied to imports from the EU on 1 June 2018. All other US trading partners are affected by Section 232 measures, with a few exceptions.

On 24 January 2020, the US adopted a new set of measures in the form of a tariff increase on imports of certain derivative aluminium products and certain derivative steel products, effective from 8 February 2020 and with an unlimited duration. These measures are an adjustment of the earlier US measures under Section 232 concerning steel and aluminium products.

On 31 October 2021, the EU and the US agreed (Link: https://ec.europa.eu/commission/presscorner/api/files/document/print/en/ip_21_5724/IP_21_5724_EN.pdf) to strengthen their partnership and address shared challenges in the steel and aluminium sector, and agreed to pause the WTO disputes they have initiated against each other regarding the US Section 232 measures (DS548) and the EU’s additional duties (DS559). As a part of that partnership, both parties intend to negotiate for the first time, a global arrangement on sustainable steel and aluminium to address carbon intensity and global overcapacity.

In line with its announcement of 31 December 2021 (LINK), the US decided to remove the Section 232 tariffs on steel and aluminium on EU imports up to a level in line with historical levels of trade and to replace them with a tariff rate quota (TRQ). This decision was implemented as of 1 January 2022. In parallel, the US fully removed its Section 232 duties on imports of EU derivative articles. The EU on its side, suspended temporarily as from 1 January 2022 the additional duties it imposed on US goods in response to the Section 232 actions (LINK). The relevant US implementing regulations establishing the US 232 TRQs on EU steel and aluminium products can be consulted here:

  • https://www.federalregister.gov/documents/2022/01/03/2021-28514/adjusting-imports-of-aluminum-into-the-united-states 
  • https://www.federalregister.gov/documents/2022/01/03/2021-28516/adjusting-imports-of-steel-into-the-united-states

On 19 December 2023, the EU prolonged the suspension of its duties on US products until 31 March 2025 (Link: https://ec.europa.eu/commission/presscorner/detail/en/ip_23_6713). Subsequently, the US prolonged the TRQs on EU products until 31 December 2025: 

-  A Proclamation on Adjusting Imports of Steel Into the United States | The White House; 

- A Proclamation on Adjusting Imports of Aluminum Into the United States | The White House

title: IPR: inadequate protection of GIs
description: Difficulties to protect intellectual property rights and prevent the continuing use of EU geographical indications on food and drinks produced or sold in the U.S., especially in the food (such as cheese and meat products) sector are a source of considerable frustration for EU producers. In addition, the fact that the U.S. still considers a number of important European wine names as 'semi-generics' remains problematic, despite progress achieved under the 2006 Wine Agreement. While no new wine labels using 'semi-generics' are approved, U.S. producers making use of 'grandfathered' 'semi- generics' can still take advantage of, or could damage, the reputation of the geographical indication in question.

title: US-citizenship requirement for drone delivery services
description: European companies are not allowed to deliver commercial services when providing drone delivery services. They are required to have the approval from the US Department of Transport (DOT). However, the relevant statute (49 USC 41703) establishes a US-citizenship requirement to grant a license for drone transportation for commercial purposes, which is considered a commercial cargo aircraft operation under US law.

title: Aviation: ownership restrictions
description:
US Code 40102 establishes that 75% of the voting rights in a US carrier must be owned by persons who are citizens of the United States.

The second stage Protocol to the EU-US Air Transport Agreement was signed on 24 June 2010 and incentivises a change in US law in order to enable EU investors to take full ownership and control of the other’s airlines. However, this has not resulted in any change so far.

title: Rules for import of dairy products into the USA
description:
Grade A milk products (pasteurised, liquid products such as cream or yogurt) must come from establishments approved and listed by the Inter State Conference of Milk Shipments (IMS). There is no generic definition of Grade A products. The Insterstate Conference can always add products to the list of Grade A and then automatically the Pasteurized Milk Ordinance applies to these products.

An equivalency exercise is ongoing since 2006 in collaboration with three pilot Member States, FR, IRL and the NL. After a paper evaluation, confirmatory audits were done by FDA in the three Member States in spring 2015.

FDA has not yet come to a decision.

title: US Tax Cut and Jobs Act
description:
President Trump signed on 22 December 2017 a major revision of the US tax system with the "Tax Cuts and Jobs Act" (TCJA). In addition to lowering the corporate tax rate from 35% to 21%, the TCJA substantially changed the manner in which the United States taxes international income. Proposed regulations implementing these changes were issued on 10 October 2018, 21 December 2018 and 6 March 2019.

A specific fiscal incentive, the foreign-derived intangible income (FDII) tax deduction, bestows a fiscal incentive to exports. Specifically, a special tax deduction is linked to US exports of many goods and services, and the amount of the benefit depends on export performance. Given its design and effect, this tax deduction is a measure that would most likely qualify as a prohibited export subsidy under the WTO Agreement on Subsidies and Countervailing Measures. It is estimated that this new export subsidy grants a significant financial benefit to US corporations.

Secondly, the US introduced an additional corporate tax, called the base-erosion anti-abuse tax (BEAT), which taxes royalties, intra-firm transfers, payments for machinery used in the US, insurance premiums, or payments in any way reducing the gross income of the US-based part of the firm.It is believed that this provision is not WTO-conform as it discriminates against imported goods or services. The inclusion of insurance premiums specifically targets European insurance companies. The latest US tax data released by the US government indicates that this additional tax is around $3.5 billion annually. Large insurance and financial companies might be incentivised to transfer assets into the US to reduce the BEAT, negatively affecting the efficiency of their operations. Smaller EU financial sector companies might even abandon the US market altogether.

In addition, the US federal revenue code contains the Interest Charge Domestic International Sales Corporation (IC-DISC) rules, which were enacted by the Deficit Reduction Act of 1984 and is a remnant from the Domestic International Sales Corporation (DISC) rules, which the EU successfully challenged in the GATT. They offer a tax benefit for exports of goods if done through a special-purpose corporation. The main tax benefit is that a portion of export income avoids corporate tax and is taxable to individual shareholders at the lower rates applicable to dividend income. It is estimated that this old export subsidy grants a significant financial benefit to US corporations.

title: Maritime: Cabotage restrictions
description:
The Merchant Marine Act of 1920 has been a fixture of U.S. law and an imposition on the U.S. economy for almost 100 years. Better known as the “Jones Act,” the law was presented as a plan to ensure adequate domestic shipbuilding capacity and a ready supply of merchant mariners to be available in times of war or other national emergencies.1 The law aims to achieve those objectives by restricting domestic shipping services to vessels that are U.S.-built, U.S.-owned, U.S.-flagged, and U.S.-staffed. These provisions extend beyond basic cabotage, for example, also restricting the provision of dredging services in a similar manner.

As a result of these restrictions, the U.S. economy endures artificially inflated shipping costs because the transport of cargo between U.S. ports and within the country’s vast inland waterways is off‐​limits to foreign competition and domestic shipping firms must pay vastly higher prices for the ships they use.  It has proved particularly disastrous for Hawaii and Puerto Rico.  However, it is claimed that the Jones Act creates and preserves jobs for Americans and therefore enjoys widespread and bipartisan support (even though the evidence supporting these claims is lacking), including from the Biden administration.  The claim that the Jones Act is necessary to protect the national security is also widely accepted despite compelling evidence it has harmed the nation’s security interests. Moreover, whilst the economic benefits of the Jones Act are concentrated, the costs are diffuse. This explains why the several attempts made over a century to render such rules less restrictive have all failed.

While cabotage restrictions on maritime transportation between ports of the same country is common everywhere in the world (and to a certain extent also in the EU), what makes the US legislation peculiar and unduly restrictive, is the fact that domestic transportation - even when carried out by US operators - can only be performed using vessels which are US built, US owned/controlled, US crewed and US maintained. These requirements add to the effects of traditional cabotage measures important limitations in terms of shipbuilding (because no foreign built ship can be used), establishment (because only companies owned and controlled by Americans can carry out coastal trade services) and repair services (because vessels repaired/reconverted outside the US risk losing the necessary qualifications to operate again within US waters).

The President has the authority to waive the Jones Act restrictions. Waivers “from navigation and vessel inspection laws”, allowing the recourse to non-US flagged vessels when there is no US-flagged capacity, are possible “in the national  interest”, although limited in practise. However, this power has been used only sparingly and for short periods in the past, for example, for less than two weeks after Puerto Rico was hit by a devastating hurricane in 2017. Highly specialised waiver programs also exist (e.g. for the installation of jacket platforms (offshore platforms) ), but even these limited waivers come under attack by Jones Act proponents. 

Congress included in the 2021 National Defence Authorization Act (NDAA) an amendment that clarifies that Jones Act restrictions extend all the way to the Outer Continental Shelf and apply to non-mineral energy resources, including offshore wind installations. Known as the  ‘Garamendi amendment’ (named for a Congressman who is a staunch supporter of the act), this provision will adversely affect offshore wind projects by substantially limiting the Executive’s ability to grant Jones Act waivers for offshore energy projects that have been fairly routinely granted in the past. This understanding has been confirmed in a first ruling by the CBP (27 January 2021) related to this topic: https://rulings.cbp.gov/search?term=H309186&collection=ALL&sortBy=RELEVANCE&pageSize=30&page=1. Another amendment to the NDAA 2021 affects the waivers introduced at the request of the Secretary of Defense, by specifying that such waivers should be deemed “necessary in the interest of national defense to address an immediate adverse effect on military operations” instead of “only” “in the interest of national defense”.  At least one expert has concluded that the vast majority of administrative waivers issued over the last 20 years would not have met this new standard.  Finally, an additional amendment to the NDAA 2021 provides that the aggregate duration of “waivers” is limited to 45 days. It also appears that public reporting will be required on any foreign vessel using such a waiver to operate in US domestic commerce. European providers have found some success participating in wind farm installations, either by transiting products from ports in Canada or by working with US partners who move products from the US port to the off-shore installation site.  In both cases, European installation companies have been utilizing US labour. 

CBP Ruling HQ H309186, the first one regarding offshore wind since the Garamendi Amendment's passing, came in late January 2021. The agency addressed the Jones Act's application under the new Amendment, specifically how it applied to the transportation of construction materials. CBP strictly interpreted the Amendment's language, finding that construction materials loaded in a U.S. port and destined for an offshore point in the U.S. exclusive economic zone (EEZ) on a non-coastwise qualified vessel (even if the project was just beginning and there was no physical installation yet) would violate the Jones Act. The parties requesting the rulings, involved in the construction of the Vineyard Wind Project, wanted to use a Netherlands-flagged vessel or a foreign-flagged barge to transport and install scour materials. CBP concluded that the only way that this would be legal was if the scour material was loaded in a Canadian port and not a U.S. port. This ruling was a departure from CBP's previous stance.  On Mar. 25, 2021, CBP issued HQ H317289, which significantly modified its previous position. This clarification, more in line with prior CBP rulings, states that the pristine seabed does not fall under the Jones Act's scope, and establishes a new precedent for America's offshore wind development. 

In February 2021, when Maersk Supply Services wanted permission to use a foreign jack-up vessel for the installation of materials, CPB ruled that such use was permissible so long as the vessel was used as a crane (remaining stationary) and did not transport people or materials between coastwise points. This is consistent with prior rulings.  

Most recently, Congress introduced in February 2022 the “American Offshore Workers Fairness Act” (AOWFA) in both House (H.R. 6728) and Senate (S.3705). The bill proposes to amend the Outer Continental Shelf Lands Act to require that all mariners on foreign-flagged vessels be either U.S. citizens, green card holders, or citizens of the nation of the flag state of the vessel. This workforce does not yet exist in the US, and will take years of apprenticeship to develop. European companies have pledged to support US offshore wind workforce development, and the US offshore industry has asked Congress to focus on such training, rather than on well-intentioned but detrimental restrictions. If implemented, AOWFA would make it very difficult (if not impossible) for specialized foreign-flagged offshore vessels to continue their operations in the US, potentially closing the domestic offshore market (wind as well as oil & gas). This would ultimately cripple US offshore energy development – especially offshore wind – without yielding any security benefits or economic advantage to the US. 

Note: The House adopted its bill on 29 March as part of the Coast Guard Authorization Act of 2022 (H.R. 6865) and the CGAA was itself adopted by House on 14 July 2022 as part of the National Defense Authorziation Act of 2023. The Senate version of the CGAA has not yet been published.

title: Foreign Account Tax Compliance Act (FACTA)
description:
The US Foreign Account Tax Compliance Act (FATCA), enacted in March 2010, is designed to increase the ability of the US tax authorities to combat cross-border tax evasion by US persons who use foreign financial institutions (FFIs) to hide assets and avoid reporting income taxable in the US. FATCA tries to achieve this objective by imposing obligations on the FFIs to carry out due-diligence, reporting and withholding tasks on behalf of the US tax authorities. FFIs are defined to include not just banks but also funds, insurance companies, securitisation vehicles and many other entities. 

While FATCA’s aim is a legitimate one which the EU and many other countries support, it has caused serious concern to financial intermediaries because of the legal problems and administrative burdens that it creates.

In recognition of the many legal difficulties that FFIs faced in reporting directly to the US under FATCA, the US concluding FATCA agreements with 113 countries (including all 27 EU Member States) under which the financial institutions will report to the tax authorities of their own countries instead of directly to the US and will not be required to withhold US tax (except in few specific cases).The tax authorities of those countries will then report the information to the US tax authorities.

While these FATCA agreements may eliminate all or most of the legal difficulties for financial institutions, potentially they will not remove all the difficulties for EU financial institutions to invest in the US market or market their products to US clients since i.a. to do so will now carry reporting obligations.  As a practical matter, some EU FFIs have denied banking services to EU citizens with any indicia of US citizenship, such as “accidental Americans,” so as to avoid any reporting obligation.

Furthermore, FATCA is enforced unequally, and US financial institutions do not live up to their obligations under the IGAs.  They do not have the same level of due diligence, reporting and withholding obligations in relation to US citizens and they are not required to report on anything other than interest payments and US source dividends paid to non-US citizens.

title: Anti-dumping measures: practice of zeroing
description: Zeroing is a calculation methodology used by the United States (US) for increasing, often substantially, the exporter’s margin of dumping and thus the amount of anti-dumping duty paid. Zeroing has two main effects on EU exporters. Firstly, it increases the amount of duty paid on those goods exported to the US, thus reducing their competitiveness. Secondly, by increasing the rate of anti-dumping duty, it deters many exporters from exporting to the US at all.

title: DS 160 - Section 110(5) of the US Copyright Act (“Irish Music”)
description:
On 27 July 2000, the DSB adopted the Panel report that found Section 110(5)(B) of the US Copyright Act to be incompatible with the TRIPs Agreement, in connection with the Bern Convention on the Protection of Literary and Artistic Works, as it provides an exceedingly broad derogation from the exclusive right of authors to authorise the public communication of their works. In particular, Section 110(5) allows the public retransmission of broadcast music in commercial premises (bars, shops, restaurants etc.) without royalties being paid.

In 2001, an arbitration panel determined that the level of nullification or impairment was equal to € 1.219.900 per year.

The EC’s right to suspend concessions or other obligations has been safeguarded by means of a request under Article 22.2 DSU made on 7 January 2002. The requested suspension of TRIPs obligations consists in the levying of a special fee to US right holders that apply for action by the EU customs authorities to block pirated copyright goods. The EC request was immediately submitted to arbitration due to US opposition. After the arbitration, the parties reached a temporary resolution of the dispute, which was notified to the DSB on 23 June 2003. That temporary arrangement covered the period through 20 December 2004.

So far, the US has failed to comply with the DSB report adopted in 2000.

On 10 December 2021, the US circulated a Status Report pursuant to Article 21.6 of the DSU. In this Status Report, the US announces again that its Administration will "work closely with the US Congress and will continue to confer with the European Union in order to reach a mutually satisfactory resolution of this matter."

title: Boeing Subsidies
description:
Barrier partially resolved: on 15 June 2021 the EU and US reached an Understanding relating to large civil aircraft, transforming almost 17 years of disputes into a forward-looking, collaborative platform to address bilateral issues as well as global challenges. The EU and the US also agreed to suspend application of harmful tariffs for a period of five years.

The state of play of the WTO cases related to civil aircraft can be consulted in the comprehensive 'Overview of the EU's active dispute settlement cases' that is regularly updated and is publicly available on the website of DG TRADE. 

October 2021 update: https://trade.ec.europa.eu/doclib/docs/2021/february/tradoc_159429.docx.pdf (p.22-25). The understanding on a cooperative framework for Large Civil Aircraft is available here. More information is also available in a dedicated factsheet.

Detail:

On 5 March 2021, President of the Commission, Ursula von der Leyen and President of the Unites States, Joseph R. Biden, announced a mutual suspension of countermeasures imposed by the EU and US in relation to WTO civil aircraft disputes (on US side on imports of certain EU products as of October 2019, and on EU side on imports of certain US products as of November 2020). The suspension allowed both sides to focus on resolving this long-running dispute.

The intensive efforts resulted in an announcement of decisive steps to end the aircraft disputes during the 15 June 2021 EU-US Summit . The EU and US reached an Understanding relating to large civil aircraft, transforming almost 17 years of disputes into a forward-looking, collaborative platform to address bilateral issues as well as global challenges.

As part of the Understanding, the EU and US will now seek to overcome long-standing differences in order to avoid future litigation and preserve a level playing field between our aircraft manufacturers and will also work to prevent new differences from arising working through a new EU-US Working Group on Aircraft. At the same time, the EU and the US will continue to suspend application of their countermeasures for a period of 5 years, avoiding additional duties on billions of euros of transatlantic trade. The two sides will also collaborate on jointly analysing and addressing non-market practices of third parties that may harm our large civil aircraft sectors. The suspension of the EU countermeasures was done through Commission Implementing Regulation (EU) 2021/1123 of 8 July 2021. The US suspension went into effect on the basis of the US Federal Register notice of information 86 FR 36313 of 9 July 2021.

title: IPR - Violations
description:
Main areas of intellectual property rights (IPR) violations in Uruguay are:
1) Piracy of, CDs, software, DVDs and books as well as copyright protected content via the internet: Piracy is very present both in production and consumption. Production is carried out in particular at the Uruguayan border zones with Argentina and Brazil. With the spread of access to digital technology, digital piracy is increasing on computers and mobile phones. Uruguay was classified in November 2011 as having Latin America’s highest broadband penetration.
2) Counterfeiting of trademarks: clothing, footwear, domestic appliances, electronic devices, luxury items, spirits, soft drinks and tobacco.
3) Infringements of patents, especially pharmaceuticals.

title: Maturated pork meat products - Classic and African swine fevers (CSF and ASF), and Listeria monocytogenes.
description:
Ban on Italian pork meat products with less than 400 days of maduration due to animal health reasons (swine vesicular disease, classic swine fever).

• Sanitary requirements to the EU meat by Governative Resolution 5/09/2004 and Governative Resolution n. 62/05 -16/06/2005. Information about origin and the characterisitics of the produts should be provided;
• The product has to be boned with a seasoning not inferior to 400 days and with an adequate sanitary certification;
• The pigs from which hams are derived must be born and raised in Italy and not in any other EU Member State.
The only authorized imports are the ones of “Prosciutto di Parma” and “San Daniele” (Governmental Resolution of 05.09.2004 and number 62/05 of 16.06.2005).

In June 2014, Uruguay accepted Italian exports of bresaola made with meat from Italy and from authorised countries to produce cured pork products to be exported to Uruguay (Argentina, Brazil). Uruguay drafted the health certificate in May 2015.

In 2022, Uruguay removd the Swine vesicular disease (SVD) requirement from the heath certificate, but did not confirm it will apply regionaization to CSF and ASF.

title: Additional import conditions for bovine semen and embryos related to the Schmallenberg virus (SBV).
description:
Since February 2012 Uruguay imposes additional import conditions for bovine semen and embryos related to SBV, following a Mercosur resolution. Since December 2011, several EU Member States have reported a previously unknown virus in ruminants (cattle, sheep and goats), named "Schmallenberg virus" (SBV). There is no evidence that it causes illness in humans while in ruminants it causes non-specific clinical signs in cattle and congenital (present at birth) malformations, mainly in sheep and more seldom in cattle and goats. SBV is not an OIE listed disease. OIE standards clearly establish that only OIE listed diseases should be included in international veterinary certificates. In addition, countries are obliged to ensure that import measures are not more trade restrictive than those applied within the country. Uruguay has not provided information about the presence /absence of the virus on its territory.

According to Mercosur Resolution, MERCOSUR/GMC/RES. N. 45/14, which was adopted on 27/11/14, EU Member States that have detected SBV in their territory can continue exporting bovine animals and genetic material (like embryos and semen) only if the relevant certificate includes information on SBV testing before and after semen collection. The resolution introduces some flexibility but has not addressed the problem of seropositive bulls. Therefore, imports of semen and embryos from seronegatives animals are not allowed, even if properly tested.  

Only OIE listed diseases should be included in international veterinary certificates.

title: Regulation affecting Geographical Indications: Reglamento Bromatologico
description: The modified regulation "Reglamento Bromatologico Nacional" includes a lax regime and allows the use of European Geographical Indication (GI) names to describe food products, often in combination with the expression " type". This creates a risk for confusion among consumers.

title: Discriminatory medicines registration requirements
description: Changes to the pharmaceutical law in Uzbekistan have entered into force on 23 January 2023 regarding new registrations of medicinal products, which create a barrier to the import of medicines from 15 EU Member States. The new technical regulation introduced two new requirements that must be met by manufacturers wishing to register medicines in Uzbekistan: 1) positive results of clinical trials conducted in Uzbekistan and 2) on-site examinations of the manufacturing facility from Uzbek authorities to verify Good Manufacturing Practice (GMP) compliance. While the new requirements apply also to Uzbek pharmaceutical companies, a waiver list of 21 countries was introduced including 12 EU Member States. As a result, the 15 EU MS not included in the waiver list are discriminated against those EU and non-EU MS that are listed given that Uzbekistan does not accept all EU exports complying with EU requirements or EU standards. The waiver list was modelled on the list of countries that were founding members of the ICH (International Committee for Harmonization), which defined drug registration standards. However, the list does not consider that also Member States that joined the EU from 2004 onwards (all excluded from the list apart from Hungary and Slovenia) adhere to the same high and strict regulatory standards as other EU Member States.

title: Price Control. Organic Law of Fair Prices
description:
The pricing of goods and services in Venezuela, coming from foreign trade transactions or produced as result of foreign direct investments, is restricted by two laws which integrate a price control system that might constitute a technical barrier to international trade with Venezuela, and considering that the EU has no Free Trade Agreement with Venezuela.

The Organic Law of Fair Prices (O.G. 40787 of 12/11/2015), establishes controls on pricing goods and services commercialised within the Venezuelan market, including imported ones, by the Superintendence for the Defense of Socioeconomic Rights (SUNDDE), which fixes the selling prices, as well as of the all cost structures components. Also the law rules the limits to the profits of producers and importers.

There is also the Constitutional Law on Agreed Prices (O.G (e) 6342 of 22/11/2017), which establishes an additional mechanism for determining the prices of goods and services that the Government considers prioritised. This mechanism is controlled by the Government and involves negotiations with the different competent entities of the public sector, as well as price inspections by the communal power bodies and the Productive Workers' Councils. The Government reserves the right to incorporate any good or service into this price control system.

This legal framework establishes that every single person or company dedicated to the commercialisation of goods and services must be registered in the Unique Registry of Individuals and Companies that Develop Economic and Commercial Activities (RUPDAE), which is mandatory for companies dedicated to the international trade.

The prices are fixed in three categories: i) the Fair Sale Price (PVJ), determined exclusively by the SUNDDE, ii) the Maximum Retail Price (PMVP), which may be determined by the producer or importer with a margin of net profit no more than the 30% over the cost structure, or unilaterally fixed by the SUNDDE, and, iii) Agreed Prices, resulting from the negotiation between producers, importers and the Government. In all these modalities, the prices may be fixed at the discretion of the Government when special circumstances or the general and social interest prevail.

The cost structures of these three pricing modalities must also be authorised by the Government. In the cases of the PVJ and the PMVP the updates will be made through the reference values of the System of Regular Price Adjustment (SACP). In terms of the Agreed Prices, through a methodology established by the Law in the Informatics System of Price Management.

The market access is also controlled by SUNDDE. The possibility of incorporating products or services into the domestic market must be previously authorised by this agency, which will perform all the procedures for determining and fixing retail prices prior to marketing within the country.

The price control system is supported by a regime of sanctions, which includes the occupation for 180 days, extendable, of the establishments and warehouses, the suspension from 3 to 10 years in the RUPDAE, the seizure of the goods, the revocation of permits and licenses, the application of fines and/or prison between 3 to 15 years for crimes of usury, speculation, fraudulent alteration, hoarding, boycott, destabilisation of the economy, resale of products, among others.

The SUNDEE is attached to the Ministry of Internal Commerce, created in September, 2018 (O.G 41479). This ministry exercise the stewardship of the internal trade plans and the surveillance of the overall domestic commerce activities.

The verification of the agreed price list of the 27 food items belonging to the basic basket continues in Venezuela. Likewise, the inspections in supplies, butchers, pharmacies, among other businesses continue, especially of the Maximum Price of Sale to the Public (PMVP), and the use of the Official Exchange Rate for users paying with foreign currency. Moreover, also inspections of schools and clinics continue.

At the moment, there are no intentions to reform the law. However, the prices of EU products in Venezuela can be set without apparent intervention by the Venezuelan authorities for all products other than the 27 essentials, where the government establishes the cost structures. Thus, the application of the law is in a "low profile mode", but there are risks that it could be used at any time to limit the freedom to set prices. For now, SUNDEE does not use the legal tool coercively.

title: Foreign investment law
description:
On 29 December 2017, entered into force the Constitutional Law on Foreign Productive Investment (O.G. No. 41310), approved by the National Constituent Assembly (NCA), which revokes the Foreign Investment Law of 18 November 2014 (O.G (E) 6.152). The NCA was an entity not recognised by the EU then. The Law incorporates regulations that restrict the movement of foreign direct investment (FDI) to the Venezuelan economy. It concedes huge discretionary powers to the President to adopt measures that modify the mandates established in the Law, without the opinion of other public entities, regulators or arbitrators. The Law transfers the rules exercised by the National Centre for Foreign Trade (CENCOEX) to the Ministry for Foreign Trade and International Investment (MIPPCOEXIN), and expands the surveillance functions over companies that invest with foreign capital, and for the establishment of FDI policies. The MIPPCOEXIN was eliminated in 2020 and became part of the portfolio of the Ministry of Economy and Finance. The minimum investment is EUR 800 000, or RMB 6.5 million or its equivalent in another currency with a term of not less than two years. The repatriation of capital and profits is allowed  2 years after the investment was made. It is also allowed to repatriate up to 100% of the profits obtained in a year and the total of the investment in case of liquidation of the company, once discounted the applicable taxes. The President may reduce these percentages of repatriation between 60% and 80% in special economic situations. The Law includes an investment contract, which must be signed by the foreign investor with its local public or private counterpart, including all the terms and conditions of the investment. This contract is part of the documents required for the Foreign Investment Registry that must be made before the authorities, regardless of the activity to which the investment is dedicated.

In contrast to the 2014 law, it is not possible to keep part of the investment or assets abroad, since it is required that 100 % the constituent value of the investment must be represented by assets present within the country. The assets invested will also be subject to surveillance. In addition, it is established the channelling of all monetary funds obtained from FDI through the national financial system. Consequently, the use of accounts abroad for the management of the investment is restricted, having to use only the national banks for this purpose. Likewise, the Law establishes a 15% limit on the maximum amount of domestic financing. Investors with income of more than 70% from oil exports, or mining, must pay their taxes in foreign currency. Investors are allowed to carry out financial transactions, if they do not imply new capital investments. Any financial action must be notified to the authorities, otherwise it would be considered void.

The Venezuelan State reserves for itself the development of strategic sectors according to the national interest. These sectors are not explicitly defined by law, which leaves a legal vacuum with respect to access and treatment criteria. In addition, for reasons of security and defence, the Government might decree especial investment regimes with the participation of foreign capital at different access levels than those established by law. The Law orders exhausting the national judicial means (courts) for the solution of controversies before resorting to any other mechanism offered by the integration systems of Latin America and the Caribbean, as well as within the framework of other integration schemes.  The system of fines in case of breach of the investor obligations increases. The pecuniary sanctions are calculated based on a percentage of the total amount invested, payable in the currency in which the investment was made within a period of 15 days. The authorities may also consider the suspension of favourable conditions granted to the investment, such as accelerated depreciation, purchase of production by public entities, tariff and tax exemptions, special rates for public services, preferential access to inputs or raw materials administered by the State, and any other benefit provided by the Government. The registration of foreign investment might also be revoked. The Law prohibits the investor from participating in political activities or boycotts that could be considered as destabilizing and/or that threaten democracy and institutions, as well as in shaping opinions on topics of public interest in social media. The authorities must  authorise the participation in social activities within the country or to collaborate in any way with any Venezuelan institution, whether public or private.

In 2020, the authorities issued the Anti-Blockade Law as new economic policy tool to “reverse the effects of foreign sanctions. The purpose of the law is to establish a special and temporary regulatory framework that provides the Venezuelan authorities with legal tools to counter, mitigate  the impacts of unilateral coercive measures of any State or group of States, or by acts or omissions derived from them, by international organizations or other public or private entities outsiders. The provisions of this law are of public order and of general interest and will be applied at the national, state, and municipal levels.  This law goes far beyond an Enabling Law, which grants exceptionally broad powers to the executive but creates a system that temporarily overrides constitutional, institutional and legal controls. It allows the government to sign contracts make decisions and manage assets without the limits of current legislation and, in addition, to do so in secret, while the law lasts. The mechanism takes discretion in public management to the extreme. Article 24 gives the Executive power to modify "the constitution mechanisms" of mixed companies in which PDVSA has a majority shareholding, in accordance with Article 303 of the Constitution, which establishes that the State will retain all of PDVSA's shares. An Observatory on unilateral coercive measures will created as an agency for the generation of relevant knowledge, and for the monitoring and evaluation of the implementation processes and their results. All public administration entities are obliged to supply the information required by the "Observatory" created, and the data handled "confidentially”. The income generated as a result of the application of the law will be oriented to i) developing compensation systems for wages; ii) finance the social protection system; iii) recover public services; iv) boost strategic industries and selective import substitution: v) support the implementation of the 16 productive economic engines of the Bolivarian Economic Agenda; and, vi) maintain public infrastructure.

The authorities may proceed to the reorganization of decentralised entities for business purposes, inside and outside the country, to modernise and adapt them to the mechanisms of the commercial practices internationally. So, the mechanisms of constitution, ownership, management, administration, and operation of public or mixed companies, both in the national territory and abroad, can be modified without prejudice to the provisions of the Constitution. One of the most controversial aspects of the Anti-Blockade Law is linked to the confidentiality of decisions, de facto creating a transitional regime based on the classification of documents aimed at protecting and ensuring the effectiveness of the decisions taken by the Venezuelan authorities. All act and records are declared secret and reserved, up to 90 days after the cessation of the unilateral coercive measures and other restrictive or punitive measures that have led to the situation.

The former NA declared "ineffective", the law and warned that any company or individual who makes agreements or negotiations under this instrument could be involved in crimes against the country, as being unconstitutional because it was not approved by it (art 202 NC).

The instrument has been used among Russians and Chinese investors. In the oil sector, the state-owned PDVSA can modify the composition of joint ventures, so that a foreign partner can keep the majority shareholding.  Up to 2024, no changes have ocurred to the FDI legal framework in Venezuela. 

The Anti-Blockade Law also created the International Centre for Productive Investment (CIIP) as a State institution with legal personality and its own assets, distinct and independent from the Republic, which enjoys the prerogatives and privileges granted by this Law. The CIIP is responsible for the registration, study and monitoring of Unilateral Coercive Measures and other restrictive or punitive measures; as well as the evaluation, approval and promotion of productive projects and the management of the Country Brand, as a strategy aimed at the promotion of investment and foreign trade. (Art 15. O.G No. 6.583.

There has been no change in the law yet. Although a committee of the National Assembly is working on a project of draft reform, the ongoing rules continue been those issued by the defunct National Constituent Assembly, which was not recognised by the EU. It will be necessary to wait for a reform to be approved by the current Assembly before this barrier can be lifted.

title: Foreign exchange control
description:
The Venezuelan exchange rate regime has shifted significantly towards a more flexible one. After the country maintained an exchange control that adopted different schemes from 2003 to 2018, with all types of restrictions to foreign currency transactions and impacts on foreign trade and capital transactions, the current situation for the use of foreign currency has improved substantially. The legal basis for this flexibility is in the Exchange Agreement No. 1 adopted between the Central Bank of Venezuela (BCV) and the Ministry of Economy and Finance, on 7 September 2018, (G.O. 6405 (e), which establishes a more flexible framework for foreign currency operations by introducing the "free convertibility" of the local currency (bolivar) and the ending of many existing exchange restrictions.

According to the ongoing exchange rules, private sector individuals and companies are free to carry out foreign currency transactions without having to request the intermediation of the BCV, including foreign trade operations, labour and procurement contracts, digital payments. The possibility of entering into any transaction in foreign currency within the country is open.

On 2 May 2019, Venezuela relaxed its exchange procedures by adopting the Central Bank Resolution 19-05-01 (O.G. 41.624), which authorised banking institutions to intermediate directly in the buying and selling of foreign currencies between individuals, companies and inter-banks transactions, and by using their own exchange tables. The system works with foreign and local accounts in foreign currencies maintained in the national and international financial places. The transactions of international organisations, diplomatic personnel and consular representations also can take place freely.

The BCV may also carry out automatically sales operations of foreign currency to banks, when it deems appropriate, through unilateral debits in the accounts maintained by the respective banking institutions in the BCV, for the amount in bolivars equivalent to the exchange operation executed (Resolution 19-05-03; O.G.41.640, dated on 24 May 2019). The Central Bank interventions will be in accordance to the exchange rate policy, the reserve requirements ratios applied to banks (currently at 73% by Resolution 22-01-01) and the exchange intermediation indexes adopted on 15 May 2019 (Resolution 19-05-02; O.G. 41.633). The BCV carries out foreign exchange sales operations (foreign exchange interventions) to final customers through banks, which carry them out at their foreign exchange desks with the freedom to offer and agree on the operations, with transparency and traceability. Foreign currency accounts may be mobilised by customers not only for the different mechanisms that make up the Exchange Market System (EMS), but also with the products and services offered by the banking entities and/or through cash withdrawals in foreign currency.

The BCV has a determining role in the exchange rate valuation, even considering that the BCV is not legally committed to offer any foreign currency to the new system. Since 2021, the central bank has been making regular interventions in the foreign exchange market as part of its anti-inflationary strategy. The BCV publishes on daily basis the weighted average exchange rate of the transactions traded at the bank exchange tables, which is official exchange rate of reference to the economy (Article 9 of Exchange Agreement No. 1).

Banks must sell to their clients through their respective exchange tables at least 80% of the foreign currencies acquired, and the remaining 20% for inter-bank operations. The calculations for the fulfilment of the Index of Exchange Intermediation (IEI) to the final customer is on the last banking day of each week, based on the information corresponding to the daily flows. The BCV may modify the IEI when it deems appropriate. Banking institutions may also maintain a weekly average amount in liquid foreign currencies, equal to or less than 30% of the balance of the net availabilities in foreign currency held abroad by each banking institution as of 30 April 2019. The authorised exchange operators will not be able to process requests for the sale of foreign currency on behalf of their executives, shareholders, workers, attorneys, companies related, or affiliated. Financial institutions cannot buy foreign currency for themselves.

Regarding retail sell transactions equal or less than € 8,500 in cash and electronic transfers by operation continue through authorised exchange houses, as adopted on September 2018. The issuance and placement of securities denominated in foreign currency continue within the Caracas Stock Exchange.

In 2022, the BCV ruled that foreign currency positions of banks in cash to retail transactions, may not be sold in their foreign exchange desks at a higher exchange rate than the rate established for the last foreign exchange intervention carried out by the BCV in the respective week when the banks received the cash.

In 2024, the Venezuelan authorities continue allowing massive digital payments using accounts with deposits in foreign currency. Since February 2021, the local banks were selling USD and EUR over the Internet for their clients who already have accounts in bolivars and in foreign currencies within the same entity. In 2024 this selling over the internet is not as fluid due to the international reserves constraints of the BCV. However transactions with USD and EUR electronically are available in daily basis for corporations. For now, just transfers are available among clients of a same bank, but the BCV and banks are preparing the basis for the clearing room among banks in foreign currencies for the future. The payments n stores through the debit cards, including international credit and debit cards in USD or EUR are allowed.

Banks cannot grant loans in foreign currency yet backed by their deposits in foreign currency, but in January 2022 were allowed to grant credits in bolivars backed by their foreign currency positions within certain limits, provided that the credits are expressed only through the use of the Credit Value Unit (UVC in Spanish). Besides, the Superintendence of Securities authorised since November 2020 the issuing of commercial papers in foreign currency on the Caracas Stock Exchange, with several primary placements of USD securities since then.

At the present time, the total amount of money in USD in circulation is four times greater than the total liquidity in bolivars at the current exchange rate (Informal dollarisation), which shows that foreign currency transactions are more important in terms of quantity and volume than local currency transactions. The larger amounts of foreign currency come from the BCV's supply through banks and from migrant remittances. Given that more than 60% of the country's transactions are already carried out in foreign currency, in March 2022, the authorities reformed the Law on the Tax on Large Financial Transactions (Igtf), to tax transactions in foreign currency and cryptocurrencies other than the official cryptocurrency Petro (G.O. Ext. No. 6.687) at initial rate of 3% at banks and shops.

As of 9 October 2023, the scope of the cap on the exchange rate applicable by banks to the sale of foreign currency was extended until banks have sold all the intervention foreign currency provided by the BCV. Previously the cap only applied to the amount of intervention foreign exchange allocated in cash, and is now expanded to the total amount of intervention foreign exchange, which includes the cash foreign exchange allocated by the BCV and the foreign exchange that the BCV indicates to sell from the local use of international cards and the foreign exchange from the fraction of exports that must be sold by exporters to the BCV. The measure creates incentives for banks to sell intervention foreign currency quickly.

Informal dollarisation of the economy is still very present. The exchange control situation is stable, as foreign exchange operations remain open, although restrictions on the mobility of funds persist, and foreign exchange accounts are restricted to manage cash deposits. Clearing between banks is not yet available.

title: Acceptance of UNECE certificates and test reports
description:
The objective of Annex 2-B of the EVFTA on “Motor Vehicles and Motor Vehicles Parts and Equipment.” (the car annex) is to prevent that technical obstacles restrict the EU exports of automotive products to Viet Nam and to ensure trade facilitation. The EVFTA establishes that the annex should apply after three years from the date of entry into force of the Agreement, i.e. 1 August 2023.

 The EU concerns are as follows:

  1. Narrowly interpreted scope of car annex: The EU interprets the car annex to cover products listed in Article 1(a) and (b), regardless of their HS 2012 classification. Viet Nam, however, limits the annex’s scope to products in specific HS 2012 chapters listed in Article 1, paragraph 1.
  2. UNECE-type approval delay: Under Article 4(3)(a) of the car annex, Viet Nam was required to accept UNECE-type approval documents for fully assembled cars starting from 1 August 2023. However, Decree No. 60/2023 delays this until 1 August 2025. Viet Nam recently joined the UNECE 1958 Agreement but hasn’t clarified plans for adopting each UN regulation or its latest versions. However, as of 1 August 2025, Viet Nam should accept a valid whole vehicle EC Certificate of Conformity.
  3. Additional document requirements: Decree No. 60/2023 introduces extra documentation requirements beyond the EU-Viet Nam Free Trade Agreement (EVFTA), including production reports and VIN decoding details.

title: Preferential use of domestic materials in public procurement
description:
The EVFTA entered into force on 1 August 2020. However, Viet Nam's commitments on government procurements will be applied gradually, as Viet Nam has been granted very long transitional periods and the obligation to apply transitional measures in the meantime. In particular, domestic preferential measures will be completely phased out only in 2038, with maximum percentages of the contract price of the bid packages allowed in 2 transitional phases until complete phasing out.


As of December 2022, the assessment of the Viet Nam’s legislation shows that the transposition of its commitments into its law are correct.


The industry reported to the EU Delegation that current major issues in public procurement procedures concern various aspects, mainly linked to the lack of transparency of the system.  In particular

  • Lack of transparency, at all levels and in particular, at the local level. Instances are reported of bids’ publication only after the bidding deadline has elapsed.
  • Information on the bids is often incomplete. Most EU companies would need/wish to employ the services of a local agency to mediate these contacts. All bids are available only in Viet NamVietnamese.
  • As to electronic tendering: companies need to open an account for which they have to pay.
  • Under the EVFTA Viet Nam commits to publish summary notice in English language of its intended procurements. Viet Nam by now has not yet implemented this commitment ( as enshrined in Article 9.3) on the ground that first the EU needs to provide supports (as committed in the Article 9.4) and the EVFTA language allows Viet Nam 5 years transition.

Viet Nam has recently introduced changes to its legislation on procurement. The 2023 Law on Tender (Law no. 22/2023/QH15) entered into force on 1 January 2024. It replaced completely the Law on Tender 2013. Together with the new law, a series of sub-law regulations have been put in place, including Decrees 23/2024/ND-CP and 24/2024/ND-CP, which were both published on 27 February 2024 and entered into force on 27 February 2024. The new law can be considered better in terms of transparency and more facilitating in the aspect of decentralisation of procurement decision and contractor selection methods. Nonetheless, Viet Nam still privileges domestic producers or service providers in public procurement procedures. The implementation of the new 2023 Law on Tender however has not indicated any infringement of Vietnam’s commitments under the EVFTA. After 11 months of application, the Commission has not received a complaint from EU operators about this law.

title: Pharmaceuticals – registration of drugs and procurement rules
description:
On 12 November 2018 Viet Nam adopted Circular 32 that regulates the registration of drugs. The Circular entered into force on 1 September 2019. The stated objective was to ensure quality and traceability of pharmaceutical products imported to Viet Nam and the Circular was seen as a measure to reduce the presence of counterfeited drugs on the Vietnamese market. Several specific requirements, however, were excessive and not in line with international practice. The Circular 32 differentiated among Member States’ competent authorities, as in some Member States they were defined as “Reference Regulatory Authorities” (RRA) and in others as “Stringent Regulatory Authorities” (SRA). This differentiation implied simplified registration procedures for pharmaceutical products registered in one of RRA countries, for example it implies clear exemptions on phases of clinical trials for pharma registered by an RRA country. In addition in public procurement, there was a distinction of technical scoring between RRAs and SRA. This allows hospitals to give better scoring to medicines from the RRAs, eliminating drugs from the SRA countries.

The Circular 15/2019/TT-BYT (“Circular 15”) on Bidding for Supply of Drugs for Public Health Facilities was officially issued on 11 July 2019. The Circular contained a distinction of technical scoring between the Reference Authorities countries (15 authorities) and Stringent Regulatory Authorities countries (“SRA”). 

Viet Nam issued the new Circular 08/2022/TT-BYT of 5 September 2022, which ended the discrimination among EU regulatory authorities. Since 20 October 2022, date of its application, all EU MS producers have been treated at the same level.

With regard to the validity of marketing authorizations, Circular 29/2020/TT-BYT of 31/12/2020 extended the validity of marketing authorisations, which expired during the period from 1/1/2018 until 31/12/2021. It also simplified certain aspects of the burdensome requirements of CPPs as introduced by Circular 32. It re-conduced GMP of the European Medicines Agency until 2021 and allowed for electronic certificates, both for CPPs and GMPs. According to EuroCham, approx. 464 medicines produced in the EU would have been affected given the fact that their marketing authorisations had already expired or would have normally expired by the end of June 2021. Resolution 12/2021 extended the validity of marketing authorizations until the end of 2022, but it continued to provide only a temporary solution to the marketing authorizations’ validity and was implemented in a fragmented manner.

On 8 February 2023 Viet Nam's Ministry of Health (MOH) published and enacted Decision 62/ QD-QLD on the “Announcement of the List of Medicines and Medicinal Materials with Market Authorisations Allowed to be Used under the Clause 1 Article 3 of the National Assembly Resolution 80/ 2023/ QH15 dated 9 January 2023”. 1856 imported medicines have been extended market authorisation validity until the end of 2024. 

However, this being a temporary solution, Viet Nam intends to offer a long- term, systemic solution through the amendment of its Pharma Law 2016 that would prolong the existing marketing authorisations beyond 31 December 2024. In the last Trade in Goods Committee in July 2024 Viet Nam announced that the review of the pharma law will resolve the problem of market authorizations that should remain valid beyond end of 2024. EUDEL understands that the draft amended pharma law has been presented to the National Assembly but it still to be confirmed.

A preliminary check indicates this draft contains improvements compared to the current legislation with simplified procedures for the renewal of marketing authorisations (there would be no gap from 31 December 2024), a shortened review timeline for imported products, and more rights given to FIEs in the pharma sector. Other issues remain vague given the fact that the implementation will depend on guiding decree (to be enacted by Prime Minister) and Circular (by Minister of Health).

title: Protection of Intellectual Property Rights
description:
Enforcement:

Although positive developments have been noted in IPR, counterfeiting and piracy remain the major IPR infringements, both online and in physical marketplaces. A broad range of counterfeit products continue to be sold, there is no effective system for site blocking and the enforcement system remains highly complex, which makes it challenging for rightholders to take effective and efficient action against IPR infringements. 

Geographical indications: 

Following the implementation of the EU-Viet Nam FTA (EVFTA), the enforcement of GI protection is a main focus of attention notably in what concerns administrative action, including ex officio, in accordance with Article 12.31.
In particular, there is uncertainty in relation to the enforcement of GI protection concerning the 3 Italian cheeses (Asiago, Fontina and  Gorgonzola) for which an exception was granted in the EVFTA, and Prosciutto di Parma (various online cases). There are also recently reported cases of infringement of protection concerning wine GIs from Spain (e.g. Rioja, Ribera del Duero) reported by Spanish Authorities and no action was taken,  and France (e.g. Bordeaux) for which GI rightholders contacted Vietnamese authorities on and are expecting administrative action. These cases were specifically discussed at the 4th Working group on IPR.

As regards Bordeaux, in spite of the good cooperation with FR Authorities on effective enforcement, EU DEL was informed by operators that they need to register with VN Customs Authorities to benefit from “enhanced surveillance” at border. However it seems that such registration is not simple notably if the operator is not the “right holder” indicated in the EU single document (For example, CIVB, a legitimate user, tried to register “Bordeaux” with customs but as in the EU official document, the contact point is INAO it makes that registration difficult. Such registration with Custom Authorities is not foreseen in the FTA.
Viet Nam revised its IP legislation in 2022, including on GIs, to align domestic legislation with related provisions in the EVFTA. New provisions were inserted on homonymous GIs following Article 12.27.3 of the EVFTA, as well as on GI ownership and the need for every GI user to be registered with the IP Office.

title: Cybersecurity law
description:
A Law on Cybersecurity was adopted by Vietnam in 2018 and entered into force on 1 January 2019. The Law contains data localisation and local presence requirements. These requirements would affect services, which are foundational to the digital economy provided also by foreign firms on a cross-border basis.

Vietnam subsequently adopted an implementation Decree to allow full implementation of the Law (Government No. 53/2022/ND-CP) on 15 August 2022, which took effect on 1 October 2022. The Decree (Article 26) provides for data localization as well as establishment of a branch or representative office in Vietnam. In particular, foreign enterprises conducting certain businesses in Vietnam shall comply with the requirements on data storage and establish a branch or representative office in Vietnam in case the service(s) provided is/are used to commit act(s) that violate(s) the law on cyber security, which has been notified by the Ministry of Public Security and the foreign enterprises have been requested in writing for coordination, prevention, investigation and handling of the same but failed to comply, incompletely complied, or prevented, obstructed, disabled or invalidated the effect of cybersecurity protection measures taken by the cybersecurity task force.

The foreign enterprise will decide itself the form of data storage in Vietnam and follow he prescribed steps to do so.

title: Food additives for meat an cheese
description: Several food additives that are used in the EU in the production of cured meat products (e.g. potassium nitrate INS 252, sodium erythorbate INS 316) and in the production of cheese (e.g. potassium nitrite INS 249, sodium nitrite INS 250 and sodium nitrate INS 251) are not approved in Vietnam see attached Circular 19-2012-MOH. This hinders EU exports of cured meat and cheese to Vietnam.

title: Market access procedures for animal products
description:
Long list of pending applications (more than 50) from several Member States for exports of animal products to Vietnam including: poultry, pork, beef meat, dairy products, eggs. Many of these applications were submitted in 2015-2016 and there is slow progress done by Vietnam.

In the context of the implementation of the EU-Vietnam FTA, the Commission has been urging VNM to set clear timeframes for the processing of MS applications. Once the approval is granted from the Vietnamese Competent Authority (CA) to export a particular product from an EU MS to Vietnam, each subsequent approval from another EU Member State for the same product should be conducted by the same CA in an accelerated way, focusing only on the specific elements and SPS risks relevant to that particular EU Member State. Clear timeframes should be defined for this procedure.

In 2020 Vietnam opened its market to egg products and poultry meat from Belgium. In 2021 Irleand got market access for pork offal and Estonia for dairy products and in 2022 Austria for dairy products.

title: Market access procedures for fruits and vegetables
description:
There are many pending applications from several EU Member States for products such as: pears, apples, citrus fruits, kiwi, grapes.

Applications submitted by MS are treated individually and only one application per Member State is under review, which includes the Pest Risk Assessment. Some applications were submitted in 2014/2015 and there is still no progress. There are currently 13 pending applications on which Vietnam needs to act.

In 2017-2018, Vietnam opened its market to: pears and apples from Belgium, potatoes, kiwi and seeds of different fruits/vegetables from France. However, no new market opening was granted since 2019.

title: Restrictions on animals and animal products related to Bovine Spongiform Encephalopathy (BSE)
description:
Vietnam does not allow the import of all products deemed risk-free irrespective of BSE country status and does not allow the import of other products under the conditions laid down for countries with controlled or undetermined BSE risk.

Vietnam did not provide any additional scientific evidence to support its deviation from the World Organisation for Animal Health (OIE) standards. Furthermore, Vietnam does not recognise the BSE status assessment made by the OIE since it requires its own risk assessment. Several EU Member States face difficulties in exporting beef to Vietnam, while other countries with the same OIE risk categorisation status, can export beef to Vietnam.

This is not in line with the relevant OIE standard, which describes safe trade conditions of bovine products regardless of the BSE risk status of the exporting country. This includes deboned beef under conditions as described in the OIE standard. At the same time, Vietnam imports beef from other trading partners with a similar risk category status that several EU Member States. Therefore, the measure is unjustified, discriminatory and should be lifted without delay.

In 2015, as a positive step, Vietnam allowed exports from France and eliminated the associated BSE restriction. In 2017, it granted market access to Spanish beef and in 2018 to Belgian and Dutch beef. However, a "born, raised, slaughtered" clause has been included in the bilateral veterinary certifictes for the majority of MS exporting beef to Vietnam.
